column1:
Cassa Integrazione Guadagni (CIGO/CIGS/CIGD)~"Wage Guarantee Fund (CIGO/CIGS/CIGD)"~"Italy"~"

Cassa Integrazione Guadagni (hereinafter also ‘CIG’) is a fund aimed at protecting workers’ income in case of suspension or reduction of work due to business crises. CIG is financed by employers and the State
column2: and administered by the National Institute of Social Security (Istituto Nazionale della Previdenza Sociale
column3: INPS). Italian law provides two kinds of workers’ income protection
column4:
i.e. the ordinary CIG (the so-called ‘CIGO’) and the extraordinary CIG (the so-called ‘CIGS’).
CIGO is applicable in case of business crises determining a temporary downturn or a reduction of the firm’s business activity due to:

 

  • reasons independent from the willing of the parties of the employment relationship;
  • temporary market situations (e.g. cancellation of clients’ orders
column5: lack of raw material
column6:
etc.).\r\n\r\n

CIGS is applicable in case of long-term business crises determining corporate reorganisation and/or restructuring and/or conversion of the business activity
column7: bankruptcy
column8: liquidation
column9: extraordinary administration
column10:
debt restructuring or the execution of job security agreements.
Personal scope of CIGO is restricted to:

 

 

  • employers operating in the industrial sector;
  • cooperative companies carrying out activities similar to the industrial one
column11: including activities of transformation
column12: handling and marketing of agricultural and zoological products pursuant to Law No. 240/84
column13: regardless of the number of employees. Employers operating in craft
column14:
agricultural and commercial sectors are not eligible to benefit from CIGO. 

 

Personal scope of CIGS is restricted to employers that in the six months preceding the CIGS request have employed
column15: on average
column16: more than 15 employees
column17:
and fall under one of the following categories:

 

  • firms operating in the industrial sector (including the construction and building supply sector);
  • suppliers of restaurant and catering services to client companies admitted to benefit from CIGS coverage;
  • cooperatives (including those carrying out activities of transformation
column18:
handling and marketing of agricultural products);
  • suppliers of cleaning services;
  • commercial firms with more than 200 employees or craft enterprises (regardless of the number of employees) that have suspended their employees from working due to the influence of other firms admitted to CIGS;
  • commercial firms with more than 50 employees;
  • tourism and travel agencies or tour operators with more than 50 employees;
  • security service firms with more than 15 employees and firms operating in the air transport sector or airport system. Harbour firms are excluded from CIGS coverage but harbour employees
column19: including those employed by a temporary agency
column20:
are admitted to a special indemnity equal to 1/26 of the monthly CIGS maximum indemnity per each day of lacking work.

 

Enterprises that are not admitted to CIGO/CIGS or that have already exhausted their treatments can request to access the ‘CIG in deroga’ (hereinafter also ‘CIGD’).

"~"

CIGO is financed through a contribution of:

  • 1.90% for employers up to 50 employees in the preceding solar year;
  • 2.20% for employers with more than 50 employees in the preceding solar year.

Furthermore
column21:
an additional contribution is set forth to be calculated on the amount of the authorised and paid indemnity and equal to:

  • 4% for employers up to 50 employees in the preceding solar year;
  • 8% for employers with more than 50 employees in the preceding solar year.

CIGS is financed through a contribution of 0.90% (0.60% borne by employers and 0.30% borne by employees). Furthermore
column22:
an additional contribution is set forth to be borne only by employers and to be calculated on the amount of the authorised and paid indemnity. Such contribution is equal to 3% for employers with more than 15 employees and up to 50 employees; it is equal to 4.50% for employers with more than 50 employees.
The coverage provided by CIGO and CIGS consists of a special allowance making up employees’ salary up to 80% of the lost pay. The relevant indemnities are paid within a maximum monthly amount subject to yearly adjustment.

\r\n

The Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs/Regions are in charge of the procedures pertaining the CIGD. Each Region must hold negotiations with the social partners to establish modalities and award criteria.
In 2014 the maximum monthly amount for CIGO
column23:
CIGS and CIGD is the following:

 

  • for salary up to

CIGO can last up to a maximum period of three months that can be quarterly extended
column35:
up to a maximum period of 1 (one) year (not necessarily consecutive).
In the construction and building supply sectors
column36: CIGO coverage can be stretched to 52 weeks only in the event of reduction of working time
column37:
but not if working time is reduced to zero hours worked per week (known as ‘CIG zero hours’).
Following CIGO
column38: a production unit can apply for a second treatment
column39: only after production has resumed for at least 52 weeks. If the enterprise benefits from the measure for non-consecutive periods
column40: the maximum length of the treatment is 52 weeks in two years. Starting from 20 April 2004
column41: in order to check the observance of the time limit
column42:
reference is made to the number of weeks effectively enjoyed.
CIGS can last for a maximum of 36 months in five years. In the event of restructuring
column43: reorganisation or change of activity CIGS coverage can be provided for 24 months
column44: with a possible extension of 12 months that can be granted twice
column45: following two separate applications. In case of a company crisis
column46: the measure can last for 12 months and can only be extended once for a maximum of 12 months. In case of bankruptcy
column47:
the measure can be used for 12 months and can be extended for a further six months.

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

"~"

In 2013
column48: the authorised hours of CIGO have been 356.2 million
column49:
while the authorised hours of CIGS have been 527.1 million.

\r\n

Due to the limited funds
column50:
229 million hours have been authorised in 2013 for the CIGD. The decrease is of -20.5% compared to 2012.

"~"

Involvement of unions and employers’ organisations; State control on access requirements; good attempt to mix up CIGO/CIGS with active labour market policies.

\r\n

During the crisis
column51:
CIGD was a frame to let the workers not entitled to CIGO/CIGS benefit from unemployment schemes.

"~"

Limited personal scope; limited duration of benefits.

\r\n

There is a risk not to get back the whole CIGD request as state resources for CIGD are yearly fixed by the Budget Law (the so-called ‘Legge di stabilità’).

\r\n

 

"~"

column1:
Procedura di mobilità - indennità di mobilità~"Mobility procedure "~"Italy"~"

Mobility allowance (hereinafter also ‘indennità di mobilità’) is payable to blue-collar workers
column2: white-collar workers
column3: and professional and managerial staff (the so-called ‘quadri’)
column4: employed with a long-term contract in possession of a seniority of at least 12 months
column5:
who had been dismissed by:
\r\n
    \r\n
  • employers that employed an average of more than 15 employees in the last six months
column6:
in the industrial sector;\r\n
  • employers that employed an average of more than 200 employees in the last six months
column7:
in the commercial sector;\r\n
  • cooperatives within the scope of mobility
column8:
that employed an average of more than 15 employees in the last six months;\r\n
  • spin-off SMEs
column9:
when the buyer company applies to mobility; 

In accordance with law provisions
column10:
the mobility allowance is also payable to workers who have been dismissed by:

  • commercial companies that employed an average of between 50 and 200 employees in the last six months; 
  • tourism and travel agencies and tour operators that employed an average of more than 50 employees in the last six months; 
  • security service firms that employed an average of more than 15 employees in the last six months. 
Since 2005
column11: workers of enterprises of the air transport sector are also entitled to the mobility allowance
column12:
regardless of the number of workers employed in the last six months.
Coverage applies when dismissal is due to: CIGS resources being no longer available
column13: staff reduction
column14: restructuring
column15:
change or closure of business. The affected employees must be within the same production unit or at several production units within the same province.

\r\n

 

"~"

In accordance with Article 4 of Law No. 223/91
column16: employers entitled to commence the mobility procedure must first contact unions to inform them of the reason of the procedure. After examining the situation with unions and employers’ organisations
column17: employers are entitled to determine the number of redundant workers. At the end of the procedure
column18: employers proceed to the dismissal of workers
column19: and communicate the data to the District Labour Office (Direzione Territoriale del Lavoro
column20:
DTL) which enrol workers in the lists of mobility.
Dismissals must occur within 120 days of the end of the procedure
column21: unless otherwise expressly specified in the collective agreement (Article 8
column22: paragraph 4
column23:
Law No. 236/93).
In 2014 the maximum mobility allowance is the following:

  • for salary up to

column1:
Sistema Informativo sulle Professioni, SIS~"Occupation Information System"~"Italy"~"

Occupation Information System aims at making information about the characteristics and the trends regarding occupations available to different stakeholders
column2: namely: policy makers
column3: researchers
column4: employers
column5:
workers and students.

"~"

The Occupation Information System builds on the Nomenclature and Classification of Professional Units (Nomenclatura e Classificazione delle Unità Professionali
column6: NUP)
column7: a classification of occupations made of 800 professional units with the aim of allowing the matching of data released by different sources
column8:
concerning labour market and occupations.
Currently
column9:
the system integrates the following sources and the related information:
\r\n
    \r\n
  • the Sample Survey on Occupations (Indagine campionaria sulle professioni)
column10: first conducted in the 2005–2007 period
column11: involving approximately 16
column12: 000 workers
column13: and containing around 250 variables. The survey aims at defining the importance of a set of variables concerning knowledge and skills
column14: individual attitudes and characteristics
column15: activities and working conditions (Institute for the Development of Workers’ Vocational Training
column16: Istituto per lo Sviluppo della Formazione Professionale dei Lavoratori
column17:
ISFOL);\r\n
  • the Audit of Professional Needs (Audit sui fabbisogni professionali)
column18: first conducted in 2012
column19: and involving about 35
column20:
000 private firms in a view to inquire their skills and knowledge needs (ISFOL);\r\n
  • forecast studies centred on mid-term recruitment needs (five years) (ISFOL);
    • \r\n
  • data on the stock and on the characteristics of occupations derived from the Labour Force Survey (National Statistical Office
column21: Istituto Nazionale di Statistica
column22:
ISTAT);\r\n
  • short-term forecast of labour market needs
column23: a periodical survey inquiring the occupation and skill needs
column24: and the difficulty in recruiting the required profiles of about 100
column25: 000 firms (Union of Chambers of Commerce
column26:
Unioncamere);\r\n
  • data on accidents at work and occupational diseases (National Institute for Industrial Accident Insurance
column27: Istituto Nazionale Assicurazione Infortuni sul Lavoro
column28:
Inail);\r\n
  • Job offers collected on the Cliclavoro website (Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs
column29:
Ministero del Lavoro e delle Politiche Sociali).\r\n\r\nThe system plans also to provide information on the description of occupations defined by Regional Laws and of the learning and training opportunities available at regional and at local level.
Data are provided online together with various applications and tools in order to improve accessibility and make information available for researchers
column32:
employers and job-seekers.

\r\n

 

"~"

Not available.

"~"

The system integrates different data concerning labour market and characteristics of jobs on the basis of a single classification. This entails the possibility to further enrich the information as long as other organisations and surveys adopt an analogue classification.

"~"

The high level of differentiation of occupations and the amount and complexity of data do not make the information fully accessible and easy to understand for all the addressed stakeholders.

column1:
Contratto di Solidarietà~"Job security agreement"~"Italy"~"

‘Contratto di solidarietà’ is a form of job security agreement (hereinafter also ‘CDS’) that can be defined as a firm-level collective agreement by which reducing working hours
column2:
in order to avoid a reduction of staff (‘Type A’ job security agreement) or to allow new hires (‘Type B’ job security agreement).
Type A CDSs are bargained by the employer and workers’ representations along with local unions. It applies to all workers.
Type B CDSs are bargained by the employer and workers’ representations along with local unions to establish permanent reduction of working hours
column3:
in order to facilitate the hiring of new workers.

"~"

CDS fixes a reduction of working hours on a daily
column4: weekly or monthly  basis
column5: with a correspondent wage reduction. Workers covered by a Type A  CDS are entitled to an allowance of 60% of the wage reduction
column6: for a  maximum of 24 months
column7: which can be extended for a further 24 months (36  months in Southern Italy). This legislation applies only to employers  included in the scope of CIGS
column8: while a specific discipline applies to  other employers. In particular
column9: workers of employers that are not  included in the scope of CIGS are entitled to an allowance of 25% of the  wage reduction
column10: for a maximum period of 24 months
column11:
which can be extended for a further 12 months.
Employers that signed a CDS are entitled to a reduction of the contribution rates
column12:
which ranges from a minimum of 25% to a maximum of 40%.
Employers under the regime of a Type A CDS cannot proceed to collective dismissal during the established period.

"~"

Since the recession began
column13: the use of job security agreements has increased significantly
column14:
both in large enterprises and in SMEs.

"~"

Bargained internal flexibility against dismissal procedures.

"~"

Limited personal scope

"~"

Alitalia; Telecom.

column1:
Fondi di solidarietà bilaterali~"Paritarian institutions"~"Italy"~"

Law No. 92/12 introduced the possibility for employers that are not under the regime of CIGO and CIGS
column2:
to allow the workers’ access to benefits provided by Paritarian Institutions (hereinafter also ‘Fondi di solidarietà bilaterali’ or ‘FSB’).

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

"~"

The special FSB applicable to SMEs and craft firms (hereinafter also ‘FSBA’) was established by a collective agreement signed by the most representative sectoral unions and employer organisations.
Social partners defined the rules concerning contribution to the FSBA
column3: special security benefits paid by FSBA and the structure of this paritarian institution. Up to date
column4: these rules must still be approved by a Decree of the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs
column5:
and the Ministry of Economy and Finance.
FSBA is jointly managed by social partners
column6:
under the control of the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs.
On 7 February 2014
column7: the regime of a general FSB (the so-called ‘Fondo Residuale’) was fixed by means of Decree of the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs
column8:
and the Ministry of Economy and Finance.
The ‘Fondo Residuale’ was created at the National Institute of Social Security (Istituto Nazionale della Previdenza Sociale
column9:
INPS).

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Involvement of paritarian governance and unions in such institutions.

"~"

column1:
Gestion Prévisionelle des Emplois et des Compétences au niveau de l'entreprise, GPEC~"Human Resources (HR) Planning"~"France"~"

Human Resources (HR) Planning applies to firms or groups of more than 300 workers and community-scale companies or groups including at least one establishment or undertaking employing 150 employees in France.

"~"

Mandatory agreements contents (article L2242-15 Labour Code)

\r\n

There is an obligation on the employer to engage every three years
column2: on the corporate strategy and its foreseeable effects on jobs and workers
column3:
a negotiation on:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • the introduction of an 'anticipatory management of employment and competences' scheme
column4: on which the works council is informed
column5: and which includes supporting measures such as training
column6: validation of prior work experience
column7:
skills assessment and support for occupational and geographical mobility; \r\n
  • if applicable
column8: the conditions of internal occupational or geographical mobility; If such a scheme has been introduced by collective agreement in the company
column9:
it has to be subject to a specific chapter in the GPEC agreement.\r\n
  • the overall guidelines for the next three years about vocational training and the objectives of the training plan
column10: in particular categories of employees and jobs to which the plan is primarily focused on
column11:
and skills and qualifications that are to be acquired during the three year plan;\r\n
  • the predictable use of different types of employment contracts
column12:
of part-time work and traineeships and the measures taken to reduce the use of precarious forms of employment for the benefit of open-ended contracts;\r\n
  • the conditions on which subcontractors are informed about strategic guidelines of the company that might have an effect on their profession
column13:
employment and skills.

An assessment has to be made at the expiration of the agreement.

Optional agreements contents (article L2242-16 Labour Code)

Triennal negotiation can also cover

  • methods based on which the works council is informed and consulted about collective dismissals;
  • the qualification of categories of employment threatened by economic and technological developments;
  • procedures for association with subscontractors on the anticipatory management of employment and competences scheme;
  • conditions under which the company takes part in actions on the anticipatory management of employment and competences at the territorial level.
"~"

Use of this model was moderate up until 2008. As of 31 December 2008
column14: 570 GPEC agreements were signed
column15: concerning approximately 1
column17: 000 workers; 41% of these firms have between 300 and 1
column18: 000 workers
column19: and a further 36% are firms with more than 1
column20:
000 workers.

\r\n

In 2009
column21: 903 GPEC agreements were signed. However
column22: this rise can be explained by the fact that Law n°2005-32 stated that companies employing more than 300 employees must have opened negotiations on GPEC in January 2008 latest. As many companies opened negotiations late
column23:
this explains the peak in agreements deposit in 2008 and 2009.

\r\n

In 2010
column24:
the number of GPEC agreements decreased to 557 and a study published in 2012 based on 12 case study showed that the current trend is on the decline.

"~"

This is used as a tool to anticipate labour market changes
column25: mainly those caused by economical and technological changes. It focuses on adapting workers' skills
column26: and aims to avoid massive restructurings. It presents a good way of addressing both competitiveness for the company and the management of employees’ career. It involves selecting the best tools required to implement change and enables staff to acquire a deep insight into the reasons behind expected changes. In doing so
column27: it enables them to become real actors in the development of their career and their employability. This model takes a 'voluntarist' approach to social dialogue and information sharing. It involves commitment and support from all stakeholders. Teritorial HR planning (GPEC territoriale) assesses labour market changes at a regional level
column28: which allows a more strategic approach. The geographic region is the cornerstone of the territorial GPEC; this is relevant to the extent that the territory and its characteristics (workforce
column29: infrastructures and enterprises) comprise a key factor in the attractiveness of new enterprises. The territory is also the main issue in terms of mobility of the workforce; for this reason
column30:
territories are often characterised by the availability of specific skills. Territorial GPEC allows a concerted social dialogue at regional level; this is more valuable than the HR planning of one company.

"~"

Differing views may be held by management and the trade unions regarding information that should be shared; issues here relate to strategy
column32: foresight and dialogue. There is a need to take time to develop tools for mapping
column34:
and other shared tools where necessary. A challenge also is to mobilise management.

"~"

column1:
Droit individuel à la formation, DIF~"Individual right to training"~"France"~"

The Individual Right to Training (droit individuel à la formation
column2: DIF) applies to workers on an open-ended contract with at least one year senority in the company (if the worker is employed on a part-time basis
column3:
the duration of the rights acquired is calculated proportionally to the working time) and workers on fixed-term contracts with four months seniority acquired during the last 12 months.

\r\n

Apprentices and people under training contracts do not benefit from the individual right to training. 

"~"

Each employee has a right to 20 training hours a year. The rights acquired annually can be capitalised over a maximum period of 6 years
column4: in the limit of 120 hours of training. The employee has to ask for implementing his individual right to training and the employer has one month to agree to the training action. If the employer disagrees
column5:
the employee can only reiterate the request later.

\r\n

Following Law n°2013-504 on job security and in order to facilitate access to lifelong training
column6: any person above the age of 16 in employment or seeking employment will be granted an individual training account. This scheme will be implemented as from 1 January 2015. From then on
column7: the individual training account will replace the DIF scheme and this account is intended to accompany the worker through his whole career
column8: even if he changes employment or experiences unemployment (whereas before
column9: the DIF was attached to the employment contract
column10: not the worker). Law n°2014-288 on professional training
column11: employment and social democracy establishes that this account is credited each year
column12: by 150 hours maximum over 7 years. Beyond
column13: additional subscriptions may be made by the employer
column14: the worker
column15:
the public employment agency or regional councils. 

"~"

DIF is accessible to a large proportion of employees. It is the first training scheme ever used by employees.

\r\n

However
column16: the French government has decided to reform the DIF scheme because its efficiency is unproven. In 2011
column17:
only 4.9% of workers used the DIF.

"~"

DIF is used by small and medium enterprises
column18: which are generally least likely to resort to training. According to some collective agreements at branch level
column19:
training can take place during the working time. This acts as an incentive for workers to make use of this training opportunity.

"~"

Some are sceptical regarding the multiple training options and the complexity of the training schemes. This has also led to the creation of multiple training schemes of poor quality and criticisms were addressed that there is no sufficient control over the content and execution of training schemes. 

\r\n

The DIF also lacks to contribute to qualified trainings. Besides
column20: as the DIF is attached to the employment contract and not to the individual
column21: the hours accumulated are lost from one job to another
column22: when in fact training is very important for people looking for a new job. Law n°2009-1437 introduced portability of these rights but in practice it is not used very often because it is up to the worker to ask for it (66
column23:
000 workers asked for it in 2012). 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Validation des acquis de l'experience, VAE~"Validation of acquired experiences"~"France"~"

All those who have worked for at least three years in one or several positions directly related to the desired qualification are eligible for this support. This is regardless of their present or previous professional status (public or private sector worker
column2: freelancer
column3: craftsman
column4: tradesperson
column5: job-seeker
column6: voluntary worker
column7: trade union responsibilities)
column8:
age and nationality.

"~"

Every eligible person has a legal right to have the knowledge and resources they acquired at work to be recognised by means of a national diploma. Following the passing of this legislation in 2002
column9: a file of all accessible degrees delivered by the national education system was created. This included a list of all skills and competences needed to be granted each qualification. Since then
column10: any individual who is willing to validate their skills and competencies must produce evidence of having at least three years of work experience in the area concerned. Each candidate can access support from an expert in the field in making their application. Generally
column11:
the expert spends between 10 to 20 hours in this role with each candidate. Experience is validated by an independent panel.

"~"

In 2012
column12: approximately 64
column13: 000 application forms were declared admissible for VAE. 48
column14: 700 candidates appeared before the panel and approximately 28
column15:
700 of them obtained full validation. Those figures have decreased compared to 2011 while they were stable between 2010 and 2011. 

\r\n

Since the scheme was introduced in 2002
column16: more than 250
column17:
000 people benefited from it. 

"~"

It helps to formally recognise and acknowledge the experience gained over the years without having to undertake further training or examinations to validate it. 

"~"

column1:
Congé individuel de formation, CIF~"Job training leave"~"France"~"

All employees are eligible for this leave
column2: both those on temporary and permanent employment contracts. This is regardless of the number of workers in the enterprise. Seniority of at least 24 consecutive months applies
column3:
at least 12 months of which must be in the same enterprise.

"~"

The CIF is the right for a worker to be absent from work in order to undertake training. Unless an agreement has been reached for a longer duration
column4: this leave can not last for more than one year
column5: if the training is full-time or 1
column6:
200 hours if the training is part-time.

\r\n

A waiting period must be respected between two CIF. Its duration is calculated on the basis of the leave's duration and can not last less than 6 months or more than 6 years. 

\r\n

It is up to the worker to ask for such a leave
column7: with 60 days notice (or 120 days if the training lasts for a continuous period of more than 6 months). If the worker fulfils the conditions (seniority
column8: waiting period) and respects the notice period
column9:
the employer can not deny authorisation. He can only postpone it for two reasons: if he considers that the employee's departure will compromise the productivity or if several employees have asked for the leave at the same time in company employing more than 200 workers.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This scheme enables workers to have access to long term training.

"~"

This is only used by a small number of workers
column10:
even though it has been in operation for a relatively long time.

column1:
Activité partielle ~"Partial activity"~"France"~"

Partial activity is directed at companies experiencing : 

  • either a reduction in their usual working time 
  • or a temporary closure of all or a part of the company.

It is possibly to implement partial activity when the reduction or the temporary suspension in the activity is due to : 

  • the economic situation
  • provision difficulties
  • a disaster or weather conditions of an exceptional nature 
  • the transformation
column2:
restructring or modernisation of the company\r\n
  • or any other exceptional circumstance
    • \r\n"~"

    The principle is to compensate earning losses experienced by workers due to the reduction in their working time under the legal
column3: conventional or contractual duration (within the limit of 1
column4: 000 hours per year and per worker
column5:
a quota that is laid down by ministerial decision) while helping employers to fund this compensation. 

\r\n

Workers are granted an hourly differential
column6: paid by the employer
column7: equal to 70% of their gross hourly wage (approximately 84% of the net hourly wage). In any case
column8: their remuneration can not go below the statutory minimum wage. Workers placed under the partial activity scheme can benefit from trainings. In this case
column9:
the compensation is increased to 100% of of the net hourly wage.

\r\n

The employer receives an allowance jointly from the state and the unemployment insurance body. For a company employing fewer than 250 workers
column10: the employer receives €7.74 per hour per worker. For a company with more than 250 workers
column11:
the employer receives €7.23 per hour per worker.

\r\n

During partial activity
column12: the employment contract between the employee and the employer is only suspended. Therefore
column13:
the employee is still linked to his employer by the initial employment contract.

\r\n

Before placing its employees under partial activity
column14:
the company must ask the labour inspectorate for authorisation. The labour inspectorate has 15 days to answer.  

\r\n

Partial activity is allowed for a maximum period of 6 months
column15:
renewable.  

"~"

The DARES (direction of research
column16: studies and statistics) publishes every three months data about the number of hours and expenses spent on partial activity
column17:
as well as the number of employees involved.

\r\n

Overall
column18: partial activity has increased since the beginning of the 2008 crisis and has started to slow down by the end of 2009. In 2010
column19: it reached its lowest level since the beginning of the crisis
column20: but in 2012 it started increasing again. In 2012
column21: slightly more than 21 million hours of partial activity were used. Each month
column22: on average
column23: more than 56
column24:
000 workers were placed under partial activity with an average 32 hours reduction in their monthly working time. 

\r\n

Research carried out on over 36
column25: 000 French companies (with at least 50 employees) using partial activity between 1996 and 2004 has shown that participation in the scheme does not reduce layoffs as a consequence of short-term economic downturns. This is especially so in cases of long duration of partial activity (Calavrezo et al
column26: 2009). In addition
column27:
the uptake of partial activity tends to be an early indicator of dismissal that will follow. These results do not necessarily suggest that partial activity is an inefficient job security policy instrument. It may be the case that short-time working and layoffs play a complementary role to each other in addressing temporary economic difficulties.

"~"

Employees’ entitlements to unemployment benefits and future pension are not negatively affected in situations where they have been placed under the partial activity scheme. A good level of consensus between the social partners has facilitated the implementation of urgent measures in response to the global recession. Finally
column28:
the scheme provides affected employees with the right to training days provided by different employers.

\r\n

Following Law n°2013-504 of June 2013 on job security
column29:
the partial unemployment scheme has been reformed (and renamed into partial activity). This reform is supposed to facilitate the previous scheme that was considered too complex: different levels of compensation were cumulated throughout different reforms. 

\r\n

This new scheme is also supposed to provide better compensation for workers and advantageous support for companies.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Pole de compétitivité~"Poles of competitiveness"~"France"~"

The scheme operates in specific geographic regions.

"~"

Competitiveness poles are clusters recognised by the French government and defined in the 2005 Finance Law as regrouping in the same territory companies
column2: higher education institutions
column3:
public or private research organisations whose vocation is to work in synergy to carry out projects of economic development for innovation. 

\r\n

This scheme links industrial policy with research and innovation by organising the collaboration of industrial and scientific players and those responsible for relevant training in the region. Certain skills and competencies are sought out
column4:
and efforts are made to match training courses with skills required by companies.

"~"

In 2014
column5:
there are 71 such schemes in France.

"~"

Strengths include: the identification of characteristics of the local labour market and firms' skill needs; a built-in option of trying and testing different approaches within a region; flexibility; the willingness of training providers to adapt their offers to identified needs; the involvement of all shareholders; the fact that a good level of trust is established between the suppliers and SMEs. The involvement of and funding from local state administration also played a crucial role. Proximity of key players to each other facilitates contacts being built. This also leads to the input of expertise from different legitimate actors
column6: the pooling of knowledge
column7:
and the development of European and international partnerships.

"~"

The involvement of those involved in poles of competitiveness as players in matters of employment and skills remains weak. Adopted strategies are poorly developed. The process can be slow if all stakeholders are not fully confident in the scheme. Finally
column8:
SMEs still face difficulties in identifying their future skill needs.

"~"

column1:
Observatoires prospectifs des métiers et qualifications ~"Prospective observatories on jobs and qualifications"~"France"~"

Coverage extends to individual professional networks.

"~"

The national cross-industry agreement of 5 December 2003 called for the implementation of observatories in each occupational sector in order to provide workers and companies with information enabling them to:  

  • better anticipate the evolution of jobs and qualifications 
  • facilitate readability of professional certifications 
  • promote the development of validation of prior experience

Law n°2004-391 legally enshrined their existence. 

Observatories collect and analyse information on companies in their field and on employment and training in their sector. However
column2: some observatories may also cover several professional branches (for instance Observia
column3: the prospective observatory for the food industry covers 17 different national collective agreements). Therefore
column4: their scope varies from 10 to 450
column5: 000 companies and from fewer than 1
column6: 000 jobs to 1.5 million. They also analyse and anticipate the impact of economic
column7: technological
column8: regulatory or demographic trends in employment and training requirements. In doing so
column9:
they provide trainers with information on required skills and make employees more responsible for their own training.

"~"

In 2011
column10:
126 observatories existed in France. 

\r\n

Their usefulness regarding the issue of securing career paths was reaffirmed in another national cross-industry agreement from 2009 on the development of lifelong training. 

"~"

Strengths of this model include: an agreed methodology to fuel social dialogue; communication with employees; changes being shared by employees
column11: the HR department
column12: management
column13: experts and representatives; the provision of information on required skills
column14:
thus making employees more responsible for their own training.

"~"

Their positioning is yet to be improved as they lack visibility and their usefulness is poorly known. 

"~"

Insurance business observatory; observatory of household services.

Coverage extends to specific geographic regions.

"~"

OREF is a technical tool used to analyse the current and future requirements of the regional economy in terms of employment and training. This includes job creation
column2: labour demand
column3: recruitment difficulties
column4: and qualifications expected by firms. At sectoral level
column5: procedures are often in place to enable the exchange of information and to reflect both sides of industry. Relevant issues include training
column6: transfer of employees
column7: and reemployment of workers to other jobs in the region
column8:
in order to preserve its economic potential and quality of life there.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This involves a holistic approach to employment and training issues.

"~"

A high level of variation is found across regions in terms of budget and means
column9: activities and effectiveness
column10: which can lead to a lack of visibility for external actors. The lack of research that aims to anticipate and explore forthcoming issues represents another weakness. Finally
column11: in some regions
column12:
there has been a poor level of cooperation between the observatory and the 'poles of competitiveness'.

column1:
Cellules de reclassement~"Re-employment units "~"France"~"

Re-employment units are available for companies employing fewer than 1
column2:
000 workers. 

\r\n

Any employee who might be dismissed for economic reasons can benefit from this instrument
column3:
no matter his seniority or age. 

"~"

This instrument develops measures to identify internal or external alternatives to laying off an employee; these are known as individualised tools. Three types of such tools exist: informal units (cellules non conventionnées)
column4: which comprises the majority of cases
column5: formal units (cellules conventionnées) and inter-enterprise units (cellules interentreprises)
column6: for cases involving several companies. Informal units are entirely financed by the companies
column7: formal units benefit from public support that can go up to 50% of the unit's budget
column8:
or 75% in the case of inter-enterprise ones. 

\r\n

Employees facing the threat of redundancy present themselves to these units. The units assess their professional situations and qualifications
column9: and provide guidance
column10: advice and assistance in gaining other employment; for example
column11: they provide them with training or match them with available positions. They use the network to seek job offers. The company and other bodies arrange for the reclassification of workers. Support is available for a maximum of 12 months
column12: with the possibility of a six month extension if required. The effectiveness of the individual units is monitored by a committee (commission de suivi) which is made up by company representatives
column13: workers' representatives
column14: a public employment service (PES) and other regional stakeholders
column15:
if appropriate.

"~"

In 2008
column16: its usage was mentioned in 85% of redundancies plans (plans de sauvegarde de l'emploi). According to information from the labour ministry department in charge of research
column17: studies and statistics (Direction de l'animation de la recherche
column18: des études et des statistiques
column19: DARES)
column20: out of 10 employees involved in a re-employment unit
column21: only three gained an indefinite contract
column22: and one quarter accessed a temporary
column23:
short-term contract.

\r\n

In 2009
column24:
only 18% of people that resorted to reemployment units found a permanent contract. 

\r\n

In 2011
column25: 350 formal units were implemented; in 2010
column26: 447 and in 2009
column27: 719. According to the DARES
column28: this decrease is likely to continue because since the end of 2011
column29:
formal re-employment units are only used on exceptional basis. Another instrument - professional security contracts - is meant to replace them. 

"~"

This instrument provides help and support to vulnerable workers. It uses company networks to find job offers and to help workers prepare applications.

"~"

It is often criticised as regards outcomes in terms of long-term returns to employment. The quality of a re-employment unit depends on the company resources
column31: the actual desire of the worker to be re-employed and the quality of the responsible company. The instrument can also be very costly to run
column32:
even when it is not successful. A weak level of control is exerted over completed cases.

"~"

Thomson.

column1:
Contrat de sécurisation professionnelle, CSP~"Professional security contract"~"France"~"

Coverage extends to companies that are not obliged to offer re-employment leave (i.e. workers made redundant from companies with fewer than 1
column2:
000 employees).

To be eligible to such contracts workers must : 

 

  • have one year seniority 
  • fulfill the membership conditions and age conditions for unemployment compensation
  • be physically fit to perform the job

 

"~"

The professional security contract was created by Law n°2011-893 of 28 July 2011 and entered into force on 1 September 2011. It replaces the former 'contrat de transition professionnelle - CTP' (professional transition contract) and 'convention de reclassement personnalisé - CRP' (personnalised re-employment agreement). 

This contract can last for a maximum period of 12 months and is aimed at organising a return to employment programme
column3: for example through retraining or business creation/takeover. This programme starts with a pre-assessment phase in order to define a career development plan
column4: taking into account the labour market situation at regional level and comprises personalised support measures such as skills assessment
column5: social accompaniment
column6: validation of prior experience
column7:
training and work periods. 

\r\n

For the duration of the contract
column8: the worker receives compensation during the period he does not work
column9:
which represents 80% of his basic daily wage. 

\r\n

The employer has to offer the benefit of this instrument to each worker that is about to be dismissed for economic reasons. If he fails to do so
column10: he is liable to pay to the public employment service a specific contribution corresponding to 2 months of gross salary
column11:
or even 3 months of gross salary if the worker agrees to benefit from the CSP after the public employment agency's proposal. 

"~"

In 2012
column12: on average 80
column13: 260 people benefited from the CSP
column14:
which represents € 1.2 billion.

\r\n

Between September 2011 and December 2012
column16:
557 people benefited from the CSP.

"~"

Strengths include : 

 

  • professional continuity
  • unification of the service offered by the public employment agency (CSP replaces CTP and CRP)
  • positive effects of personnalised support measures 
  • facilitated access to training 

 

"~"

Some criticisms were addressed as to the quality of the reclassification offered and claimed that the CSP responds to 'statistical objectives': during the CSP
column17:
workers are considered as vocational trainees and are not registered as unemployed. 

"~"

Transitio-CTP Morlaix.

column1:
Kurzarbeitsbeihilfe~"Short-time working support"~"Austria"~"

Coverage relates to economic difficulties
column2: that is for companies with a drop in production/supplies or sales/demand and to short-time working caused by natural catastrophes
column3: such as avalanches or floods
column4:
but also other disasters (such as the aftermath of 9/11). The company must not be affected by economic difficulties due to seasonal variations. Difficulties must be temporary.

\r\n

Before introducing short-time working
column5: other options need to be used
column6: such as the reduction of overtime
column7: vacation entitlements and working time accounts. A social partner  agreement must be established for each company. This must  address  the terms and conditions of the short-time working arrangement
column8: more specifically
column9: the section of the company that has been affected
column10: the duration of the short-time working
column11: the maintenance of the number of  employees
column12: the extent of short-time working payments
column13: the level of  decreased working time
column14:
and educational measures (if applicable).

\r\n

All employers are eligible except those in the public sector and political parties. Temporary work agencies can only avail of this support if they can prove that workers sent to specific companies cannot be redeployed in other companies and that the company in which the workers have been employed has registered its core staff for short-time working with the Public Employment Service (AMS) In such cases
column15: additional requirements have to be met (for example
column16:
special agreements among social partners).

\r\n

All workers are eligible except for CEOs
column17: board members
column18: apprentices
column19:
and employees who work such a low number of hours that they are not obliged to make social security contributions (marginal employees (geringfügig Beschäftigte)).

"~"

Short-time working in Austria refers to the temporary reduction of working hours based on a social partner agreement. Workers receive short-time working support (Kurzarbeitsunterstützung) from their employer for the non-worked hours in order to bring their income closer to their normal wage level. In order to do so
column20: the employer receives a short-time working subsidy (Kurzarbeitsbeihilfe) from the Public Employment Service (AMS). Working hours under the short-time working arrangements were made more flexible during the recession
column21: in that they may now range from at least 10% to a maximum of 90% of normal working hours. In 2009
column22:
the eligibility period was (temporarily) extended to a maximum of 24 months until the end of 2013. This was extended to the end of 2015 for all cases having been granted before 2012.

\r\n

The short-time working subsidy amounts to the level of unemployment benefits (including social security contributions) for the non-worked hours (about 55% of the net wage); in this way
column23: lump sums per non-worked hours are determined. This lump sum is based on the normal (legal or collectively agreed) working time
column24: the worker’s monthly gross wage (including pro rata holiday and Christmas remuneration) and the number of children the worker has to care for. Furthermore
column25: short-time working subsidy is provided for a monthly gross wage of up to € 4
column26: 074.46 (for 2014) - those on higher wages only receive a subsidy for the salary of € 4
column27:
074.46 (for 2014). Increased rates are provided if training is conducted while employees are not working.

\r\n

The employer must pay the employees concerned the total of their normal wage for the hours they do work
column28: along with the short-time working support for the non-worked hours. On a monthly basis
column29: they must also report to the AMS regarding the number of non-worked hours per short-time worker
column30:
the amounts paid to the short-time workers as short-time working support. They must also confirm that no short-time workers have been dismissed.

\r\n

The social security contributions (and benefits) paid during short-time working are based on the previous full-time wage before short-time working commenced. Periods of short-time working are considered as normal/full-time working time regarding qualification periods for unemployment benefits. Furthermore
column31: if unemployment occurs immediately after short-time working
column32: unemployment benefits are calculated on the basis of the previous full-time wage (rather than the reduced income during short-time working). In most cases
column34:
the social partner agreement states that companies must not make employees redundant for a stated period following short-time working; this ranges from one to four months. Companies must apply for short-time working support six weeks before they initiate the measure (or four weeks before extending it). They must also take part in a consultancy session (involving the works council) with the aim of identifying potential alternatives to short-time working.

"~"

In 2013
column35: public support was applied to over 4
column36: 000 workers (35% females)
column37: resulting in public subsidies of over € 7.8 million (Sozialministerium
column38:
2014).

"~"

The combination of subsidies with training increased the attractiveness of the scheme. It is a cheaper option for the state than unemployment. The employer avoids 'firing-and-rehiring' costs and is given some time to develop strategic considerations. The wage decrease is lower than the proportion of working hours lost. Moreover
column39: employees avoid unemployment and they also maintain their social security level. The scheme is very targeted
column40:
it is available to many employees. It also represents a comparatively fast response to crisis situations.

"~"

The Austrian Federal Economic Chamber (WKO) notes that short-time working is mostly applied for by production companies. It also concludes that both service companies and smaller enterprises find it difficult to access it
column41: due to the complex preconditions and administrative burden involved. Issues are also present in terms of its administration and calculation of pay; the latter requires a software programme as soon as a certain number of employees are affected. The necessity of involving different stakeholders can also pose a barrier for some companies. Not all associated costs
column43: are covered by the subsidies; dismissal protection can be a significant burden for the employers. Finally
column44:
it can be difficult to arrange training during short-time working as meaningful training might not be available during the short-time working period and employees might prefer leisure time to training.

"~"

Magna

Infineon.

"~"Management"~"training*working time flexibility*income support for workers"~"national funds*employer*employees"~"employers' or employees' organisations#Eligibility for this subsidy is contingent on the competent bargaining parties of the two sides of industry having concluded a collective agreement on the payment of a compensatory short-time working support (KurzarbeitsunterstΓΌtzung).*national government#Funding; legal framework.*regional/local government#*public employment services#The employer may receive
column51: a special subsidy (Kurzarbeitsbeihilfe). The company has to inform the regional PES at least six weeks before the starting date of the planned short-time working and has to undergo a consultation process with the PES
column52:
involving the plantβ€™s work council (if established). *other#Employers(funding)."~"

column1:
Chômage partiel~"Temporary unemployment support "~"Belgium"~"

Short-time working is available in the private sector and the semi-public sector – in public enterprises with an economic aspect
column2: such as the rail service and the postal service. It applies to blue-collar workers
column3: to employees during an economic downturn
column4: and to those whose employability has been impacted by bad weather or an unforeseen event such as a technical accident. The measure must involve a group of workers
column5: such as all those from one unit within a company or all blue-collar workers
column6:
and it also has to be temporary.

"~"

In cases of economic hardship
column7: the employer may establish a system of temporary unemployment for workers in totally suspending the execution of the employment contract or by establishing a system of short-time working
column8:
applicable to a certain number of employees and only after exhausting their recuperation days. Total (during all days of the week) or partial (at least keeping two working days a week) suspension of employment contracts is possible for a period of at least one or two weeks and up to a maximum of 16 or 26 weeks a year. This is a way to suspend temporarily the execution of the employment contract instead of cutting jobs when the business activities of the companies are not progressing well.

\r\n

The decrease in working time must be formally established by a collective agreement at the sectoral or company level or in the company's internal rules
column9:
thus requiring the agreement of the trade unions.

\r\n

The provision is assessed based on a worker's last monthly wage and can not exceed a maximum of €2
column10: 206.46 per month (as of 2013). In the past
column11: workers received 60% of their salary if they lived with their partner and 65% if they lived with their partner and children or lived alone during the period of temporary unemployment. On 7 April 2009
column12: this percentage rose from 60% to 70% and 65% to 75% respectively
column13:
following new legislation aimed to boost the economy. This constituted an incease of €300 for the maximum salary level.

\r\n

This new legislation also extended the measure to temporary workers and to those on a fixed-term contract. In cases of reduced working time
column14:
a variety of regimes or durations are possible. No time limitation is placed on situations where work is reduced to at least three days per week or one week per fortnight.

\r\n

A maximum period of three months is placed on cases where the employer has reduced working time of less than three days per week or
column15: on a fortnightly schedule
column16: of one week off and more than two days worked the following week. By royal decree
column17:
a maximum period of four weeks is extended to cases where work has been reduced to less than two days a week without specific derogation.

\r\n

These cases are generally dependent on the existence of a collective accord. The employee remains under contract to their employer during periods of temporary unemployment
column18: even though the operation of the contract is suspended
column19:
and they retain all rights related to the contract. An additional right is conceded to workers on temporary unemployment – they are exempt from the requirement to give their employer notice of their intention to leave in order to work elsewhere.

\r\n

Workers and employees are not protected from dismissal during temporary unemployment but the period of dismissal notice may only begin after the temporary unemployment period has elapsed. Workers' long-term entitlements to pension
column20: social security or health benefits are not negatively affected in situations where they are put on temporary unemployment. Temporary unemployment days are in the same category as days taken for sick leave – although not worked
column21: they count towards the calculation of all benefits. This is financed by the social security budget of the state. The employer must notify the local branch of ONEM/RVA
column22: the federal agency responsible for payment of unemployment benefits
column23:
as well as the workers affected and worker representatives at least one week in advance.

"~"

Temporary unemployment is often used by SMEs in Belgium. ONEM estimates that net employment losses in 2009 would have been nearly double the recorded 30
column25: had the temporary unemployment scheme(s) not been in place. The Belgian employment rate declined by 0.5% over the year. The average daily number of employees benefiting from temporary unemployment allowances during the year was 28
column26: 185. An average of over 210
column27: 000 workers were on temporary unemployment each month. This represents a rise of 57% from 2008. The OECD estimates that this measures saved around 55
column28:
000 jobs in 2009.

"~"

This instrument is established and well-known. It has a strong level of legitimacy from the social partners and the government. It offers employers both certainty and flexibility in relation to staffing levels; for example
column29: it provides the choice of whether or not to implement full or partial temporary unemployment
column30: or to change leave days in case of partial temporary unemployment. It enables companies to retain its human capital (and to a lesser extent
column32:
employees' income is cushioned during periods of temporary unemployment and access to long-term benefits and entitlements is not negatively affected.

"~"

One weakness relates to the transfer of responsibility for the cost of flexibility from the business company to the collective body
column33: with public authorities paying a part of the unemployment benefit. The system can be hijacked by the employers
column35: and turned into an illicit means of avoiding paying taxes. In such cases
column36: workers on temporary unemployment continue to work
column37: and are illegally paid by the company to do so. In addition
column38:
the two-week waiting period for approval of temporary unemployment requests from employers poses problems in terms of planning; this leads to employers making precautionary applications for temporary unemployment.

"~"

Ford-Genk

column1:
Částečná nezaměstnanost~"Partial unemployment "~"Czech Republic"~"

This scheme is available for all employers unable to assign work to employees.

"~"

In case an employer cannot assign work to employees within the range of weekly working hours due to a temporary reduction of demand for the company's products or services
column2:
it is possible to reduce working time and wages by up to 60% of average earnings through an agreement between the employer and the trade union organisation.

\r\n

In workplaces where no trade union organisation operates
column3:
this agreement may be substituted by internal regulations.

"~"

Prior to 2008
column4: use of this measure was minimal. Since the end of 2008
column5: however
column6: there has been a high level of interest in partial unemployment. The Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MoLSA) only began to obtain statistics on it in December 2008. Figures suggest an increasing number of applications
column7: most of which have been approved. In 2009 and 2010
column10:
999 employees affected by this wage reduction were registered (MoLSA). More up to date information on affected employees has not been made available.

"~"

This measure can help employers to endure a period of reduced demand for the company's products or services rendered without facing redundancy.

"~"

Employees experience a wage reduction.

"~"

column1:
Kurzarbeitergeld~"Short-time working allowance"~"Germany"~"

All workers liable to social security contribution are entitled to short-time working allowances
column2: including temporary agency workers and people on a fixed-term contract. Workers holding so-called ‘mini-jobs’ who are therefore not liable to social security contribution (earning up to €450 per month) are excluded. In the calendar month for which short-time working support is applied for
column3: at least one third of all employees (trainees are not considered) of the company (or one or several specific unit(s)) must be concerned. Moreover
column4: the wage cut has to amount to more than 10% of their monthly gross wage. In this case
column5:
all workers (including those experiencing an income reduction of less than 10%) are eligible to short-time working allowance.

\r\n

Reduction of working time needs to be temporary and unavoidable. For example
column6: it must be due to economic conditions (i.e. a sharp decline in demand)
column7: unforeseeable accidents
column8: force majeur or structural changes. With a few exemptions
column9: the company has to have exhausted all other options that might help to avoid using short-time working
column10:
such as balancing working time accounts or granting leave days (only holiday entitlements for the previous years need to be used - the current year’s entitlements need to be aligned with workers’ preferences).

"~"

Three short-time working arrangements exist: short-time working due to economic reasons/temporary shortfall of orders (konjunkturelle Kurzarbeit); seasonal short-time working (Saisonkurzarbeit); and short-time working in the event of restructuring (Transferkurzarbeit). As laid down by Social Security Code III
column11: the employer pays for the effective working time and the Federal Employment Agency contributes a short-time working allowance of 60% of the missing net wage (or 67% if the worker is a parent). This allowance is provided for monthly wages that do not exceed €5
column12: 950 in Western Germany and €5
column13:
000 in Eastern Germany (as of 2014).

\r\n

Introduction of short-time work has to be agreed upon by managment and works council. If no works council existis
column14:
all affected employees have to grant their approval.

\r\n

The maximum duration of state-funded short-time working allowances is six months. According to the legislation
column15:
this maximum duration can be extended by ministerial decree to up to 12 months in cases of exceptional circumstances in the labour market in specific industries or regions. It can be extended even up to 24 months in cases of exceptional circumstances on the general labour market.

\r\n

Currently short-time working allowances are granted for 12 months (until the end of 2014).

\r\n

While a company is receiving public short-time working support
column16: new employees can only be recruited for sections of the company that are not subject to short-time working. Moreover
column17: it has to be proven that the intended job cannot be filled by other employees (short-time workers) of the company. Dismissals during short-time working are possible
column18: but the worker has to return to full-time employment during the notice period
column19:
and the employer is not entitled to the public short-time working allowance.

"~"

\r\n
column20:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi; mso-fareast-language:EN-US;} -->

\r\n

Short-time work peaked during the crisis. Numbers of affected employees rose from 68
column25: 407 in the three year period 2007 to 2009. Similarly the numbers of establishments using short-time work increased from 8
column28: 937 in the same time span. After 2009
column29: numbers decreased from 502
column31: 978 in 2013. The same holds true for employers: In 2010
column33: 121 establishments were affected. This compares to 10
column34:
381 in 2013.

\r\n

 

\r\n

The publicly supported short-time working arrangements are calculated to have accounted for about 300
column36:
000 saved jobs during the crisis.

"~"

Drawing a short-time allowance does not affect eligibility periods for unemployment benefits. The measure offers companies cost and productivity advantages by adjusting working time to the market situation and volatile demand. The measure may also increase workers’ commitment towards the company
column37: thereby strengthening their motivation and engagement. The measure makes it possible to react quickly and flexibly to volatile production levels
column38: by enabling an immediate return to full-time work in case order levels improve. The need for severance payments and costs related to hiring and induction of new staff that may arise in case of dismissals is avoided. At the same time
column39: workers benefit from job security. The public support partly compensates workers for their loss of income and allows them to maintain a certain level of social security; which in turn results in higher purchasing power and willingness to spend available funds. Finally
column40:
the measure creates a strong and constructive partnership between the representatives of employers and employees.

"~"

The measure is only feasible for financially strong firms: non-wage labour costs are not proportionally reduced as it is the case with wage and working time reduction. It is difficult to combine short-time working with training. An administrative burden is involved in the implementation of short-time working.

"~"

Praktiker
column41:
Lufthansa.

"~"Management"~"training*working time flexibility*income support for workers"~"national funds*employer*european funds (esf)"~"national government#Funding; legal framework.*employers' or employees' organisations#In addition to the legal regulations
column42: there are sectoral collective agreements on working time arrangements
column44: in most sectors. Some collective agreements provide for supplements to these public short-time working allowances.*public employment services#The government delegates the administration of short-time working schemes to the Federal Employment Agency (Bundesagentur fΓΌr Arbeit
column45: BA). Employers must apply to the local employment agency (Agentur fΓΌr Arbeit
column47: if they want to introduce short-time working. In order to align the procedures among all local agencies
column48: a substantial guideline is provided by the BA
column49: specifying the administrative process as well as clarifying contents.*regional/local government#Companies (funding)
column51:
European Social Fund (ESF) co-funding."~"

\r\n
column52:

column1:
Arbejdsfordeling~"Work-sharing"~"Denmark"~"

The firm must be part of a collective agreement in order to be eligible for this measure.

"~"

A work-sharing agreement is an arrangement whereby employers and employees agree on reducing work hours
column2: within a limited
column3: low-demand period
column4: in order to avoid redundancies. The agreements do not involve terminating the workers' employment contracts. However
column5: the workers are subject to a pay cut during the work-sharing period. A work-sharing agreement has to include all employees in a firm
column6: department or production unit. It is a prerequisite of the scheme that firms are part of a collective agreement. Work-sharing is laid down in the Danish collective agreements
column7: such as the trend-setting industry agreement
column8: as an option during hard times. However
column9:
regulations concerning the payment during periods without work fall under the law on supplementary unemployment benefit financed by the state.

\r\n

According to the agreements
column10: work-sharing can take place over a maximum of 13 weeks. They can receive unemployment benefit for a minimum period of two days. Employees can work for one week and receive unemployment benefit the following week
column11: and so on. They could also
column12: for instance
column13:
spend six weeks at work followed by seven weeks on benefits or vice versa.

\r\n

During the days or weeks of unemployment
column14: the periodically unemployed are subjects to the provisions of the law on supplementary unemployment benefit. They must be active jobseekers
column15: they must prepare a CV and send out job applications. They are obliged to take part in unemployment meetings and cannot refuse if they are offered another job. This means that the agreed period of work-sharing falls under the responsibility of the parties to the collective agreement
column16: while the payment of the weeks without work falls under the area of responsibility of the Minister of Employment. A paragraph in the sector agreement (§ 8 section 7) provides an option for companies to prolong this period to a maximum period of 30 weeks. If this is allowed
column17: the company has to apply to the Regional Employment Council
column18:
which finances the period of extension.

"~"

In 2006
column19: there were 33 work-sharing arrangements in operation in the country. In 2007
column20: the number fell to 27. Following the beginning of the economic crisis
column21: this number started to increase. According to the National Labour Market Authority
column22: a total of 200 13-week arrangements were approved during 2008
column23: impacting on 3
column24: 718 persons. Use of work-sharing then increased rapidly during the first quarter of 2009. In this year
column26: 925 13-week work-share deals were announced
column27: which affected 32
column29: this dropped to 838 such deals
column31:
458 persons.

"~"Subsidisation helps smooth temporary slumps in labour demand. Besides helping employers retain skilled employees
column32: the scheme allows them to avoid the costly process of recruiting and training new employees when business returns to normal levels. Work-sharing also helps employees to maintain their skills and their job. It is a flexible tool that is easy to access for employers. "~"The scheme is not satisfactory for employees
column33: as they are neither in nor out of the labour  market. Abuse of entitlements has been also observed. Job-sharing schemes need to be combined with targeted training activities. In addition
column34: it could be argued that the maximum period is too short; unions tried unsuccesfully to persuade the government to extend it. "~"Danfoss

column1:
Expediente de Regulación de Empleo~"Temporary lay-off plan"~"Spain"~"

A temporary layoff plan is a special administrative labour procedure which can be executed due to failure of the business activity as a result of economic
column2: technical
column3: organisational or production problems. Since Law 3/2012 was approved
column4:
it can be implemented irrespectively of the number of workers affected. That law also eliminated the requirement of administrative authorisation.

"~"

In temporary layoff cases
column5: workers are entitled to unemployment benefits
column6:
while the enterprise must continue paying social security contributions.

\r\n

In the case of working time reduction
column7:
workers are entitled to partial unemployment. In those cases working time can be reduced between 10% and 70%.

"~"

Accordingly to the statistics of the Ministry of Employment
column9: 713 workers were affected by temporary dismissal. This figure implies a decrease since 2009. In 2009
column10: the number of workers affected dramatically increased from 104
column12:
281 workers

\r\n

As far as working time reduction is concerned
column14: 724 workers were affected by those measures in 2012. Since the onset of the crisis there has been an increase in the use of those measures. In 2008 and 2009 2
column16: 591 workers were affected
column17: respectively
column18: by working time reduction schemes
column19: while in 2011 60
column20: 636 workers were affected. Bearing that in mind
column21:
it is not possible to exclusively associate the increase in the number of workers affected by those measures to the new regulation enacted in 2012.

\r\n

As in the previous years
column22:
in 2012 most of the temporary dismissals and working time reduction schemes occurred in the field of industry.

"~"

It reduces the number of job losses and permits employers to adapt their production to the recession.

"~"

Before Law 35/2010 of 17 September 2010
column23: this could not be applied to small enterprises; in Spain
column24:
these companies's employees comprise a large proportion of the total workforce.

"~"

column1:
chômage partiel ~"partial unemployment"~"Luxembourg"~"

This measure may be used when all other possibilities within the company have been exhausted. These include a reduction in the use of agency-supplied temporary workers
column2: time off in lieu of overtime
column3: use of remaining holiday entitlement
column4:
and internal redeployment.

\r\n

Short-time working for economic reasons: in order for this to be provided
column5: there must be economic difficulties in a sector which has been declared to be in a state of crisis by the government council. The Committee for the Economy assesses the sector’s situation and the company’s individual situation. Moreover
column6:
the committee must avoid creating situations of unfair competition. The companies concerned may not make any workers redundant for economic reasons while the short-time working scheme is in operation.

\r\n

Short-time working due to an economic dependency link: this applies when the applicant company is in a position of serious dependence on one or more companies that are already benefiting from the short-time working scheme in Luxembourg. In such cases
column7:
the benefits are the same as those provided for economic reasons. The company concerned may not make any workers redundant for economic reasons while the short-time working scheme is in operation.

\r\n

Short-time working on structural grounds: this applies to companies facing structural difficulties
column8: and aims to facilitate adaptation and enable them to maintain employment at a satisfactory level. The procedure is the same as for the other short-time working regimes. The Committee for the Economy’s assessment will relate to the company’s individual situation. In this case
column9:
the difficulties encountered are not purely due to widespread economic recession.

\r\n

Partial unemployment due to force majeure: here
column10: all employees working in Luxembourg on either a permanent or fixed-term contracts (including part-time workers) who are fit for work are eligible
column11:
with the exemption of apprentices.

"~"

Subsidies may be allocated to employers who
column12: rather than carrying out redundancies
column13: undertake to maintain the employment relationship with their personnel and to pay them compensation for lost salary. The compensation for the non-worked hours amounts to 80% of normal pay.  It is provided for all non-worked hours except the first 16 hours per month for full-time workers
column14: or the first eight hours per month for part-time workers. There is
column15: however
column16:
a ceiling on the public reimbursement which is set at 250% of the minimum wage. The amount of time off work under short-time working arrangements may not exceed 50% of the normal monthly hours worked.

\r\n

The maximum duration for public support is proposed by the conjuncture committee and varies among the different partial unemployment pathways
column17:
as outlined below.

\r\n

Partial unemployment due to economic reasons: this is provided for a maximum of six months
column18:
over a period of twelve months. The hours involved per month cannot exceed 50% of the employee’s normal working hours.

\r\n

Partial unemployment due to economic dependency: this is individually fixed on the basis of the partial unemployment duration of the firm(s) on which the company depends. Here
column19:
the hours involved per month cannot exceed 50% of the employee’s normal working hours.

\r\n

Partial unemployment due to structural reasons: this is individually fixed on the basis of the restructuring plan
column20: to be submitted to the conjuncture committee. If applicable
column21: this submission is accompanied by an employment maintenance plan. The hours involved per month cannot exceed 50% of the employee’s normal working hours. For the non-worked hours
column22:
social contributions are based on the reduced salary (at 80% or 90% for those taking part in training).

\r\n

In cases of dismissal following the partial unemployment period
column23: the unemployment benefits are calculated based on the full-time wage before partial unemployment. This is with the exception of partial unemployment for structural reasons; in this case
column24: the employer is obliged not to dismiss any workers for economic reasons during partial unemployment. They must also maintain their positions following the partial unemployment period
column25:
for the same length of time as the partial unemployment measure was being used.

\r\n

Companies have to apply for partial unemployment compensation to the so-called conjuncture committee
column26: a tripartite body consisting of members representing the government (the Ministry of Economy
column27: the Ministry of Labour and the Ministry of Finance)
column28:
representatives of employers’ organisations and trade unions.

"~"

In June 2014
column29: 18 out of 24 demands for partial unemployment were approved by the conjoncture committee. A total of 1
column30: 403 employees benefited form the partial unemployment measures
column32:
231 persons employed by those companies.

"~"

This measure allows companies to retain their skilled and qualified workforce. It leads to consensus and cooperation among the social partners. Extensive monitoring is involved.

"~"

There is a limited uptake of training during partial unemployment due to organisational problems. Agency workers and interns (apprentices) can not benefit from this measure.

"~"

Many large companies and SMEs.

column1:
Permittering~"Temporary layoffs "~"Norway"~"

This is available to employers who need to reduce their workforce temporary due to lack of work.

"~"

An employer can temporarily lay-off employees if there is a jusitfiable basis for this and the need is temporary. Jusitifiable reasons may be low influx of orders
column2: financial problems
column3: need to undertake reparations of machinery and more. The employer still has to pay them for 20 days during this period. If the need to reduce the workforce is due to fire
column4: accidents or nature
column5:
the duty to pay wages for 20 days does not apply.

\r\n

After 26 weeks of temporary redundancy within a time period of 18 months
column6:
the employer must resume paying the employees' salaries.

\r\n

Before temporary lay-off is decided
column7:
the employer should notify the public employment authorities.

\r\n

Employees that are temporarily laid-off are entitled to unemployment benefits in accordance to the National Insurance Act.

\r\n

There is also the opportunity to use part-time layoffs
column8: for instance by reducing working hours. However
column9: if working hours are reduced by less than 50%
column10:
the employee will not be entitled to unemployment benefits.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This measure allows companies to retain their workforce during situations where the need for labour is lower
column11:
and allows for a quick reduction in pay costs.

"~"

It might be misused
column12:
as costs are turned over to the state. It might also delay necessary readjustments in situations where the workers have looked for other work.

"~"
