column1:
Suport public pentru programe anuale de formare profesională la nivel de companie, pentru angajaţi - Legea nr. 76/2002 privind sistemul asigurărilor pentru şomaj şi stimularea ocupării forţei de muncă~"Public support for companies' annual vocational training programmes for employees - Law no. 76/2002 on unemployment benefit and employment stimulation"~"Romania"~"

\r\n

This is available to employers who develop annual professional training programmes for their own workers (with the assistance of professional providers of training programmes).

\r\n

Currently
column2: due to Law no 250/2013 (modifying the Law on unemployment
column3: no. 76/2002) the amount for training is granted to the employers select by the agency for employment
column4:
in compliance with applicable regulations in aid de minimis.

\r\n

"~"

A legal provision stipulates that the approval of the company programme by the National Employment Agency (ANOFM) depends on the existence of an annual professional training plan. The labour code states that the employer is bound to develop annual professional training plans
column5: following consultations with the trade union
column6: or
column7: if no trade union is involved
column8: with the employees’ representatives. The professional training plan is written into the provisions of the company collective agreement
column9: and the employees have the legal right to be informed of its provisions. Financial aid is provided
column10: equal to 50% of the professional training expenditures
column11: for a proportion of employees
column12:
not be in excess of 20% of the employer’s total workforce.

"~"

 


 

"~"

This programme provides an incentive to employers and employees to develop vocational training programmes.

"~"

The funding of this measure is still limited. Companies accesing this fund may not dismiss the trained employee for a peripd of at least three years following the training course; this generates rigidity within human resources policies.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Rapid Response Service (RRS) ~"Rapid Response Service (RRS) "~"United Kingdom"~"

Coverage extends to organisations and their employees facing redundancies. All people impacted by redundancy are eligible to access the services offered by RRS. This includes those under threat of redundancy but who are still employed; those under notice of redundancy but who are still employed; those who lose their jobs in companies which are in the supply chain of a larger company making redundancies and those who lose their jobs in a location designated as having RRS status by JobCentre Plus. This includes those indirectly losing their jobs as a result of the redundancy and those whose redundancy period has elapsed
column2:
regardless of whether or not they have made a claim for benefits.

"~"

JobCentre Plus support under the Rapid Response Service (RRS) includes helping workers facing redundancies with CVs
column3: general advice about benefits
column4: helping workers identify transferable skills and training needs
column5:
providing training in vocational skills and assistance with costs like travel to work expenses. 

\r\n

JobCentre Plus also provides fast-track access to for large scale redundancies. This service includes on-site advice; links and referrals to other agencies; information and advice about job vacancies and training opportunities; skills and training need analysis; training; and one-off payments for expenses associated with obtaining new employment.

\r\n

 

"~"

Recent statistics are not available. Between April 2002 and January 2003
column6: the Rapid Response Service (RRS) provided new and continued support to 178 projects covering over 210 companies that were making over 70
column7: 000 people redundant. Around 10
column8: 000 people took up services offered under RRS
column9: with the majority receiving information
column10: advice and guidance (nearly 7
column11: 900) and skills and training analysis (3
column12: 300). Training was offered to 970 persons only. Over 60% of individuals whose destinations are known moved into employment following RRS
column13:
and the majority of these people were still in work four weeks later.

"~"

The fast-track service for large-scale redundancies is an on-site measure
column14: and it is a fast and responsive service. It leads to an improved relationship between JobCentre Plus and employers
column15:
and to improved use of labour market information at regional and local levels.

"~"

The fast-track service is provided 'proactively' only in cases where 20 or more redundancies are planned. This clearly limits the accessibility of SMEs to the scheme. 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
SMART: SCOTLAND~"SMART: SCOTLAND"~"United Kingdom"~"

Coverage for SMART: SCOTLAND extends to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that are in
column2: or investing in
column3:
Scotland. Discretionary grants are available to SMEs based in Scotland or planning to locate to Scotland.  

"~"

The SMART: SCOTLAND initiative was established out of recognition that a funding gap existed for innovation/research and development (R&D) for small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). SMART: SCOTLAND funds feasibility studies and research and development (R&D). The purpose is to support innovation and improve company competiveness for the benefit of the Scottish economy. The scheme
column4: an amalgamation of three existing grant schemes
column5: has existed since 2007.  Grants are intended to help SMEs undertake technical feasibility studies and research and development (R&D) projects that have a commercial endpoint. Feasibility studies are conducted as an early stage of an R&D project to evaluate if the new product or process has practical and commercial viability. Grants support up to 70% of the project costs for a small company and up to 60% for a medium-sized company. Following the European Community definition
column6: the former is defined as having less than 50 employees and an annual turnover of less than €10 million; the latter as having 50-249 employees and a turnover of less than €50 million. The maximum grant is £100
column7: 000 (€125 million on 20 August 2014). R&D grants are intended to help SMEs develop a pre-production prototype of a new product or process. The maximum grant is £600
column8:
000 (€750 million on 20 August 2014). Projects must offer significant technology advancement with good commercial prospects and be undertaken by financially viable businesses. The scheme encourages companies to work with universities and non-profit research centres.

"~"

Between 1999 and 2008
column9: SMART: SCOTLAND funded 506 projects at a cost of £58m (€72.5 million on 20 August 2014). These projects have been evaluated against five key scheme aims: to assist research
column10: develop and exploitation of new technically innovative products; to stimulate technological innovation and best practice amongst companies; to strength the scientific and technological base of Scotland; to improve the competiveness of the Scottish economy through SME technological innovation; to encourage a climate of innovative technology development to stimulate a market in technical advancement. Evaluation takes account of gross attributable impact (Gross Value Added (GVA) and employment)
column11: deadweight (what would have happened with the scheme)
column12: displacement (its effect on competitors)
column13: leakage (benefits outside Scotland)
column14: linkages and multipliers (supply chain effects) and persistence (sustainability of effects). Measured against its five aims
column15: SMART: SCOTLAND has been evaluated as follows. Almost all projects were additional; enabling innovation that would not have happened otherwise. Two-thirds of grant recipients took their innovations to market. A large majority reported improved innovation culture. Three-quarters had developed new intellectual property (IP)
column16: with the rate of IP generation greater with SMART: SCOTLAND support. With more than half collaborating with universities
column17: the scientific and technological base of Scottish SMEs was boosted. Increased turnover
column18: export sales and employment in some companies were attributed to SMART: SCOTLAND support. Grant recipients had increased their innovative capacities
column19: though whether a cultural shift had occurred was difficult to measure adequately.  The gross total impact of these projects was and £122 million (€152.5 million on 20 August 2014) GVA and 1
column20: 381 full-time equivalent (FTE) jobs. The consensus was that SMART: SCOTLAND represented value for money. Between 2009 and 2013
column21: SMART: SCOTLAND provided grants of £25.4 million (€31.74 million on 20 August 2014) to fund a further 241 projects. No substantive evaluation of these projects exists
column22:
but the headline figures indicate that a further £54 million (€67.5 million) in financing was levered by these projects.   

"~"

The high rate of additionality is a strength of the scheme. SMART: SCOTLAND has levered innovation that otherwise would not have happened or would have happened to a lesser degree. With SMEs in the EU struggling to be innovative in recent years
column23: with SMART: SCOTLAND
column24: over half of participating SMEs in Scotland gained access to leading edge science and technology through increased collaboration with universities and other research centres. Some companies have also been able to access extra funding from private sector sources because of SMART:SCOTLAND. Indeed
column25: being a grant recipient made it easier for most companies to obtain finance. In this respect
column26: a key strength of SMART: SCOTLAND might be that involvement in it acts as a signalling mechanism to finance markets about particular companies. Finally
column27: involvement in SMART:SCOTLAND has sustained effect
column28:
with supported companies going on ot spend more on innovation than the average SME.

"~"

There are a small number of specific weaknesses raised by grant recipients: the grant application process was not rated as good and it was suggested that a network of recipient ‘alumni’ is needed to help disseminate advice and opportunities arising from projects. There are more general weaknesses too: it is acknowledged that the gains made by the projects
column29: whilst positive
column32: temporary. With the respect to the former
column33: best practice spill-over effects to other companies have been limited. With respect to the latter
column34:
just over a fifth of grant recipients say that they will offshore production jobs once the grant’s embargo period on doing so ends (five years post award). As a consequence there is scope for impact improvement as the scheme goes forward.

"~"

Rockstar North
column35: the internationally recognised video games development studio based in Edinburgh
column36:
received an R&D grant of just over £1 million (€1.25 million on 20 August 2014) from SMART: SCOTLAND. The grant supported an £8 million (€10 million on 20 August 2014) project that created 25 new high value jobs in the Edinburgh and Scottish video games sector.

column1:
Union Learning Fund (ULF) ~"Union Learning Fund (ULF) "~"United Kingdom"~"

The Union Learning Fund (ULF) is managed and administered by unionlearn
column2: the UK TUC’s Learning and Skills Organisation
column3: under an agreement with the UK Department for Business
column4: Innovation and Skills (BIS). The ULF covers England
column5: Scotland and Wales (i.e. Great Britain) and directs the level and type of learning activity that should  be supported by the Fund. The purpose of the ULF is to support unions in encouraging learning by workers. This learning must not substitute for that which should be provided by employers
column6:
in other words it is intended to create additionality.

"~"

The first ULF was established in 1998 and successive governments in the UK have continued to fund projects through a series of funding rounds
column7: which were initially annual. Funding is provided by government to unions
column8: with supportive funding sought from employers as part of project bids. Within the UK
column9: monies have been apportioned to projects via the Union Learning Fund (ULF) in England
column10: the Wales Union Learning Fund (WULF) in Wales and the Scottish Union Learning Fund (SULF) in Scotland – with ‘ULF’ a generic term. Unions’ strategic activity around learning is now organised in England through unionlearn
column11: in Wales through Wales TUC Learning Services and in Scotland through Scottish Union Learning. A similar
column12:
yet separate fund is in place in Northern Ireland (the Northern ireland Union Learning Fund).

"~"

There is no UK-wide reporting system of ULF outputs and activities. The most comprehensive data is provided by unionlearn in England. For the 2013-14 financial year it reported 44 projects costing £13 millio (€6.25 million on 20 August 2014)
column13: the supporting of just over 220
column14: 00 learners
column15: the training of over 2500 new ULRs
column16: the opening of nearly 70 learning centres and the signing of over 200 learning agreements with employers and leaning providers. It also reported undershooting some targets because of government funding cutbacks (19% cut in funding) and employer disinclination during the economic downturn.   A range of evidence suggests that the ULF has met its intended objectives. In the decade and a half of its existence
column17: significant numbers of individuals have gained access to learning opportunities
column18: many workers have gained new skills and qualifications
column19: workplace learning centres have been established and learning agreements made between unions and employers. Individual project targets for stimulating learning in the workplace are mostly met or exceeded. Evidence highlights that unions are an important lever for learning amongst lower paid and lower skilled workers as well as older
column20: ethnic minority and migrant workers. Although demand exists across all occupations
column21: ULFs have been particularly good at reaching difficult to engage workers
column22: including ‘non-traditional’ learners and workers on temporary contracts. Many participating employers also claim operational benefits to the businesses
column23: with increases in company performance. With the economic recession in the UK
column24: there is evidence of increased joint working between management and unions on learning. Overall therefore
column25: evidence suggests that employees
column26: employers and unions accrue tangible and intangible benefits from ULF-led learning. A range of stakeholders regard ULF as providing good value for money. Following its initial successes
column27:
the UK created statutorily-supported Union Learning Representatives (ULRs) in 2003 to further support the initiative.     

"~"

A key strength of ULFs is that they meet a demand. Research has revealed a large
column28: latent demand for workplace-driven learning amongst the workforce generally and with over half of workers indicating that their likelihood of undertaking this learning was increased if organised through a union. Indeed unions can provide assurance for vulnerable employees in revealing any skills deficits or learning difficulties. With multiple funding
column29: learning escalators can be created for employees. Moreover the vast majority of workplace projects are open to all employees
column30: not just union members. In addition to helping to improve management-union relations
column31: ULFs have gained employer support and put learning on the bargaining agenda between employers and unions
column32: company policies on learning improve and employers benefit from workforce upskilling. Union-led workplace learning can thus offer mutual gains to unions
column33: employers and all employees.  It has also helped deliver government policy in the UK aimed at boosting learning capacity
column34:
and skill and qualification acquisition amongst the workforce.

"~"

Across the UK the different the ULFs are fragmented by country
column35: with operational variations and no common reporting system of outputs and activities. Operationally
column36: there are time pressures on ULRs to promote and deliver learning opportunities in workplaces and employers granting employees paid time-off to learn is a challenge. Moreover there are variation in the extent that learning has become formalised within union operations and structures
column37: and a debate within unions about the purpose of learning: as a service in itself
column38: enhancing the employability (and non-working lives) of members or a means to another end – increasing rates of unionisation. These operational challenges often relate to the level of employer support.  Whilst often negotiated in workplaces between unions and management
column39: union-led workplace learning is not an embedded bargaining issue between employers and unions. In this respect
column40: the key weakness of union-led workplace learning through the ULF however is its sustainability. Despite nearly 15 years of operation and its presence in many UK workplaces
column41:
it remains dependent upon support from whichever government is in power and there are already reductions in available funding.

"~"

Unison's Quick Reads Initiative;  USDAW's Tesco IT Initiative; Detailed organisational case studies of two ULF projects plus a third case intended as a funded project

column1:
Program zwolnień monitorowanych (Outplacement)~"Training and retraining for workers threatened by redundancies/Monitored dismissals"~"Poland"~"

The programme applies to redundant workers in firms where the employer aims to dismiss at least 50 workers within a three month period.

"~"
column2: sans-serif;"">Employers who aim to dismiss at least 50 workers in a three month period are obliged to agree with the Poviat Labour Office on the range and forms of support to be made available for redundant workers. This support means offering job broking services
column3: vocational counselling
column4: trainings and assistance in active job search. The programme can be financed by the employer
column5: or co-financed by employer and public authorities
column6: or other organisations
column7:
based on agreement with the employer. The programme may be carried out by the Poviat Labour Office or a training institute.

\r\n
column8: sans-serif;"">In the framework of the programme the employer can finance training that lasts up to 6 months
column9: sans-serif;"">
column10: sans-serif;"">after the dismissal date
column11: sans-serif; font-size: 7.5pt;""> and the costs of which should be equivalent to the employee's monthly remuneration when on holiday leave
column12: but should not exceed 200% of the national monthly minimum wage. During the training
column13:
the employee is entitled to advice from the relevant Poviat Labour Office. The employee can also take part in a one time training organized by the Office. 

"~"

This regulation is operational. However
column14: the legal obligation to offer retraining programmes to employees before they lose their job make it unpopular among employers
column15:
so that some of them avoid to meet the criteria.

"~"

Strengths include the fact that it reinforces public-private partnership. In particular
column16:
it fosters cooperation between PES and companies.

"~"

Hardly any initiatives take place at regional/local level. It involves weak social dialogue.

"~"

column1:
Budoucnost profesí~"Czech Future Skills"~"Czech Republic"~"

This measure deals with future occupational requirements such as qualifications and skills requirements.

\r\n

The main focus of the National Observatory of Employment and Training (NOET)
column2: an analytical unit of the National Training Fund
column3: is the development of a methodology for forecasting skills needs in the labour market. The objective is to systematically generate and analyse information about future occupational requirements
column4: qualifications and skills. That would be designed for labour market institutions
column5: the education sector
column6: potential learners
column7: employers and public institutions to help hem in their decision-making. There are two interconnected approaches to the methodology. These are quantitative projections based on a mathematical model and a qualitative approach based on analyses and expert assessments of future development in economic sectors (sector studies). The NOET has made use of the experience in forecasting skills needs as part to the Labour Market Institute project. The NOET carries out its tasks in close co-operation with ministries
column8: specialists and research institutions in the areas of education
column9: employment
column10: economic and social affairs as well as with the Czech Statistical Office
column11:
employers' organisations and trade unions.

 

"~"

This measure anticipates the future needs of the economy in terms of human resources. It consists of four main sections:

  • The future of professions: This involves employment projections on many professional groups (and their subgroups) and an evaluation of the chances of employment in these professions based on the methodology of the Research Centre for Education and the Labour Market Maastricht (ROA) which was in case of the Czech Republic implemented by the Research Institute for Labour and Social Affairs (RILSA). 
  • Sector studies: This focuses on current and expected trends in selected sectors and the expected trend in demand for qualified workers in specific professions over the next 10–15 years
column12: including changes in educational and skill requirements. Sector studies also work with data on the supply side of the labour market
column13: namely schools
column14: their capacity and specialisations. This allows for the identification of future weak spots in the labour market
column15:
such as the mismatches between future supply and demand.\r\n
  • Industrial development: This looks at developments during the period 2000–2009
column16: as well as the predicted situation in many industries up to 2020
column17:
with a focus on the development of the structure of the industrial labour force.\r\n
  • Regional analyses: These provide basic comparisons of employment and human resource characteristics across different regions in the Czech Republic.
    • \r\n"~"

    The activities created a sufficient base of knowledge and established a network of research organisations for the systematic anticipation of future needs of the economy regarding human resources;. However
column18:
the data is hardly ever considered by schools and companies.

"~"

Strengths include the projection of numerous job profiles
column19:
complemented by ad-hoc analyses and relatively up-to-date information.

"~"

The sample used by the Czech Statistical Office (Labour Force Survey) is too small (for cost reasons) to give detailed data on sectors and regions. Funding is low. Data quickly becomes out of date due to the dynamism of the labour market.

"~"

Not applicable.

Slovenská agentúra pre rozvoj investícií a obchodu~"SARIO (Slovak Investments and Trade Development Agency)"~"Slovakia"~"

Not applicable.

"~"

SARIO develops a business-friendly environment in Slovakia. It manages investment projects
column2: and provides assistance in the establishment of joint ventures. It provides its services to SMEs
column3:
regional self-governments and self-employed individuals who are interested in receiving EU structural funds.

\r\n

Negotiations usually take place between SARIO and foreign investors
column4: regarding existing conditions such as the unemployment rate
column5: the available labour force and infrastructure in the region
column6: the number of planned new jobs
column7: and
column8: in particular
column9: preconditions for receiving a state aid. SARIO is also involved in identifying and assisting companies to take advantage of market opportunities
column10:
providing governmental support to businesses and diplomatic support in international trade relations. It maintains an electronic database of demands of and offers to Slovak firms.

"~"

This measure has resulted in the creation of 60
column12: 000 new jobs. It plays a significant role in attracting foreign investment: in 2008
column13: SARIO attended 44 events abroad and 117 events in Slovakia
column14: and at the end of 2008
column16: 651 domestic and foreign companies were registered. In addition
column17: there were 1
column18: 650 offers and demands for cooperation activities
column19:
services or partnership offers with a foreign company.

column1:
Skills Development Scotland (SDS) Individual Learning Accounts (ILAs)~"Skills Development Scotland (SDS) Individual Learning Accounts (ILAs)"~"United Kingdom"~"

Skills Development Scotland (SDS) Individual Learning Accounds (ILAs) are available to people living in Scotland who have an income of £22
column3: 060 on 19/08/2014) or less a year and are 16 years of age or older. It is open to UK citizens and national members of the European Economic Area who have utilised their 'right of residence' and who are ordinarily resident in Scotland. ILAs only remain in Scotland. In England
column4: ILAs were suspended in December 2001 due to abuse of the system by a small number of providers. In Wales
column5:
ILAs closed in March 2011.

"~"

The premise behind ILAs is based on a model of entitlement to learning which is flexible and not time-bound
column6: equitable
column7: guaranteed and non-bureaucratic. It is favoured as a method of encouraging entry or re-entry and engagement in learning for adults. The main purpose of the Scottish ILA scheme it to encourage individuals to take up learning opportunities and invest in their learning as they do so. The scheme was designed to increase and widen participation in lifelong learning among adults.  Two ILAs are available. The first covers learning new skills or improving existing skills. It provides learners with £200 (€237 on 19/08/2014). The second covers part-time higher education and professional qualifications courses (Higher National Certificate
column8:
Higher National Diploma or Degree level courses) and provides learners with £500 (€592 on 19/08/2014).

"~"

According to Skills Development Scotland's annual statement on efficiency
column9: effectiveness and economy
column11: there were 54
column12:
082 active learners through SDS ILAs in 2011-12.

\r\n

An independent evaluation of the Scottish ILA scheme was published in 2007. The overall aim of the evaluation was to guage the impact of the ILA Scotland scheme. The original scheme was first introduced in 2000 and was generally considered to be sucessful (p. 5).

\r\n

In 2001
column13: the scheme was suspended as a result of some providers incorrectly selling ILAs. The revised ILA Scotland scheme was relaunched in December 2004. It was aimed at those on low incomes who are eighteen and normally resident in Scotland. The scheme was revised again in 2005 to remove the low income threshold for eligibility. In terms of the overall perceptions of the ILA Scotland scheme
column14: the evaluation found that the scheme had been generally welcomed by both learning providers and intermediaries. It was viewed as useful to be used in conjunction with other initiatives. It was viewed as encouraging people to take steps into learning. It was thought that the scheme needed to better address the needs of learners with disabilities
column15:
mental health needs or learning difficulties as well as migrants for whom English is a second language (p. 14).

"~"

There are more than 470 approved learning providers across Scotland
column16: offering a wide range of courses that ILA funding can be used for. An independent evaluation of the Scottish ILA scheme was published in 2007. The evaluation found that the majority of learning providers held positive views with respect to the scheme. Provision of support for part-time study
column17: widening access to education and training and promotion of greater flexibility were among the identified strengths of the scheme (p. 7). In addition
column18: forms of financial support were regarded valuable in that the provided learners with a wider choice of providers
column19: not being restricted to formal educational settings (such as colleges and HEIs). Clients also found the opportunity to learn outside the formal system advantageous (p. 7). Trade unions reported that the role of ILAs in Scotland contributed to an improvement in existing skills of the workforce
column20: particularly workers who may not have been in a position to pay for courses otherwise (p. 7). The scheme was also considered helpful for individuals who had been made redundant or who were facing redundancy. A growing interest from people for whom English is a second language was also seen as a strength of the scheme. In terms of registering for the scheme
column21: learning providers were generally positive about the experience
column22:
feeling that ILA Scotland governmental staff provided valuable support.   

"~"

An independent evaluation of the Scottish ILA scheme found that some representatives from learning providers and intermediaries felt that learners were often confused about the restrictions of the scheme and that these restrictions sometimes acted as barriers to accessing the scheme (p. 8). There was a general sentiment among some learning providers that awareness among client groups was often limited. In particular
column23: agencies working with learners with disabilities
column24: mental health problems  and substance abuse problems were more likely to comment on the low level of awareness among clients (p
column25: 8). Clients with literacy difficulties were also likely to find it difficult to access information about the scheme (p. 8). People were most likely to hear about the ILA scheme by 'word of mouth' (p. 9). The requirement for self-employed or workers with no regular income (many of the latter being women) found it difficult to obtain proof of their position to meet eligibility. Since the evaluation was undertaken
column26:
further revisions have been made to the scheme. This includes the development of an online application process via the scheme's web portal. This may pose as a barrier to people who do not have the necessary IT skills or access to the internet.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Statistinis verslo tendencijų tyrimas (tame tarpe - darbuotojų skaičiaus prognozė)~"Business trends survey (including employment forecasts)"~"Lithuania"~"

This survey covers manufacturing
column2: construction
column3: trade and services sector<span style=""mso-bidi-font-size: 12.0pt; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-ansi-language: EN-US;"">s. Objective of the survey is to collect data (opinion) of the enterprises on the economic changes; to estimate confidence indicators which describe changes and trends of specific economic activity (including employment forecasts). The population of the survey covers all joint stock companies
column4: private limited companies
column5: state and municipal enterprises
column6: branches of foreign companies
column7: individual companies and cooperative companies which were carrying out their economic activity in the reporting year and economic activity of which covers all economic activities according to NACE Rev.2 except agriculture
column8: wholesale
column9: financial intermediation
column10:
public administration and defence.

"~"

This survey of business trends collects data on a range of indicators. This includes data on predicted employment figures up to three months in the future. It is conducted on a monthly basis
column11: and collects the opinions of companies’ executives regarding past
column12:
present and future changes in their economic activities and expectations.

\r\n

\r\n
column13:
sans-serif""; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman"";} -->

\r\n

Different questions on the current economic situation and changes (as well as future changes) in the enterprise are posed to the enterprises according to the kind of their economic activity. Enterprises selected using the purposive sampling method must represent the economic activity according to NACE Rev.2 at a 3-digit level. Enterprises are selected taking into account their income and the number of employees. The number of selected enterprises in every sector cannot exceed 1
column14:
000 as data must be expedited. All biggest enterprises are selected in every sector and 10% of small enterprises are selected every year by using rotation principle. The manager of the enterprise fills the questionnaire.

\r\n


There are three versions of answers provided to each question – positive
column15: neutral and negative; the respondent must choose one answer. Positive
column16:
negative and neutral answers to each question are separately summed up taking into account the size of enterprise and a percentage is calculated. The difference between positive and negative answers is called balance. Different indicators (including forecasted number of employees) are estimated by calculating the arithmetic mean of answers.

\r\n

 

"~"

In practice
column17: this survey is not used in the context of anticipating change and restructuring
column18:
although it would be a good instrument for this purpose.

"~"

The survey gathers reliable information on an ongoing basis. It also provides the opportunity to evaluate possible business developments and the attitudes of companies’ executives regarding employment figures in different economic sectors.

"~"

Weaknesses include its short-term nature
column19: the fact that it is hardly ever used in pursuing economic and social policy
column20:
and the fact that it is based on subjective assessments.

"~"

\r\n

Business trends survey

column1:
Darbo rinkos prognozės~"Labour market forecasting"~"Lithuania"~"

This instrument covers the sectors of agriculture
column2: manufacturing
column3:
construction and services.

"~"

Forecasts of labour force employment have been produced by the Lithuanian Labour Exchange (LLE) on an annual basis since 1995. Every year (in September and October)
column4:
interviews are conducted with employers based in specific regions.

\r\n

Forecasts made are preceded by an analysis of economic and demographic indicators which uncovers general developments in the labour market. One-year forecasts of professions are based on an analysis of the survey data
column5:
data regarding registered labour supply and demand and a forecast of labour force employment figures.

\r\n

A random selection method is used to select employers for inclusion in the survey. A standardised questionnaire is used. It addresses the following subjects: existing and predicted demand for products; investment expectations; existing and predicted number of employees; figures regarding intended redundancies and recruitment; and the need for vocational training. Findings are presented at regional and national levels.

"~"

The results of the survey are rarely used for economic and labour market policy or for the anticipation of restructuring.

"~"

This survey provides the opportunity to examine employers' intentions regarding recruitment and the letting go of staff. This analysis can be done by different economic sectors
column6: company size
column7: and the public/private sector. The survey also highlights which occupations will be the most and the least in demand in the forthcoming year. In addition
column8:
the fact that the study involves the use of two sources of information - labour market trends data and interviews with employers - increases its reliability.

"~"

The results of the survey are rarely used for economic and labour market policy or for the anticipation of restructuring.

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
Aktyvios darbo rinkos politikos priemonės (ADRPP)~"Active labour market policy measures (ALMPM)"~"Lithuania"~"

This scheme is available to employees who are employed by a company that is undergoing economic difficulties and are earning less than usual due to shortened working hours in the company. It is also available to those being served a notice of redundancy and who are therefore unsure of their future prospects
column2:
those who have been dismissed from their job and the unemployed.

"~"
column3:
sans-serif""; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman"";} --> ALMPM cover:

\r\n
column4:
sans-serif""; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman"";} -->
  • Vocational training of the unemployed and employees who have been given a notice of dismissal;
  • Supported employment (subsidised employment
column5: support for skills acquisition
column6: job rotation
column7:
public works); \r\n
  • Support for job creation (subsidies for job creation
column8: implementation of the local employment initiatives
column9:
support for self-employment); \r\n
  • Support for geographical mobility of unemployed.
    • \r\n"~"

    ALMPM increase the employability of both
column10:
unemployed and employees who have been given a notice of dismissal.

"~"

Unemployed and employees receive income support during vocational training and/or are given a chance to find a new job or start their own business.

"~"

In spite of the rather wide range of measures that are available
column11: in practice many of them are mainly used for unemployed additionally supported in the labour market (disabled
column12: youth
column13: prepension age
column14:
etc.)

"~"

column1:
Poortwachter Centers ~"Gatekeeper Centres"~"Netherlands"~"

This initiative is available to employers with employees who have a disability or a long-term illness.

"~"

The Gatekeeper Centres (Poortwachter Centers) are employer-initiated
column2: regional cooperative communities. The first one opened in 2003 in the north west region. Today
column3: nine other centres exist
column4: and there are plans for a further 20 to open in the future. According to the 'Gatekeeper Act'
column5: participating employers are obliged to find a new place of work for employees with a disability or long-term illness
column6:
should there be no possibility of these employees returning to work for them.

"~"

The initiative has grown in popularity
column7:
not just among workers with a disability who are returning to work. Its structure and low-profile working methods create strong opportunities for enhancing proactive mobility in the labour market.

"~"

This initiative has a very non-hierarchical organisational structure.

"~"

column2:

\r\n

Local branch offices of the Public Employment Service (PES; Nemzeti Foglalkoztatási Szolgálat
column3: NFSZ)  ask companies in their respective areas on a quarterly basis about foreseen recruitment and layoffs by occupation
column4: as well as the form of employment should recruitment take place. In the latest survey
column5: in March 2014
column6: more than 16
column7: 000 companies were contacted nationwide. A total of 11
column8: 130 companies
column9: employing altogether more than 677
column10: 000 persons
column11:
filled in the short questionnaire. 

\r\n

 

"~"

\r\n
column12:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} -->

\r\n

The main aim and function of the survey is to strengthen the relationship between employers and local branch offices and thus enable PES to respond efficiently to the forecasted vacancies and redundancies. It is in the interest of the PES to involve as many local companies as possible
column13:
and thus to predict local labour market trends for the quarter and the year ahead.

 

"~"

 

The survey gives a quarterly overview and provides data on a rolling way basis. Thus
column14:
it is suitable to signal both unexpected and more predictable changes on the labour market.

"~"

column1:
Szechenyi Kartya Program~"Micro enterprise and SME support programme"~"Hungary"~"

\r\n
column2:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} -->

This credit opportunity is available for small and medium enterprises having at least one year of operation and can be used for various purposes.

 

"~"
column3:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} -->

\r\n

The Széchenyi Card offers SMEs easy access to subsidised loans via using a credit card. The purpose of this scheme is to provide SMEs with gradually increasing revolving credit
column4: starting with small amounts and going up to EUR 100 000 or the equivalent. KAVOSZ Zrt
column5: a private limited company
column6: established by the National Association of Entrepreneurs and Employers (Vállakozók és Munkáltatók Országos Szövetsége
column7: VOSZ) and the Hungarian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (Magyar Kereskedelmi és Iparkamara
column8: MKIK) is responsible for the professional management and coordination of the scheme. KAVOSZ Zrt. carries out the pre-selection of potential card users
column9: using SME rating tools. The final qualification thresholds are decided by the banks involved in the implementation of the scheme. Recently the agriculture sector have been a beneficiary of the scheme. With the Agriculture Széchenyi Card
column10: farmers can get credit lines of between HUF 500
column11: 000 and HUF 25 million (EUR 1.600-80.000) for one
column12:
two or three years. The state pay a two-percentage-point interest subsidy as well as subsidize the guarantee fee for the credit.

\r\n

 

"~"

\r\n
column13:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} -->

\r\n

Since its launch some 2
column14:
5 billion EUR credit have been provided to 140.000 SMEs. This scheme has proved especially successful in the context of the economic crisis.

\r\n

 

"~"

\r\n
column15:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi;} -->

\r\n

The gradually expended scheme provides low-cost
column16: simple
column17: standardised service and fast access to funding. The interest rate is discounted
column18:
and there is a state support on guarantees.

\r\n

only a couple of commercial banks deal with the product. The process of credit rating may take several weeks.

The program also available for those who are jeopardised by unemployment risk and have obsolete professions. Public workers are also invited.

\r\n
column4:
"sans-serif"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-bidi-font-family: "Times New Roman"; mso-ansi-language: EN-IE; mso-fareast-language: HU; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA;"" lang=""EN-IE"">

\r\n

Participants of CVT receive an OKJ (National Training Registry) qualification and there is opportunity to take part in language courses as well. The National Employment Service (NFSZ) also support courses that are in connection with different vehicles’ driving.

\r\n

  Some courses prepare participants for the master licensing exam (mestervizsga). Training courses are regulated by public authorities (hatósági jellegű képzés). They award nationally or internationally recognised qualifications and licenses
column6: primarily in the fields of transport (by road
column7: water and air)
column8:
plant and veterinary health inspection and food hygiene. They also run various courses that do not lead to a nationally recognised qualification.

\r\n

 

\r\n

There is a financial incentive to supporting private investment in CVT: since 1997
column9:
employers have been given the opportunity to spend (at most) one third of their so-called vocational training contribution (a tax levied on enterprises to the amount of 1.5% of total labour cost) on financing the vocational training of their employees. Micro-enterprises and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) can spend up to 60% of this contribution in this way.

"~"

All of the trainings that can improve an individual's chances in the labour market.

"~"

The courses are subsided by the National Labour Offices (training and exam fees as well as accomodation and travelling costs)

"~"

Employers in SMEs are reluctant to let their employees take part in CVT
column10: partly because of difficulties associated with substituting them for the duration of the training. Another problem
column11: according to SMEs
column12: is the lack of a wide range of short-term
column13: adequate and efficient training programmes and materials; their special training needs are not adequately met by the traditional training courses offered by adult training institutions. Finally
column14: CVT
column15: as a company policy
column16:
is almost completely absent from collective agreements.

"~"

column1:
Foglalkoztatási Paktum~"Territorial Employment Pacts "~"Hungary"~"

Coverage extends to specific regions and occurs on an ad-hoc basis.

"~"

This instruments involves cooperation between regional actors in the labour market
column2:
with a view to identifying opportunities for job creation and human resources development in the sub-region or region in question. It also aims at developing and implementing a common strategy and an action plan to promote employment in the area.

The objectives are:

- fighting against unemployment through initiatives

- improving employability

- supporting local development

- providing training and educational programme for labour market

 

"~"

Currently
column3: 52 of these pacts are in place throughout the country. For the most part
column4:
their full potential has been under-exploited.

"~"

The employment pacts have established cooperative practices between HR staff and civil organisations. These practices can play a useful role in managing labour market tensions
column5: helping the flow of information
column6: submitting applications for job preservation programmes
column7: administrating public work and developing the strategy of vocational training. It allows for the movement of labour
column8: including cross-border movement. This scheme also impacts on the vocational
column9: educational and training (VET) scheme; for example
column10:
it impacted on the ‘Expert Academy’ that was established between Hungary and Austria.

"~"

This scheme is very dependent on external funding
column11:
and its sustainability is therefore not guaranteed. The employment pacts have 2 options in the future: the work to be continued based on projects or the already started processes will be finished due to the lack of subsidies.

"~"

Not applicable.

Implementierung eines Früherkennungssystems zur Vermeidung bestandsgefährdender Risiken ~"Statutory implementation of risk management system "~"Germany"~"

This instrument is available to corporations.

"~"

Paragraph 91/2 AktG of the Stock Corporation Law requires public limited companies to establish a system of measures and control instruments that pinpoint developments that might negatively affect the continued existence of the company at an early stage. A similar stipulation can be found in paragraphs 264 HGB (Commercial code)
column2:
which is generally applicable to corporations. This is done by implementing a risk management system (identifying internal and external risks and developing suitable counter solutions).

column1:
Erkenning van Verworven Competenties (EVC)~"Accreditation of prior learning"~"Netherlands"~"

No information available.

"~"

The 'EVC procedure' (EVC = competencies achieved elsewhere) provides certificates for work experience and informal learning
column2:
in order to facilitate the 'job-to-job mobility' of workers.

"~"

A pilot project in The Hague highlighted its huge capacity to empower employees and to make them less vulnerable in the face of restructuring. In 2008
column3: 105 former ID employees
column4: who had worked in so-called 'subsidised labour'
column5: were invited to particpate in an EVC procedure. This group faced poor labour market prospects: the ID status no longer exists
column6: as the government curtailed funding for these positions
column7: most of which had existed in the public sector. Among them
column8: 74 gained a Level 2 formal certification
column9: and another 42 gained one or more partial certificates for this VET level. The pilot project showed that the EVC process can unveil and certify hidden talents and competencies. Data from the EVC monitor 2002 showed that a minimum of 6
column10:
000 people from 500 organisations took part in an EVC procedure.

"~"The EVC procedure empowers employees with informal qualifications
column11: thus strenghthening their position on the labour market."~"No information available."~"NXP; Schlecker (temporary arrangement)."~"Anticipation"~"recognition of informal/non-formal training"~"national funds*companies"~"regional/local government#No information available.*employers' or employees' organisations#Funding*public employment services#UWV Werkbedrijf*national government#Funding (tax credits and funding based on collective agreements or sectoral training funds have given a boost to EVC); the Ministry of Labour coordinates the activities.*other#Temporary agency sector; funding based on collective agreements or sectoral training funds have given a boost to EVC."~"Sprenger

column1:
O&O-fondsen ~"Sectoral training and development funds"~"Netherlands"~"

Coverage occurs on a sectoral basis
column2:
and is based on collective agreements.

"~"

In 2007
column3: researchers identified 149 O&O fondsen
column4: across  116 different sectors. The instrument's collective annual budget came to about €700 million. Most individual training schemes are 'connected' to a sectoral collective agreement
column5:
in the sense that issues such as its approximate budget and strategic approach can be decided during collective agreement negotiations.

\r\n

During the years prior to the economic crisis
column6: the priority objectives of the funds were: the promotion of good industrial relations in the sector (68% of all funds); retention and improvement of professional skills (67%); improving the connection between education and labour market (62%); and keeping employees in the sector (61%). Once the collective agreement becomes mandatory and binding
column7: all employers within a sector must contribute to the fund. All employees receive training rights and facilities
column8: if their training interests fit the objectives formulated by the social partners. During restructuring
column9: additional claims can be made on a fund
column10:
if agreed by the social partners agree.

\r\n

Training funds (scholingsfondsen) are sector-based funds. They are drawn from levies paid by individual companies of a particular sector; levies range between 0.1 and 0.7% of the company's gross wage bill. These funds focus on providing training and education to employed  people.

\r\n

Employed education funds (opledingsfodsen) involve other sectors and government funds; they focus on the indirect promotion of training. Most of their funding comes from national public finances and European subsidies - the European Social Fund (ESF). Activities include: training for employees; provision of information on training-related regulation included in the collective labour agreement; research to stimulate the labour markets and training needs; working and learning trajectories in order to create learning and working places for young persons; and employment projects which aims to offer training to specific
column11: at-risk groups
column12: such as unemployed people and employees without a minimum qualification
column13: namely
column14:
a diploma of secondary education.

\r\n

In general
column15: employers choose the training course that employees are to complete
column16: from a catalogue of different institutions approved by the O&O fund itself. O&O funds cover the training costs (usually between 50-80% of direct costs) and
column17: in some cases
column18: indirect costs
column19:
such as travel expenses.

"~"

Around 40% of all workers are covered by a training fund. Small firms (those with fewer than 50 employees) provide a lower level of training than that provided to employees of larger firms.

"~"

Temporary agency workers have access to these training funds (unless this right is abolished by a collective agreement); there even is a separate training fund for temporary agency workers. All employers and employees contribute to funding (irrespective of whether or not they access the training provided). The system exists in parallel to governmental support programmes. Training costs can be deducted from the pre-tax profits and incomes of both employers and individuals. It offers support to companies involved
column20: by helping them to conduct training within statutory limits. The scheme increases awareness
column21: among employers and employees
column22: of the importance of training
column23: and encourages them to participate in training activities. It leads to an improvement in the quality of training courses provided and aligns them with the sector needs. Finally
column24: as a result of this scheme
column25:
available training becomes more independent of the economic situation; the system of deducting compulsory contributions from salaries is a stable one.

"~"

The scheme involves no intersectoral or interregional perspective
column26: and training only focuses on one sector. All companies do not benefit from training activities supported by the O&O funds. This is due to a lack of information on this training opportunity
column27: poor alignment between training supply and demand (from employers or employees)
column29: such as those involved in finding replacements for employees who are on training. In particular
column30:
the scheme has encountered difficulties in reaching small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

Fund for the process industry (OVP); fund for the metal sector (OOM).

column1:
Mobiliteitscentra~"Mobility Centres"~"Netherlands"~"

Coverage extends to all companies
column2: but in practice it is mainly used by small and mediumd enterprises (SMEs)
column3:
as well as sectors that have been most affected by the economic crisis.

"~"

A number of regional stakeholders work together to provide immediate support to employees facing unemployment. Specifically
column4: they help them to get new jobs in their own sector or another sector
column5: and/or to access training required for further employment. In a regional mobility centre
column6: the Mobility Coordination Centre (MCC) contacts employers to identiy their needs
column7: as well as options for training and posting employees. Together with the individual employer
column8: the MCC decides on the steps to take
column9: and which regional parties could be of help. They can also be used in times of labour shortages
column10: to assist managers in recruiting personnel from other parts of the organisation. They can disseminate information among employees regarding job opportunities in other parts of the organisation
column11:
and identify employees' training requirements for such job openings.

"~"

According to the director of UWV Werkbedrijf
column12: in the first half of 2009
column13: 431 'work-to-work' projects have been set up by the centres
column14: each of them involving an estimated 10 – 15 employees. The lack of qualified work coaches had hindered the centres' work during the initiation phase. The Nijmegen centre reported thaat  it protected 800 employees from dismissal
column15: across 40 regional companies. The centre in Emmen
column16: in the north-east of the country
column17: reported 500 dismissals from three company closures in August 2008. Half a year later
column18: 62% of  these 500 employees had a new job
column19:
and 16% were in a training-with-job guarantee scheme.

\r\n

During the first five months of 2009
column21: 000 people have found a new job via a work mobility centre. Up to September 2010
column23: 600 employees threatened with dismissal have been assisted in finding another job. Moreover
column24: they have enabled 174
column25: 500 unemployed people to find work within a three month period. A total of 1
column26:
500 company agreements have been conducted on services regarding mobility.

"~"Regional stakeholders cooperate to foster employees' job-to-job transition. The scheme leads facilitates faster provision of existing services."~"There is a lack of internal evaluation systems. Greater harmonisation of various funding sources is needed. Within an organisation
column27: the scheme can be viewed as a resource for 'losers' (i.e. those who are being made redundant)."~"Companies in the region in which Corus
column29: dominates the industrial landscape can have their employees who are in a PTUB scheme retrained at Corus
column30: which has a huge company education centre. \r\nIn addition
column31: many Eindhoven companies share knowledge on the subject of mobility and company training programmes. Examples include NXP
column35: and Semperit."~"Management"~"training*matching/networking"~"national funds*employer"~"regional/local government#Cooperation*employers' or employees' organisations#No information available.*public employment services#The UWV (the unemployment office) and UVW Werkbedrijf (the employment office).*other#Knowledge centres

column6:

column1:
Job rotation~"Job rotation"~"Denmark"~"

This scheme can be availed of by any company and any employee who meet its general conditions.

"~"

Employers hire unemployed people as temporary workers
column2:
while the permanent employed staff members complete training courses. The length of time employees spend in training must be equal to the number of hours worked by the temporary workers. Participating companies receive a 'job rotation grant'; this corresponds to 160% of the highest level of daily allowance.

"~"

Recent years have seen a low level of uptake
column3: due to the 'job-first' approach that job centres are taking. Those involve endorse the idea but in practice
column4:
it is not used very often.

"~"

The scheme provides participating companies with the opportunity to re-organise its workers and thereby perform a smooth internal transition of its employyees
column5: instead of being forced to fire workers. This also increases flexibility within the firm. Moreover
column6:
it creates room for unemployed people on the job market. It is not expensive.

"~"

A low take-up of job rotation has been observed: employers see it as a cumbersome process. Its focus is limited to blue collar workers and low-skilled workers. The job-first approach taken by job centres reduces its perceived value.

"~"

Ballerup Kommune/municipality; Jammerbugt Kommune/municipality.

This is available to high tech industries.

"~"

This involves the development of technologies that create growth opportunities and employment by supporting projects in competitive areas for Danish businesses on the global market. Examples include the fields of energy/environment
column2: IT/telecommunications
column3: production
column4: food
column5:
and construction. Applicants can apply for financial support for high tech projects. Grants range from Kr. 2.5 million to Kr. 15 million.

"~"

In spring of 2011
column6: the fund had a budget of Kr. 600 million
column7: to be invested in new collaborations between researchers and businesses. At that point
column8:
over 95 high-tech projects had been launched.

column1:
Varslingspuljen~"Warning pool "~"Denmark"~"

This applies to companies undergoing major job reductions - this is defined as at least 50% of the employees at a workplace with at least 100 employees. Workplaces with at least 20 employees can undergo a trial period.

"~"

The state provides dedicated funds to each employment region for 'the warning pool'. It is up to the employment regions to administer this funding. In practice
column2:
the initiative works in the following way: a firm undergoing mass redundancies must make a written application for funding from the warning pool. It does this in cooperation with the local job centre.

\r\n

The application shall
column3: among other things
column4: provide detail on how the company proposes to use the funding. Applications are then sent to the employment region centres
column5: where they are considered. If the application is successful
column6: the firm and the local job centre are jointly responsible ensuring that the initiatives are accomplished in accordance with the description in the application. Projects can involve consultation; courses in job searching for up to two weeks within the notice period; skill development
column7:
including further education of the employees for up to eight weeks within the notice period; the preparation of job plans for the dismissed workers; the establishment and operation of an office at the workplace where warned or dismissed workers can seek help and assistance.

"~"

At first
column8:
it seemed that uptake of this instrument was low. It is too early to assess whether or not trial access is working.

"~"This gives very targeted funds to companies undergoing major job reductions. "~"Weaknesses include the high level of bureaucracy involve
column9: the length of time it takes to access funding; the fact that grants are underused; and the fact that the notice period given for many low-skilled workers is too short for the scheme to be feasible."~"The furniture producer RMB; the steel firm Schmolz+Bickenback

column1:
IDA Ireland~"IDA Ireland"~"Ireland"~"

This relates to high end manufacturing
column2: global services (including financial services) and research
column3: and development and innovation. The key sectors within these areas for investment are: life sciences (pharmaceutical
column4: biopharmaceutical and medical technologies); information communications technology (ICT); engineering; professional services; digital media
column5:
consumer brands; and international services.

"~"

The IDA provides information and statistical data on key business sectors and locations within Ireland. It also provides assistance in setting up a business in Ireland. The body introduces potential investors to local industry

column7: service providers and research institutions. Finally
column8: it offers international investors advice regarding property in Ireland
column9:
with the aim to attracting them to Ireland.

"~"

The IDA has a consistent record in attracting foreign direct investment (FDI) to Ireland.

Shannon Development ~"Shannon Development "~"Ireland"~"

This covers the Shannon region in Ireland.

Among other things

column4: on the west coast of Ireland. Shannon Development provides financial assistance to companies wishing to be based in 'Shannon Free Zone' or to expand their existing operations. It offers negotiated incentive packages

Since its establishment in 1959

column1:
Trygghetsråden~"Job security councils "~"Sweden"~"

This is available to employees who have been employed for a minimum period (normally over one year) on a permanent contract
column2:
and are facing dismissal.

"~"

The job security councils were established to administer support outlined in the job security agreements. A job security council is a non-profit foundation
column3: which provides support to employees who have lost their job due to collective redundancies. The council helps these employees in their efforts to find new employment. They provide advice and consultation to the employers and trade unions. They also provide transition services and guidance to workers who are made redundant; this includes labour market and training market information
column4: training
column5: business start-up support. In most cases
column6: support activities are initiated by some form of counselling
column7: guidance meetings or advisory seminars
column8: in order to determine the state of the person as well as to inform the worker of what lies ahead. These initial activities are usually followed by further measures in the form of training or education
column9: personal development activities
column10:
study or support in starting a new business.

\r\n

Employees facing redundancy may also receive financial compensation
column11:
in addition to general unemployment benefits; this may exceed the so-called A-kassataket - the maximum amount of unemployment benefits to which a person is entitled. This can occur if an employee finds a new job that involves a lower salary than their previous position.

\r\n

The work of the job security council normally starts before the dismissals take place. The council is a separate legal entity
column12: known as a collective agreement foundation (Kollektivavtalstiftelse). It is made up of a board of representatives from the different partners involved in the agreement
column13: with the seats split equally between the employer representatives and employee representatives. The board has the task of deciding upon the scope and content of the support that is to be granted. The system works like an insurance system. The premiums that are paid by each company vary between sectors and occupational groups (as defined by union demarcations). About 0.3% of the wage bill are paid by each affiliated company. In certain circumstances
column14: local agreements can be drawn up; they provide less comprehensive support but also involve  lower payroll contributions – ranging from 0.18 % to 0.3 % for affiliated companies and from 0.7% to 0.58 % for non-affiliated ones. When applying for support
column15: each redundant employee receives financial support ranging between €2
column16: 000 and €3
column17:
000; this is to cover the costs for job coaching and other supportive measures.

\r\n

The advisers and consultants working in the job security council have a high degree of freedom in preparing individualised support for each affected employee. The measures provided are flexible and the support activities are  tailored to the needs of each individual
column18: taking into account their qualifications
column19: professional interests and personal preferences and concerns. In some agreements
column20: the support activities last for a maximum of five years
column21: or until the client has found a new job or chosen to discontinue their relationship with the council. However
column22:
support usually is provided for a period of six to eight months.

"~"

Between 1990 and 2009
column23: the Job Security Foundation has been involved in approximately 18
column24: 500 restructuring projects and has supported more than 10
column25: 0000 individuals in their new activities or jobs. A total of 74% of these clients find a new job or other solution
column26: while 26 % remain job seekers. Of those who find a job
column27: 42% become employed within the governmental sector
column28:
and 40% find work in the private sector. The remaining gain employment in the municipality sector. As of 2014 nine out of ten active job seeking clients found a new job or became self employed within seven months following their first contact with the Job Security Foundation. Among the clients 8% start own businesses. Out of these 80% remain in business after two years. Moreover 70% of the clients have an equal or higher salary as the job they were forced to leave (Job Security Foundation).  

"~"

The support provided involves the use of a personal adviser or coach
column29: and is adjusted to the individual situation of the affected worker. The scheme is based on a cooperative model between the social partners. In their new jobs
column30:
most of the displaced employees receive salary that is either equal to or greater than that which they receive for their previous position. The risk of long term unemployment is reduced by this fast and high quality intervention. Outcomes also include a positive fiscal effect for the state.

"~"

In the case of restructuring at Swedish telecom company Ericsson
column31: it was regarded as old fashioned. With the use of old-fashioned methodologies and outdated concepts
column32: here dismissal was regarded as as psychological crisis that should be treated
column33: rather than providing workers with the confidence and skills to take responsibility for their own career development. In addition
column34:
it does not cover the newly employed or those employed on a non-permanent basis. Further subsidy levels are rather low.

"~"

TRR-Trygghetsrådet (Whitecollar workers in the private industry

column1: LO-ekonomerna~"Research by the Swedish trade union confederation research institute
column2:
LO-ekonomerna."~"Sweden"~"

This relates to the Swedish economy in general.

"~"

LO-ekonomerna has provided research and analysis of Sweden's economy since the 1940s. The main objective is to provide employee organisations with research that include forecasts of the Swedish economy's future development. Twice a year LO-ekonomerna publish reports on the economic development under the name Ekonomiska utsikter. Further LO-ekonomerna also monitors the income development for highly paid industrial leaders compared to the income development of blue-collar workers.    

"~"

LO-ekonomerna has been analysing the development of the Swedish economy since the 1940s. It is one of Sweden's most central economy forecasting institutions.

"~"

According to a report from the Swedish central bank
column3:
LO-ekonomerna is most accurate when it comes to assesing growth among the studied forecasting institutes in the period 1999-2008 (Riksbanken). The National Institute for Economic Research has also evaluated forecasting institutes in the period 1997-2013 (Konjunkturinstiutet 2014). In this evaluation LO-ekonomerna performs on average with nine other forecasting institutes. 

"~"

Although research has shown LO-ekonomerna to be accurate when it comes to assesing growth
column4:
forecasters in Sweden appear to have overestimated inflation and growth in the time period 1997-2013 (Konjunkturinstitutet 2014). There are indications in several countries that forecasters have been unable to identify structural changes in growth patterns even after prolonged periods of time.

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
Konjunkturinstitutet~"The National Institute of Economic Research (NIER)"~"Sweden"~"

This applies to the Swedish and the international economy.

"~"

The NIER performs analyses and and provides forecasts of the Swedish and international economy. It also conducts research related to these subjects. The Institute is a government agency accountable to the Ministry of Finance. In addition
column2: the NIER accepts various kinds of commissioned assignments in the areas of macroeconomics and environmental economics. NIER publishes a variaty of reports on the Swedish economy. The most notable is a report on the Swedish economy (Konjunkturläget)
column3: which is published four times a year. Besides this the NIER every month publishes a survey of 1
column4: 500 households and 6
column5:
000 companies on their view of the economy (Konjunkturbarometern). 

"~"

Four times a year
column6: the NIER publishes its latest analysis and forecast in a series of reports entitled 'The Swedish Economy'. Here
column7: one and two year forecasts are presented and systematically analysed. Twice a year
column8:
these shorter-term forecasts are supplemented by medium-term analyses for the next five years. The NIER forecasts serve as a basis for the government's spring financing proposal in April and for the budget proposal in September or October.

"~"

In an evaluation carried out by the Swedish government on economic forecasts between 1994-2013 NIER's economic forecast's faired best in foreseeing changes in employment (Regeringen 2014). NIER has also done a self-evaluation of their own performance between the years 1997 and 2013. The self-evalaution show that NIER was more successful in forecasting GDP growth and employment compared to inflation rates (Konjunkturinstitutet 2014) and that it was in line with other forecasting institutes. 

"~"

The frequent publication of the forecasts ensures the timeliness of data
column9: but the time horizon is relatively short. If the Public Employment Service (PES) bases its decisions about labour market training on this information
column10: there is a risk that demand might decrease before
column11: for instance
column12:
trainees have completed their training. A general problem among forecasters in Sweden is that they appear to have had much greater difficulty in assessing growth than inflation during the last decade. There has also been a general overestimation of inflation and of growth between 1997-2013 (Konjunkturinstitutet 2014). There are indications in several countries that forecasters have been unable to identify structural changes in growth patterns even after prolonged periods of time.

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
Arbetsförmedlingen (Yrkeskompassen)~"The Public Employment Service's forcast ('the occupational compass')"~"Sweden"~"

This forecast is conducted on 200 occupations.

"~"

The Occupational Compass is updated
column2: revised and published twice a year. This involves forecasting of demand and future competition
column3: over a period of 5-10 years. It is targeted at those who are about to choose their future occupation and those who are working with outplacement or counselling services. The short term forecasts on one-year-basis is done at the local level
column4: while the long-term forecasts (5-10 years) are only done at the national level. The forecast is based on retirement statistics
column5:
the availability of education positions and occupational choices and participation in the labour force. 

"~"

The occupational compass covers the largest and most common occupations in the labour market and professions. It covers about 80% of employment options in the labour market. Forecasts are made for one year
column6:
five years and ten years into the future. Occupations involving very few employees are not covered.

"~"

This is one of few labour market forecasts that provides detailed occupational forecasts.

"~"

The annual assessment is based on the individual local employment offices' forecasting. The results are then summarized to a regional and national assessment. In a government report
column7:
some doubts on the quality of the local offices' forecasts accuracy were raised (SOU 2007:18).

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
Business Region Göteborg AB~"Business Region Gothenburg (BRG)"~"Sweden"~"

This relates to the region of Gothenburg.

"~"

Business Region Gothenburg (BRG) is a collaborative platform representing the 13 municipalities that form the Göteborg region. It aims to strengthen and develop trade and industry by focusing on the following: business development
column2: projects that promote clusters and industries
column3: marketing the region nationally and internationally
column4:
creating and collaborating with international networks and providing service and advice to investors and newly established companies in the region. It engages in discussions and debates about the future economic development of the region.

"~"

BRG is a good example of a platform for policy dialogue and economic development. It involves different municipalities and includes representatives from businesses
column5:
employers and various interest groups. The platform's approach has aroused interest from both Swedish and Nordic municipalities.

"~"

BRG has been successful in the promotion of social dialogue. This in turn has prepared the region and the stakeholders for times of economic recession (for instance
column6:
the telecom crisis in 2003-2004 and the global economic and financial crisis from 2008 and onwards).

"~"

Attempts to export the concept of BRG to other regions
column7: such as Stockholm
column8: have had limited success. One hypothesis was that this was due to the exceptionally strong regionalist attitude among citizens of the Gothenburg region. This facilitated and sustained social dialogue
column9:
which is required in order for the Business Region Gothenburg to be a success.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Varasemate Õpingute ja Töökogemuse Arvestamine (VÕTA)~"Accrediting Prior Experiential Learning (APEL)"~"Estonia"~"

The APEL system can be used by individuals who wish to resume formal education studies (higher and vocational level education) that had been previously interrupted. It enables students to acquire a vocational certificate.

"~"

The APEL system enables the accreditation of a person's knowledge and skills-set
column2: regardless of whether these have been acquired at a workplace
column3: in training courses or in educational institutions. APEL takes into account a range of factors: previous studies
column4: participation in professional training or courses
column5: self-learning
column6: and skills and knowledge acquired during a professional career. Accreditation requires the following documentation: a written application; documents that prove acquired knowledge and experience
column7: such as  a training certificate
column8: or job description; and Europass documentation. It also involves an interview
column9: the preparation of a practice report
column10:
and observation of skills.

"~"

The APEL system is implemented in higher education and vocational education. It is also used to acquire professional certificates. According to 2013 data
column12: 534 applications were submitted for APEL. 5
column13:
905 of these were fully approved and 273 receive partial approval. Only 7% of applications were declined.

"~"

APEL improves an individual's competitiveness in the labour market. It makes qualifications more visible to employers.

"~"

The biggest problem relates to the accreditation of work experience; this is due to the novelty and complexity of this task.

"~"

No information available.
