column1:
Majandus- ja Kommunikatsiooniministeeriumi tööjõuprognoos~"Annual forecast of the labour force demand by Ministry of Economic Affairs and Communications"~"Estonia"~"

This forecast is conducted for all economic sectors.

"~"

The tool provides a forecast regarding changes in the employment structure. This includes changes in employment figures
column2: and the movement out of employment areas and between sectors. In doing so
column3: it gives an assessment of developments in the demand of employment and labour force by sectors of activity
column4: occupations and educational levels. The forecast makes use of the Labour Force Survey data and registry data of the Tax and Customs Board on the declaration of social tax. In assessing sectoral level developments
column5: additional sources of information are used. These include entrepreneurship data
column6:
results of related studies or expert assessments of sectoral organisations or large enterprises. The macro level model is based on national accounts data.

"~"

The forecast is used in the planning of publicly financed education and training courses
column7:
and as a tool for designing employment policies.

"~"

The forecast enables anticipation of changes in economic structures. It is used as a tool for planning education and training.

"~"

The size of the sample used for this forecast exercise limits the interpretation of its results
column8:
and the extent to which more detailed information can be provided. The forecast does not enable the anticipation of needed skills in the labour market.

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
Kollektiivsetele koondamistele reageerimise teenus~"Response service to collective redundancies"~"Estonia"~"

Coverage extends to most situations involving collective redundancies. This comprises a minimum of five employees in small companies
column2:
and more in larger ones.

"~"

This provides employees facing collective redundancy with tailor-made and institutionally-linked services
column3: with the aim of avoiding unemployment or reducing the duration of unemployment for those concerned. Employers who are carrying out the collective redundancy are given adequate and institutionally-linked information
column4: while information on those seeking work as a result of redundancy is passed on to the employers who wish to recruit new workers. Information is also provided on rights to services and unemployment benefits. Workers are given help in searching for a job
column5: including information on means of finding jobs
column6: writing CVs
column7: and job interview skills. Meetings can be arranged between potential employers and employees. Other services include individual counselling and job mediation
column8: and individually tailored measures
column9:
if required.

"~"

Assessment of this service has shown that
column10: since 2007
column11: the job prospects of redundant workers have improved as a result of sharing information between the workers and potential new employers. Some people who were made redundant became involved before their actual dismissal; for example
column12: they met with prospective future employers. It was found that
column13: three to five months following their dismissal
column14: these workers were more likely to be working and less likely to be receiving insurance benefit than other workers. This effect occurred even after controlling for differences in people’s gender
column15: age
column16: employment history
column17: previous earnings and the region of workplace. Depending on the method and the period
column18:
the size of the impact ranged from 10 to 20 percentage points.

\r\n

The overall impact of the service on the duration of unemployment insurance benefits was estimated to be around 5-10 days. The delay of the impact may be due to the influence of redundancy benefits; econometric analysis of the determinants of employment probability showed that people with higher redundancy benefits had significantly lower probability of working during the first two months after the redundancy.

\r\n

The measure also helps to bring together based on assessment of labor market services those being made employment and who is the target group of service ""Public Employment Scheme"". In principle
column19: the service is paid work
column20: which does not require unemployed vocational
column21:
professional or occupational preparation.

"~"

The response service offers both group-based and individual measures. It is possible that its flexibility is one of the reasons for its success. It has been recognised that it is not always necessary to involve all partners
column22: in all cases of restructuring. Rather
column23: the composition of partnership and the need for different representatives is determined on a case-by-case basis. Calculations using 2006 data have led to the response service being assessed as cost-effective. Nonetheless
column24: in order to cover the costs involved in providing this service
column25:
an increase of less than 1% in employment probability was required for a one-year period.

"~"

The outcomes and general effectiveness of the response service have not been assessed since 2007. However
column26: the design of the service
column27: as well as the economic and labour market context
column28: have both changed significantly. Thus a more up to date assessment is required
column29: in order to evaluate the service's performance during a period of high unemployment. One of the challenges in terms of implementation has related to the range of partners involved in the service. They are often engaged in other activities
column30: and yet responding to redundancies requires immediate action. Thus
column31: a certain degree of flexibility is demanded from the partners
column32:
which is sometimes difficult to achieve.

"~"

Elcoteq.

column5:
movement and geographical mobility of labour were conducted.
Since 2007 the Ministry of Economics elaborates labour market development scenarios and provides medium and long-term forecasts. Forecasts for 2008-2013 (later updated to 2009-2015) were developed in the framework of 15 economic sectors and 37 aggregated professional categories. Labour market forecasts are based on three economic development scenarios - slow
column6:
moderate and dynamic growth.
Labour market forecasts are discussed in meetings of the Labour Market Forecasting Advisors Council

The Ministry of Welfare organizes regular monitoring of labour market
column11: informs the Cabinet of Ministers once in a year on the situation of labour markets and provides short-term forecasts of labour market twice in a year. In order to plan employment support measures
column12: such as training
column13:
the Ministry of Welfare prepares and submits for discussion in the Cabinet of Ministers annual Informative report on short term forecasts of labour market and priority directions of training of unemployed and job seekers (the last one is dated as 17.04.2014).

column1:
Karjeras konsultācijas ~"Career consultations"~"Latvia"~"

Available to unemployed people and those at risk of unemployment.
Included in the Youth Guarantees system and complex aid measures. Provided by the State Employment agency
column2: Latvian Employers confederation
column3: education institutions
column4:
private career consultation organisations.

"~"

The State Employment agency provides career consultations which are aimed at supporting the unemployed
column5: job seekers and other persons at risk of unemployment in solving issues related to professional suitability
column6:
retraining and career planning in accordance with the Support for Unemployed Persons and Persons Seeking Employment Law. 

\r\n

Overall
column7: the career consultation services provide group or individual career and/or psychological counselling; career guidance; assistance in identifying suitable work goals; coaching and role playing; information and assistance when searching for a job; job retraining; and work placements. Individuals availing of this service can undergo testing in the areas of personal interest
column8: aptitude
column9: personality and psychometrics. Health profiling can also be provided. Group activities involve consultations
column10: seminars and lectures on career management issues
column11:
career motivation tests and interpersonal communication training.

\r\n

The counsellors assess the individual's professional interests and competences against specific professional profiles. They evaluate factors such as their personality
column12: cognitive styles
column13: aptitude for work and individual psychological characteristics against job requirements. Internet services are also provided; this includes online career interest tests
column14: information on careers and training opportunities
column15: and the electronic storage of CVs
column16: cover letters
column17:
and responses from career guidance and/or psychological counsellors.

"~"

In 2013 44
column18: 118 people have received career consultation provided by the State Employment agency
column19: of which 38
column20: 448 unemployed people and job seekers
column21: and 5
column22:
670 other people under risk of unemployment.

"~"

Career consultations help to identify the professional suitability
column23:
to evaluate training abilities before taking part in any courses or retraining measures. The task of a career consultant is to provide psychological support and educate the client on career choice and planning.

column1:
Kompleksie atbalsta pasâkumi~"Complex aid measures "~"Latvia"~"

These measures are provided to unemployed people who face a particular risk of social exclusion
column2: due to factors such as a low level of education (at most
column3: a basic level)
column4: having a disability
column5:
or substance dependence.

"~"

These measures aim to help particular groups of unemployed people in dealing with personality problems and dependency problems. They also work towards improving participants' motivation and stability in order to promote their inclusion in the labour market.

\r\n

The maximum length of involvement in the complex aid measure is two years. An assessment is carried out of the social situation and individual needs of an unemployed person. This includes their health status
column6: professional and physical capacities
column7: psychological characteristics and professional suitability
column8: as well as
column9: if necessary
column10: dependency and other social problems. It can also involve an evaluation of a crisis situation
column11:
if this is required.

\r\n

Mental health specialists
column12: for example
column13: psychologists
column14: psychiatrists and psychotherapists
column15: attempt to address participants' personality problems and increase their motivation; this work reflects the specific needs of each participant
column16: as identified in their individual assessment. Measures for improving social functioning abilities are introduced. These include group classes for persons with dependency problems
column17: alongside other steps. If positive results are achieved here
column18: further measures are introduced
column19: this time with the aim of improving the individual's opportunities within the labour market. These can include the acquirement or renewal of elementary work skills
column20: measures to increase competitiveness
column21: career consultations
column22:
as well as steps towards entering into an employment contract.

"~"

column1:
Les qualifications de demain~"'The skills of tomorrow'"~"Luxembourg"~"

Coverage of this programme extends to the industrial sector and that of information and communication technologies (ICT).

This involves an investigation of companies' needs for employees
column2: both in terms of replacements and new positions
column3: and expected skill levels. Surveys are conducted every two years
column4: and they alternate between the fields of industry and ICT. The objectives of this research are to provide guidance to young people (and their parents) regarding their further education
column5:
and to encourage public authorities and professional training providers to achieve a balance between business needs and the training courses they provide.

"~"

These surveys have led to concrete outcomes. Following the detection of a need for manufacturing workers

column9: National Center for vocational training)

column11:
vocational training measures have also been organised as a result of this research. Specialised training in ICT has been implemented in schools. The University of Luxembourg has finally organised specific courses in technology.

Formation professionnelle continue en entreprise~"Collective access to vocational training"~"Luxembourg"~"

This relates to vocational training in companies. In order to be eligible for financial support
column2: companies must develop a plan or project for training. The training plan must involve training activities that closely relate to those of the enterprise and which concern the adaptation
column3: conversion or promotion of employees. At least half of the training programme must take place within normal working hours. Periods of learning taking place outside normal working hours qualify either for compensatory time off
column4: equal to 50% of continuing professional training hours
column5:
or a financial compensation calculated at the rate of normal working hours.

"~"

This involves the cofinancing of training and subsidies for Luxembourgish language courses.

\r\n

Concerning the cofinancing
column6:
the financial assistance from the State will be comprise between 20 % to 35% depending on the situation of the employee (35% will be available for employee without diploma or with 10 years or more of seniority).

"~"

In 2011
column7:
the State's participation to the on-going vocational training is representing 41 million EURO. 1 291 companies are beneficiaries of this state assistance and the average amount perceived is 38.300 euros.

column1:
Congé individuel de formation, CIF~"Individual training leave "~"Luxembourg"~"

This is available to employees working in the private sector who have been in their current place of employment for at least six months. It is also available to self-employment and liberals professions who are affiliate to the Luxembourg's social security for at least two years.

\r\n

 

"~"

Employees receive additional leave for training
column2: up to a maximum of 80 days during an individual career. A maximum of 20 days leave can be taken for this purpose within a two year period. Training must only be offered by institutions issuing certificates that are recognised by the public authorities. During training leave the employee receives compensation
column3: paid by his employer
column4: which is equal to his wage. The employer is then reimbursed this amount
column5: as well as the employer's social contributions
column6:
by the Ministry of National Education and Vocational Training.

column7: enacted on 24 October 2007
column8: envisages that all those involved in professional activity in the private sector are eligible to 80 days of the training leave during their working life. Critics suggest that this is already out of date. Social partners point out that the current economic environment is rapidly changing; in this context
column9:
80 days does not seem to be a sufficient period of time to keep one's skills up to date.

column1:
Le congé linguistique~"Language leave"~"Luxembourg"~"

This is available to employees working in the private sector who have been in their current place of employment for at least six months. It is also available to self-employment and liberals professions ed people and to those professoinals who are affiliate to the Luxembourg's social security for at least 6 months.

\r\n

 

"~"

 

\r\n

The  relevant legislation relates to ""The language leave"" concern the training in learning of Luxemburgish language in order to a better integration in the Luxembourg's society through the labour market. It must be provided by recognised institutes in Luxembourg or abroad. The total leave time for language courses is 200 hours. The employers of employees taking a language leave are entitled to a reimbursement of the employee's salary
column2: for each hour they spend in training (with a maximal amount of four times the minimal social salary - 44
column3: 42 euros- ). Employees availing of this scheme must receive a diploma or certificate following 80 hours training
column4:
before they may take any of the remaining 120 hours leave.

column1: VATTAGE ~"VATTAGE - A dynamic
column2:
applied general equilibrium model of the Finnish economy"~"Finland"~"

Serving policy-making and analysis.

"~"

This is a dynamic
column3:
applied general equilibrium model of the Finnish economy developed by the Government Institute for Economic Research. The model is based on an extensive database that describes the transactions between different agents in the economy. This means that the forecasting model requires continuous updating.

The model has
column4: for example
column5:
been used to study the effects of tax policies and environmental policies on the economy and to study scenarios concerning the driving forces of economic growth and employment. 

\r\n

There is also a regional version of the model
column6: VERM. This model has been used to study the effects of various tax policies
column7: regional policies
column8: and environmental policies on the economy. Lately
column9: the model has seen extensive use in the anticipation of regional development
column10:
especially in the labour markets. 

"~"

The model is widely used by ministries and authorities to evaluate impacts of potential policy measures.

"~"

The model's key strengths is its flexibility. It is easily customisable to evaluate different policy issues thanks to an underlying extensive database.

"~"

The model needs continuous updating of underlaying data. Although flexible
column11:
it can be strenuous and time consuming to customise the model to a specific need. 

"~"

One notable example where the model has been used is in an analysis on the development of the Finnish economy after the global financial crisis. In the study the scenario work was based on the assumptions raising from the policy goals of the Europe 2020 growth strategy.

\r\n

The study pointed out the importance of increasing labour supply
column12: household consupmtion and competitevness in production in order to secure the economic growth in Finland. The study was made in 2012 by The Government Institute for Economic research (VATT) in cooperation with the Ministry of Employment and the Economy
column13: the Ministry of Education and Culture
column14:
the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health and the Ministry of Finance.

column1:
Valtakunnallinen ammatillisten osaamistarpeiden ennakointi (VOSE)~"National anticipation model regarding the future demand for skills"~"Finland"~"

This process model is developed to anticipate vocational competences and skill needs for the future
column2:
with a time span of 10-15 years.

"~"

The model was developed within a European Social Fund-project on future competences and skills
column3: known as the VOSE project in 2008 - 2012
column4:
coordinated by the Finnish National Board of Education. The anticipation model created in the project is now in regular use at the National Board of Education in the qualitative anticipation of education and training.
The VOSE model collects previously developed anticipation methods. The model is based on the involvement of a group of experts
column5: representing social partners representing the piloted sectors
column6: representatives of research institutions and of various fields of education
column7: as well as other experts in the sectors in question. The expert group meets in workshops where future challenges for the branch is identified. Based on this
column8:
scenarios for the field is developed using a futures table method that identifies future skills needs.  

"~"

The model is reported to effectively coordinate resources for the qualitative anticipation of future competence and strengthen future-oriented activity both within the public sector and for individual enterprises. It can be used by political
column9: regional and institutional actors as well as by companies. Resluts may be utilised
column10: for example
column11: in curriculum planning and other development of the content of education at different levels and by different providers; including vocational
column12:
polytechnic and university education. The model is regularly used by the National Board of Educaiton to anticipate the skills needs in 2-3 fields every year. 

"~"

column1: Työvoima- ja koulutustarvetiedustelu (TKTT)~"Study of the need for workforce and training
column2:
TKTT-model "~"Finland"~"

Anticipating the future need for workforce and skills on the regional level.

"~"

The model builds on interviews with regional companies conducted by civil servants in employment offices. Information is gathered about the companies short-term views on a range of subjects. These include: 

  • changes in the use of workforce 
  • recruiting problems
  • training requirements for professions and job assignments
  • changes in core professions and job content
  • age distribution and the retirement rate of personnel
  • current economic situation and one year economic projection
  • training needs
  • needs regarding networking and sub-contracting
  • prospects for export contracts
  • investment needs
  • needs regarding premises


The TKTT model comprises the following main phases:

  1. The selection of fields of business
  2. Training for interviewers
  3. Launching the campaign
  4. Carrying out the interviews
  5. Applications
  6. Producing a summary for a council of experts
  7. Meeting the council of experts and conducting a SWOT analysis
  8. Delphi survey
  9. Reporting
  10. Connecting the recommended actions to decision making

 

"~"

Almost all regional Centres for Economic Development
column3:
Transport and the Environment (ELY Centres) in Finland use the so called TKTT-model for regional anticipation.  

"~"

The model provides timely multifaceted knowledge about the workforces
column4: branches and regional specificities
column5:
especially helpful for the planning of labour market training.

"~"

The reliablility of the collected data is dependent upon employers' business foresight planning and their ability to predict future needs of workforce. These predictions might be especially difficult for many SME's. 

"~"

The Kainuu region used the model for mapping workforce and training needs within health and social services.

\r\n

 

\r\n

column1:
Muutosturva~"'Change Security' model"~"Finland"~"

This scheme is available to workers who are at risk of being made redundant due to economic reasons and who have a job history of at least three years. It also covers employees on a fixed-term contract who have been employed by the same employer for a minimum period of three years or at least for 36 months within the last 42 months. Workers who resign after being laid-off for at least 180 days without interruption are also eligible for the scheme. 

"~"

The 'Change Security' system has been created with the purpose of promoting flexible reemployment from one job to another for workers at risk of dismissal for economic reasons. The 'Change Security' model consists of four basic elements. Firstly
column2: changes to Finnish Labour Law required employers with more than 10 workers to inform employees of forthcoming substantial changes such as dismissal. Secondly
column3: employment offices must provide counselling for staff who have been laid off. They must also help them in preparing to seek new employment
column4: either before or after they have been made redundant. Thirdly
column5: once a 're-employment plan' has been prepared
column6: financial aid is given to those who have been made redundant
column7: in addition to a normal allowance; its aim is to encourage job-seeking activity. Jobseekers who are looking for work independently can receive this allowance for up to 200 days. Fourthly
column8: employees are entitled to a specified number of additional job-seeking leave
column9: prior to redundancy. This ranges from 5-20 days
column10:
depending on the duration of their employment.

\r\n

The cooperation and involvement of other stakeholders has increased over time; examples include the labour movement and third sector actors.

"~"

A study commissioned by the Ministry of Employment and the Economy about the 'Change Security' shows that among eligible persons
column11: 35% find employment within three months
column12: and nearly 56% within eighteen months. The scheme offers individual guidance to relevant training schemes etc
column13: meaning that the proportions of persons left outside the labour force are marginal. During the years 2005-2013 almost 100
column14:
000 persons have benefitted from the scheme. 

"~"

The following factors have probably led to the success of this measure: the involvement of different stakeholders and their collaboration; early intervention with those who have been made redundant; the activation of job-seeking measures and rapid utilisation of training.

"~"

The scheme requires rather extensive resources of the employment and economic development administration in order to be able to offer active individual counselling for employees who have been laid off. 

\r\n

There has also been some problems with awareness rising of the model and neither employers nor employees always take full advantage of the 'Change Security' model. Some problems in the implementation have been observed in SMEs as they tend to have a lack of information and resources. The 'job-seeking leave' an employee is entitled to prior to redundancy might be difficult to arrange in a small firm.

"~"

No information.

column1:
Laki ammatillisesta aikuiskoulutuksesta~"The Vocational Adult Education Act (631/1998)"~"Finland"~"

This applies to all adults in Finland.

"~"

The purpose of the Act is to maintain and increase the professional skills of the adult population
column2: to contribute to the development of working life and to promote and support employment and life-long learning. The Act provides a legal framework for the acquisition of an officially recognised qualification for occupational skills
column3: regardless of how they have been acquired. For example
column4: they may have been gained in educational institutions
column5: at work
column6: by self-study
column7: or by some other form of activity. Through a competence-based qualification a Vocational upper secondary qualification
column8:
a Further vocational qualification or a Specialised vocational qualification can be obtained.  

The recognition is done through a a 'qualification event'
column9: where the professional competence is assessed by training experts and representatives of working life in authentic work assignments. Candidates also assess their own skills. After this
column10:
a vocational certificate can be awarded as a proof of competence.

\r\n

Preparatory training can be organised as independent or labour political training
column11:
through an apprenticeship contract or as staff training. Staff training is organised by an employer.

\r\n

column9: "sans-serif"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-language: DE; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"" lang=""EN-GB"">The RVCCS enables each person aged 15 years and over to receive accreditation for skills and competencies that they have acquired in different learning contexts
column10: including their personal
column11: professional and social life. There are two types of RVCC process: Educational RVCC (RVCC Escolar) and Occupational RVCC (RVCC Profissional). The first one can be initiated by persons aged 15 and over  that did not finish basic education by presenting an application to the Centre for Educational and Professional Qualification (Centros para a Qualificação e Ensino Profissional - CQEP). The Occupational RVCC can be initiated by adults (18 and over) that acquired knowledge and skills through their work experience by presenting an application to the CQEP. It seeks to provide a supply of training that reflects the needs of companies and workers. It also aims to highlight the value of learning by experience and to provide clear training pathways. The RVCC process includes three stages: recognition (of knowledge
column12: know-how and skills of each applicant)
column13: validation (of skills through a standard assessment) and certification of skills (is formalised by issuing a certificate of basic education at level 1
column14: 2 or 3 or a secondary education diploma
column15:
depending on the case).

column1:
Quarterly surveys of employers~"Quarterly surveys of employers"~"Malta"~"

Surveys are conducted of various economic sectors.

"~"

Surveys forecast short-term employment needs in industry.

"~"

These surveys are often quoted in the local press
column2:
in articles dealing with the performance of the Maltese economy.

"~"

The identification of gaps and skills in the labour market provides well informed updates of needs and demands in the labour market. This facilitiates the designation of training and education courses for the unemployed and for those in employment who are willing to upgrade their skills or are seeking new jobs.

"~"

There is a lack of funded initiatives to conduct future trends analysis; such sources could complement these surveys by forecasting skill requirements in the context of changes in the economy. Moreover
column3:
these reports are not widely publicised and hence their impact may be limited.

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
ETLAn aluetietokannan ennusteet~"ETLA economic five-year regional forecasting system "~"Finland"~"

This covers 15 industries and 19 counties in Finland.

"~"

Five-year projections are made on regional production and employment in 15 industries on a biannual basis. The model also makes forecasts regarding unemployment
column2: population and migration in all the 19 counties of Finland. The projections are available in the 'Sector Online' service
column3: an information system managed by the Ministry of Employment and the Economy
column4: which provides extensive
column5:
up-to-date statistics on future developments of business activities and the economy. This service is available to subscribers.

"~"

The projections are of great importance for regional authorities. 

"~"

column1:
Vocational education and training (VET) provider accreditation system~"Vocational education and training (VET) provider accreditation system"~"Ireland"~"

This relates to vocational education and training (VET) providers.

"~"

FETAC provides publicly recognised awards to learners on a broad range of programmes offered by VET providers. In doing so
column2: it applies a comprehensive quality assurance system. All VET providers offering FETAC awards
column3: which are reviewed at least every five years
column4:
must have a quality assurance system agreed by FETAC (including external evaluation). Programmes offered by VET providers are validated by FETAC before being implemented. They are monitored and evaluated both during and after their delivery.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

An external evaluation of the scheme is conducted by FETAC. VET providers feel this is valuable
column5:
as it helps them to continuously improve the quality of their work.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

column1:
Yrkeshögskola~"Higher Vocational Education"~"Sweden"~"

This is available to adults who have completed secondary education or adults over 25 years with at least four years work experience.

"~"

The Swedish National Agency for Higher Vocational Education is responsible for approving and accrediting continuing training courses according to quality standards. Adults with completed secondary education or adults over 25 years with at least four years work experience can apply for higher vocational training. The agency
column2: which is independent but steered by the Swedish government
column3: operates nationwide and supports recognised training courses with its financial grants. It must also ensure that every curriculum maintains an appropriate quality standard at all times. Formal approval must be given to any new course
column4: before it commences
column5:
in order for the agency to be enabled to pay grants to students and to providers.

"~"

The number of applications for advanced vocational education in Sweden has increased markedly in recent years. In 1998
column7: 363 people applied and in 2012 there were 40
column8: 700 applicants. According to a report by the the Swedish National Agency for Higher Vocational Education
column9:
more than nine out of ten students who graduated in 2012 had a job one year after graduation. (Myndigheten för Yrkeshögskolan).

"~"

Cooperation between employers and vocational and educational training (VET) providers ensures that training is provided to an adequate standard. 

"~"

According to a report by the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training
column10:
no links are made between the output achieved by VET providers and the amount of public funding provided.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Servicio de integración activa en la PYME~"Service for active integration in SMEs "~"Spain"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

Firstly
column2: the skill requirements of SMEs in a specific region are identified. Following this
column3: free training is provided to selected candidates registered with the Public Employment Service (PES). Training addresses general subjects
column4:
such as personal development and IT skills. Job-specific training is also provided. A third stage provides paid internships to companies. These last up to two months. About 70-75% of required funding is provided by the PES.

"~"

During the first stage of the measure
column6: training was provided to 1
column7: 005 participants
column8:
482 of whom were later hired by SMEs.

column1:
Dispositivo de evaluación y reconocimiento de la competencia ~"Device for the assessment and recognition of competence"~"Spain"~"

Coverage extends to the Basque region. The scheme is available to people aged 18 years and over with at least two years professional experience.

"~"

Certification is provided for skills and competences acquired in the workplace
column2: through vocational training programmes and through apprenticeships. If the training programme fulfils certain requirements and if the person achieves certain targets
column3: a professional
column4:
official qualification is provided.

"~"

A total of 6
column5:
000 people have participated in the programme since 2004; 85% of the participants have obtained certification for skills and competences.

"~"

The programme encourages life-long learning. According to the director of the Basque agency for the assessment of competence and quality of vocational training
column6: Imanol López Lacalle
column7:
50% of participants have continued taking training or education.

"~"

The information of the programme and the procedures should be more accessible.

"~"

No information available.

column3: "sans-serif"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; color: black; mso-ansi-language: DE; mso-fareast-language: DE; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"" lang=""DE"">The catalogue aims to promote and facilitate access to dual certification pathways
column4: by introducing a wider variety of modules for certification purposes and by developing a framework to facilitate the RVCC processes (th
column5: "sans-serif"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-language: DE; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"" lang=""EN-GB"">e  RVCC enables each person aged 15 years and over to receive  accreditation for skills and competencies that they have acquired in  different learning contexts
column6: including their personal
column7:
professional and social life. There are two types of RVCC process: Educational RVCC (RVCC Escolar) and Occupational RVCC (RVCC Profissional). The first one can be initiated by persons aged 15 and over  that did not finish basic education by presenting an application to the Centre for Educational and Professional Qualification (Centros para a Qualificação e Ensino Profissional - CQEP). The Occupational RVCC can be initiated by adults (18 and over) that acquired knowledge and skills through their work experience by presenting an application to the CQEP - see ID111).

\r\n
column8: "sans-serif"; mso-fareast-font-family: "Times New Roman"; color: black; mso-ansi-language: EN-GB; mso-fareast-language: DE; mso-bidi-language: AR-SA; mso-bidi-font-weight: bold;"" lang=""EN-GB"">The catalogue seeks to provide a supply of  training that reflects the needs of companies and workers. It also aims  to highlight the value of learning by experience and to provide clear  training pathways. The RVCC process includes three stages: recognition  (of knowledge
column9: know-how and skills of each applicant)
column10: validation (of  skills through a standard assessment) and certification of skills (is  formalised by issuing a certificate of basic education at level 1
column11: 2 or 3  or a secondary education diploma
column12:
depending on the case).

\r\n

column1:
Sistema Prospectivo de Indicadores do Mercado de Emprego, SPIME~"Prospective System of the Labour Market Indicators"~"Portugal"~"

The survey targets enterprises with more than 10 workers and gathers information that enables the prediction of restructuring cases over the subsequent nine months.

column4: the content of local
column5: regional
column6: and national newspapers is analysed
column7: in order to identify potential cases of restructuring. Secondly
column8: a biannual survey of employers is carried out to identify possible restructuring cases
column9: and the number and characteristics of workers that might be affected. Thirdly
column10: a network of experts with knowledge of employment and restructuring processes anticipates possible cases of restructuring
column11: and provides support during those processes. This network validates the information collected through the other methods.  It also complements this information with in-depth knowledge of the situation under analysis. Moreover
column12:
the network analyses the reasons behind restructuring processes and provides  a comparison between existing and required skills among the workforce.

column1:
Zakon o pomoči za reševanje in prestrukturiranje gospodarskih družb v težavah ~"Act governing the rescue and restructuring aid for companies in difficulty"~"Slovenia"~"

This is available to companies that are unable to access funding to curtail negative trends in their business performance
column2: which would
column3: without intervention
column4:
jeopardise the existence of the company.

"~"

A company in difficulty that wishes to get state aid must prepare a restructuring strategy. This must include a programme to address the needs of employees facing redundancy and a training and education programme for employees. State aid can be provided in different ways
column5: for example in the form of a loan
column6: a subvention
column7: an interest rate subsidy
column8: a guarantee
column9:
a financial investment or as a deferral of taxes or contributions payments.

"~"

State aids given to enterprises that are experiencing difficulties do not usually prove to be an efficient means of addressing the issue.

"~"

column1:
Bildungskarenz (Weiterbildungsgeld)~"Training leave (Further training benefit)"~"Austria"~"

Training leave is available to employees who have been employed by their employer for at least six months. It must involve the agreement of both the employer and the employee. Seasonal workers can also take training leave
column2: provided they have worked for at least six months within the last four years for their employer
column3: and have been employed for at least three consecutive months by that employer
column4:
immediately prior to taking training leave.

"~"

During training leave
column5: the worker receives further training benefits (Weiterbildungsgeld). It is drawn from unemployment benefit funds
column6: and is equal to this welfare payment (basic amount: 55% of former income)
column7: at a minimum of €14.53 per day. However
column8: the employment relationship is not terminated
column9:
although the worker receives no wage and does not work in the company.

\r\n

The worker must participate in training measures for at least 20 hours per week
column10: or 16 hours for those with care responsibilities (for a child under the age of seven). The period of training leave
column11: which must be agreed on by the employer and employee
column12: may last between two and 12 months
column13:
and can be split into intervals of at least two months within a four-year period. The leave must be registered with the Public Employment Service (AMS). Benefits in the amount of (fictional) unemployment benefits are received.

\r\n

Training leave can be taken every four years
column14:
dating from from the beginning or first interval of the last one. Training leave is taken into account in the calculation of employees' pension entitlements.

"~"

Due to both the economic crisis and improved access to the programme
column15: use of training leave increased from an average of 1
column16: 635 persons in 2008 steadily to an average of 4
column17: 986 persons in 2009
column21: 771 in 2011 and a peak of 8
column22: 069 persons in 2012 (BMASK
column23:
2013.)

"~"

During the economic crisis
column24:
the measure has often been used instead of making workers redundant and has thus acted as an employment-saving instrument.

"~"

Participation in this scheme involves long absences from work which must be reconciled with companies' requirements. This can be a particular problem for smaller companies: if one of their employees is not working in the company for a longer period
column25: specific knowledge and skills are lost. In addition
column26:
it is not certain that the education market can provide suitable training courses - both modular and individualised measures are needed. Training costs are not covered.

"~"

column1:
Arbeitsstiftung (outplacement)~"Work foundation (outplacement)"~"Austria"~"

Coverage varies depending on the type of work foundation (also: reemployment scheme); in general
column2:
this is available to persons entitled to unemployment benefits.

"~"

A work foundation is usually installed for employees concerned by mass redundancies. Different types of foundations exist. Company foundations are for employees of one company; insolvency foundations are run by a legal entity in case of the insolvency of a company; and regional foundations are provided for several companies within a region.

\r\n

Regarding procedures
column3: the employer and the works council agree on a social plan which offers the workers the possibility to participate in a work foundation (training) course. Following consultation with the social partners
column4: the regional branch of the Public Employment Service (AMS) recognises the foundation. Workers can choose to participate in the work foundation course or to benefit from other PES measures. Those who agree to take part in the foundation undergo a substantial profiling process that lasts six weeks. This forms the basis of an individualised training plan which may last for up to four years. Training may include apprenticeship programmes
column5: vocational adult training courses
column6: company internal training
column7: school-based courses and university-based vocational training. Finally
column8: workers are supported in finding a new job or in starting their own business. During participation
column9: the workers receive 'foundation unemployment benefits' that are equal to standard unemployment benefits (basic amount: 55% of former income). The length of time during which unemployment benefits can usually be obtained (in case of unemployment) is extended when participating in a work foundation (up to 156 weeks
column10: and in case of a longer training course or for persons older than 50 years
column11: up to 209 weeks). Besides the AMS
column12: concerned companies have to provide funding to the work foundation. Furthermore
column13:
local labour market actors and the social partners are also involved.

"~"

This programme is very successful; it has a job placement rate of about 75% one year after the end of the measure (includes all types of work foundation
column14: incl. implacement foundations). In 2005
column16: 833 people were supported by outplacement foundations. As a consequence of the economic crisis
column17: some 5
column18: 780 persons were supported in outplacement foundations in 2009. In the following years
column19: the numbers decreased again (3
column23:
772 in 2012).

"~"

They enable workers to avoid the stigma associated with dismissal. Social partners are intensively involved at regional and company level. The training leads to a substantial and long-term qualification (including complete requalification for occupational change). This benefits both employees and employers. Participants can choose the qualification they will work towards. The companies concerned cover parts of the costs of the programme
column24: which reduces the amount of public money that is spent on it. The programme fosters initiative among participants who can also avail of unemployment benefits for a longer period of time than is usually allowed. Finally
column25: employers benefit from 'social peace' - they keep their good image
column26:
among their remaining workers as well as on the market.

"~"

This programme is expensive. Participation limited to specific target groups.

"~"

column1:
Arbeitgeberzusammmenschlüsse (AGZ)~"Employers' groupings "~"Germany"~"

Implemented in various regions. Groupings often being supported by the European Structural Fund (ESF) and regional/national government funding.

"~"

Several employers (private
column2: public or NGOs) form a 'labour pool' (AGZ). In many cases
column3: this is preceded by a feasibility study to investigate regional demand for an AGZ and the feasibility of combining different employers' labour need. The labour pool is a separate legal entity; it employs workers who are then sent to work in the member companies. Workers are recruited on the basis of an assessment of the needs of each member company
column4: taking into account how many hours a worker is needed. The member companies have to guarantee these hours and pay for them. In general
column5: each worker has between two and four jobs per year
column6: either on a seasonal or continuous basis - for example
column7: workers can work every working day or every second week. Contractual relations with the employer remain intact
column8:
and wages (which are guaranteed to be of the same level as those of core staff) continue to be paid.

\r\n

In addition to the provision of workers
column9: the AGZ might also provide other services to the member companies. Such services could include the organisation of training
column10: recruitment (of core staff in individual member companies as well as to the 'labour pool')
column11:
and administration of core staff.

"~"

Currently
column12: four AGZ are active
column13:
involving 97 members and 75 employees.

"~"

This scheme provides participating firms with an additional instrument for managing cyclical and seasonal variations in demand. It provides workers with employment security and they are guaranteed the same wages as the core staff in the member companies. A feasibility study to be conducted prior to implementation or during the start-up phase is recommended. The scheme provides companies with skilled and continously trained workers who are benefitting from different work experiences and high adaptability. In contrast to temporary work agencies
column14: the AGZ does not aim at making a profit
column15: hence companies only have to cover wage and administration costs (about 15%)
column16:
but no agency fees.

"~"

There is a low level of awareness and familiarity with AGZs among companies. No legal framework has been made available yet; currently they are treated as temporary work agencies which results in several problems:

1. farmers bear higher administration costs for AGZ-employees in comparison to other branches (around 19%).

2. It is difficult to set up an AGZ for the construction sector.

3. A certain organisational and financial capability is needed to set up an AGZ (solo-entrepreneurs with low-level income are found to have difficulties organising an AGZ).

Previous examples show that setting up an AGZ with an external initiator (i.e. one that is not part of the AGZ) proves difficult (lack of identification and involvement of member companies with the AGZ). Member companies need to share the same goal and must have analysed and defined their need for labour very well.

"~"

AGZ Südbrandenburg which has 30 members and 45 employees.

column1:
Transferagentur oder Transfergesellschaft/Beschäftigungs- und Qualifizierungsgesellschaften~"Transitional employment agency or transitional company"~"Germany"~"

This mesure applies to employees whose employment contract ended due to structural changes in a company (Betriebsänderung) or who are threatend by unemployment due to substantial alterations to the establishment. This includes trainees who have succesfully completed their training and are threatend by unemployment due to a restructuring in their company. The following situations are considered to involve substantial alteration: reduction
column2: closure
column3: relocation of establishments or important parts of the company
column4: fusion with other establishments
column5: substantial changes in the operations
column6:
work (processes) and equipment of establishments. Employees who have been affected by these circumstances can be taken on by a transitional employment agency or a transitional company that must have an internal system for quality assessment. It must also guarantee that the measure is financed until its completion. Public employees are exempt from these regulations.

"~"

Two forms exist: the transitional employment agency (Transferagentur) and the transitional company (Transfergesellschaft
column7: Beschäftigungs- und Qualifizierungsgesellschaft). The transitional employment agency tries to place workers who are still employed by their (old) company
column8: but are threatened by unemployment
column9: in a new position outside the company. To this end
column10: it provides career advice
column11: training for job interviews
column12: and job placements. In the second case
column13: a tripartite contract between employer
column14: employee and a provider of a transitional company (Transfergesellschaft or Beschäftigungs- und Qualfizierungsgesellschaft) is concluded. It regulates the transfer of the employee to another company in the same holding or to a service provider. The emloyee becomes employed by the transitional company
column15:
usually for a 12 month period.

\r\n

Outplacement-related services are usually delivered for both instruments. If the worker becomes unemployed
column16: this will be regarded as the automatic result of the fixed-term contract expiring; sanctions against entering unemployment ‘voluntarily’ or ‘prematurely’ (before the end of the notice period) do not apply. Workers receive an assessment of competences/profiling
column17: training
column18:
job search training and placement support.

\r\n

Affected workers are supported by receiving short-time working allowances under certain circumstances (60-67% of their former net wage); these are usually supplemented by the former employer to guarantee net income levels between 75 and 90 % during the transfer period. The maximum period for which transfer-oriented short-time allowances are granted is now 12 months. A foreruner of the allowance was first introduced in 1988. Legislative changes in 2004 led to the transfer-oriented short-time allowance. In January 2011
column19:
further changes concerning the procedure were introduced.

\r\n

Amongst other things
column20: social partners in restructuring companies are now obliged to report on the introduction of transfer measures or the use of the short-time working allowances in advance of their decision. Companies also have to use the advisory service of the local employment agency. This service advises employers on how to balance employer and employees interests when setting up a social plan regulating substantial alterations of an establishment. The advisory service is now mandotory for employers
column21:
if they wish to apply for grants for transfer measures or short-time working allowances in the context of their restructuring.

\r\n

Since 2011
column22: employees are obliged to report to their local employment agency that they are looking for new jobs
column23: before entering a transitional employment agency or transitional company. The new rules explicitly state that
column24: if the transitional short-time working allowance is granted
column25: the employer has to make job proposals to the affected employees. For evaluation purposes
column26: these measures have to be documented by the employer in a so-called 'transfer file'. If employees' skills are deficient
column27: the employer has to offer corresponding training measures. Furthermore
column28: recipients of the transitional short-time working allowances can be qualified by working for a short period for another employer. However
column29:
the hiring out of recipients of the scheme is not allowed.

"~"

In December 2013
column31: 000 people were supported by this scheme. This compares to over 16
column32:
000 persons in January 2013.

\r\n

Evaluations of transitional employment agencies come to different conclusions on their effectiveness:

\r\n

In an evaluation of job transfer schemes (Kirsch et al.
column34: 74% of respondents(survey and follow-up telephone interviews) were not unemployed subsequent to their participation in the schemes. However
column35:
some had gone on to further vocational training or withdrawn from the labour market; only 60% were in new employment or had set up their own business. One quarter of those who were re-employed had moved on to their new job without experiencing any period of unemployment.

\r\n

Another evaluation (Mühge et al.
column36:
2012) shows that 51.4% of respondents were in a job liable to social security contributions after leaving the transitional employment agency. Another 2.3% became self-employed. 42.5% of the respondents were unemployed.

\r\n

Another evaluation (Schneider et al.
column37:
2007) does not find any indication that the job transfer scheme improves employment perspectives of participants considerably more in comparison to offers made by the local employment agencies.

"~"

Advantages for the employee include: no (immediate) unemployment; being able to continue to claim unemployment benefits after the scheme; the fact that benefits received in the framework of the social plan do not reduce unemployment benefits; and gaining a qualification. Advantages for the employer include: avoidance of dismissals and potential legal consequences
column38: namely law suits; the option of dissolving employment relationships more quickly; and a better social image
column39:
which has relevance regarding potential investors.

"~"

This scheme is costly
column40: both for the former employer and the unemployment insurance fund. The PES financially supports transfer services although it does not order these services - this results in weak monitoring and control of the scheme. It is rarely implemented by companies without works council; this means 50% of employees cannot avail of it
column41:
most of whom work for small and medium enterprises (SMEs). No support is provided unless a substantial proportion of employees are negatively affected.

\r\n

Companies do not want to publish information about restructuring at an early stage of the process. This makes it difficult for them to initiate an external consulting process. Workers’ representatives aim to maintain jobs
column42:
so the suggestion to establish a transfer is typically only announced when negotiations fail.

\r\n

Beneficiaries are employees of individual companies
column43: for each company at a different point of time. Hence
column44: there is little possibility of bring together a sufficient number of affected workers to offer differentiated support. In other words
column45: all workers of affected companies will receive the same treatment
column46:
irrespective of their individual needs.

\r\n

Decisions regarding European Social Fund (ESF) and European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) support can come too late
column47: leaving little interest in workers’ reintegration. The importance of maintaining the company's image can have a limited effect
column48:
particularly in cases of insolvency/closure. The division of work between transitional employment agency/transitional company and PES is unclear. The mechanism is complex and difficult to explain to the general public and affected stakeholders. The scheme has little relevance to SMEs due to the bureaucratic and financial expenditures involved.

"~"

Siemens

and Quatro Transfair.

column1:
Voksenlærling~"Adult traineeship"~"Denmark"~"

Coverage extends to persons over 25 years who have been unemployed for more than six months and are without formal education beyond primary school.

"~"

This instrument provides incentives to employers to hire as trainees persons over 25 years who have been unemployed for more than six months. For every trainee hired
column2: the employer gets a wage subsidy of DKK30 per hour
column3:
for up to two years.

"~"

The scheme was quite succesful but in 2008 it was revealed that many of the unemployed participants actually possesed education. The rules were then modified and the scheme was made permanent in 2009.

"~"

It combines employment with the upskilling of adult workers who might have outdated skills.

"~"

Difficulties can be encountered in crisis situations
column4:
as companies have to find ways to finance the training. Companies still prefer to hire young trainees.

"~"

column1:
Casa Socială a Constructorilor~"Builders’ Social House"~"Romania"~"

This is available to companies from construction sector that are members of Builders’ Social House and have contributed with 1.5% of turnover and 1% of the gross base monthly salary of employees to the social protection fund.

"~"

According to Article 3 para. (1) of Law 215/1997 the Builders’ Social House has as main object of activity ensuring protection of employees in branch of construction and building materials production during interruption of work due to adverse weather conditions (November 1 - 31 March). This provides social protection over the coldest period of the year; in this time
column2: even though work does not take place<span id=""result_box"" lang=""en""><span>
column3:
employees keep their jobs and their income is ensured from the funds of the Builders' Social House.

\r\n

It is provided to workers who have an employment contract with the member companies. The monthly social protection benefit is 75% of the average monthly base salary of the prior three months
column4:
and is paid for no more than 90 calendar days.

"~"

In 2009
column5: CASOC had 594 corporate members. Until then
column6: provided social protection measures to over 212
column7:
000 employees.

\r\n

In 2013
column8: 29
column9: 940 persons were granted social protection. For them
column10:
38.22 million lei have been paid as active social protection.
At the end of 2013
column11: total construction workers protected by Builders’ Social House than 366
column12:
000 employees (total compensation from 1998 to 2013 over 243 million lei)

"~"

This supports qualified workers in the sector.

"~"

The funding level is low.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Tewerkstellingcel, Cellule de Reconversion~"Reconversion cells "~"Belgium"~"

This is available in the Walloon region in Belgium. It extends to workers who have been employed by companies that are undergoing restructuring; this includes those on fixed term contracts
column2: temporary workers and those taking early retirement. Employees of a subcontractor who have been dismissed as a result of the economic difficulties of the contracting firm are also eligible. It applies to those employees who lost their job due to a collective lay-off
column3:
when a minimum of 100 workers are affected. It applies to the following sectors: glass manufacturing; air transport; textile and garments; social sector; construction; the health sector; the metal sector; the energy sector; the food sector; mining; and information technologies.

"~"

The cell can be specific to a (large) company or can bring together the victims of separate restructurings from the same area. The beneficiaries receive assistance in dealing with redundancy; this can comprise individual contacts and meetings with employment advisers who specialise in redeployment
column4: ongoing psychological support
column5: and assistance in social and administrative affairs. They are also supported in developing their CV
column6: in securing professional references
column7: and accessing information on the job market and in finding a new job. They are also assisted in accessing vocational or reconversion training courses; this includes identifying relevant training and information about the training market
column8:
and assistance accessing training funding.

\r\n

Before assistance is provided
column9: the beneficiaries sign a socio-professional contract. In doing so
column10: they commit to being actively involved in the programme. In return
column11:
they receive an allowance. The establishment of the cell is carried out at the request of the workers’ representatives and can last one or two years.

"~"

Between 2005 and 2009
column12: the number of cells ranged between 20 and 40 approximately
column13: and the number of beneficiaries varied between 1
column14: 000 and 3
column15: 000 each year.  The programme has a high reintegration rate - more than 50% of beneficiaries are in employment again
column16:
with a high percentage of open-ended contracts. The social partners perceive it to be a very effective tool.

"~"

A personalised psychological follow-up support is provided to people who are the victims of restructuring. A collective spirit is retained
column17: encouraging emulation
column18: and avoiding isolation
column19: the shock of dismissal and the erosion of social ties. The involvement of unions in the cells appears to be an important factor in their success. A decree
column20: introduced by Wallonia
column21: recognises the people registered with the cells as vocational trainees (stagiaires de formation professionnelles). This entitles people to the following benefits: training allowance
column22: travel allowance
column23: professional insurance and help with childcare costs. Finally
column24: intervention is provided rapidly
column25:
at local level.

"~"

The programme could be adapted to better anticipate restructuring; for example
column26:
a cel could be established when restructuring is announced and not when people are actually laid off. Deciding whether or not to attend a training course means postponing a return to work; this is often a difficult decision for workers whose primary motivation is that of gaining employment.

"~"

Klaverbel
column27: ARTLAINE
column28:
and Volkswagen.

column1:
Fonds Social ~"Social intervention fund"~"Belgium"~"

Coverage extends to the Flanders area. It  relates to the outplacement of business directors who are bankrupt and want to become employees
column2:
as well as redundant workers who worked for the company up until a year before bankruptcy.

"~"

This instrument finances the outplacement of business directors who are bankrupt and want to become employees
column3: as well as redundant workers who worked for the company up until a year before bankruptcy. Applications can be made by the bankruptcy trustee who was named by the commissioner in the judicial agreement
column4:
or the employer in difficulty himself; the latter is mandatory if approached by a worker representative. The outplacement programme is managed by a private provider accredited by the regional government. The fund also coordinates the special reemployment units (set up by the companies under restructuration) or the 12 permanent special reemployment units responsible for the accompaniment of small companies under restructuration.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The aims of social fund extend beyond funding outplacement in case of restructuring. Those sectoral funds offer many other benefits
column5: such as training. In the case of restructuring
column6: its main strength is that the redundant workers are not alone in facing the situation
column7:
as they are sustained by an official institution.

column1:
Cellule pour l'emploi~"Re-employment units"~"Belgium"~"

This is available to workers aged over 45 years who have been made redundant by a company declared to be restructuring. They must have worked in this company for a  minimum period of one year. The cells must be set up by businesses with more than 20 workers that have announced their intention to carry out a collective layoff.

"~"

Businesses (with at least 20 employees) are obliged to set up a special re-employment unit or in certain conditions
column2: to contribute to a special re-employment unit or a regional special re-employment unit
column3: of a reconversion cell type. In setting up a unit
column4: the employer guarantees outplacement for all its workers who are affected by the layoff. The employer is committed to paying a reclassification allowance
column5: for a period of three months for workers aged under 45 years or six months for those aged over 45 years. This allowance replaces the advance notice indemnity and is the equivalent of the current salary plus the extra-legal advantages. It apllies to all affected workers who have worked in the company for a minimum period of one year. Measures have been put into force to compensate these companies in setting up these employment cells
column7: comprising €1
column8:
800 per laid-off worker.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

These cells sustain redundant workers
column9: which is important in the case of resturcturing
column10:
especially regarding workers who are most vulnerable to unemployment.

column1:
Frauen in Handwerk und Technik (FIT)~"Women in crafts and technical occupations (FIT)"~"Austria"~"

Coverage extends to unemployed women and women reentering the labour market after career breaks
column2:
taken for reasons such as childcare commitments. Participants must be interested in receiving training and being employed afterwards in technical occupations.

"~"

Women receive training in 'non-traditional occupations' - this term refers to technical and male-oriented occupations that are not traditionally associated with women. At the same time
column3: support is provided for companies that need skilled workers in technical occupations
column4: through the provision of training. The length of the measure is dependent on the qualification chosen (e.g. apprenticeship training
column5: studies at universities of applied sciences). During participation in the programme
column6:
a benefit corresponding to the (individual) fictional unemployment benefit plus allowances in order to cover living expenses and allowances for course costs are provided.

"~"

In 2013
column7: over 7
column8: 300 women were funded in this programme
column9: resulting in costs of over €23 million which corresponds (on average) to about €3
column10: 254 per person (Sozialministerium
column11: 2014). A recent study conducted by FORBA for the Public Employment Service (AMS) shows that 55% of recent participants in the programme have become employed within three months after having finished the training measure (observation period July 2011-December 2012). The share increases to 70% after six months and 81% after twelve months (AMS
column12:
2014).

"~"

This measure aims to reduce the wage gap between men and women. It provides companies with skilled employees.

"~"

Strong cultural and social stereotypical views of women make it difficult for the Public Employment Service (AMS) to convince women to take on such jobs.

"~"

column1:
Kündigung mit Wiedereinstellungszusage~"Temporary suspension of employment and reemployment commitments"~"Austria"~"

In theory
column2: this is available to all employees except for civil servants. In practice
column3: it tends to apply to sectors that involve seasonal work
column4:
such as tourism and construction.

"~"

An employment relationship is terminated
column5: either by mutual agreement or by dismissal through the employer
column6: but the employer commits to reemploy the employee at a later point in time. During the period of unemployment
column7: the employee can receive unemployment benefits. That means
column8: however
column9: that they might be placed in a different job by the Public Employment Service (AMS). If reemployment is promised within a six week period
column10: employees are exempt from being given placements by the AMS. The reemployment commitment is legally binding. If it is not kept
column11:
compensation for termination of employment (just like in cases of unjustified dismissals) applies.

"~"

In May 2009
column12: the number of workers who benefitted from this scheme (over 3
column13: 500) had increased by almost 50% since May 2008. In July 2009
column14: the number of affected unemployed persons represented an 18% increase from July 2008
column15: involving 26
column16:
325 concerned workers. No more recent data on reemployment commitments in the following years are available.

"~"

This scheme is easy to implement
column17:
and is cost-efficient at company level.

"~"

From a macro-economic perspective
column18: it is not a very sound model as it does not ensure that non-worked time is used effectively
column19: either regarding the employee's qualification or structural change of the company. Moreover
column20:
there is no real obligation to reemploy the worker. The company cannot promise additional payment/bonus when work is taken up again and the unemployed period is not perceived as constituting 'real unemployment'. The employee also experiences a reduction of income due to receipt of unemployment benefits instead of regular income.

"~"

Kaufmann Holz.

column1:
Groupements d'employeurs~"Employer groups"~"France"~"

This applies to specific regions and sectors.

"~"

Several employers (private or public) collectively found a 'groupement d'employeurs'; this employs workers that are sent to work in the member companies as needed. Workers are recruited
column2: based on the outcome of an assessment regarding the number of hours required by of each member company for that position. Member companies must guarantee these hours and cover payment for them. In general
column3: each employee works on 2-4 projects every year
column4: either on a seasonal or ongoing basis; for example
column5:
they may work every working day or every second week in the same company.

\r\n

A collective agreement codifies the fundamental conditions and procedures of temporary staff transfers and the rights of the workers affected. Contractual relations with the employer remain intact
column6: and wages continue to be paid; next to the provision of workers the employer group might provide other services to the member companies
column7: such as organising training
column8: recruiting (also core staff in the individual member companies)
column9:
administration of the core staff in the member companies.

\r\n

Two distinct systems coexist: Employer Pool for Integration and Qualification (GE-IQ) which imposes both the profile of the shared people and training programmes (with a public financial assistance in compensation); classic Employer Pool without these obligations or any public help

"~"

In 2014
column10: there are about 4
column11: 000 agricultural employer groups with about 19
column12: 000 employees. There are 400 employer groups with about 1
column13:
000 employees in other industries.

"~"

This model provides the participating firms with an additional instrument for managing cyclical and seasonal variations in demand. It has also expanded into collective activities among the companies involved
column14: and the exchange of experience in fields such as human resource development
column15: information and communications technology (ICT)
column16:
and supply and logistics. It provides the workers with employment security.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Charentes Innov'emplois (Pons/Poitou-charentes) with 35 employees and 25 companies (mainly food manufacturing and metal); Mode d'Emploi in Châtellerault (Poitou-Charentes) with 90 employees and 37 companies (mainly food manufacturing)
column17: Forval (Beaufort den Vallée
column18: Pays de la Loire) with 100 employees and eight companies (agriculture
column19: forestry
column20:
wood/furniture manufacturing); and Adequat (Niort) with 100 employees and 250 companies (mainly craft and construction).

column1:
Гаранционен фонд за микрокредитиране~"Micro-credit Guarantee Fund"~"Bulgaria"~"

This is available to those in the following categories who cannot meet the requirements of their bank: small and medium enterprises (SMEs)
column2: unemployed people
column3: people working in the crafts sector
column4:
cooperatives and agricultural producers.

"~"

Under Decision № 309 of 3 May 2007
column5: the Council of Ministers and the Law on Bulgarian Development Bank (promulgated SG 43 of 29 April 2008) the project managed by the MLSP 'Micro-credit Guarantee Fund' has been transferred to National Guarantee Fund
column6: owned by Bulgarian Development Bank<a href=""http://www.google.bg/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&ved=0CB8QFjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.milkbg.org%2Flanguage%2Fbg%2Fuploads%2Ffiles%2Fusefull__1%2Fusefull__a48b335f15584360681e30cb370c69f8.doc&ei=JpfDU5vIK4qAywP274CwAg&usg=AFQjCNGrZKlfdG5ZczsL_ptGRqI1qieyCg&sig2=6rNfZxqY2y0esImnZJi63A&bvm=bv.70810081
column7:
d.bGQ&cad=rja""> for administering and managing.

\r\n

Loans are easily accessed and provided quickly
column8: of up to 50
column9: 000 BGN (€25
column10: 000). Loans for start-up businesses can be given for up to 100% of costs
column11: while existing businesses are given loans of up to 70% of their costs. The maximum period of a loan is seven years. A monetary guarantee of the credit is provided
column12: with preferential conditions - the fund offers the lowest rates of interest in the country
column13: as well as long-term investment credits
column14:
and loans involve lower collateral requirements. A free consultancy service is provided for all applications.

\r\n

When a loan of up to €12
column15: 500 of credit is given
column16: at least one permanent job position should be created. For loans of over €12
column18: at least two permanent jobs must be set up. One of these jobs should be created within six months
column19:
and the remaining jobs should be in place within 12 months.

"~"

According to the official data available from the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy
column20: as of 15 October 2008 about 12
column21: 200 applications had been made. Of these
column23: 361 were approved
column24: leading to the creation of about 18
column25:
500 new jobs. The total value of the loans provided is more than BGN 164 million (about €84 million). These data relate to the period 2001 (when the project began) to 2008.

\r\n

According to the Annual Report of the National Gurantee Fund (NGF) at 31 December 2012 the total credit portfolio included 1
column26: 813 micro-credits at the total amount of BGN 16
column27: 697 million BGN (€8
column29:
040).

"~"

This gives access to funding for companies that have short business histories
column31:
but which have strong potential. It provides a more efficient loan process and more favourable lending conditions.

"~"

No information available.

"~"
