column1:
Fondi paritetici interprofessionali per la formazione continua~"Vocational training paritarian institutions"~"Italy"~"

Vocational training paritarian institutions (hereinafter also ‘Fondi interprofessionali’) is applicable to economic sectors (e.g. agriculture
column2: manufacturing
column3: tertiary and handicraft)
column4:
as well as different sectors at the same time or specific occupations (e.g. managers).

"~"

In accordance with Law No. 388/00
column5:
vocational training paritarian institutions are established by two different steps:
\r\n
    \r\n
  • A collective agreement signed by social partners
column6:
which have to indicate the purpose and also draft the statute and the internal regulation code of the ‘Fondo interprofessionale’;
  • Authorisation from the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs. 
    • According to the provisions of the mentioned law
column7: employers can allocate 0.30% of the social security contributions to workforce training to the National Institute of Social Security (Istituto Nazionale della Sicurezza Sociale
column8: INPS) or to the selected ‘Fondo interprofessionale’. Employers can enrol in any authorised ‘Fondo interprofessionale’
column9:
regardless of the specific economic sector. Employers that do not enrol in any ‘Fondo interprofessionale’ must allocate 0.30% to INPS.
‘Fondi interprofessionali’ finance company
column10: territorial
column11: sectoral or individual training plans
column12:
bargained between the social partners. These plans are sent to the competent regional government that may take them in consideration as part of its planning.
As of 2013
column13:
‘Fondi interprofessionali’ can also provide special unemployment benefits to workers within a vocational training programme.

"~"

According to the XIV Report on Vocational Training provided by ISFOL (2013)
column14:
at the end of 2012 there were 15 vocational training paritarian institutions.
During 2013
column15: the number of employers that joined ‘Fondi interprofessionali’ increased by 13%
column16: compared to 2012
column17: while the number of employees increased only by 8%
column18:
due to the fact that mostly SMEs joined vocational training paritarian institutions.
With regard to the training plans approved
column19: nearly half of them (43.8%) concern the maintenance/upgrading of skills
column20:
followed by the competitiveness of enterprise/innovation (27.3%) and by mandatory training (12.7%).

"~"

Vocational training paritarian institutions directly involve social partners. They have positive influence on the Continuous Vocational Training (CVT) system.

"~"

The main difficulty consists in coordinating the intervention of ‘Fondi interprofessionali’ when it complements that of public institutions
column21: since only five Regions implemented a real integration among them. In addition
column22:
the share of firms and employees contributing to ‘Fondi interprofessionali’ greatly varies across sectors and regions: there is the risk that only employers located in rich regions with a strong interest in vocational training might make use of the available resources. Some ‘Fondi interprofessionali’ are not particularly able to integrate groups of micro and small enterprises in each training plan.

"~"

Fondimpresa; Fondirigenti; Fondartigianato.

column1:
Sector Skills Councils~"Sector Skills Councils"~"United Kingdom"~"

Sector Skills Councils (SSCs) are indepenent
column2:
employer-led organisations which seek to build a skills system that is driven by employer demand. SSCs apply to specific economic sectors. The are 19 Sector Skills Councils (SSCs) with the following industry coverage:

 

  • Building Futures Group - Facilities Managment
column3: Housing
column4: Property
column5:
Cleaning and Parking;\r\n
  • Cogent - Nuclear
column6: Chemicals
column7: Polymers
column8: Petroleum
column9:
Life Sciences and Pharmaceuticals;\r\n
  • ConstructionSkills - Construction;
    • \r\n
  • Creative and Cultural Skills - Craft
column10: Cultural Heritage
column11: Design
column12: Jewellery
column13: Literature
column14: Music
column15:
Performing Arts and Visual Arts;\r\n
  • Creative Skillset: TV
column16: Film
column17: Radio
column18: Interactive Media
column19: Animation
column20: Computer Games
column21: Facilities
column22: Photo Imaging; Publishing
column23:
Advertising and Fashion and Textiles;\r\n
  • Energy and Utility Skills (EU Skills): Gas
column24: Power
column25:
Waste Management and Water Industries;\r\n
  • e-skills UK: Business and Information Technology;
    • \r\n
  • Financial Skills Partnership - Finance
column26:
Accountancy and Financial Services;
  • Improve: Food and Drink Manufacturing and Associated Supply Chaines;
  • Institute of the Motor Industry: Retail Motor Industry;
  • Lantra: Land Management and Production
column27:
Animal Health and Welfare and Environmental Industries;\r\n
  • People 1st: Hospitality
column29: Passenger Transport
column31:
Engineering and Manufacturing Technologies;\r\n
  • Skills for Care and Development: Social Care
column33:
Early Years and Young People's Workforces in the UK;\r\n
  • Skills for Health: UK Health;
    • \r\n
  • Skills for Justice: Community Justice
column36: Fire and Rescue
column37: Forensic Science
column38:
Policing and Law Enforcement and Prosecution Services;\r\n
  • Skills for Logistics: Freight Logistics and Wholesaling Industry;
    • \r\n
  • SkillsActive: Sport
column40: Outdoors
column42:
Caravans and Hair and Beauty;
  • SummitSkills: Building Services Engineering.
    • In addition
column43:
there are 4 Sector Skills Bodies (SSBs) with the following coverage:
  • ECITB: Engineering Construction;
  • Proskills: Printing
column45: health and safety and process and manufacturing of furniture
column48:
coatings and paper;\r\n
  • SkillsCFA: Business and Administration
column54:
marketing and sales; and
  • Skills for Security: Security.

    •  

    "~"

    Sector Skills Councils (SSCs)  have four key goals: to reduce skills gaps and shortages; to improve productivity
column55: business and public service performance; to increase opportunities to boost the skills and productivity of everyone in the sector's workforce; and to improve learning supply through National Occupational Standards
column57:
and further and higher education. Each SSC agrees sector priorities and targets with its employers and partners to address five key goals: identify and articular the sector's skills needs; help develop more responsive provision to meet business needs; provide the business case for skills; engage employers in skill development; and influence skill policy. Activities involve: analysing the skills and qualifications that both employers and employees want; establishing the content of qualifications; forecasting future skills required within the sector; contributing to the development of National Occupational Standards; the design and approval of apprenticeship frameworks; brokering sector skills agreements and creating sector qualification strategies.

"~"

There are 19 Sector Skills Councils and 4 sector skilsl bodies based across all sectors of the UK economy
column58:
representing 80% of the workforce in the UK. The SSCs and Skills bodies come under the umbrella of the Federation for Industry Skills & Standards.

"~"

SSCs work with over 550
column59: 000 UK employers. A joint approach is taken
column60: involving a range of stakeholders; these include employers
column61: trade unions and training providers. A holistic approach is taken towards training
column62:
which includies link trainees to the workplace. Funding is provided by government.

"~"

There is no legal requirement for employers to train and there is a lack of awareness among employers about SSCs. Furthermore
column63: not all industry sectors are covered by SSCs. In addition
column64: accessibility to SSCs tend to be lower amongst SMEs than among larger firms. The results of a 2009 survey by FSB
column66: revealed that: 71% of the respondents had never heard of SSCs; 90% did not know which SSC was related to their business; among those who knew about SSC
column67:
only 10% felt that the Councils' programmes were responsive to the needs of micro and small businesses. 

"~"

The Financial Skills Partnership (FLSP) supports skill development in the UK's financial
column68:
accountancy and financial services.

column1:
Weiterbildung Geringqualifizierter und beschäftigter älterer Arbeitnehmer im Unternehmen (WeGebAU)~"Training of low-skilled workers and older employees in companies"~"Germany"~"

Measure is available to older employees (45 years and above) and low-skilled workers. The programme has also been opened up to younger employees.

"~"

\r\n
column2:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi; mso-fareast-language:EN-US;} -->

\r\n

In addition to providing training for low-skilled workers the programme tries to improve and update the skills of older employees
column3: reflecting the changing needs of the job market. WeGebAU includes a particular instrument for older workers (45 years and older) from companies with less than 250 employees (small and medium enterprises
column4: SMEs). However
column5: support for younger workers is also possible. Employers may receive financial assistance for training for workers while on training. The range of qualification and training measures is broad and varies according to the needs of each employee
column6: ranging from a short-term workshop to an entire apprenticeship programme. Low skilled workers are assisted in gaining a job qualification certificate. In SMEs
column7: training fees are covered by 75 % for older workers (those aged 45 years and over). Until the end of 2014
column8:
fees are covered by 50 % for employees aged younger than 45 years. In certain circumstances their subsistence costs are covered as well.

\r\n

 

"~"

\r\n
column9:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi; mso-fareast-language:EN-US;} -->

\r\n

In 2007
column11: 100 new cases were approved for qualification and training measures. Since then
column12: the numbers have increased significantly
column13: with 61
column15: 890 new cases in 2008 and 2009. Recently
column16: numbers of new cases decreased (19
column17: 184 in 2013). As an analysis from 2010 shows
column18: 35% of establishments were aware of all training support measures offered by the local employment agency in 2008. Out of those being familiar with the programme for low-skilled and older workers
column19:
23% had actually used the subsidy.

\r\n

 

"~"

A wide range of qualification and training measures are provided
column20:
varying according to individual needs. SME specific problems and barriers for training are addressed.

"~"

Large companies have only recently shown interest in the financial support for qualifications and training measures offered by the programme. In the past
column21: large companies rarely applied for WeGebAU funding
column22: criticising the administrative burden involved. However
column23:
an IAB analysis shows that 24% of establishments with 250 or more employees used parts of the programme in 2006. It was also found that this category of companies had become more familiar with all the regulations of the programme in 2006.

"~"

column1:
Union learning representatives (ULRs)~"Union learning representatives (ULRs)"~"United Kingdom"~"

Training is available to union members.

"~"

Union Learning Representatives (ULRs) were granted statutory rights in 2003 by UK-wide legislation. Employers must enable ULRs to have reasonable paid time to undertake their duties.  The key functions of ULRs within workplaces are set out in the Employment Act 2002 are: analysing learning and training needs; providing information and advice to employees (and sometimes employers) abut learning or training matters; arranging and supporting learning and training; consulting with the employers about these activities. The key aim is to raise awareness of learning and training opportunities amongst employees and facilitate take-up of these opportunities where practicable. Typically ULRs will negotiate with employers to achieve these aims. In workplaces in which the relevant union is recognised
column2: union members are entitled to unpaid time off work to consult their ULR. The TUC coordinates ULRs for Great Britain (i.e. England
column3:
Scotland and Wales). Northern Ireland has a similar yet separate scheme for union-led learning.

"~"

There are now over 23
column4: 000 ULRs in Great Britain. Under the Employment Act 2002
column5: ULRs must be trained sufficiently to carry out their duties and they have a statutory right to paid time off work to undertake this training. Most ULRs are located in the public sector. ULRs are more active in larger organisations (>249 employees)
column6: though activity rates are increasing generally amongst ULRs. Most hold other union posts
column7: though over a third are new activists in their union. These new activists are more likely to be female and younger than existing activists. ULRs are very effective at bottom-up champions of learning within workplaces. They both meet existing demand and stimulate that demand. ULRs increase the likelihood that employees receive training and also increase the incidence (or number of days) of training within workplaces. In surveys
column8: female ULRs report higher levels of impact. Almost all ULRs report have provided information and advice
column9: over three-quarters report having arranged or helped to arrange learning or training courses for employees
column10: and over half have conducted a learning needs assessment in their workplace. Almost half have also helped employees access funding for training. In terms of the type of learning over half ULRs report stimulating training leading to qualifications as well as basic literacy and numeracy courses
column11: and course that both lead to personal as well as professional development for employees. In surveys
column12:
half of managers report that ULRs have impacted employer-funded or non-employer funded training in their companies. ULRs effectiveness is greater in workplaces that have supportive management and where negotiations occur between unions and management over learning and training. The existence of workplace learning agreements and partnerships also boost ULR effectiveness.

"~"

From the employee perspective
column13: ULRs represent a source of up-to-date expert advice and information that may be familiar
column14: trusted and confidential; is trained and independent; and willing to be an advocate for their learning and training needs. That learning and training can also relate not just to professional but also personal development – the latter being a key trigger for enragement particularly amongst non-traditional learners. ULRs undertake their functions during working hours and so are
column15: in addition
column16: available to employees; an important issue for shift workers for example. From a union perspective
column17: offering a learning service helps unions engage with all employees
column18: not just union members. There is evidence that
column19: through learning
column20: ULRs can help increase rates of union membership within workplaces. For employers
column21: ULRs offer a source of expert advice which is inexpensive and can help identify learning and employee training needs and encourage a learning culture within the company. As intended at their establishment
column22: ULRs have a frontline role in delivering successive UK governments’ policies aimed at boosting learning capacity
column23:
and skill and qualification acquisition amongst the workforce.

"~"

Most ULRs are located in public sector and larger organisation
column24: neither of which provides the bulk of employment in the UK. Gaining presence in private sector SMEs is particularly challenging. Typically ULRs spend more time undertaking their functions than is accredited by their employer
column25: leading to unpaid time off work. There is mixed evidence from across the UK as to whether the ULR role combined with other union representative roles leads to work overload for ULRs
column26: making them less effective. It should also be noted that the current UK Government has not extended employees’ right to request time to train in smaller companies (that is
column27: those with fewer than 250 employees) as intended by the last government. The implication is that ULRs could do more to help boost learning and training if given the extended scope. From the employer perspective
column29: costs are incurred with ULRs having paid time off work for training and to fulfil their statutory functions. Whilst the ULR role is now included in unions’ rule books
column30: there is still some debate within unions about how much emphasis should be placed on their role when there is internal competition within unions for resources. Whilst employers benefit from having ULRs in their companies
column31: they are not obliged to negotiate with unions over learning and training
column32: though only just over a third of ULRs report that management does not negotiate and only a third does not consult. However less than half of ULRs report that senior management value their activities and only one-third report managements generally value their activities. This last point is significant
column33:
given that ULRs are more effective with supportive management.

"~"

column1:
Arbetstagarkonsult~"Labour consultant"~"Sweden"~"

This is used in response to changes that have a considerable impact on the economy and employment of the company. It is available to companies with more than 50 employees.

"~"

The use of a labour consultant is regulated in an agreement from 1982 between Swedish confederation of Enterprises and the confederation of unions; LO and TCO. The possibility to use a labour consultant is primarily used by union representatives (works councils) at company level to analyse the consequences of a proposed restructuring and to look into alternative strategies or change proposals. From a management perspective it is a way of getting a second opinion on the proposed change but also to check that ample measures are taken in connection with the restructuring. Activities conducted include: going through relevant economic and company background material important for the change decision – from auditing and annual reports to cost estimates
column2: internal result reports and strategic documents on markets
column3: products and technology; interviewing managers
column4: middle managers and employees in the concerned part of the company; looking into market aspects and seeking information outside of the company; and analysing the proposal and its effects on the business
column5: employment and working conditions; proposing alternative strategies
column6:
including change process and redeployment measures. The consultant can be either an external or an internal expert.

"~"

The framework of labour consultants is more than 30 years old. Due to globalisation
column7: the labour market has fundamentally changed during this time frame. This requires higher skills from the union representatives when hiring a labour consultant. However
column8:
a report shows that half of the assignments lead to some kind of change – smaller or larger – in the way the was restructuring originally planned.

"~"

Union representatives can benefit by getting greater knowledge on restructuring and its implications. It also leads to greater understanding among the employees.

"~"

A labour consultant is only approached after the announcement of the restructuring
column9:
which might be too late. The employer and the union must agree on the scope of the assignment. The right to hire a Labour Consultant is restricted in the agreement to companies with more than 50 employees.

"~"

The closure of tire manufacturer Continetal in Gislaved decribed in LO 2003.

column1:
Experts auprès des Comités d'entreprise ~"Work council expert (labour consultant)"~"France"~"

This relates to all companies with a works council
column2:
namely all those employing 50 or more workers.

"~"

The works council can appoint an expert for two types of missions: 

 

  • legal missions (funded by the employer) 
  • contractual missions (funded by the works council's operating budget)

 

Legal missions mainly include the annual statement of account
column3:
the alert procedure and assistance in the economic layoffs procedure. 

\r\n

In the 'alert procedure'
column4: the expert’s role is not to issue a report but to bring to light relevant elements and pieces of information
column5:
with a view to helping the works council to compile its own report.

\r\n

In the case of a restructuring project implying collective redundancies
column6: the works council has the right to appoint an expert at the first official meeting of the procedure. Once he is appointed
column7: the expert has 10 days to ask the employer for any necessary documents. The employer then has 8 days to hand them over. The expert has to submit his report 15 days before the end of the deadline (depending on the number of dismissals expected). The expert's role is to analyse the economic reasons for the dismissals
column8: to make alternative proposals
column9: to improve the measures proposed in the social plan
column10:
to give his opinion about the probability of the company's failure. 

"~"

External experts were used in a minority of cases (27% of the redundancy plans
column11:
or PSE) because the costs are supported by the enterprises and can be taken from the budget devoted to the severance payments (DARES).

"~"

This allows companies to react in a proactive way. It contributes to a better mutual understanding between the employer and unions. It facilitates the preparation of negotiations regarding severance payments. If the case is subject to trial
column12:
the report written by the expert can lead to a cancellation of the redundancy plan if the judge considers it to be irrelevant or insufficiently justified.

"~"

It is persistently difficult for the workers' representatives to act before the announcement of the restructuring project by the management
column13: and limited time is available once the announcement has been made. The works council
column14: supported by its expert
column15:
can make suggestions but the company is not obliged to act on them.

"~"

column1:
Flexpool~"Flexpool"~"Netherlands"~"

This is available to members.

"~"

A flexpool comprises several employers who are based in the same area and are looking for the same types of skills. Unemployed workers are hired by the Flexpool organisation. They are then trained and sent to participating companies during their busiest periods of activity. Dutch legislation requires the management of each flexpool to offer open-ended contracts to the workers who have been involved in the system for 72 weeks.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This mechanism is designed to regulate and secure employment in the sectors concerned
column2: while at the same time responding to companies’ flexibility constraints. For companies
column3: it permits the combination of flexibility and a secure supply of qualified workers
column4: while the pool’s workers benefit from job and income security
column5: as well as professional training. It allows participating companies to compensate for seasonal and unpredictable fluctuations in production demand and limit the costs inherent in recruiting temporary staff. It offers the pool’s workers a qualified and stable job
column6:
thus allowing them to benefit from an appropriate and predictable income.

"~"

There is a risk of differentiation in terms of status and salary
column7: between pool workers
column8: the user company’s permanent staff and the temporary workers recruited outside the pool structure. There is also a risk of lower investment on the part of user companies
column9: regarding on-the-job training of pooled workers. A low level of 'sideways mobility' occurs for pool workers
column10: towards a permanent position within one of the participating companies. The type of work provided is not suited to all job seekers
column11: insofar as it assumes flexibility
column12:
versatility and the capacity to adapt.  A low level of responsibility is demanded of the participating companies in the management of the pool; this is likely to increase the administrative requirements  of the system and to hinder its development and continuity.

"~"

column1:
Groupement d'entreprises~"Labour pool"~"Belgium"~"

The creation of an employer group is open to any natural person or legal entity
column2: under public or private law
column3:
on condition that it meets certain criteria: it must involved at least two entities who have a business activity; no banks can take part; incorporate participation in the group in the purpose of the company and sign an act of constitution

"~"

A labour pool is a separate legal entity established by several companies. It hires workers who are then made available to the partner companies. A labour pool can only hire long-term unemployed workers with low skills
column4:
who are recipients of the minimum subsistence allowance or social financial aid. Employees must be hired on full-time unlimited term contracts.

\r\n

According to the contract binding the members
column5: workers are hired and shared by member companies. In times of both reduced and increased need for labour
column6: bilateral agreements are established among member companies regarding the use of the workers. The labour pool must be a non-profit organisation with its sole objective being the sharing of workers who are employed on full-time
column7:
open-ended contract. Members must be held jointly liable for its funding (while no capital is being paid into the constitution of the company).

\r\n

A labour pool can be in existence for five years at most. Employer groups are entitled to an integration allowance equivalent to a maximum of €500 per month. This continues to be paid by the bodies responsible for making payments for unemployment benefits and that they can therefore deduct from the wage they pay their employees.

\r\n

They are also entitled to an annual sliding scale reduction in social contributions. The group is administered by a board of directors appointed by the general meeting. Each company has an identical voting right and in general
column8:
decisions are taken by consensus.

"~"

Four organisations are involved in the labour pool
column9:
representing about 30 workers.

"~"

The following strengths apply this scheme:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • greater flexibility
column10:
allowing for volatility regarding company activity;\r\n
  • it allows companies to restructure their organisation without having to lay off staff;
    • \r\n
  • a higher level of job security for workers
column11:
due to indefinite contracts;\r\n
  • loyalty is built up among staff
column12: which in turn provides a certain level of stability for the user company
column13:
as the loss of good quality work and knowledge is avoided;\r\n
  • the closeness that comes about as part of an employer group often creates various types of collaboration among members that goes beyond the strict framework of sharing workers (examples include joint initiatives for external publicity and advertising
column14:
grouped purchases or the exchange of good practices);\r\n
  • hourly cost of the worker is a net cost;
    • \r\n
  • the administrative burden is reduced for each individual company
column15:
as it is taken on as a collective responsibility;
  • it is easy to replace a worker who is ill or absent;
  • the employer group organises the training of workers based on the needs of the companies involved;
  • the pool of workers formed in this way constitutes a potential reserve for more long-term recruitment;
  • although they work in a number of different companies
column16: the workers involved have a single employer
column17:
which makes negotiation easier and increases transparency in terms of responsibility.\r\n"~"

In practice
column18: the temporary transfer of workers remains reliant on the willingness of other participating companies to increase their use of shared workers. This is the case even though the collective requiremen for a concerned workers needs were supposed to remain stable. The process of creating a labour pools requires at least three months (and often more)
column19: in order to find partners
column20: to define the status of the pool and to secure agreement from the authorities. Constraints are associated with the target group - those involved in restructuring are still in employment and therefore do not fall within the legally defined target audience. It may be the case that the remuneration of these workers differs to that regarding permanent staff. Finally
column21:
the scheme is only possible to the degree that the time periods for which participating companies need certain workers are complementary.

"~"

Hommex

B4M Company.

column1:
Outplacement et cellule pour l'emploi~"Outplacement and employment cells units"~"Belgium"~"

This is available Flanders
column2: to enterprises
column3: with at least 20 employees
column4:
that have announced a collective dismissal.

"~"

Enterprises with at least 20 employees announcing a collective dismissal are obliged to create an 'outplacement unit. Supportive services and recommendations are carried out by a third party (the outplacement office or outplacementkantoren). Services provided include: emotional support for the redundant employee who receives counselling to cope with the redundancy; logistical support with the search for a new job which covers secretarial work; and personal support from a consultant who will guide the job seeker through the various stages in the search for a new job. The process involves three steps. Firstly
column5: an assessment is made of the job seeker’s strengths and weaknesses; as a result. Following this
column6: a career plan can be mapped out. Secondly
column7: the job market is approached. Here
column8: selected jobs reflect the career plan mapped out at the previous stage. Potential employers are approached
column9: and a communication strategy is designed to that effect.  Thirdly
column10: an evaluation of job offers is carried out. Help is provided in negotiating working conditions with employers
column11:
and support is given during the placement and integration into the new work environment.

\r\n

Support is provided for a maximum of 60 hours (divided in three phases of 20 hours each)
column12: over one year at most. It leads to a reduction of social security contributions for both the employers and employees. In cases of successful outplacements - those that lead to a job - the outplacement costs will be reimbursed at a higher rate. Incentives have been put into place to encourage companies to set up these employment units - they receive €1
column13:
800 per laid-off worker.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The training offers workers a wealth of new opportunities.

"~"

Time pressure can occur in cases of mass redundancies.

"~"

column1:
Industriens Kompetenceudviklingsfond~"Competence Development Funds"~"Denmark"~"

This is available to employees with nine months experience in the company concerned. Once a company (through its representatives) agrees to the collective agreement regulating the training fund
column2:
it is obliged to contribute to the funds.

"~"

An education course may be taken at the request of the enterprise or as part of an education plan made in the enterprise. Employees with nine months experience in the company are entitled to full pay (often for two weeks per year). The companies involved pay the salary and training fees. In addition
column3: the individual employee is entitled to participate in an individual clarification of competences course. Collective agreements provide for the establishment of a Competence Development Fund for Industry
column4: to which employers will contribute €35 per employee per week
column5:
increasing to €70 over the agreement period. These funds will be used to finance the employees' wages while they complete two weeks of training.

"~"

Generally
column6:
this is well perceived by social partners. Some complaints have been made that the scheme is too bureaucratic. Funds have dried up quickly in crisis situations.

"~"

The scheme grants workers with rights to upskilling; they both strengthen internal and external functional flexibility and mobility. It plays an important role in bringing social partners closer together on CVET-related issues.

"~"

The scheme has been criticised for being too bureaucratic.

"~"

column1:
SKILLNETS~"SKILLNETS"~"Ireland"~"

individual sectors

"~"

Skillnets conceive and deliver training programmes across a broad range of sectors nationwide. In each Skillnet
column2: three or more enterprises cooperate to carry out a training project that individual companies would be unable to undertake alone. Each network is designed to specific industry needs and delivers training
column3: upskilling and professional development programmes.There are 4 main strategic pillars: PILLAR 1 - Driving Skills Strategies through Sectors and Partnerships (partnerships for training between employees and enterprise
column4: enterprises and enterprises
column5: and between enterprises and others engaged in the world of learning); PILLAR 2 - Growing the Skills Base (LLL by supporting training networks focused on workers with low basic skills
column6: those at risk of becoming unemployed in areas of the economy encountering rapid change
column7: workers in declining sectors
column8: non-national employees
column9: part-time
column10: female and older workers
column11: in SMEs and micro enterprises
column12: helping workers to adapt to technological change and respond effectively to the challenges of the knowledge economy); PILLAR 3 – Developing Local Learning Responses (training networks with a local or regional focus); PILLAR 4 – Growing the Skills Base (develop
column13: transfer and promote best training and development practice across enterprises). The Skillnets approach is built around training networks (which are called 'Skillnets') where companies get together to decide what training they want
column14:
how it will be delivered and who will deliver it.

"~"

uptake of training within 43
column15: 000 companies; over 200
column16:
000 employees have benefited from Skillnets training; The 2008 Skillnets figures show that SME’s accounted for 95% of the total number of companies funded with 63% of the total number of companies being micro companies (<9 employees). 13% of all trainees were owner-managers.

"~"

leadership by industry; By forming training networks
column17:
SME’s have buying power – often for the first time – and this allows them to tell trainers what they want instead of having to send their staff on courses more relevant to large companies. The cost for each company in the network is greatly reduced and these companies are provided with expert staff and advisors to facilitate them in choosing the training that is best for their business.

"~"

column1:
Zakładowy Fundusz Szkoleniowy~"Training fund in enterprises"~"Poland"~"

\r\n
column2:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-fareast-theme-font:minor-fareast; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin;} --> This applies to all employees and companies in all sectors.

\r\n

 

"~"

This support instrument is not mandatory. The fund can be used to finance and co-finance training courses. The training courses and criteria to recruit participants are not specified. After the training courses
column3: costs can be reimbursed by the Labour Fund and/or the European Structural Fund (ESF). The fund can be created by more than one employer on the basis of an agreement among them
column4:
although this is not often done.

\r\n

An employer who wants to claim training expenses has first to prepare an agreement with an employee regarding the training course. They then submit a claim to the labour office
column5: and sign the agreement on reimbursement. The training allowance can cover up to 50% of training costs
column6: but it never exceeds the minimum wage. For employees aged 45 years and over
column7: up to 80% of the costs are covered
column8:
but no more than 300% of the monthly minimum wage.

\r\n

The reimbursement also concerns the costs of the salary of the employee who is replacing the worker on training leave. The training fund is mainly financed by the contributions of the employers
column9:
according to the collective agreement or training fund regulations. It constitutes no less than 0.25% of the payroll budget.

"~"

According to research findings
column10: very few employers are interested in creating training funds; 12.9% of respondents declared that they created a training fund
column11:
and 4.2% said they created enterprise training fund. The vast majority (85%) did not have any kind of training fund. Over 55% of respondents had no knowledge of training funds and 70% respondents declared they did not plan to create any training funds in the future.

"~"

The measure supports a life-long learning as well as long-term professional development of employees.

"~"

The instrument is not very widely known among employers
column12: and neither is commonly used by them. Over 55% of employers had no knowledge about training funds and 85% of companies did not establish training funds. Moreover
column13:
70% of employers declared they had no plans to establish one. The training fund was only established within 4.2% of companies.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Płatny urlop szkoleniowy~"Paid training leave "~"Poland"~"

This support instrument is available to all employees. It was established within the Act of 20 April 2004 to promote employment and the development of human resources.

"~"

Employees have the right to take paid training leave. Employers may hire unemployed persons from the local labour office to temporarily replace employees on paid training leave. Employers may receive reimbursement from the labour office
column2: provided that they send employees on training courses lasting at least 22 days and they guarantee paid training leave. Training costs can be reimbursed up to 80% of the average salary at national level. Employers also receive reimbursement for the salary of the person replacing employees on training leave
column3:
up to 40% of the average salary. Received support is classified as public aid.

The employee is also entitled to:

 

  • 21 days of paid leave during the last year of his studies (academic year);
  • 6 days of paid leave for preparation and taking the final exams.

 

 

"~"

The programme is not monitored
column4:
but research indicates that training courses are not popular and not widely used by employees.

"~"

Strengths include the reinforcement of partnerships
column5:
especially between the public employment service (PES) and companies. New skills and qualifications are acquired by employees and people who are unemployed.

"~"

Very few initiatives have taken place.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
ВАУЧЕРИ ЗА ОБУЧЕНИЕ ПО ОП РЧР 2009-2013: 'АЗ МОГА ПОВЕЧЕ'~"Training vouchers under OP Human Resources Development 2009-2013: 'I can more'"~"Bulgaria"~"

Anyone working on a labor contract in the private sector can apply to participate and receive a voucher for training. Self-employed also can apply. The programme cannot be undertaken by staff in the public sector - teachers
column2: military
column3: police
column4:
state administration. 

\r\n

 

"~"

Everyone approved gets a training voucher at the amount of 700 BGN (€358) for language courses and 1
column5: 800 BGN (€920 EUR) for professional training. Individual training vouchers cover 100% of educational expenses. The trainee can choose language courses in English
column6: French
column7: Spanish or  German
column8:
or professional courses in web programming or accountancy.

\r\n

The applicant needs to apply directly at the regional Labour Office.

\r\n

The training vouchers programme was developed within the framework of three schemes under the Operational Programme for Human Resources Development 2009-2013: 'Development'; 'I can more'; and 'Adaptability'. The new Operational Programme Human Resources Development 2014-2020 (OP HRD) is not approved as of July 2014
column9: but according to MLSP experts and official publications the measure 'I can more' is extended up to 31 August 2015
column10:
and the vouchers will be valid till 31 December 2015.

\r\n

The budget for 'I can more' has been increased with approximately 7.8 million BGN (€ 3
column12:
076) because of the high interest by recipients.

"~"

The training vouchers scheme started in 2010. Initially the scheme 'I can more' was intended for 27
column13: 000 participants. However
column14: the first issue was heavily oversubscribed with 60
column15: 000 applications from employees and self-employed people seeking to upgrade their competences and qualifications. The extension allowed for 54
column16: 000 approved participants in total
column17: twice the original number. According to the latest preliminary 2010 report on activities of the NEA
column18: about 32
column19: 000 persons participated in training
column20: including 8
column21: 309 in professional qualification training and 23
column22: 684 in key qualification training. As yet
column23: some 17
column24: 000 unemployed people and about 2
column25: 000 employees submitted applications under the scheme entitled 'development'. A total of 1
column26:
836 of people who were undemployed found work following participation in training.

\r\n

This measure was evaluated as succesful
column27: so in 2013 according to an official statement of the National Employment Agency from 23 August 2013
column29: 000 employed persons are approved for inclusion in the training voucher scheme 'I can more'
column30: compared to an planned indicator of 137
column31: 000 people and financial resources of 100 million BGN (€51
column34: 000 of the approved have already received their vouchers. Over 62
column35:
000 people have successfully completed their training under the scheme.

"~"

This scheme increases the quality of the human resources. It provides a better match between labour market demands and the existing and future needs of employees and unemployed people. It takes a flexible approach towards training
column36:
in line with the life-long learning strategy of the country.

"~"

Funding levels do no meet the needs of all those who wish to participate. For example since March 2013
column37: the Employment Agency ows approximately 7 million BGN (€3
column39:
043) to business and training organisations for activities under OP 'HRD'. This was announced on 27 March 2013 at a press conference by the deputy minister at the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy.

"~"

Kabinata is a leading education provider under the OP 'HRD' and the measure 'I can more'. All news about the measure are available at the web page of kabinata.

column1:
Mini darbo birža~"Mini labour exchange"~"Lithuania"~"

The measure applies in situations of mass dismissals. It covers all employees warned about dismissal.

"~"

A temporary office of the PES is set up in companies facing massive lay-offs. The mini labour exchange is a subdivision of the Lithuanian Labour Exchange (LLE) and actually provides the same services as ordinary PES; it differs only regarding its location. Services provided include: information and consultation (individual or collective); provision of a list of relevant vacancies; provision of information about available active labour market policy measures; other.

"~"

It is a good means of providing direct and up to date support for those facing dismissal.

"~"

It provides direct (personal) communication
column2:
and the possibility to provide workers with all available support in the region. It is especially effective if social partners actively participate in it.

"~"

Sometimes
column3: LLE representatives are not able to provide any real support as labour market opportunities are very limited. In these cases
column4:
the activities of the mini labour exchange might be rather formal.

"~"

Usually mini labour exchanges are established in the large companies intended to dismiss groups of employees.

column1:
Implacement Arbeitsstiftung~"Implacement work foundation"~"Austria"~"

Eligibility varies slightly by the different provinces. Generally
column2: an implacement foundation is available to unemployed persons with an interest in receiving training qualifications
column3:
who have not been employed by the company looking for staff during the previous 52 weeks.

"~"

Implacement foundations seek to place unemployed people with appropriate qualifications with available jobs. They involve the careful development and implementation of individualised (re-)integration processes by offering a broad package of supportive measures; these include career guidance
column4: various training measures
column5: active job searches
column6: and work experience programmes. The lenght of the training measures varies; support is provided for up to 156 weeks and under certain circumstances (e.g. the respective employee is over 50 years of age) up to 208 weeks (i.e. the maximum length lies at three and four years
column7:
respectively). Training can involve available apprenticeship programmes. The social partners have to agree on the design of the work foundation.

\r\n

During participation
column8: workers receive financial support to the amount of the unemployment benefit (in some provinces
column9: such as Vorarlberg
column10: they receive an additional stipend). The company registers its demand for labour with the Public Employment Service (AMS) which looks for appropriate candidates among the register of unemployed people. If a company volunteers to participate
column11: it can make a final selection from candidates. At that stage
column12: a training plan is prepared
column13: including training provided by external training providers as well as theoretical and practical training in the company. After this
column14:
the employment contract begins.

\r\n

In 2011
column15: a specific implacement foundation for young workers between 19 and 24 years (called JUST implacement foundation) was implemented
column16: targeted towards qualifying 1
column17:
500 lowly qualified young persons (with a focus on apprenticeships).

"~"

At the end of 2009
column18: about 170 implacement foundations were in place. The peak with regards to new entrants into implacement foundation reached its peak in 2009 with 7
column19: 441 new entrants. In 2012
column20: the number has been less than halved and reduced to 3
column21:
579 persons.

"~"

In growth sectors
column22: implacement work foundations offer companies a chance to access the skilled labour that they seek; workers are trained to meet their specific needs. During the training period
column23: the company does not have any wage and ancilliary wage costs and saves costs relating to training and HR administration. At the same time
column24: the scheme gives job seekers the opportunity to gain qualifications as well as the promise of employment at the end of the training process. They promote greater occupational
column25:
remunerative and regional mobility. The division of costs among various stakeholders means that the amount of required public funding is quite low.

column1:
Partage de compétences~"Skill-pooling"~"Belgium"~"

Coverage extends to workers whose careers are well advanced and who already have a certain amount of experience.

"~"

Labour is shared between a number of businesses. The skills of salaried managers working for large companies are 'sold' to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with specific ad hoc needs for highly-qualified staff. A skill-pooling company plays the role of intermediary between a company that has over-capacity and a company that has under-capacity.  The worker continues to be paid by their original company
column2: where they still work for part of his time. Their services are then made available to an SME for the remainder of their working time. The employer invoices the client company for this work
column3:
based on a commercial contract.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

It  enables companies to retain the type of skills that have been taken away from them as the result of successive waves of early retirement.

"~"

A judicial void seems to surround the concept
column4:
to the extent that it is by no means certain that provisions regarding the secondment of personnel from one company to another apply in this case.

"~"

No information available.

\r\n

The qualification barometer is an extensive online information system on qualification trends. Information on current and future qualification requirements is compiled and organised and made publicly available through the internet. It involves the secondary analyses of statistical data provided by the Main Association of Austrian Social Insurance Funds (Hauptverband der Sozialversicherungsträger)
column3: Statistik Austria and the Public Employment Service (AMS)
column4: as well as studies on the development of qualification requirements and the labour market. Job advertisements in Austria’s main daily and weekly newspapers and print media (a total of 84 sources) are analysed. Interviews are held with experts in different occupational areas
column5: such as HR managers
column6:
heads of education and training organisations and representatives of professional and trade associations.

The qualification barometer is the only such online information tool on qualification trends in Austria. Information is available according to qualification levels
column7: professions
column8:
and regional states.

This provides comprehensive
column9:
extensive and current information on developments within the labour market and subsequent levels of need for specific qualifications. It can be used for forecasts on future developments.

The qualification barometer is a measure of short-term nature; this can lead to distortions that may result in some trends being given too much significance.

column1:
Töötasu ja tööaja vähendamise õigus~"The right of employers to reduce salary and working time "~"Estonia"~"

In situations of unforeseen economic difficulty
column2:
employers are allowed to reduce the working time and salary of their employees.

"~"

If an employer
column3: due to unforeseen economic circumstances beyond his/her control
column4: fails to provide an employee with work to the agreed extent
column5: the employer may
column6: for up to three months over a period of 12 months
column7: reduce the salary to a reasonable extent
column8:
but not below the minimum wage if payment of the agreed salary would be unreasonably burdensome for the employer.

\r\n

Before reducing wages the employer shall offer the employee other work
column9:
if possible.

\r\n

Before reducing wages an employer shall inform the trustee / shop steward or
column10: in his or her absence
column11:
the employees and consult them pursuant to the procedure provided for in the Employees’ Trustee Act. The employer shall provide notice of the reduction of wages no less than 14 calendar days in advance. The trustee / shop steward or the employee shall give his or her opinion within seven calendar days as of the receipt of the employer's notice.

\r\n

An employee has the right to refuse to perform work in proportion to the reduction of the wages. Also
column12: an employee has the right to cancel the employment contract on the grounds
column13: notifying thereof five working days in advance. Upon cancellation of the employment contract
column14: the employee shall be paid compensation to <span>the extent of one month’s average wage (also
column15:
an employee has the right to receive a benefit upon lay-off under the conditions and pursuant to the procedure prescribed in the Unemployment Insurance Act).

\r\n

Before the employment contract act reform went into force on 1 June 2009
column16:
an employer with the consent of the labour inspectorate had a right to establish part-time working time for an employee for up to three months per year or to send the employee on a holiday with partial pay for the same period with the agreement of the employee. The employee had the right to demand termination of the employment contract if he or she did not consent to such changes in work organisation.

"~"

Since employers are no longer required to inform the Labour Inspectorate about using this measure
column17:
information is no longer collected on cases of reduced salary and working time.

"~"

Reducing salary enables employers to react to changes in economic situation flexibly and for a limited period of time. In response
column18:
employees are allowed to reduce their working time accordingly.

"~"

There is no information on the extent to which employers make use of this measure in the current economic context.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Flexikonto a podpora dočasného udržania nadbytočných zamestncov ~"Short-time working/work-sharing and Annual working time account"~"Slovakia"~"

This is provided when the employer cannot provide work to an employee
column2:
due to substantive operational reasons.

"~"

In cases where an employer outlines
column3: in a written agreement with employees' representatives
column4: substantive operational reasons that prevent them from designating work to an employee
column5: that employee is entitled to wage compensation. The amount of this compensation is stipulated in the agreement and must be
column6: at minimum
column7:
60% of their average earnings.

\r\n

Another option allowing flexibility in case of substantive operational reasons that prevent them from designating work to an employee is the implementation of a working time account. It must be agreed in written with employees´representatives (also in collective agreement) and can not exceed 30 months. An employer is obliged to pay an employee the basic wage component corresponding to the employee's determined weekly working time. The employee is obliged to complete any working hours owed to the employer without undue delay
column8:
when the employer is in a position to provide them with work again.

\r\n

Based on a collective agreement or an agreement with employee representatives
column9: an employer may distribute working time unevenly for individual weeks over a period of 4-12 months. Working time may
column10: however
column11:
not exceed 12 hours within 24 hours. An employee may be requested to work overtime for up to 150 hours per calendar year.

"~"

It is assumed that dozens of companies implemented this measure
column12: impacting on about 40
column13:
000 workers.

"~"

This measure allows employees to maintain their jobs during temporary downturn in business.

"~"

The application of Flexikonto is limited to the end of 2012. In the case of temporary contracts
column14:
state subsidies to compulsory insurance funds are limited to 60 calendar days in the year

"~"

column1:
Nachfolgebörse~"Succession bourse "~"Austria"~"

This is available to all companies.

"~"

This service
column2: which is free of charge
column3: aims at bringing together potential successors and entrepreneurs who want to transfer their business. Details of potential new entrepreneurs and companies to be transferred are registered on the website of the Federal Economic Chamber (WKO). Users can then select from the list given and contact the chosen company or candidate for the transfer. The search profile offers the following possibilities: region
column4: sector
column5: turnover
column6: number of employees
column7: size of the business
column8: type of business acquisition (rent/lease/buying/life annuity)
column9:
location.

\r\n

Upon registration
column10: the users must indicate their name
column11:
business and contact details. These data are not published and users can remain anonymous if they so wish.

\r\n

Usually the advertisements are placed directly by the users and are online immediately. There is no systematic screening of advertisements and the Nachfolgebörse does not monitor them. However
column12: obviously inappropriate entries (e.g. advertising for products or services) are removed by the administrators. Advertisements can be changed at any time; it is the users’ responsibility to keep them up to date. The user can also predefine an expiry date
column13:
but there is no time limit for advertisements.

\r\n

Nachfolgebörse does not provide a matching service. In order to establish contact
column14: a registered user can send a message to an advertiser’s mailbox. The latter will be informed by email that someone has tried to contact them. The first contacts between members of the bourse can remain anonymous; only user IDs are revealed in the exchange. Additionally
column15:
the partners of the business transfer can get advice regarding specific problems that may arise. General services include:

  • Succession check – is the business 'fit' to be transferred?;
  • Guidelines for the succession of a business – information on all important aspects;
  • Checklist for successors and the person who transfers;
  • Support in determining the selling price of the business (this includes an assessment of the company and its assets).
"~"

At time of writing (5 June 2014)
column16: there are 345 active inquiries and 1
column17: 661 active offers on the website of the WKO's succession bourse. Since the scheme began on 1 March 2003
column18:
there have been over 18 million visits to the website.

"~"

It provides substantial expertise; all interested parties can access its main services
column19: such as succession checks
column20: guidelines
column21: calculators
column22:
and price determinations.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
ICHEC-PME~"ICHEC-PME"~"Belgium"~"

Coverage extends to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Brussels.

"~"

A range of measures and programmes are provided for entrepreneurs who run an SME. Every year
column2: a theme that is important to SME managers is chosen; this is known as 'colloquia'. A book is regularly published
column3: with contributions from SME managers and experts. PME-PLUS is a coaching programme for SME-managers. Coaching for new SMEs and SME managers is provided by a team of eight people
column4: who are available for information
column5: support and counselling. Finally
column6:
a forum of SME managers meet to discuss the 'qualities of SMEs'; this is planned to take place every year.

\r\n

Programmes aim to stimulate entrepreneurship and to train future enterpreneurs. DREAM (Démarre la Recherche d'une Entreprise A ta Mesure) is one example; it tries to stimulate entrepreneurship among students in secondary school. Another example is the two year bachelor degree in SME management
column7:
which can be taken following the first two years of a general commerce degree; 25% of commerce students choose this path.

column1:
Agentschap voor Innovatie door Wetenschap en Technologie~"IWT - Innovation network"~"Belgium"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the Flanders region.

"~"

This network provides SMEs with information on and referral to all Flemish organisations that provide SMEs with innovation-related information and services
column2:
including advice and coaching at reduced and subsidised prices. The network brings together the knowledge and expertise of 37 intermediary organisations for Flemish enterprises. Organisations in the network include: regional development agencies (GOM); universities and technical colleges; research institutes and research centres; cluster organisations; and public Flemish organisations.

column1:
Peterschapsprojecten~"Mentoring projects "~"Belgium"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the Flanders region.

"~"

Over a period of one to two years
column2: a group of small business managers come together every month to exchange their experience with one or two mentors. Most of the mentors are experienced
column3: small business managers who want to share their skills and experience. At each session
column4:
a specific subject is introduced by an expert. Care is taken to ensure that the expert has experience with small businesses.

column1:
PLATO~"PLATO"~"Belgium"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that have between five and 100 employees and are based in Flanders or Wallonia regions in Belgium.

"~"

The main objective of this scheme is the transfer of management skills from professional (large enterprise) managers to SME managers. A group of about 15 SME managers receive mentoring support from two managers of large companies. These mentors counsel the group on all aspects of enterprise management.

"~"

Since it began in 1999
column2: Plato has involved 4
column3:
000 entrepreneurs and 630 mentors from 297 large enterprises.

"~"

This programme provides managers with a place to share their practical experience.

"~"

column1:
Erhvervsforskere~"Business researchers "~"Denmark"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

The aims of this scheme are as follows:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • to establish a more direct link between SMEs and research and development (R&D) centres
column2:
such as universities;
  • to stimulate the use of R&D in Danish SMEs;
  • to support SMEs in hiring a researcher;
  • to place a researcher in SMEs
column3: thereby addressing internal problems or needs
column4:
as well as establishing a bridge between the companies involved and R&D centres.\r\n"~"

The opportunity to have a business researcher has been positively received by companies
column5:
universities and researchers who now see enhanced scope for research funding. Some concern has been raised that research will become too dependent on the interests of the businesses concerned.

"~"

This scheme gives companies
column6:
universities and researchers an opportunity to fund mutual objectives.

"~"

There is a risk that the scheme will drain research funds.

"~"

Novo Nordic.

column1:
Innovationsmiljøer~"Innovation centres"~"Denmark"~"

These centres are available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

This scheme aims to create more new innovative companies in Denmark. Its approach is to develop a close network of entrepreneurs
column2: research department and investors
column3: thereby facilitating the development of new products and services. Companies with an annual turnover of less than DKK 50
column4: 000 can receive up to DKK 750
column5:
000 to prepare a project. The centres are established near universities and research departments and have good physical facilities.

"~"

An evaluation of this scheme
column6: conducted in 2000 and 2001
column7: found that it worked well. It showed that the service met its objectives
column8:
such as those of securing capital and knowledge for entrepreneurs who wish to develop new ideas. The evaluation did not give rise to any significant changes in the scheme's  operation.

"~"

This helps innovative SMEs to access financial support and to overcome the difficult initial years of business.

"~"

Not enough funding has been provided to help all innovative SMEs.

"~"

Kontaktpunkter for iværksættere~"Contact points for entrepreneurs "~"Denmark"~"

These contact points can be accessed by small and medium enterprises (SMEs) aged up to three years. 

"~"

Advice is provided to entrepreneurs that either seek to start up an enterprise or have started one within the past three years.

"~"

The service was evaluated in 2003. It was found to provide a helpful environment for entrepreneurs during the early stages of setting up a business.

"~"

This scheme aids in the setting up of innovative SMEs
column2:
by providing practical knowledge and information at an early stage.

"~"

Agencies and contact points involved in this scheme have been criticised for being under-qualified.

column1:
Yritys-Suomi~"Enterprise Finland"~"Finland"~"

Enterprise Finland offers public entrepreneurial services to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and to potential entrepreneurs. 

"~"

Enterprise Finland is under the responsibility of the Ministry of Employment and the Economy together with the organisations and interest groups of its administrative branch. The aim is to develop the operating conditions of enterprises in order to improve Finland's competitiveness by providing companies and the founders of companies with access to public business services equitably and under equivalent criteria in all parts of the country. This service helps firms to set up
column2: expand
column3: and develop their business operations and personnel. A range of services are provided; examples include providing assistance in setting up the company and evaluating alternative financing options. Entrepreneurs may access guidebooks
column4: workbooks or a business partner
column5:
if required. 

Enterprise Finland operates through three service channels:

 

  1. Face-to-face services
column6:
which are produced by national and regional organisations that are part of the network;\r\n
  • Yrityssuomi.fi online service that offers up-to-date information on entrepreneurship and corporate activities
column7: as well as corporate services and tools. The site contains all of the key forms needed in the establishment of an enterprise and in functioning as an enterprise. The service also includes an entrepreneur's own electronic desk My Enterprise Finland (oma.yrityssuomi.fi)
column8: which offers information based on the user's profile information
column9:
as well as tools to help entrepreneurs and those planning to go into business;
  • Enterprise Finland telephone service is a national service channel of the Ministry of Employment and the Economy for entrepreneurs and those planning on going into business. 

    •  

     

    "~"

    No information available.

    "~"

    The point of single contact for SMEs is of great importance for potential entrepreneurs.

column1:
Business Angels~"Business Angels"~"Germany"~"

This measure targets small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

SMEs and private investors with a high level of experience and strong business skills are brought together. The investors bring in both capital and expertise
column2:
gained from running their own company. Networks are set up for the purpose of establishing initial contact between SMEs and investors.

"~"

"~"

'Business angels' can invest in many business start-ups that involve innovative ideas and products. The scheme enables many new businesses in the high-technology sector to set up; business angels can help by sharing their financing and business knowledge.

"~"

Fewer business angels are active in Germany

"~"

This measure targets small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

This is a voluntary service
column2: through which older experts assist younger people in starting up a new business or in securing an existing one. Meetings are arranged between the business owner and the senior consultant in order to review difficulties faced by the company. The consultants also participate in round table meetings which are organised by institutions
column3:
such as banks or chambers of commerce to discuss problems faced by SMEs such as financing issues.

"~"

Over the last 12 years
column4: more than 30
column5:
000 enterprises received coaching and consultancy support through this scheme.

column1:
Mentor Network~"Mentor Network"~"Ireland"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

This scheme links small businesses with experienced business people who are willing to assist the business in identifying and overcoming any problems and obstacles that limit its abilities to grow. Companies primarily receive mentor network support via a referral from their Enterprise Ireland Development Adviser
column2: Shannon Development or County Enterprise Board. The mentor are reimbursed for basic expenses
column3: but they do not receive a consultant’s fee. A panel of over 300 experienced mentors
column4: with strong industry backgrounds
column5: has been assembled. A specific mentor is assigned to work with the chief executive officer (CEO) of one small company. The mentor is made available to the company for about 8-10 days each year
column6:
at no cost to the company.

"~"

Since its inception over ten years ago
column7: the Mentor Network has provided almost 5
column8: 000 Irish companies with pragmatic advice and assistance to help them identify and overcome barriers to growth. A survey of companies which have participated in Enterprise Ireland’s Mentor Network has shown significant increases in sales
column9: exports and employment as a result of participation. More than 90% of respondents described the mentor’s input as either important or very important. The survey of participating companies was carried out by an independent consultancy called Commencements Limited. Representatives of sixty companies were interviewed and the responses were overwhelmingly positive. These participants came  from the following sectors: electronics
column10: consumer goods
column11: services
column12:
food and general manufacturing.

"~"

column1:
SIVA (Selskapet for industrivekst)~"SIVA (The Industrial Development Corporation of Norway) "~"Norway"~"

This is available to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

SIVA – The Industrial Development Corporation of Norway - is a governmental corporation founded in 1968. It is owned by the Norwegian Ministry of Trade and Industry and aims to develop strong regional and local industrial clusters through ownership in infrastructure
column2:
investment and knowledge networks as well as innovation centres.

\r\n

The goal is the improvement of national infrastructure for innovation. SIVA's main objective is to contribute to the achievement of the Norwegian government’s policy goals in remote areas
column3:
and within this framework contributes to unleash innovation capability and increase wealth creation in all parts of the country.

\r\n

SIVA has ownership in 150 companies in total. This includes subsidiary companies and attached companies.

\r\n

SIVA operates within four areas. One relates to real estate: SIVA is a professional property developer. It develops ways in which industrial premises can be adapted to regional needs. This reduces some of the risks faced by new companies
column4: and reduces their capital expenditure. SIVA is also engaged in multiple-use premises; here
column5: it develops activities that aim to faciliate synergy among companies. Thirdly
column6: SIVA owns and establishes incubators together with several industrial companies
column7: and runs a national programme for incubators. Finally
column8:
SIVA is a shareholder in a number of strategic investment and development organisations. Its goal here is to increase employment levels and enable business opportunities to emerge.

"~"

SIVA fosters a large innovation system in Europe. More than 1
column9: 500 stakeholders
column10: including private investors
column11: industrial and financial corporations
column12: companies
column13: universities and other important R&D institutions
column14: participate in its activities. SIVA functions as an exchange for sharing approaches to industry and innovation. SIVA is a partner in 56 business gardens
column15: 24 business incubators
column16: 19 industry incubators in core industries
column17: 25 science and research parks
column18: 10 seed-venture companies and 12 Norwegian Centres of Expertise across Norway (SIVA
column19:
2014).

"~"

This scheme was evaluated in 2010
column20:
and the findings were mainly positive. It showed that SIVA contributes positively both to infrastructure (property) and innovation. It also found that there was a demand for the services it provides.

"~"

Funds do not always meet demand; greater funding is required in areas such as participaton in regional partnerships and fostering innovation.

"~"

column1:
Business Angels~"Business Angels"~"Spain"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

SMEs are brought together with private investors
column2: or 'business angels'
column3: who have a high level of experience and strong business skills. The investors bring capital and expertise
column4: gained from running their own company. Organisations are set up for the purpose of establishing initial contact between SMEs and investors. In Spain
column5: business angels have a local focus. In fact
column6: some business angels are directly promoted by the regional governments
column7:
as they work from within the economic departments of local authorities.

"~"

Business angels have grown rapidly since 2002
column8: when the first business angels' network appeared. It is worth noting that 65% of the 40 existing networks were set up after 2005. Today
column9: business angels' networks exist in all regions except Aragón
column10: and most of them have a markedly local character (52% cover only one region). Almost three quarters (73%) of the networks do not specialised in a specific sector. The three most financed sectors are: ICT
column11:
software and renewable energy.

"~"

This scheme involves people with investment capacity and expertise in order to encourage innovation and competitiveness and to promote economic activities during the early stages of a company's development.

"~"

The business angels' networks are neither recorded nor verified by any public or private institution. The lack of regulation can generate distrust towards business angels.

"~"

column1:
Servicio Cameral de Orientación Profesional, SCOP~"Career Guidance Service provided by Chambers of Commerce"~"Spain"~"

This is available to all companies and unemployed people.

"~"

The main objective of this service is to support businesses in recruiting the most suitable individuals for available jobs
column2:
and to provide these companies with tools for training tools existing and new staff.

\r\n

A firm can reach SCOP by contacting any of the 50 Chambers of Commerce that offer this service. They can make contact by fax
column3: phone
column4: e-mail or through the service'swebsite
column5: which invites candidates for existing vacancies. Within 48 hours
column6: the Chamber of Commerce will look for suitable candidates
column7: contact them and send their details to the firm. At the company's request
column8:
SCOP will also deal with the recruitment process. SCOP provides a guidance service for individuals who have to fill in a form or prepare standard CV; this involves meeting an advisor.

"~"

In 1999
column9: SCOP was launched by 23 local Chambers of Commerce. Since  then
column10: it has grown steadily; a total of 50 Chambers of Commerce now offer this service. In addition
column11: seven Spanish Chambers of Commerce that are overseas are waiting to adopt it. The service
column12: once it is known of
column13: is very positively accepted both by firms and individuals. Around 67
column14: 000 jobseekers are currently registered on the database. More than 5
column15: 500 firms have used SCOP regarding over 12
column16: 000 job offers. Of these
column17: 3
column18: 000 have been successfully filled and a further 1
column19:
000 are in going through the recruitment process.

\r\n

Qualitative data have been collected regarding this service. Notwithstanding the difficulties associated in assessing such findings
column20:
they suggest that the service is improving all the time. This is attributed to the facts that companies trust the service and that jobseekers access Chambers of Commerce to gather all kinds of information on employment.

"~"

In a short period of time (less than 48 hours)
column21:
this service matches jobseekers to employers with vacancies and sends the CVs of suitable candidates to these companies.

"~"

It focuses on labour intermediation and does not provide support or assistance for those seeking work or training courses. Neither does it facilitate access to learning.

"~"

No information available.
