column1:
NyföretagarCentrum Sverige~"Jobs and Society Foundation's enterprise agency"~"Sweden"~"

This is available to people who wish to start their own business.

"~"

The Swedish Jobs and Society Foundation
column2:
the national body for regional enterprise agencies (NyföretagarCentrum) represents 200 of Sweden's 290 municipalities. The foundation has a number of aims:

  • to stimulate and facilitate the growth of healthy business ventures;
  • to build new bridges between businesses via increased cooperation;
  • to promote the entrepreneurial spirit;
  • to strengthen the sense of local community and to encourage engagement at the local level;
  • to promote a broad-based economy and to reduce the dependence of individual communities on a dominant employer;
  • to support the idea of helping those who help themselves by becoming self employed;
  • to build and maintain networks for the transmission of experience and business opportunities; 
  • to help create businesses with a high rate of survival.

At Jobs and Society enterprise agencies
column3: the person seeking advice is given an initial consultation with an experienced advisor
column4: using a well-tested business plan that was developed by Jobs and Society. This consultation also takes advantage of the local network of experts
column5: marketing experts
column6:
banks and other relevant bodies.

"~"

Jobs and Society’s first local agency was established in 1985. Since then
column7: more than 140
column8: 000 new companies have been established with the support of the network. In 2013
column10: 000 people came to the agency for advice
column11: of which 9
column12: 000 have started their own business. Of those who started their own businesses through the enterprise agency
column13: fewer than 1% went bankrupt after three years. After three years
column14:
80% of the companies are active and have an average of two employees. 

"~"

Each enterprise agency is led by an advisor who has personal experience with the business world; most of them are
column15: or have been
column16:
self-employed.

"~"

Many support services are available in Sweden; in particular
column17: the private supply of support has grown by more than 15% during the last five years. However
column18: according to a report from the European Commission  (2002)
column19: micro
column20: small and sole proprietor’s businesses in Sweden still seem to make relatively little use of the services available to them. Only 10% of the companies in question have utilised support services during the last five years and it is clear that support services are less commonly used in Sweden than in the other European Union (EU) Member States. The main reason for this is that many Swedish enterprises do not perceive a need for external help. A total of 86% of companies do not feel that there are any benefits to be gained from participatng in a support service for their business. Moreover
column21:
12% of entrepreneurs are not even aware of the existence of support services.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Scorecard opvolging ~"Succesion Scorecard"~"Belgium"~"

This is available to family businesses.

"~"

The Succession Scorecard aims at being a unique contact point with regard to succession in family businesses. A website approach was adopted in order to give family entrepreneurs as much access as possible. This website includes a self-test
column2: through which the entrepreneur can check how they score on the scorecard. The Scorecard brings together 10 factors that have been identified as the most important factors for success in business transfers. The web application consists of a questionnaire with 50 questions related to the 10 success factors. Filling in the questionnaire takes about 10 minutes and allows the target group (incumbent leader
column3: potential successor
column4: shareholders
column5: staff
column6: external consultants) to know where the company and those involved in the succession stand. In an evaluation of the answers
column7: which is automatically available after completion of the questionnaire
column8: the respondent will get extensive and detailed information on those factors that pose potential problems with regard to succession as well on as those factors that are have been dealt with sufficiently. Additional questions with regard to the score or the scorecard can be sent via the website. As the website is free of charge
column9:
it is open to everyone.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The web application offers the opportunity to contact specialists with further questions. It is easy to access.

column1:
Bourse d’entreprises ~"Successors bourse"~"Luxembourg"~"

Company sellers must be registered with the Chamber of Skilled Crafts. Company buyers need the qualifications required to take over a business.

"~"

The successors bourse provides a platform on which business owners can offer to sell their company and potential business buyers can look for a firm to purchase. The objective is to bring buyers and sellers together and to conclude a transfer. The owner has to fill in a relatively detailed form (fiche signalétique). This requires details on issues such as the type of business
column2: its location
column3: its legal form
column4: the number and qualification of employees
column5: the language used in the business
column6: and the size of the business premises. However
column7: in order to protect the anonymity of firms
column8:
this detailed information is not published. It is only used in the matching process.

\r\n

The collected data are analysed and the most relevant features are included in a summary. The Chamber continuously publishes all of this summarised information on the internet and an extract in its regular publication
column9: 'd´Handwierk'. Interested persons or enterprises must firstly contact the Chamber. If both parties agree
column10: the Chamber will then organise an initial meeting between the potential partners. The Chamber will mediate these meetings and will also give free advice on issues such as legal and financial matters. There are no costs involved for participants
column11:
and advertisements are published for an unlimited period.

\r\n

The Chamber of Commerce participates in a project of transborder successors bourses that covers Luxembourg and the two French regions Alsace and Lorraine (www.opportunet.net).

"~"

The measure is quite efficient. Over 100 participants are permanently registered with the crafts sector. It can be estimated that between 100 and 150 takeovers are realised every year in Luxembourg and around 15 of these occur in the crafts sector. Since 2000
column12: the Chamber of Skilled Crafts has had 300 clients on this scheme
column13:
with a success rate of about 10%.

"~"

This measure enables enterprises to continue
column14:
thereby safeguarding jobs.

"~"

column1:
Groeifaciliteit ~"Growth facility"~"Netherlands"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) located in the Netherlands and with business activities mainly in the Netherlands. SMEs who avail of this scheme must have a reasonable earning capacity and continuity perspectives for their business plan. No excessive capital withdrawals can have been made in the 12 months prior to accessing this scheme. It is only to be used for financing the company's own business activities and business transfer. It is not available to companies in the following sectors: agriculture and fishing (except service and suppliers); real estate (except mediation); finances; and health care.

"~"

This facility offers businesses a guarantee of a maximum of 50% for risk capital (shares and subordinated loans) with a maximum of €5 million provided for growth or business transfer. The financial institutions can request a guarantee from SenterNovem. SenterNovem is a technology agency of the Ministry. It decides whether or not a guarantee can be granted. The enterprises pay interest for the loan to the financial institution. The financial institutions pay a premium to SenterNovem.

"~"

this scheme should not be used by firms that are not experiencing financial problems.

Services to support internationalisation of businesses in Finland. The services are mainly directed towards SME's but representatives of large companies are also welcome.

Team Finland is a broad network consisting of the Ministry of Employment and the Economy
column2: the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Education and Culture
column3: working together with publicly funded bodies and Finnish offices abroad to promote Finland internationally. A numer of services supporting the internationalisation of businesses are provided brought together under one umbrella. This includes everything from basic guidance on internationalisation
column4: export promotion and financing
column5: promoting and protecting investment abroad
column6: networking and promotion services abroad
column7:
to international foresight information. 

\r\n

column1:
BusinessInfo.cz – Oficiální portál pro podnikání a export~"BusinessInfo.cz – web portal for Czech businesses"~"Czech Republic"~"

BusinessInfo.cz is the official Czech portal for business and exports. The portal is available to all kinds and sizes of enterprises
column2: including start-up businesses
column3: foreign companies
column4: exporters and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Information is presented in Czech and 5 foreign languages (EN
column5: GER
column6: FR
column7: RU
column8:
ES).

"~"

The website is a one-stop-shop that combines information from state administration bodies
column9:
agencies and non-governmental associations and chambers. It covers a wide variety of information that range from ‘easy read’ to complex material.

\r\n

In mid-2012 the BusinessInfo.cz portal underwent a major technological overhaul. 

"~"

Each year
column10:
the number of users almost doubles compared to the previous year. The average number of visitors to the site every month grew as follows:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • 6
column23:
547 in Q1 and Q2 of 2014.\r\n\r\n

The portal is successfully overcoming the issue of institutional fragmentation. It is a good channel of communication between state administration and businesses. User comments are positive.

"~"

Information provided by the state administration of the Czech Republic is fragmented. The portal has a large potential target group and includes information from a wide spectrum of branches and areas of interest. The information is up-to-date and is presented in a structured way.

"~"

No concrete information is provided in relation to addresing cases of restructuring and redundancies. State agencies and institutions are often reluctant to share information and data. Drawn from the national budget
column24:
funding is only provided on an annual basis and subject to parliamentary approval.

column1:
Προγράμματα Ασφάλισης Βραχυπρόθεσμων Εξαγωγικών Πιστώσεων ~"Short-term Export Credit Insurance Scheme "~"Greece"~"

Insurance programmes for short-term export credits for exporters of consumer goods.

"~"

This programme contributes to the effective promotion of the exports of Greek small and medium enterprises (SMEs). It covers up to 95% of the export value in case of non-payment due to commercial or political risks. The period of the insured export credits can be up to 180 days. For some specific products
column2:
this period can be extended to one year.

\r\n

According to EU and OECD rules
column3: as well as the International Practice
column4:
the maximum repayment period for short-term export credits is 2 years.

\r\n

An exporter willing to obtain cover fills out an application form and submits it to the export credit insurance scheme (ECIO). If ECIO approves the exporter’s request for insurance
column5: the two parties sign an insurance policy. Premium rates depend on the risks covered
column6:
the country of destination and the terms of payment.

\r\n

If the risk covered by the insurance policy actually occurs
column7: ECIO
column8: following the customer’s request
column9: indemnifies the exporter and at the same time assumes all of the exporter’s rights and claims against the foreign buyer-debtor. This only occurs if the initial period has elapsed; it ranges between three and nine months
column10:
depending on the risks that are covered.

\r\n

ECIO does not provide financial support for export companies. However
column11: it allows every insured exporter to assign their right for indemnification to a bank or any other financing institution as ‘collateral’. In doing so
column12:
it indirectly helps SMEs that are facing difficulties in obtaining financial support from their banks for their export orders.

"~"

The programme began in 1988. Since then
column13: approximately 2
column14: 000 insurance policies have been signed and almost 700 Greek export SMEs have benefited. As of 2014
column15:
ECIO's value amounts to €1.47 billion; this  includes its state guarantee capital.

"~"

According to ECIO's management
column16: the programme is not only an excellent combination of insurance and financing ensuring export credits
column17:
but also a solution to the vast problem of liquidity facing the Greek enterprises. It is implemented in cooperation with all the banks without any additional guarantees while offering direct compensation.

"~"

According to ECIO's management
column18: the programme while in operation for several years had not reached the public
column19: resulting in limited disclosure of the organisation's role and work. Additionally
column20:
there is still need for attracting new exporters.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Finpron vientirenkaat~"Finpro Export Partner Groups"~"Finland"~"

This is available to companies based in Finland. Export Partner Groups are mainly intended for SMEs. Large companies can participate
column2:
but the financial support they receive is lower.

"~"

In this project
column3: a group of SMEs work together in targeting a selected foreign market. The aim for the companies is to establish independent internationalisation activities within two to three years. Each collective initiative must involve at least four companies
column4: with the most usual numbers being four to six. The cooperating companies are usually in the same sector
column5:
have an interest in the same market and do not compete with each other.

\r\n

Each group is led by a jointly selected export manager. This manager acts as an extra resource for the companies involved. Alongside their own network
column6: they offer a local presence in the target market. The export manager may also be based in Finland
column7:
if the operation mode supports that. The participating companies have an active role in the project. The job description of the export manager can be designed to reflect the companies' needs.

\r\n

This project is primarily about opening doors
column8: market research
column9: searching for partner companies and discussion. It starts with a company analysis
column10: evaluation of the target market and the operational planning of the internationalisation activities (including financial estimates). The agreed upon plans are then implemented by the shared export manager
column11:
supported by the participating companies.

\r\n

Finpro also applies for internationalisation aid from the Ministry of Employment and the Economy which can be provided for a maximum period of 3.5 years. Support is provided on an annual basis. New partnerships can engage in a six month 'preparatory period'.

\r\n

Next to that
column12: Finpro also provides assistance in handling agreements
column13:
invoicing and payments related to the internationalisation activities.

"~"

Finpro has run export partnerships since 1993. Since then
column14: about 300 Export Partner Groups have been established
column15: involving about 1
column16: 000 Finnish SMEs. Finpro contributed to the launch of export activities of firms
column17:
the building of new sales channels and the development of skills and experience of participating firms.

\r\n

A study from 2004 shows that 62% of participating companies increased their internationalisation skills. In 56% of the companies
column18: the number of export customers increased
column19: and in the same number
column20: cooperation with the other firms in the group continued also after the project ended. In 43% of the participating companies
column21:
the financial value of the company's export activities had incrased.

"~"

Participating companies can benefit from finding new customers and business opportunities and receive additional resources from the experienced export manager
column22: resulting in a cost-effective way of entering new markets. Through Finpro
column23:
SMEs are eligible for internationalisation aid from the government. The combined offers of the participating firms brings added value to customers and cooperation partners.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

St. Lapland: Eight businesses in northern Finland collaborate to market their services in order to attract tourists from Russia and central Europe.

column1:
First flight~"First flight"~"Ireland"~"

This is available to companies who are new exporters or early stage exporters.  Their exports must have a value of less than €30
column2:
000.

"~"

First Flight is aimed at assisting companies — by assessing and developing key capabilities — to manage the risks
column3: time and expenses associated with going international. First Fight is a multi-step information provision
column4: self-assessment
column5:
mentoring and training process that is designed to help small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in approaching new export markets.

\r\n

Through the First Flight initiative
column6: managers can develop awareness of areas of strength and risk for their enterprise in exporting as well as be supported in taking action to prepare to enter a new export market. The programme assists the company’s management team in structuring the planning process into a systematic and consistent order
column7: by introducing the broad range of issues to consider. A questionnaire is completed by the company with the assistance of a development adviser (DA). It evaluates the company in the following areas: overview of company; company’s performance; management resources; market knowledge; the business case; and budgets and funding. Following this
column8: an action plan is developed with the company. In doing this
column9: the company can draw on a wide range of Enterprise Ireland (EI) supports
column10: including market research
column11: training
column12: access to a mentor network
column13: and participation in trade missions. An experienced mentor - who provides their time on a voluntary basis - is assigned to the company. Typically
column14:
the mentor will have had previous experience of exporting to the target market and may even be based in the region.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Mentors provide their time on a voluntary basis
column15:
so no additional costs arise.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

www.match-online.dk~"www.match-online.dk"~"Denmark"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

This is an internet-based marketplace for buying and selling (SMEs). SMEs can also seek (equity) finance and investors might offer (equity) capital through it. All the companies are described anonymously but with reference to the intermediary that made the registration. Only approved intermediaries can register companies on the marketplace and all initial contacts go through the intermediaries. The matching of buyers and sellers is done automatically and the intermediaries are informed by email of any new entries to the marketplace. The criteria for searching for prospective buyers and sellers are those of trade (NACE codes)
column2: location
column3: sales
column4:
number of employees and amount of capital.

SOWACCESS (Société Wallone d’Acquisitions et Cessions d’Entreprises)~"SOWACCESS (Walloon company of merger/acquisition and closure/bankruptcy)"~"Belgium"~"

This is available to all companies in Wallonia
column2:
with a focus on SMEs.

"~"

This is a platform that aims to facilitate the matching of potential sellers and buyers of companies and to ensure the best possible 'fit' between supply and demand. It involves a database
column3: which provides for the circulation of anonymous vendors’ and buyers’ profiles on a website and in a newspaper; the platform’s administrators act as a filter (e.g. as regards skills
column4:
expertise and available assets of potential buyers). It also includes an individualised search for counterparts performed for all profiles by the platform’s administrators.

\r\n

An annual flat fee is charged for use of this platform. An additional success fee for direct buyers/sellers also applies
column5: if matching occurred via the database. Advertisements are published for an unlimited duration
column6:
but are checked every two months.

\r\n

SOWACCESS also provides information and advice to the entrepreneur
column7:
pinpointing the importance of preparation and professional support during the transfer.

\r\n

In order not to limit its activities to Wallonia
column8: SOWACCESS established an exclusive partnership agreement with the private company MKBase in Flanders and a cooperation with the national association CRA - buyers and sellers of business in France. The three organisations jointly manage a platform (TRANSEO) covering Belgium
column9:
the Netherlands and France.

"~"

In 2009
column10: SOWACCESS contained more than 100 potential sellers
column11: more than 160 potential buyers
column12: about 800 contacts between potential buyers and sellers
column13: and 90 affiliate partners (e.g. lawyers
column14: banks
column15: advisors
column16:
accountants).

"~"

SOWACCESS facilitates the transfer of SMEs and thereby contributes to the continuity and the development of the local economic fabric.

column1:
Crédit temps~"Time credit"~"Belgium"~"

This is available to employees who have been working for their present employer for at least one year.

"~"

The law of 22 January 1985 offers a legal framework to reduce working time. Later
column2: it was complemented by several collective agreements (77
column3: 77bis
column4: 103) in order to define what a time-credit is. This means that employees can take a complete interruption
column5: a half time reduction or a one-fifth reduction. The complete interruption and the half time reduction apply for one year
column6: extendible up to five years by collective agreement. The one-fifth reduction applies for five years in general and without any restriction for employees aged 50 and over. Women aged up to 50 are the main users for the time credit entitlements and the reduction of the working hours is the largely used form. The one-fifth reduction of working hours for employees aged 50 and over
column7: however
column8: is also commonly used by male workers. Given the unlimited duration of the entitlement for employees aged 50 and over
column9:
this particular system can be seen as a part-time early retirement scheme aiming to alleviate the end of a career.

"~"

This time credit also means that 5% of the total number of workers in a company has the possibility to reduce their working times by one fifth of their total working time. The quota of 5% of simultaneous absence within the firm is determined by the National Employment Office (Office National de Sécurité sociale – ONEM / Rijksdienst voor Arbeidsvoorziening – RVA)
column10: but only for companies employing more than ten workers. The main goal of the quota is ensuring the continuity of work. However
column11: this measure concerns every worker in the company and therefore
column12: this is not specific to older workers. Nevertheless
column13: it seems that many companies have informal agreement with the older workers who want to be in this system
column14:
even if the quota of 5% was exceeded.

"~"

On hiring these workers
column2: employers can receive a reduction in social security contributions of €400 per quarter
column3: for a maximum of three quarters. Workers also receive a reduction in their social security contributions of €400 per quarter
column4:
for a maximum of three quarters following reemployment.

column1:
Aikuiskoulutustuki~"Adult Education Allowance"~"Finland"~"

This support is available to persons who have been employed by a Finnish employer or have worked as a self-employed person in Finland for at least eight years. The allowance can also be granted to an applicant who has a working history of less than eight years
column2: if he or she has a working history of at least five years by 31 July 2010. To qualify for the allowance
column3: the applicant must participate in studies leading to a degree
column4:
or in vocational further or continuation training organised by a Finnish educational institution under public supervision. 

"~"

The purpose of the adult education allowance is to support employees' and self-employed persons' voluntary vocational studies. The allowance is paid from the Education Fund
column5:
which is administered by the social partners of the Finnish labour market.

Working adults are eligible for an adult education subsidy as compensation for loss of income during vocational training. The amount of the allowance is equal to the amount of the earnings-related unemployment allowance. The maximum allowance period is 19 months if the applicant has a working history of at least eight years. If the working history is less than eight years
column6: but at least five years by 31 July 2010
column7: the allowance period is determined on the basis of the applicant's working history and ranges from 2 to 3.5 months
column8:
depending on the length of the working history.  

"~"

In 2013 a total of 15
column9:
000 persons received support from the scheme.

"~"

According to an effectiveness study of the Education Fund
column10:
income loss is the most common reason for not taking up studies. The scheme is reported to have enabled or at least lowered the threshold to take up studies. 

"~"

The processing time for applications is reported to be long.

"~"

Not applicable.

Flexible working time arrangements~"Flexible working time arrangements"~"Latvia"~"

Flexible working time is agreed in collective agreement or in individual employment contracts.

"~"

Flexible working arrangements should be within general norms of the Labour law on working time and rest time (part D of the Labour law). Normal working time should not exceed 40 hours per week (35 for young workers or employees associated with a special risk). In any case within the framework of the agreggated working time it is prohibited to employ the employee for more than 24 hours in succession and 56 hours a week.

They respond to the training needs set forth by enterprises or groups of enterprises (not necessarily of the same sector
column4:
but with the same training needs) and employees alike. Companies that train their employees and paz the compulsory vocational training levy enjoy a 'training credit' (créditos para formación continua) resulting in a reduction in social security contributions for companies. Small and medium enterprises (SMEs) benefit from special treatment.

\r\n

'Supply training' relates to training plans that have been designed for employed workers and training activities that are designed for people who are unemployed. Companies can provide training themselves or through the organisations
column5:
trade unions or specialist training bodies.

"~"

In 2009
column6: a total of 2
column8: 153 employees benefitted from 'demand training'; this marked a 21% increase from 2008. In the same year
column11: 000 people benefitted from 'supply training'
column12:
including that provided for people who are unemployed.

"~"

This encourages the adaptability of workers and enterprises. It guarantees the participation of the social partners in the design and implementation of measures involved. It permits enterprises to identify their skills gaps
column13: and to select the most suitable training programmes
column14:
which can then be financed with public funds.

"~"

Expenditure on ongoing training remains low
column15:
below the European average.

column1:
Fritvalgsordninger~"Free choice accounts"~"Denmark"~"

This is available to employees who have been working in their company for at least nine months.

"~"

Free choice accounts have been included in several recent collective agreements. A special savings account
column2: or 'free choice account'
column3:
may be set up for the individual employee. The establishment of this special savings account varies from one collective agreement area to another.

\r\n

In 2010
column4: many schemes included up to 7.5% of the employee’s pay. A compulsory contribution of 1% and more is to be made and in addition special holiday pay of up to 4% will be discontinued. The individual employee may chose to exchange five special days leave for 2.5% of their salary put into their account. In a number of schemes
column5:
employees also have the following options: to have the deposit paid in connection with leisure time; to have the deposit transferred as extraordinary pension contributions; and to transfer the deposit to the subsequent holiday year.

"~"

The arrangement has proven popular with employees and management; staff have gained more flexibility and choice regarding leave and thus their working time.

"~"

This grants employees certain guaranteed rights
column6:
and provides the opprtunity for greater flexibility in the workplace.

"~"

This could be misused if employees are forced to accept an arrangement that goes against their own wishes. The scheme runs the risk of reducing the impact of future collective agreements
column7:
as more items become free-choice.

"~"

column1:
Cellule de reclassement (CDR)~"Re-deployment units "~"Luxembourg"~"

This is available to employees of a large enterprise.

"~"

The requalification units assist workers in finding new employment. Workers placed in the CDR can be occupied in a variety of maintenance jobs in the company. They can also be lent out to other employers or undergo training measures. The workers placed in the CDR receive their full salary.

"~"

On 19 December 2008
column2: ArcelorMittal
column3: two trade unions (OGBL and LCGB)
column4: and the government reached agreement in the framework of the 'steel' tripartite body. This agreement provided a plan for the future of the steel industry within the ArcelorMittal Group in 2011. In the frame of the agreement
column5: the redeployment cell collected workers whose jobs were made redundant for structural or non-structural reasons. Workers placed in the CDR could be occupied in a variety of maintenance jobs in the company (including jobs on different production sites)
column6:
be lent out to other employers or undergo training. The workers placed in the CDR received a guarantee that they would not be made redundant and would receive their full salary. The Employment Fund paid part of the costs of the redeployment cell.

\r\n

Another example is that of the company Villeroy and Boch. This company established an internal redeployment unit in 2009 with a view to assisting affected workers in finding new employment
column7: writing CVs and preparing job applications. Villeroy and Boch also looked at 'in-sourcing' some services that were previously contracted to external providers
column8:
in order allow workers to remain in employment for as long as possible.

column1:
Betriebliche Bündnisse für Arbeit~"Company employment pacts"~"Germany"~"

Can be used by all companies that have a works council.

"~"

These agreements
column2: or pacts
column3: are made between the company's management and its works council
column4: and are usually backed by the trade union. The aim of the agreement is to maintain the number of jobs in the company
column5: as well as to foster competitiveness. The employer generally commits to an employment guarantee; employees will not be dismissed for reasons related to business conditions. In exchange
column6:
workers accept pay scales that are below the collectively agreed sectoral levels or pay cuts in the form of reduced/lost bonuses (such as Christmas/holiday bonuses or pay for overtime) or changes to collectively agreed working time.

"~"

Debate is ongoing regarding the effectiveness of this measure. Survey findings
column7: based on IAB Establishment panel data (Bellmann
column8: 2008) do not show a significant and positive association between company-level agreements and employment stability. Employment pacts offer little scope for prompting positive employment changes. At the same time
column9: pacts have been shown to foster usage of working time accounts
column10:
short-time working and training provision. Agreed measures are implemented in most cases.

\r\n

In 2010
column11: nearly 24% of all firms with an employment pact did not implement all agreed measures (Bogedan et al
column12:
2011; WSI works council survey).

\r\n

However
column13: other studies show that employers are able to reach their objectives through these pacts. One survey of employment pact companies in the machine and plant engineering industry found that: 62% were enabled to improve their productivity; 47% could deal more quickly and flexibly with the wishes of their clients and improve their ability of delivery; and 34.9% could preserve endangered jobs and sites (Berthold et al
column14:
2003).

\r\n

A survey amongst 1
column15: 285 companies in the metal and electrical industry in 2007 shows that one third of companies bound by a collective agreement had negotiated an employment pact. This held only true for 6.5% of those companies neither bound by nor oriented towards a collective agreement. Average running time of employment pacts was 30.3 months. When asked for their motives: 67% of the companies named securing the site
column16: 42% were facing economic difficulties and 27% neeeded additional investments at the site. When pay cuts were negotiated around half of the companies (50.6%) introduced pay cuts for overtime
column17: postponement
column18: reduction or cuts in collectively agreed annual bonuses (42.7%) or holiday bonuses (33.3%). A reduction of monthly pay was only named by 16.1% of the surveyed companies. With regard to changes in working time: longer working hours with no increase in pay were introduced by 42.7% or with increase in pay by 38.5%. In more than 90% of the cases
column19: intended company goals were fully or partially reached (Lesch
column20:
2008).

\r\n

 

"~"

Employment pacts facilitate the control of labour costs by enabling a variety of working time regimes
column21:
a differentiation of working conditions and an implementation of pay cuts. They enable the protection of employment and sites.

"~"

Concessions made by the workforce such  as agreeing to pay cuts and working time changes may not improve mployment stability. Co-management practice may delegitimise works councils. There is a risk that some commitments may not be implemented. It remains unclear whether or not an employment pact improves the employment situation of workers.

"~"

Schaeffler

column1:
Öffnungsklauseln~"Opening clauses"~"Germany"~"

Coverage extends to all companies.

"~"

According to the Works Constitution Act
column2: the management and the works council are not allowed to conclude a works agreement that deals with collective bargaining issues. However
column3: the bargaining partners (Collective Agreements Act) may include opening clauses to sectoral agreements which allow agreed deviations from the multi-employer agreement at company level; this involves negotation between management and works council
column4: and approval by social partners in case of deviation from sectoral agreement. Opening clauses are most often used for working time adjustments and
column5: to a lesser extent
column6:
for a reduction of wages.

"~"

The use of opening clauses continues to spread
column7: although figures vary. According to IAB Establishment Panel data
column8: 13% of establishments were covered by a collective agreement with scope for an opening clause. Of these
column9: 53% had made use of these opening clauses. According to the 2007 WSI Works Council Survey
column10:
53% of companies (with more than 20 employees and with worker representation in place) had made use of an opening clause.

"~"

Deviating from sectoral agreements provides the employer with greater flexibility in regard to working time regimes
column11: working conditions and pay rates
column12: especially in times of economic hardship. Studies hold divergent views on the strengths and weaknesses of opening clauses. Positive aspects are that opening clauses have improved acceptance of sectoral agreements and slowed down avertion of such agreements by employers (Lesch
column13:
2013).

"~"

Other research argues that the spread of these clauses has triggered a process of decentralisation that has shifted an increasingly large part of bargaining responsibilities to company level (Eurofound
column14: 2010). This has led to a significant loss of regulatory power on the part of both employers’ associations and trade unions. Collectively agreed standards have become objects of renegotiation at company level with varying degrees of involvement of the signatories to sectoral agreements. Works councils have less scope to take refuge in the mandatory character of sectoral regulations when confronted by management calls for local concessions. According to the 2010 WSI Works Council Survey
column15: 37% of works councillors see decentralisation as ‘ambiguous’ while 50% view it as generally problematic. Only 11% welcomed this trend
column16:
a lower figure than that found by the 2007 survey.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Lomautus~"Temporary layoff"~"Finland"~"

This is available to employers who needs to reduce their workforce due to lack of business.

"~"

A temporary layoff scheme
column2: or an obligatory unpaid holiday
column3: is the Finnish version of flexible protection of employment. The instrument was included in the Finnish employment contract legislation in 1970. According to the Employment Contracts Act of 2001
column4: the term 'laying off' means a temporary (either for a fixed or indefinite period of time) interruption of work. This relates to situations where the work offered to an employee has diminished substantially and permanently
column5:
for financial or production-related reasons or for reasons arising from reorganisation of the employer’s operations.

\r\n

The employer is entitled to change the employment relationship unilaterally into a part-time relationship. Remuneration is based on an employer decision or an agreement made on the basis of an employer initiative.

\r\n

During the period of layoff
column6: the employee is entitled to unemployment benefit. Temporary layoff can be either on a full-time basis
column7:
or it can involve a reduction in regular working hours. The law does not give a maximum duration during which temporary lay-off is possible.

"~"

Temporary layoffs comprise the principle means by which Finnish enterprises have tried to minimise dismissals and to survive the current economic recession. In 2013 a total of 87
column8: 100 of the unemployed registered at the Public Employment Services had been temporarily laid off on a full-time basis
column9:
which is 45% more than in 2012.  

"~"

The system benefits both employers and employees. It acknowledges the company's need to maintain its professional workers
column10:
even during periods in which they cannot provide them with employment.

\r\n

The Federation of Finnish Technology Industries represents one of the most severely affected sectors in terms of temporary layoffs. According to it
column11: the system of temporary layoffs offers an alternative to redundancies in situations where an economic upswing is anticipated. However
column12:
enterprises do not know exactly when this might happen.

"~"

The Federation of Finnish Technology Industries represents one of the most severely affected sectors in terms of temporary layoffs. According to it
column13: the system of temporary layoffs offers an alternative to redundancies in situations where an economic upswing is anticipated. However
column14:
enterprises don’t know exactly when this might happen.

\r\n

Trade unions acknowledge the value of this labour market instrument
column15: but they also identify certain difficulties. Depending on the individual situation
column16: trade unions suggest that rather than laying off employees it would be better to keep them and invest in training and further qualification measures. According to the trade unions
column17: good practice examples do exist of companies that have concluded co-determination negotiations with employees and local labour authorities
column18: resulting in the provision of training for temporarily laid off staff. Trade unions also regard a significant number of temporary lay-offs as being economically unjustified; they argue that in some cases
column19: employers dismiss staff temporarily without a genuine need. At the same time
column20: the trade unions highlight the impact of temporary layoffs on those employees who are not laid off
column21: but continue to work in the company. Often
column22:
these workers are responsible for both their own work as well as the duties of those of who have been laid off. This can result in extended working hours without proper compensation.

"~"

STX Finland; Turku shipyard temporarily laid off most staff in late 2010
column23:
but is expecting to start building a new ship in 2011.

column1:
Uddannelsesplan~"Education plan "~"Denmark"~"

This extends to all companies that are covered by a sector agreement that introduced this instrument.

"~"

The agreement for the manufacturing industry includes a joint recommendation for companies to make an education plan and to establish an education committee. It also states that negotiations about an education plan must take place if requested by the company's union organisation. The specific types of vocational training that are needed will be decided by the ‘education committee’
column2: which is set up as a social partner joint committee. These plans typically contain an evaluation of the future educational needs of the company’s employees
column3: the current educational level of workers
column4:
and an education strategy to make sure that the necessary qualifications are acquired.

"~"

It is estimated that a third of companies in manufacturing industry have an education plan.

"~"

This measure promotes education as a major employment relations issue in the workplace.

"~"

Take-up of this measure has been relatively low. However
column5: shop stewards (when present) address educational issues
column6:
even when no education plan is in place.

"~"

column1:
Job Plus Incentive Scheme (from July 2013, before known as "Employer job incentive scheme")~"Job Plus Incentive Scheme"~"Ireland"~"

This is available to employers who create new jobs for those who have been out of work for more than six months.

"~"

The programme encourages the employment of eligible workers granting the employer the exemption from the payment of the PRSI's contributions payment for 12 months. Eligible workers must have received welfare payments for a period pof at least six months. among those: Jobseeker's Benefits
column2: Jobseeker's Allowance

column1:
Statutory Guarantee Pay~"Statutory Guarantee Pay"~"United Kingdom"~"

Coverage of the UK Statutory Guarantee Pay scheme applies to workers who have been employed with the current employer continuously for at least one month (including part-time workers). An employee who is not provided with work throughout a day during which they would normally be required to work under their contract of employment is entitled to statutory guaranteed pay.   

"~"

The employment contracts of some workers specify that they can be laid off without pay when no work is available. Such employees are not redundant
column2: rather they are sent home from work for a temporary period because their employer has no work for them.  These workers are eligible to receive 'statutory guarantee pay' from the UK government. To be eligibile workers must:  have been employed continuously for one month (includes part-time workers) reasonably make sure they are available for work not refuse any reasonable alternative work not have been laid-off because of industrial action. Payments can only be made in respect of full working days lost. Employees who have not been continously employed for at least one month are excluded form the scheme. Employees who do not have normal working hours prescribed in their contract of employment are also excluded from the scheme. Some collective agreements can be made in which an employer and employees decide that parts of the statutory guarantee pay process should not apply to them. The agreement
column3: for example
column4: might state a preference for using the company’s complaints procedure rather than an Employment Tribunal process. In such cases
column5: however
column6: the collective agreement must contain guarantee pay provisions which are at least as favourable to employees as statutory guarantee pay. Sometimes an employer might state that
column7: as part of a collective agreement
column8: employees will not be entitled to parts of the guarantee payment process. To be legal
column9: this exemption must be agreed by the employer and employees and have the agreement of the Secretary of State for Business. Since 6 April 2014
column10: the daily maximum pay that a worker may receive is £25.00 (€31.25 on 19 August 2014) a day for 5 days in any three-month period - so a maximum of £125 (€156.23 on 19 August 2014). Payments made under the Statutory Guaranteed Pay scheme count as income for the purposes of social security benefits/job seeker allowance. If an employer lays an employee off without pay
column11:
not paying monies due is an unlawful deduction from wages and employees can take this matter to an employment tribunal.    

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Provides some income guarantee for some employees during temporary downturns.      

"~"

Not encompassing workers not continuously employed for a month or who do not have normal working hours prescribed in their employment contract means that many workers can be excluded from coverage by the provisions
column12: such as sales representatives and insurance agents. In addition
column13: employees who do not work regular hours of work may be disadvantaged in terms of the method of calculating any entitlement. Payments can only be made in respect of complete working days lost
column14: undertaking some work can also lead to workers’ being excluded from coverage. Thus if one hour of work is provided by the employer
column15: no payment can be made. In addition
column16: the scheme is not particularly generous. The statutory rate per day is low as is the maximum amount payable (see above
column17: coverage/main characteristics). Some employment contracts can include more than five days of contractual guarantee pay over any three month period. Even if the payments are low
column18:
a final weakness of the scheme is that responsibility for income guarantee for employees is shifted from employers to the state.    

"~"

column1:
Redundancy Action Scheme (ReAct II)~"Redundancy Action Scheme (ReAct II)"~"United Kingdom"~"

ReAct II for individuals is available to individuals who have been made redundant within six months prior to their application
column2:
and to those who face the threat of redundancy. Applicants must be residents of Wales at the time of redundancy.  ReAct II for employers consists of employer recruitment and training support for Welsh employers who take on someone who has been made redundant.    

"~"

ReAct II is part financed by the European Social Fund through the Welsh Assembly Government. The Welsh Assembly Government contributed £61 million (€76.2 million on 20 August 2014) with an additional £24 million (€30 million on 20 August 2014) from the European Social Fund (ESF). ReAct II helps people affected by redundancy gain new skills and encourages employers to recruit a redundant worker. There are two components: ReAct II for individual and ReAct II for employers. There are three elements of ReAct II for individuals: recruitment and training support; discretionary awards for vocational training and discretionary awards for extra support. Under this part of ReAct II
column3: financial support is available for eligible individuals to:  100 per cent of training costs to acquire new skills - up to a maximum of £1
column5: 875 on 20 August 2014) help with the cost of special equipment to remove barriers to training
column6: help towards the cost of travelling to training courses; overnight accommodation costs
column7: where appropriate; a contribution towards childcare costs whilst training (subject to limits and conditions)  ReAct II for Employers consists of two packages for employers who take on someone who has been made redundant:    Employer recruitment support - awards offer up to £3
column9: 749 on 20 August 2014) paid in four installments as a contribution to wage costs for eligible persons. Employer training support - a separate discretionary fund of up to £1000 (€1
column10: 250 on 20 August 2014) that an employer can put towards the cost of the new recruit's job-related training
column11: provided the worker is still in employment after 20 weeks.   In individuals working 25 hours per week or more will attract a full wage subsidy while those employed between 16 and 24 hours per week will receive a wage subsidy equal to 50 per cent of the full time rate. No wage subsidy is payable for employees who work less than 16 hours per week. Employer Recruitment and Training Support is available if:  the business is expanding and the post is new or
column12: the business seeks a justifiable replacement for a vacant post and
column13: the business does not have a director in common with the company that made redundant the person the company wants to recruit; the job is at least 16 hours per week; the job is expected to last for at least 12 months; the job is not being supported by any other public or European Fund and the business has not reached the ‘de minimis’ threshold for State Aid rules.   The funding amount for training support will be based on the costs an employer has to pay towards providing the training
column14: in line with the following conditions.  Training must be relevant to the job and approved by ReAct II. Training must improve the skills of the individual Where possible
column15: the employer must make every effort to provide training to at least NVQ level 2 (or equivalent).  ReAct II is managed by a dedicated team within the Welsh Government
column16:
but works closely with Careers Wales and JobCentre Plus. 

"~"

Between 2008 and 2014
column17: it is anticipated the ReAct II programme will support 37
column18: 230 individuals and 1
column19: 464 companies. A report on key performance outputs for ReAct II published on the Welsh Government's website indicates progress up to March 31 2011 has seen 15
column20: 850 individuals supported
column22: 237 companies supported
column23: 6.580 individuals assisted to secure employment within 12 months and 6
column24: 464 individuals assisted to achieve a qualification. An independent evaluation of the ReAct programme was commissed by the Welsh Government in 2011. The findings provided strong evidence that ReAct made a difference to individual's propensity to improve their existing skills or acquire new skills. For example
column25:
those individuals applying successfully for ReAct vocational training support were almost three times more likely to have undertaken training following redundancy than unsuccessful applicants (p. 8). 

"~"

ReAct II provides early intervention (comparatively earlier than redundancy schemes currently in place in other UK nations). There is evidence that the ReAct programme provides additionality in respect of taking up training opportunities. For example
column26: four-fifths of those receiving Vocational Training Support said that they probably would not have done the training which they undertook without ReAct support (p. 8). In addition
column27: a far higher proportion of ReAct participants than non-ReAct participants achieved qualifications (p. 9) and those ReAct participants with no or only low level qualifications were the most likely to have increased the level of their highest qualifications
column28:
again suggesting that ReAct made a greater difference to this group than other participants (p. 9).

"~"

Accessibility may not be as high as desirable. There is evidence that the level of training behaviour related additionality is not evenly distributed across all participant groups. For example
column29: participants with no or only low level qualifications beforehand were the least likely to say that they would have done the training anyway and they too were least likely to have undertaken any further training after completing the courses funded by vocational training support (p. 9). There is also evidence to suggest that training support was used by many participants to update their existing skills rather than re-skilling altogher (p. 9). Despite positive impacts in the area of participation in training
column30: the evidence was not very positive in terms of the employment prospects of participants. Furthermore
column31:
the employer subsidy does not appear to make little difference to company recruitment decisions (p. 9). A greater effect on recruitment decisions was found among smaller sized companies.

"~"

Dawson Shannon (Wales) Ltd case study

column1:
CzechInvest – Agentura pro podporu podnikání a investic~"CzechInvest – Investment and Business Development Agency"~"Czech Republic"~"

Available to all enterpreneurs; however
column2:
most of the services are provided for large businesses.

"~"

CzechInvest's original task was to attract foreign investment and to promote domestic companies through its services and development programmes. CzechInvest also promotes the Czech Republic abroad (6 offices) and acts as an intermediary between the EU and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in implementing structural funds in the Czech Republic.

\r\n

CzechInvest is exclusively authorised to file applications for investment incentives with the relevant governing bodies. It prepares draft offers to grant investment incentives. Its role also involves providing potential investors with current data and information on the business climate
column3:
investment environment and investment opportunities in the Czech Republic. All services are provided free of charge.

"~"

The number of investment projects and new jobs mediated by CzechInvest has been constantly increasing during last 3–4 years . For statistical data on this
column4: see CzechInvest's annual report
column5:
available on their website (http://www.czechinvest.org/en/czechinvest-annual-reports).

"~"

This measure is not primarily focused on restructuring processes and redundancies. However
column6: by supporting both foreign and Czech investors
column7:
it may result in an increase in the number of new jobs.

"~"

Most of the services are provided to large companies. The scheme does not focus on the needs of SMEs
column8: although it provides support to a growing number of SMEs
column9:
mostly through the use of the following European structural funds: (Operational Programme Enterprise and Innovation and Operational Programme Entrepreneurship and Innnovations for Competitiveness.

"~"

ESF Operational programmes for 2007–2013 provide support for a wide range of activities and subjects (companies
column3: SMEs
column4: NGOs
column5: communities
column6: schools
column7: enterpreneurs
column8: charity organisations
column9: social partners etc.). Eligible bodies are defined in particular programmes. Regarding restructuring

  • reskilling and retraining; 
  • starting new businesses
column11:
especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs); 
  • and the creation of new jobs. 

    • The programmes can also involve the provision of interest-free credits for small enterprises
column12: and support regarding innovation and business clusters. Operational programmes are usually implemented by the relevant department; however
column13:
some schemes can be implemented by other institutions - CzechInvest is one example.

\r\n

 

\r\n

The Operational programme (OP) Enterprise and innovation contains 17 partial support programms
column14:
OP Human resources and employment contains 6 priority axes and OP Education for competitiveness divided into 4+1 priority axes.

\r\n

Operational programmes mentioned above are opened for 2007-2013 programming period. Support from these operational programmes should have ended by the end of 2013
column15: however due to some delay in drawing money from structural funds
column16: some of the priority axes are still active and open calls (due to exceptions negotiated with EC). Operational programmes of programming period 2007-2013 will be followed by new (similar) operational programmes for the programming period of 2014-2020. However
column17:
final versions of new operational programmes have not been approved yet.

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

"~"

Outcomes are monitored by the administrator of a particular operational programme. These data include factors such as the number of financially supported projects
column18:
number of people who have been trained or reskilled and the number of supported or new businesses.

"~"

This programme is not primarily focused on restructuring processes and redundancies. However
column19: it can lead to an increase or the creation of new jobs
column20: and can result in the reskilling of employees and people who are unemployed. Some activities are focused on specific target groups
column21: such as people with disabilities
column22: older (50+) employees
column23:
women with children and ethnic minority groups.

"~"

Effectiveness is hard to measure. Substantial differences are found across supported projects. The programme involves a large administrative burden.

"~"

column1:
Innovasjon Norge ~"Innovation Norway"~"Norway"~"

This is available to companies and to persons planning to establish a company. The typical customer is a company with one to five employees and with average sales of 5.8 million NOK (around € 725
column2:
000).

"~"

Innovation Norway is organised as a special legislation company in accordance with the Act relating to Innovation Norway. The stated objective of Innovation Norway is as follows:

\r\n

'Innovation Norway shall promote industrial development throughout Norway that is profitable from a business and socio-economic viewpoint
column3: and trigger business opportunities for the various districts and regions by contributing to innovation
column4:
internationalisation and marketing.'

Its range of instruments include:

  • Financial instruments such as loan
column5: guarantees
column6:
grants and equity.\r\n
  • Networking by establishing and developing regional
column7: national and international networks for single companies
column8:
industries and industry clusters. \r\n
  • Competence development measures for entrepreneurs
column9: employees
column10:
managers board members and more.
  • Councelling on strategic decisions and dispositions to increase competitiveness.
  • Marketing together with stakeholders within the tourist industry to make Norway an attractive destination. 
    • Innovation Norway has activities both inside and ouside the Norwegian boarders.
    "~"

    Innovation Norway was evaluated by the government in 2010
column11:
looking at the activity between 2004 and 2009. The evaluation report concludes that Innovation Norway contibutes to added value in Norway.

"~"

The 2010 evaluation report pointed out that Innovation Norway acts professionally when it comes to providing financial measures. The establishment of Innovation Norway though the merger of several different agencies has led to positive synergies.

"~"

The 2010 evaluation concluded that a greater proportion of the instruments should support innovation projects of national or international character. Its achievement would be strengthened if a larger proportion of its funds was made ​​available to enterprises in key districts.

\r\n

Innovation Norway only partly has become a knowlegde based organisation and a premise setter for national industrial policy. 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Norges Forskningsråd (NFR)~"The Research Council of Norway (RCN) "~"Norway"~"

The Research Council’s services are available to all companies that are already involved in or wish to conduct research activities.

"~"

The Research Council of Norway (NFR) is a strategic and funding agency for research activities
column2: as well as an important supplier of input into research policy for the government
column3:
the central government administration and the research community.

\r\n

A number of NFR activities are aimed at companies. They include
column4: among others
column5: innovation projects initiated by companies
column6: an industrial PhD project
column7: and the setting up of networks. In the case of innovation projects
column8:
the Research Council will finance up to 50% of costs involved. Funding is also available for the commercialision of findings.

\r\n

The Research Council offers a wide range of activities
column9: from start-up help to funding for more advanced research projects
column10:
network-building and centre schemes (establishment and operation of specially designated centres of research like The Centres for Research-based Innovation scheme). 

This includes:

  • Support for innovation projects 
  • User-driven Innovation Projects comprise some 80 % of the industry-oriented research projects receiving Research Council funding.
  • Tax deduction scheme - SkatteFUNN - where all types of companies may apply for a tax deduction for costs related to research and development.
"~"

No information available.

"~"

The research council was evaluated in 2012 - A Good Council? Evaluation of the Research Council of Norway.

The evaluation shows that user-directed R&D is a useful instrument to increase business expenditure on R&D. It leads to industrial innovation (enough of which is economically successful to generate significant private returns)
column11: generates important knowledge and capability spillovers and leads companies (especially smaller ones) to want to do more R&D. The private and public returns to industrial R&D are both high. While economists often like to speculate that state funding of industrial R&D will crowd out private investment and induce companies to invest in the wrong things (‘picking winners’)
column12: the evidence shows the opposite. NFRfunding ‘crowds in’ private investment; the private returns induced are about the same as companies get from their own investments in R&D; and the societal returns are higher. The fiscal incentive is a useful way to help small companies begin to do more R&D
column13: generating high private returns but limited externalities. As companies’ R&D expenditures rise
column14: NFR’s selective approach becomes more appropriate because it increases externalities
column15:
it can support agglomeration (including around national priorities) and it avoids the problem that larger companies tend to free ride on tax incentives.

"~"

The overall impression of the evaluation was that NFR is very good at reacting to defined needs and ‘serving its customers’ but less good at being proactive. It probably needs other mechanisms for tackling things that the customers do not yet know they need
column16: including the ability to do diagnostic and prospective studies
column17: fund small-scale
column18:
promising developments on its own initiative and consider explicitly addressing high-risk and interdisciplinary research. Its ‘change agent’ role could thus be stronger.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Eksportkreditt~"Export Credit Norway"~"Norway"~"

Everyone buying goods or services from Norwegian exporters.

"~"

Export Credits Norway (ECN) extends loans to large and small companies in Norway and abroad for purchases of capital goods and services from Norwegian exporters. 

\r\n

ECN is a limited liability company wholly owned by the Norwegian government. They finance export contracts ranging from a few million to several billion NOK
column2:
across sectors and worldwide. The loans comply with the OECD framework on officially supported export credits. 

ECN was established in 2012 and the establishment is based on a legal act. 

ECN offers financing with two types of interest rates:CIRR-loans with fixed rate and CIRR-qualified market loans with floating interest rates. The fixed rate is set by OECD.

Repayments vary from two to 18 years depending on the type of project. 

"~"

At the end of 2013 the loan portifolio was around NOK 50 billion (€6.25 billion).

"~"

The scheme enables Norwegian exporters to compete on equal terms as other exporters with access to national export credit schemes.

"~"

column1:
GIEK~"GIEK"~"Norway"~"

This is available to export companies
column2:
including those in the ship-building industry.

"~"

The aim of GIEK is to promote Norwegian export by providing guarantees on behalf of the Nowegian state. Foreign buyers often depend on taking up loans or seek other kinds of financing for investmenst in goods and services. Having a guarantee is often essential to get loans. GIEK can provide such guarantees in cases where goods and services are purchased from Norwegian suppliers.

\r\n

Guarantees are provided on commercial terms. It comprises different schemes including schemes for buyers and suppliers
column3: a special scheme for the ship-building industry (for bank loans needed when building a ship)
column4: one for industrial companies' agreements to purchase electricity (guarantees for long-term contracts)
column5:
a scheme for investments abroad and a scheme for the cost of tenders submitted to developing countries.

"~"

GIEK was evaluated in 2008
column6: see Evaluering av GIEK. The conclusions were that GIEK had contributed to Norwegian export
column7:
both contributing to contracting and increasing the total volume of export.

"~"

GIEK meets a need for guarantees
column8: especially for those exporting to more unsteady countries
column9:
and for SMEs. GIEK is especially important in cases of instability in financial markets. 

"~"

The evaluation pointed to some adjustments including the level of guarantees. GIEK only gave a maximum of 90% coverage
column10:
and the evaluation report suggested that this was raised to 100% where the guarantee is less than NOK 15 million (€1.9 million) .

\r\n

The evaluation report also pointed at the development in the risk taking. The portifolio is to a large extent directed to oil and gas and ship industry
column11:
making it vulnerable if those industries face difficult times. 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Norwegian Innovation Clusters~"Norwegian Innovation Clusters"~"Norway"~"

This relates to industrial business clusters containing companies competing internationally.

"~"

Norwegian Innovation Clusters (NIC) was established in June 2014 and continues the supply of services that until then had been given through the programmes Arena and Norwegian Centres of Expertise (NCE)
column2: as well as introducing a new programme Global Centres of Expertise (GCE). The aim of NIC is to set up and strengthen cooperative innovation projects in business clusters
column3:
focusing on increasing companies' ability to innovate and their competitiveness. NIC supports clusters at three levels.

\r\n

Arena: clusters in an early phase
The programme targets regional business communities that have a high concentration of companies within one industry
column4: value chain or area of expertise
column5: and that have relevant competence centres.There must be a potential for increased innovation and value creation by way of increased collaboration between these parties. The programme offers financial and professional support for implementation of three-year development projects. In special cases
column6: and on condition that they meet certain criteria
column7:
some projects can receive support for additional two years.

\r\n

The Arena programme can cofinance activities in process management
column8: analysis and strategy processes
column9: network building arenas
column10: communication initiatives
column11: early-phase idea and project development and learning initiatives. The financing can cover 50% of the costs of a project
column12: normally NOK 1.5 million to 2.5 millon a year (€190
column14: 000). Professional assistance is also offered through methods and tools for cluster development
column15: workshops and courses
column16:
project advice and more.

\r\n

NCE: well established clusters with a national position
The NCEs aim to develop the most important regional industrial clusters in Norway - those with good resources and established competitive advantages. This extends to companies whose core activity relates to the industry in question
column17: as well as to companies involved in related work. Main focus areas are increased innovation
column18: goal-oriented internationalisation
column19:
increase attractiveness as hosts for participating companies and access to tailored competence.

\r\n

Each NCE is knowledge-based
column20:
and includes development and financial actors who support the core companies’ development. Companies involved in an NCE may recieve support for a maximum period of 10 years.

\r\n

Funding can be given to the same type of activities as in the ARENA programme
column21:
and the funding principles are equal.

\r\n

GCE: well established clusters with a global position. Infomation on this is not yet available.

"~"

A total of 12 NCEs have been established. In 2012
column22: the NCEs involved 1
column23:
127 companies. 

\r\n

The ARENA programme has 28 ongoing projects. 

"~"

The NCE programme was evaluated in 2011
column24: where it states: 'The programme is solidly anchored in relevant cluster theory
column25: reaches its target group
column26:
and offers relevant support to participating business actors. The programme is on track to deliver on its objectives and has initiated and completed a number of activities likely to underpin the overall programme goals.'

"~"

The evaluation points at uncertainties relating to whether the initiated R&D and innovation projects reach their full potential through sufficient financing. An additional challenge for the programme is how to document impact on innovation.

\r\n

The programme would benefit from more consistent operationalisation of the target group profile.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Arbetsmarknadsutbildningar~"Labour market training "~"Sweden"~"

This is available to adults over 25 years old who are either unemployed or facing dismissal.

"~"

The aim is to strengthen the unemployed person’s capacity to find employment and to help employers to find people with the right skills. The training is vocational and lasts for a period of up to six months. There is a wide variety of courses within most professions. In October 2014 the Public Employment Service offered a total of 1
column2: 579 courses. All courses offered are free for the unemployed and reimbursement for attending the courses is often payed out. The reimbursement is called Aktivitetsstöd and it is based on what you would have gotten in unemployment insurance. This means that the reimbursement varies between SEK 680 (<span style=""font-size: 7.5pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Verdana
column3: sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"" lang=""EN-GB"">€ 76) and SEK 320 (
column4:
sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"" lang=""EN-GB"">€ 36) a day. 

"~"

In the beginning of the 2000's the effectiveness of labour market training increased but later on it has diminished and today the effectiveness is close to zero
column5:
which means that attending labour market training does not increase the participants possibilities getting a job (Arbetsförmedlingen 2014). A reason for this is according to the Public Employment Service (PES) is that the participants in labour market training is further from the labour market today than before and this affects the participants' abilities' to gain from the training. 

"~"

Labour market training is in theory a strategic instrument for facilitating structural change
column6:
increased mobility and higher productivity.    

"~"

This is the most cost-intensive of all labour market programmes in Sweden and the effectiveness is low.

"~"

Not applicable.

column1:
ALMI Företagspartner~"ALMI Företagspartner business enterprise"~"Sweden"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

This promotes the development of competitive SMEs and stimulates the development of new enterprises. Its aim is to create growth and innovation in Swedish business life. ALMI offers advice in four main areas - advice
column2: loans
column3: venture capital and incubation. ALMI offers corporate loans
column4: micro loans
column5:
financing for companies operating in international markets and tailored funding for innovators.

"~"

ALMI is organised as an enterprise and was founded in 1994
column6: with the aim of promoting the manufacturing sector. While it now stimulates growth and development in all sectors
column7: ALMI is still known best among companies in the manufacturing sector; 32% of companies in the manufacturing sector have had one
column8: several or regular communications with ALMI
column9:
compared to 16% of those in the services sector.

\r\n

ALMI’s clients typically have fewer than 20 employees. ALMI meets with approximately 100
column10: 000 clients each year and of these
column12: 000 become involved in extensive development programmes. ALMI also assists in the evaluation of approximately 3
column13: 500 new technology projects and products on an annual basis. It provides funding to about 2
column14:
000 innovations.

"~"

Almis' success factors include: its strong institutional background and long-standing reputation; its national system that is adapted to regional requirements; a transparent concept and active promotion of same through various instruments (with an emphasis on face-to-face communications with participating companies).

"~"

There are quite a number of support services available in Sweden. However
column15: micro
column16: small and sole trader businesses in Sweden still seem to make rather little use of the services available to them according to a study by Boter and Lundström (2005). The use of support services is clearly less common than in the other European Union Member States. The main reason why many Swedish enterprises do not use support services is that they do not see any need for external help. It was found in a study from 2002 that 86% of the companies do not see any benefits from participation in a support service for their business. Secondly
column17: 12% of entrepreneurs are not even aware of the existence of support services (European Commission Enterprise and Industry
column18:
2002).

"~"

column1:
Stöd till start av Näringsverksamhet~"Support for starting a business"~"Sweden"~"

This is available to adults over 25 years old who are registered as unemployed or who are facing dismissal and have an approved business concept. The following groups are also eligible for support. Adults aged 18 and assessed being far away from the labour market
column2:
young adults with disabilities that affects their possibilities to work and adults already in other labour market initiatives for unemployed offered by the Public Employment Service (Arbetsförmedlingen). 

\r\n

 

"~"

The purpose of this measure is to provide unemployed people or those faced with dismissals who are capable of starting a business with financial support during the start up phase. The support is given to people aged over 25 who have good qualifications to run a business
column3: adults aged 18 that are far from the labour market
column4: young adults with disibilities and other adults already in labour market initiatives for unemployed offered by the PES. In addition
column5:
the business must be expected to have a satisfactory level of profitability and to provide long-term job. The support is payed over a maximum duration of six months and the amout of support is based on what unemployment insurance the supported would be entitled to if unemployed. 

"~"

A total of 35
column6: 892 participants accessed the support for starting a business programme in 2013. Most of the newcomers are aged between 25 and 44 years. This programme normally has the best outcome
column7: in terms of employment figures
column8: of all activity support programmes in Sweden. In 2009
column9: 84% of those who left the programme were working
column10:
regardless of measurement period.

"~"

Support for starting a business has consistently shown very positive outcomes both in terms of entrepreneurship and employment. In addition
column11: companies that are established might
column12: in the long run
column13:
hire more people which will also have a positive effect on the employment rate.

"~"

Competition may arise when companies that obtained financial support to start a business obtain a competitive advantage over firms in the same industry that have not received support.

"~"

No information available.
