column1:
Turn Around Beratung (TAB)~"Consulting on business turnaround"~"Germany"~"

This is available to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

Business counselling is provided to SMEs that face the risk of a downturn in their business. The measure is administered by development bank KfW (Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau) in cooperation with regional partners (such as chambers of commerce
column2: crafts or public offices for economic development). The service is avaialble to companies and self-employed. Supported are consulting services strenghtening the competitiveness and the economic stability of the client. Clients wanting to apply for support need to have analysed their weak business points (mostly done with another measure called 'Round table'
column3:
also supported by pulic funds).

\r\n

Regional partners have to approve the application before KfW bank is granting any aids. Financial aids can amount for up to 75% or 50% of consulting fees in eastern and western Germany (maximum of €8
column4:
000 net fee and a daily fee of €800 for eight hours a day)."~"

This proactively supports SMEs in avoiding mismanagement and insolvencies.

"~"

An evaluation of the programme concludes that its goals are reached: 85% of the supported companies showed a positive development concerning their solvency and profit situation after the consulting. Every second company was able to safeguard jobs. Most aspects of the programme (application procedure
column5: timelines
column6: quality of offered consulting) are deemed as good by participants (PricewaterhouseCoopers
column7:
2013).

"~"

An evaluation of the programme shows that it is not yet well known amongst SMEs (PricewaterhouseCoopers
column8:
2013).

"~"

TAB example

column1:
Regionales Arbeitsmarktmonitoring~"Regional labour market monitor"~"Germany"~"

This gathers administrative data on the labour market.

"~"

Regional labour market monitors by the Federal Employment Agency aim at anticipating risks of unemployment and skilled labour shortages. They also aim to improve regional labour market initiatives and networking. They hold administrative data on topics such as qualifications and training levels
column2: forms of employment and unemployment rates. Monitors are run by the regional offices of the Federal Employment Agency at federal state level
column3:
and are supported by public administration and social partners. Provided data should help to develop joint strategies to tackle identified challenges e.g. skill shortages in the region.

"~"

Regional labour market monitors were first set up in the regions of Lüneburg
column4: Wetzlar
column5: Ortenau (Offenburg)
column6: before emerging in the the states of Thuringia
column7:
and Lower Saxony.

"~"

Provides comparabale regional data. Data is discussed by social partners and offers insight into regional developments.

"~"

Monitors include only around 20 indicators. However
column8:
the low number of indicators was chosen on purpose by the Federal Employment Agency in order to provide easy to understand comparable data. The agency recommends to use further statistics and sources for in-depth analysis.

"~"

Regional labour market monitors were first set up in the regions of Lüneburg
column9: Wetzlar
column10: Ortenau (Offenburg)
column11: before emerging in the the states of Thuringia
column12:
and Lower Saxony.

column1:
Arbeitszeitkonten~"Working time accounts"~"Germany"~"

This measure is available to all companies.

"~"

Working time accounts provide companies with leeway for reacting to short-term fluctuations in the demand for labour
column2: without having to abide by the procedures required for overtime or to pay financial supplements. Employees can ‘free up’ small amounts of time for various commitments outside of the workplace. Short-term accounts
column3: where the account balance is equalised over a one-year period
column4: are still the most prevalent form. Examples of these accounts include flexi-time accounts and overtime accounts. Long-term working time accounts can be used for a life-cycle oriented human resource policy
column5: e.g. saving up time for longer leave periods (e.g. for sabbaticals
column6: educational purposes or family care
column7:
transition from work to retirement).

"~"

Evaluation studies come to different conclusions on the usage of working time accounts: In 2009 and 2010
column8: about 45% of all businesses with a works council made use of working time accounts for safeguarding employment. Most of these were crisis-hit manufacturing firms (Zapf et al.
column9: 2011). Between 1999 and 2011
column10: the share of establishments using working time accounts rose from 18% to 34%. Bigger companies are using working time accounts more often than smaller one. In the same time span
column11: the share of employees having a working time account rose from 35% to 54% (Ellguth et al.
column12:
2013).

"~"

Between 2008 and 2010 this measure proved to be an instrument for safeguarding employment.

"~"

There is an uneven distribution across sectors and use of this measure has spread more slowly in the services and public sectors. Regulatory burdens to introduce long-term working time accounts are still too high.

"~"

Infraserv.

column1:
Lokale Bündnisse ~"Local/regional pacts and collaborations"~"Germany"~"

This is available at local level. Pacts are rarely developed at regional level.

"~"

Local or regional forms of cooperation typically involve regional authorities
column2: together with employers
column3: trade unions
column4: training institutions
column5: research institutions and the Federal Employment Agency. Forms of cooperation include pacts
column6: networks and initiatives. The actors agree on fostering specific issues
column7: such as regional development
column8: employment and training. During the economic crisis
column9: some pacts were formed to weather its effects. More recently
column10:
pacts have been set up to address issues relating to training or work–life balance. A range of measures can be agreed upon. Examples include:

  • support for continuous training in companies;
  • special incentives for companies retaining older workers;
  • more generous unemployment benefits to bridge a longer time period for job hunting;
  • re-industrialisation; and
column11:
\r\n
  • incentive packages for start-ups.
    • \r\n"~"

    Following changes in public finances (regional funding or national support
column12: municipalisation of unemployment benefit)
column13: a considerable number of local networks were set up. Strong focus is often placed on raising the competitiveness of the region or city. Trade union participation is in decline. New pacts on work–life balance or training have developed
column14:
involving trade unions.

"~"

Strengths include the cooporative effort involved and the participation of social partners in local economic policy development.

"~"

Without the presence of strong actors in the fields of social dialogue and regulations in the region concerned
column15: it becomes more difficult to reach binding agreements. Moreover
column16: negotiations are harder to carry out. For this reason
column17:
sectors and regions with lower levels of institutional employment regulation are at a disadvantage.

"~"

column1:
Gemeinschaftsaufgabe Verbesserung der regionalen Wirtschaftsstruktur~"Joint task for the improvement of the regional economic structure"~"Germany"~"

This applies to companies in specified regions that require support.

"~"

Under the Act on the Improvement of the Regional Economic Structure
column2: activities are carried out under a framework agreement between the federal government and the federal states (Gemeinschaftsaufgabe Verbesserung der regionalen Wirtschaftsstruktur
column3:
GA). GA identifies structurally weak regions applicable for EU funding and sets frameworks for regional aid and investment policies. Funding is provided to individual companies.

"~"

According to an evaluation of the programme (Bade and Alm
column5: more than 23
column6: 500 establishments with a total workforce of about 826
column8: received funding between 1998 and 2008 through this measure. Of these
column9: 80% were located in eastern Germany
column10: 38.4% had less than 10 employees
column11: and only 47 establishments had a workforce of more than 1
column12: 000. Most establishments (77%) operate in the manufacturing sector. Businesses that were most likely to receive support had a positive business profile
column13:
a history of research and development activities and staff with an above-average salary.

\r\n

A follow-up study looked into the effectiveness of the programme for larger companies (Bade
column14:
2013). Results show that nearly half of the investment grants went to companies with 250 or more employees.

"~"

Findings from evaluations indicate an increase in employment among supported businesses and a decrease in non-supported businesses.

\r\n

Supporting larger companies with grants has positive effects in structurally weak regions (spill-over effects in research and development and other areas needing human capital) (Bade
column15:
2013). Larger companies improve the competitiveness of weak regions. Employment figures of supported larger companies grew faster than in smaller ones.

"~"

The service sector is underrepesented.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Zentrales Innovationsprogramm Mittelstand (ZIM)~"Central Innovation Programme SME"~"Germany"~"

This applies to companies with up to 250 employees and annual sales of €50 million. It is also available to research institutions
column2:
company networks and project networks.

"~"

This is a federal programme to promote innovation and competitiveness among small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). This includes the crafts sector and self-employed individuals. Funding supports research and development
column3: market entrance of innovations
column4: networking of SMEs and joint projects
column5: as well as consultancy. It aims at fostering innovative products
column6: processes and organisations. Successful companies are awarded with the ZIM award each year. Current programme runs until the end of 2014. However
column7:
the coalition agreement of the latest Federal government announces the continuation of the programme after 2014.

"~"

\r\n
column8:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-bidi-font-family:""Times New Roman""; mso-bidi-theme-font:minor-bidi; mso-fareast-language:EN-US;} -->

\r\n

According to the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWi)
column9: the programme received about 38
column10: 700 applications (reporting date: 7 July 2014). Over 26
column11: 100 applicants were granted a subsidy. Most of them (around 19
column12:
000) were cooperation projects. Nearly €3.5 billion of subsidies were spent by July 2014.

\r\n

A survey of 6
column13: 148 participants whose project ended in 2011 shows that 45% of the projects were undertaken by small companies (10 to 49 employees)
column14: 25% by firms with 50 to 249 employees and 19% by companies with less than 10 employees. Very small companies had most often realised their project in cooperation. With regards to their motivation to apply for funding
column15:
92% of the surveyed solo-projects and 89% of the cooperation projects wanted to enter the market with their new product.

\r\n

At the end of 2012
column16: nearly half of the solo-projects and around one third of the cooperation projects had done so. It is expected that by the end of 2014
column17: both shares will rise and around 79% of the solo-projects and 63% of the cooperation projects will have made the product market entrance. Moreover
column18: positive effects are also shown for employment figures (in 60% of the cases)
column19:
increase in turnover (66%) and increasing exports (34%).

\r\n

 

"~"

Funding for innovation is made available for small and medium-sized companies which are often lacking financial resources. Technical or other innovation is made possible by funding.

"~"

More than half of the surveyed projects faced delays in market entrance. Reasons relate to underestimation in costs related to market entrance
column20: more time needed for market maturity or unforeseen technical difficulties. The ZIM-programme offers extra support for ZIM participants with regard to consultancy and other service needs (marketing
column21: strategy etc.). In 2011
column22:
only 40% of the ZIM participants had applied for funding for service support measures.

"~"

SolarCore (winner of ZIM 2010 award)

column1:
Nexxt-change Unternehmensbörse~"Nexxt-change (Exchange mechanism for people interested in business start-up and enterprise owners intending to sell their business) "~"Germany"~"

Targets small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

\r\n

 

\r\n

 

"~"

The aim of this instrument is to secure the transition of enterprises to new owners. In this way
column2: it contributes to securing and maintaining jobs. It is especially relevant in the current context
column3: when many enterprise owners are reaching retiring age. In practice
column4: regional centres (branches of local savings banks
column5:
local Chambers of Commerce and Industry or other institutions at local level) publish offers and organise/consult on the matching process. Networking events are arranged for future enterprise starters and those enterprise owners who did not manage to find a suitable successor.

\r\n

The amount of information on businesses that is publicly available in the database is restricted to a few facts in order to avoid a business being easily identified. The database can be searched by sector and location. The partners of the initiative organise seminars and other activities under the label ‘nexxt’. The aim here is to provide information about the generational change
column6: business start up/company formation and to show concrete ways of solving problems. Information on business sucession
column7: financing a business start-up and available funds are also available on the platform. General services  are provided free of charge
column8:
although a fee might apply to additional services provided by intermediaries.

"~"

Approximately 7
column9: 000 enterprise owners are currently seeking successors who are willing to take on their enterprises
column10: and capable of doing so. Roughly 3
column11:
000 people present themselves as interested in taking over an existing enterprise. About 800 local regional centres act as cooperation partners.

"~"

A study from IfM Bonn (Schlömer
column12: Kay 2008) highlights that nexxt-change involves a wide range of network partners. Offers are directed to both company owners looking for a sucessor and potential sucessors. Evaluation reserach (2013) shows that 'nexxt-change' gained in popularity; number of users rose between February 2011 (around 80
column13: 000  users) and June 2012 (nearly 100
column14: 000 users). The website was relaunched in Feburary 2011. A usability test of the website showed positive results (concerning design
column15: search tools and finding relevant information). Positive assessment of cost-benefit ratio in terms of published offers
column16:
successions and saved jobs as well as funds spent for the programme (also in comparison to similar publicly funded instruments).

\r\n

 

"~"

A study from the IfM Bonn (Schlömer
column17:
Kay 2008) shows that only 20.4% of company owners use online tools to look for a business successor; this compares to 46.8% who approach a consultant and 45.6% who go to a chamber of commerce or guild. Many company owners avoid publicity when looking for a potential sucessor.

\r\n

Evaluation research on the platform nexxt-change (2013) shows that monthly entries of new offers is decreasing. Since total number of offers remained fairly stable
column18: offers in the database get older. 61% of the platforms' clients seek more consulting support by regional partners on the topic of finding a succesor for their business. In addition
column19: the research shows that users wish for more information on offered companies. This would help the matching process. Around every fifth negotiation on business succession is succesful. However as the analysts highlight
column20:
the platform nexxt-change has only limited options to improve this rate. Negotiation failure are most often related to financing difficulties or different price ideas. This can only be improved by additional support instruments.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Agencia de Desarrollo Local - Barcelona Activa~"Local Development Agency - Barcelona Activa"~"Spain"~"

This is available to companies
column2:
employees and unemployed people from Barcelona.

"~"

Barcelona Activa is a municipal company of the city Council of Barcelona
column3: which was created in 1986 in order to cope with the economic restructuring that Barcelona was experiencing after the industrial crisis. Its aims are: to promote entrepreneurship; to support and promote business creation; to encourage a culture of entrepreneurship; and to stimulate innovation in SMEs. According their action plan 2008-2011
column4:
Barcelona Activa offers four main services:

  • business creation and entrepreneurship support;
  • innovative business consolidation and growth;
  • human capital development and new employment opportunities;
  • access to and improvement of employment.

A range of services are provided. Unemployed people can search for work for a three hour period
column5: with support from agency staff. A two-day seminar is held on innovation and sustainable change; this aims at encouraging the creative and flexible thinking processes within enterprises. Basic management tools are taught in three hour long courses. These courses address the issue of budgeting
column6: and show participants how to get the most use out of their financial resources
column7:
by means of planning and control tools. Three hour courses are also provided on conducting a job interview. Job seekers are showed the most common mistakes made in job interviews and are taught techniques to avoid making these mistakes.

"~"

In 2007
column8: almost 1
column9: 200 businesses received advice and monitoring support from one of the entrepreneurship programmes offered by the development agency. Over 700 companies were created
column10: representing 60% of new businesses. It is estimated that this leads to the creation of around 1
column11:
500 new jobs per year.

"~"

This instrument can anticipante and react to change. It has a reliable knowledge of the demands of employers
column12:
as well as of skill gaps in the workforce. It encourage the creation of enterprises in growing sectors and activities.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Barcelona Nord Technology Park.

column1:
Planes Estratégicos~"Strategic plans"~"Spain"~"

This is available to all companies.

"~"

The preparation of a strategic plan involves different partners and agents from public institutions
column2: civil society and trade union and employers’ organisations. The main aims of a strategic plan are to improve the competitiveness of local enterprises
column3: to encourage investment in innovative technology and to open external markets to local companies. However
column4: the goals set out in strategic plans vary
column5:
depending on the features of the city or region in question.

"~"

It is not possible to offer a general assessment of the plans due to the diversity found among those that are currently being implemented.

"~"

The plans are designed and implemented through a partnership approach. The plans identify the most potential economic sectors in the region
column6:
and encourage local enterprises to orient their activities towards these sectors.

"~"

Some plans do not include measures intended specifically for small and medium enterprises (SMEs)
column7:
which in Spain represent the greatest share of the enterprises.

"~"

Plan Estratégico Barcelona 2020

Plan Estratégico Valencia 2020.

column1:
Maisons de l'emploi~"Employment centres"~"France"~"

Coverage extends to specific regional areas.

"~"

Created in 2005
column2: this measure involves cooperation between public employment services
column3: the state and local administrations in employment matters. Their aim is to provide information
column4: orientation
column5: and support for people looking for a training or a job
column6: as well as maintaining and developing employment and activity
column7:
and helping in business creation/takeover. 

\r\n

In practice
column8: employment centres regroup different services for workers or jobseekers in one place
column9: such as for instance the employment agency
column10: the labour inspectorate
column11: an advice point for career orientation
column12:
etc.

\r\n

Since January 2014
column13:
their activities are focused on two guidelines: 

  • participating in the development of anticipating economic changes 
  • contributing to local employment development
"~"

The effectiveness of this instrument is not very clear. In 2014
column14: several employment centres have been closed due to government disengagement regarding funding. However
column15: at the same time
column16: the National Employment Council (which mainly defines strategic guidelines for employment policies) has stated that those structures provide efficient support and measures
column17:
and called for maintaining their funding. 

"~"

Employment strategies and initiatives are governed at regional level. Different stakeholders in the field of employment are involved. It leads to innovative and creative initiatives.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Paris' employment  centre

column1:
Commissaires au redressement productif ~"Commissioner to productive recovery"~"France"~"

There is one commissioner per region
column2:
i.e 22 commissioners in the whole country. 

"~"

Commissioners have a double mission at local level: 

  • intervene as a unique interlocutor for companies in difficulty in order to help solving those difficulties;
  • lead a regional committee for monitoring and early-warning in order to intervene upstream and find a viable solution. 

This instrument was developed during the economic recession in 2009. At that time
column3: 10 commissioners for reindustrialisation were appointed. In July 2012
column4: with the change in majority
column5:
those commissioners were renamed and their number increased. 

\r\n

In practice
column6:
commissioners provide support and advice for companies in difficulty and help them to find a solution at the local level.

"~"

In December 2012
column7: 368 files had been successfully processed. This represents approximately 48
column8:
116 jobs maintained. 

"~"

This instrument enables support to be targeted on specific regions that are experiencing difficulties. It also involves many relevant actors.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

CLESTRA in the Alsace region (700 jobs concerned) 

\r\n

Villemur Industries in the Midi-Pyrénées region (50 jobs concerned)

This instrument provides information on business creation and transfer

column5:
and individual consultation.

"~"

In 2013
column7: 883 individual contacts have been made. This number of contacts has been multiplied by 1.6 since 2010. 3
column8:
387 projects were identified. 

"~"

This instrument eases the process of selling/taking over a company at local level. 

"~"

It may duplicate with other similar instruments
column9: such as Transentreprises
column10:
that has a larger geographical scope. 

"~"

column1:
Uj Szechenyi Programm~"New Szechenyi programme"~"Hungary"~"

Coverage depends upon the government's employment strategy. SMEs support measures are mainstreamed and the application is made easier for SMEs.

"~"

The aim of the program is that of enhancing companies' competitiveness
column2: adaptability and workforce employability through the development of employees' skills and competencies. At the same time
column3:
an important purpose is that of pormoting those SMEs which are not able to implement these advancements by the use of their own resources.

\r\n

The framework programme was launched in February 2011. Recent priorities include: the health industry; green energy
column4: housing; entrepreneurship; development of infrastructure; innovation and science; and employability. It can be available to bodies such as companies
column5:
NGOs and regional centres.

"~"

Thanks to the programme
column6: more than 100
column7: 000 companies obtained more than 1
column8: 000 billion (3.5 billion euros). Out of the 216
column9: 000 applicants
column11:
000 received the card.

"~"

The programme guarantees an easy and fast procedure. Over the last few years the programme has granted access o bank credits nothwithstanding the general credit crunch.

"~"

Prior to launching this instrument in February 2011
column12:
social partners were only involved on a consultative basis. No calls have been made to further involve the social partners.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Ταμείο για την Προστασία των Δικαιωμάτων των Εργοδοτουμένων σε περίπτωση Αφερεγγυότητας του Εργοδότη ~"Fund for the protection of employees' rights in case of employer insolvency"~"Cyprus"~"

The legislation for the protection of employees rights in case of employer insolvency covers workers against bankruptcies. In particular
column2:
all outstanding payments by employers to employees are safeguarded by a special fund established for this particular purpose.

Excluded are workers that:

  • have special links and common interests with their employer
column3:
amounting to collusion between employee and employer;\r\n
  • employees who are shareholders and members of the board of directors
column4: employees of the naval
column5:
military and air forces of the UK government;
  • employees who not habitually reside in Cyprus;
  • employees who alone or with first generation relatives own a substantial part of the business;
  • officers working for the government.
    • "~"

    The employee is entitled to the following payments from the fund:

    • all unclaimed wages due from the employer for the last 13 weeks of employment
column6:
occurring within a period of the last 78 weeks up until the date the employer's insolvency commenced;
  • the equivalent of all unclaimed paid leave for the abovementioned 13 weeks (in the event that the employer possesses a certificate of exemption from payment of contributions to the Central Holidays Fund);
  • the equivalent of the thirteenth and fourteenth salary or the wages of the 53rd–54th weeks for the same period.

    • The fund is financed exclusively by employer contributions (0.2% of gross salaries).

    "~"

    Between 2006 and 2009
column7: about 15 applications have been registered
column8:
and claims of about 130 workers were satisfied.

"~"

This instrument creates financial reserves in a period of high economic growth.

"~"

During the recession
column9:
the funds' reserves decline.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Töötukassa töövahendus~"Employment mediation service by Unemployment Insurance Fund"~"Estonia"~"

Employment mediation is available to all employers who access the Unemployment Insurance Fund in order to find new employees. Employment mediation is available to all persons who are registered as unemployed or are seeking employment through the Unemployment Insurance Fund.

"~"

Employment mediation is free of charge for employers. Employers can either publish their job offer on the website of the the Unemployment Insurance Fund for all interested parties to see. Alternatively
column2: they can ask the Unemployment Insurance Fund to select appropriate candidates
column3: according to specific job requirements. In the latter case
column4: the Unemployment Insurance Fund can either motivate suitable employees to apply for the job being offered
column5:
or it can forward the contact details of suitable persons to potential new employers.

"~"

No information is available on the proportion of participating job seekers or employers who benefit from this service. No analysis has been conducted on the effectiveness of this service. One study of reaction services to collective redundancies indicated that supporting direct links between employers and those who had been made redundant was the most effective measure in this situation. However
column6: the analysis was undertaken at a period of economic growth. In the current labour market context
column7:
results could be different.

"~"

All persons registered with the Unemployment Insurance Fund can benefit from the job mediation service.

"~"

Not many employers see the Unemployment Insurance Fund as a potential source of suitable staff. A recent survey among the clients of the Unemployment Insurance Fund indicated that just 31% of all employers who are clients use the job mediation service. Although the number has increased over the years (in 2010 it was 23%
column10:
employers should be more informed of this opportunity.

"~"

No information available.

column1: ΛΑΕΚ, Λογαριασμός για την Απασχόληση και την Επαγγελματική Κατάρτιση~"LAEK
column2:
Special Fund for the Employment and Vocational Training"~"Greece"~"

The trained personnel have to be insured by IKA.

"~"

Every year
column3: the LAEK management committee draws up its annual programme for allocating and managing funds from LAEK
column4:
covering the training programmes for staff in the eligible bodies. Enterprises can use these funds to cover the cost of training programmes for their staff. LAEK programmes take place either on-site in businesses or in educational units. They can be wholly theoretical or can consist of a theoretical part (70% of the total training hours) and a practical part (30% of the total training hours). The programmes can take place outside or within hours of work. Businesses entitled to LAEK funding may be private enterprises or semi-state bodies that want their staff to be trained. It is worth noting that LAEK also has programmes that offer training opportunities for employees in enterprises with 1-25 employees.

\r\n
column5:
since 1 July 2014 the resources foreseen for LAEK (that constitute resources of the Uniform Fund for the Implementation of Social Policies (ELEKP)) are modulated from 0.81% to 0.46% as follows:
  • Employer’s contribution of 0.24% in favour of the Special Fund for Programmes on Vocational Training and Education (ELPEKE)
  • Employer’s contribution of 0.12% in favour of Special Unified Fund for Unemployment (EKLA)
  • Employee’s contribution of 0.10% in favour of Special Unified Fund for Unemployment (EKLA)

column1:
Sectorale opleidingsfondsen/fonds des formation professionnelle~"Sectoral training funds (STF)"~"Belgium"~"

Coverage extends to the following sectors: hotel
column2: restaurant and catering (horeca); metal; textile; food; insurance; construction; confection; wood; electricity; transport; and banking. This list is not exhaustive. Funds are available to people employed in different sectors (the main target group of the activities for most STFs)
column3:
and professional and technical education students; the latter is due to increasing attention being paid to the extent to which educational qualifications 'fit' employment requirements.

"~"

Belgian employers and employee organisations agreed
column4: in the intersectoral agreement of 1988
column5: to spend 0.18% of the gross wage of all wage and income earners on training and employment support initiatives for specific
column6: at-risk groups
column7: namely young people and those who are long-term unemployed
column8:
with problematic professional qualifications.

\r\n

The percentage of the contribution has since fluctuated and different percentages have been introduced for different sectors
column9: varying from 0.10% to as much as 0.60% of the gross wage. Some Belgian STFs are only active at regional level
column10: while others operate at federal level. Training sessions are available in Dutch and in French. Most STFs organise information and promotion campaigns in which a certain profession or training is presented. Special training is also organised for teachers in professional and technical education
column11: with a view to establishing a better fit between education and the skills needs of companies
column12: so as to benefit both students and companies. Several training activities are pursued for unemployed people; these are often complemented by practical training opportunities in companies
column13: and mediation activities
column14:
whereby these activities are carried out in cooperation with official training institutions.

\r\n

STFs tend to focus their activities on specific unemployed groups
column15: such as those with low educational qualifications
column16: older people and young people
column17: as previously defined by the governing bodies of the STFs. Special attention is also paid to some groups of employees
column18: such as those with low skill levels
column19: older employees and those in danger of losing their job or having to change employment because of restructuring plans. In addition
column20: employers are also becoming a target group for the Belgian STFs
column21: which provide them with advice and support around issues such as developing training plans or corporate training policies. The general rule is that training for employees takes place during working hours. If not
column22:
compensation is paid in the form of ‘educational vacation’ and/or an extra financial incentive.

"~"

STFs have a clear added value in the Belgian vocational training system.

"~"

The activities aimed at students increase both their awareness of the different sectors and their employability prospects
column23: making sure the competences learned at school are those needed in a business environment.  A match takes place between schools and other training providers and the needs of employers. There is a high level of diversity across STFs
column24: making it possible for them to react to the specific structures and needs of each sector. A good level of cooperation also exists between the different STFs themselves
column25:
and between the STFs and other training partners (e.g. private or public training organisations). This clearly increases the efficiency and effectiveness of the existing vocational training system.

"~"

Belgian STFs might endanger the existence of private training providers as the STFs usually offer free training; this could force private training suppliers out of the market or to become mere subcontractors to the STFs. In the long term
column26: this can constitute a threat to the availability of high quality training
column27: as competition is often the basis for achieving efficiency
column29: in the end
column30:
quality.

\r\n

STFs seem to fail to access small and medium enterprises (SMEs). Employers sometimes see contributions for training as an additional burden to the already high employment costs in Belgium.

"~"

Fund for vocational training in the construction sector (FVB)

Cevora.

column1:
Fundación Tripartita para la Formación en el Empleo~"Tripartite foundation for training in employment"~"Spain"~"

This is available to people in employment and to those who are unemployed.

"~"

The main goal of the Tripartite Foundation is to foster and extend training initiatives among enterprises and workers. These initiatives reflect the needs of participants and contribute to developing the Spanish economy from a knowledge-based economy perspective.

Additional goals include:

  • to provide lifelong-learning training of workers
column2:
improving their professional capacities in addition to fostering personal promotion;
  • to provide workers with adequate knowledge and practices to match the requirements of the labour market;
  • to improve enterprises’ productivity and competitiveness;
  • to help the employability of unemployed workers
column3:
especially those with major difficulties in joining the labour market;\r\n
  • to promote formal accreditation of vocational skills acquired during formal and non-formal training routes
column4:
and to promote training activities linked to the national catalogue of professional qualifications (Catálogo nacional de cualificaciones profesionales).\r\n\r\n

The Foundation is financed by public funds that stem from a range of sources. One is the vocational training levy (cuota de formación profesional) paid by companies and employees to the general treasury of the social security. Companies may try to recover part of it by applying for grants to fund its training efforts. This levy percentage is annually established by the Law of the State general budget. In 2004
column5: it was 0.35% of total wages; in 2005 it rose to 0.42%. About 75% of the available resources come from the vocational training levy
column6: although this percentage varies from year to year. In recent years
column7:
this figure has increased as a consequence of significantly increased Spanish employment. The European Structural Fund (ESF) is a second funding source. This accounts for about 22-23% of funding.

\r\n

The foundation provides two kinds of activities. One is that of ongoing training events within enterprises. Here
column8: the foundation supports general or specific training initiatives that have been planned
column9: organised and managed by enterprises themselves for their workers. This support is either provided on an individual basis
column10: or collectively
column11: for group of enterprises. In the latter case
column12: the companies concerned may or may not belong to the same sector
column13:
though they will share the same training needs.

\r\n

The second form of training support is that of individual training leave. This is authorised by the enterprise
column14: allowing individual workers to carry out
column15: during working time
column16: an officially-recognised training activity
column17: with no direct cost for the enterprise. Demand-driven schemes are financed by 'continuing training credits' (bonificaciones para la formación continua). These credits are available for the enterprises involved in training activities that pay the vocational training levy and result in discounts in social security contributions (cotizaciones a la seguridad social)
column18: up to a specified maximum. The calculation of the total credit an enterprise is eligible for is based on the application of either a fixed amount or a percentage (annually established by the Law of State General Budget) of the amount provided by the enterprise in the previous year’s compulsory vocational training levy. The credit is made effective through a reduction in the social security contributions paid by enterprises in the current year. The enterprises granting individual training leaves have an additional training credit for training initiatives
column19: which comprise
column20: on average
column21: as an additional 5%. These demand-driven schemes require that participating enterprises jointly finance training events. This is waived in cases of individual training leave
column22: or of enterprises with fewer than 10 workers
column23: however
column24:
in order to facilitate the smaller enterprises' access to training activities.

"~"

Over time
column25: the number of trained participants trained has grown progressively. For example
column26: in 1993 there were about 300
column27: 000 trained workers
column28:
compared to 1.7 million in 2006.  The number of women and non-qualified workers who have taken part in training events has increased. The instrument is mainly used by large companies.

"~"

This instrument has had a positive effect on social dialogue in Spain. It is a very flexible measure
column29: and focuses on the personal promotion and employability of individual workers. Moreover
column30:
it has helped to increase the amount of existing public funds available for training purposes; this is a result of regional authorities becoming interested in supporting these activities with their own resources.

"~"

It clearly benefits large enterprises. Some training provisions tend to focus on relatively broad issues
column32:
health and safety and computers. It is not properly linked to specific sector training needs and output is often only measured by ‘attendance’; there is a lack of information on the effectiveness of the foundation.

"~"

Labour foundation of construction (Fundación laboral de la construcción
column33: FLC); Foundation of metal for training
column34: qualification and employment (<em>Fundación del metal para la Formación
column36:
FMF).

column1:
Organismes collecteurs paritaires agréés (OPCAs)~"Joint registered collecting agencies"~"France"~"

Coverage extends to all professional fields.

"~"

Joint registered collecting agencies (hereafter OPCAs) are bodies in charge of collecting funds for professional training and of financing vocational training. 

\r\n

Contributions for professional training are mandatory
column2: irrespective of the size of the company
column3:
and funds are pooled by the OPCAs. 

\r\n

To perform these tasks
column4: OPCAs must obtain an autohorisation from the government
column5: which will be granted on the basis of their financial capacity and their management performance
column6: as well as their committment regarding governance transparency
column7:
publishing accounts and respect of a good practices charter. 

\r\n

OPCAs are jointly managed by a management board and must be able to collect at least € 100 million contributions annually. 

\r\n

In France
column8: the law states that compulsory contributions to training development must be equal to 1.6% of the total payroll in companies with 20 employees or more
column9: 1.05% for enterprises with 10 to 19 employees and 0.55% for enterprises with fewer than 10 employees. Enterprises with more than 20 employees must also pay 0.2% of their total payroll to a training fund dedicated to individual training leave. Enterprises may decide to fulfil this obligation by spending this minimum compulsory amount on training. In such cases
column10: expenditure is proven through the official annual accounts and a fiscal form
column11: called 'declaration fiscale 2483'
column12: on which all the company’s annual training expenditure is presented. Alternatively
column13: they can pay all or part of the mandatory contribution to the representative of the OPCA
column14:
which then manages its available resources for financing training initiatives within enterprises.

\r\n

The gross contribution of enterprises is divided into two or three separate funds
column15: each dedicated to different forms of training
column16: including training plans
column17:
contributions to sectoral priorities and individual training leave. Allocations are as follows:

  • enterprises with fewer than 10 employees devote 0.4% to the training plan and the remaining 0.15% is contributed to sectoral priorities;
  • enterprises with 10 to 19 employees devote 0.9% to the training plan and the remaining 0.15% is contributed to sectoral priorities;
  • enterprises with 20 or more employees devote 0.9% to the training plan
column18:
0.5% to sectoral priorities and the remaining 0.2% to individual training leave.\r\n\r\n

The main task of the OPCAs’ boards is to collect and allocate available funds
column19: depending on priorities defined by the national committee for vocational training in each sector. In some cases
column20: OPCAs may define priorities themselves. In some cases
column21:
sectors have set up an observatory (independent of the OPCA) to anticipate training needs and priorities. These observatories also help to define priorities.

"~"

Those sectors that are characterised by SMEs or companies in difficulty (due
column22: for example
column23: to large restructuring processes) tend to transfer their training resources to their respective OPCAs. This makes them become more active in promoting competences
column24:
skills and mobility.

\r\n

In 2011
column25: about 40 OPCAs existed. Following a reorganisation in 2012
column26:
there are now 21 OPCAs in France. 

"~"

This instrument involves a consensus among social partners.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Go international!~"Go international!"~"Austria"~"

Coverage extends to all enterprises that intend to establish export relationships for the first time
column2:
or to open up new markets abroad. There is a particular focus on small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

Support programmes are structured around the instrument's five clusters: 

  • Cluster 1: How to do business abroad (motivation of SMEs to start exporting)
  • Cluster 2: Strengthen strengths (to accompany world champions in their respective niche to new markets)
  • Cluster 3: Exporting know-how (export support of the services sector)
  • Cluster 4: From exporting to integrated value-chains (FDI in growth markets)
  • Cluster 5: Communicating Austria (creation of a modern image of Austria abroad) 

Support is provided in relation to: market access and market development; developing intelligent strategies in respect to international business entry; human resources and know-how; and improving framework conditions. It also involves the provision of information
column3: consultancy
column4: training
column5: guided trips to promising markets
column6: aid in networking and establishing contacts
column7: advice regarding the target market (local guidance)
column8:
and financial support.

\r\n

Much of this is particularly relevant for small firms. In particular
column9:
SMEs benefit from the following services:

  • intelligence-gathering trips to neighbouring markets;
  • individual export training for small businesses branching into exports for the first time;
  • support for Austrian stands at international trade fairs; and
  • a 'getting started with exporting' package tailored especially to small firms.

Potential exporters can also take a test of their 'fitness' to export.

"~"

This instrument has been successful.

"~"

The initiative's visibility among its target group is considered to be high. The decision-making process takes place within a short timeframe. It has the support of approximately 100 economic chamber offices worldwide
column10:
in 73 countries. Its implementation is both simple and flexible.

"~"

column1:
Volontariat International en Entreprises (VIE)~"International Voluntary Service in Companies"~"France"~"

This is available to workers aged up to 28 years.

"~"

This enables French companies to send a young employee
column2: aged up to 28 years
column3: on a professional posting abroad. The length of time involved can range between six and 24 months
column4: and can be renewed once. The company decides on the work involved
column5: which can relate to the control of management
column6: finance
column7: international business or sales. The following sectors most commonly avail of VIE: mechanical
column8: electronics
column9: computing/telecommunications; automotive
column10: banking
column11: energy
column12:
construction and trade-distribution.

\r\n

Participating companies are exempt from any direct contractual link
column13: the contract being signed between UBIFRANCE and the young. Specific measures are suggested to SMEs: support by big groups and companies of international standing (from the hosting to the follow-up of the VIE during his mission) or the possibility of sponsoring
column14:
through the network of foreign trade advisers.

\r\n

The cost of the VIE depends on the turnover of the exporting company and of the country of destination. The company pays for associated costs. The monthly allowance of the employee varies between €1
column15: 300 to €3
column16: 700 a month
column17: depending on the country. In addition to this
column18: monthly expenses relating to management and social welfare range between €215 to €420
column19: according to the business figure and the number of VIEs. Costs can be covered by a COFACE business development insurance policy
column20: whose objective is to encourage companies to seek new foreign markets. In some cases
column21:
companies are eligible for regional grants which cover part of the cost. Using a VIE allows small businesses to take advantage of a tax reduction offered to SMEs which incur export business development costs when exploring new foreign markets.

"~"

On 31 January 2014
column22: a total of 8
column23: 048  employees were in international voluntary service
column24: for 1
column25: 770 companies. Since this instrument began in 2001
column26: approximately 30
column27:
347 VIEs have been completed.

"~"

This allows for an active presence of French companies in the foreign markets
column28:
at a minimal cost. Minimal administration is involved. It is considered as a good alternative to expatriation.

Services include: a web portal with basic and up to date  information for internationalisation beginners; consultancy and support in organising participation in international trade fairs and/or visits to fairs; training on international business (including international seminars

column1: Bildungsfreibetrag, Bildungsprämie ~"Allowance for training expenses
column2:
training tax credit"~"Austria"~"

This is available to all employees and all employers.

"~"

Austrian employers can claim an extra tax allowance for training expenses (Bildungsfreibetrag). The incentive takes the form of an extra deduction from taxable income. Deductions comprise 120% of the actual cost of the training. For example
column3: if a training initiative costs €1
column5: the company could deduct €1
column6:
200 from their taxable income. The final saving then depends on the marginal tax rate applied to the €200.

\r\n

Alternatively
column7: employers can access the training tax credit (Bildungsprämie) which covers 6% of the total cost of the training measure. Companies that do not make enough profit to benefit from the 120% tax allowance can claim this tax credit. The training credit has to be claimed within the employer’s tax return and is deducted from tax liability
column8:
so it can be regarded as a direct tax credit.

\r\n

Activities supported by the tax incentives include any training carried out for employees that is of relevance to the interest of the business. Employer training expenses which primarily serve the interests of the employee are not eligible. Neither are training measures in the form of auxiliary services (such as introductory training for a new machine). For training carried out by external providers
column9: applicable costs include course fees
column10: trainer fees
column11: and rent charges for training spaces and learning materials. Accommodation and travel costs are not eligible. The provider of external training has to be an organisation or institution with a significant business activity in education and training. Regarding in-house training measures
column12: training must be comparable to an independent division of a business
column13: and must not provide training services for external people (non-employees). The training facility must have a degree of independence and organisational isolation. The training measures must have formal content and they must be organised. Eligible expenses include direct costs of the respective training measure (such as remunerations and rent charges) and indirectly assignable expenses (such as fixed costs and depreciations). The expenses per internal measure must not exceed €2
column14: 000 per day. There is no tax credit applicable to in-house training; in such cases
column15:
only the tax allowance can be used.

"~"

When introduced in 2000
column16: the government estimated that these incentives would lead to a loss of tax revenues of about €22 million. For 2008
column17: this loss was estimated to be approximately €30 million. The tax credit accounts for two thirds of the loss
column18:
and the tax allowance for one third. Austrian employer organisations value the extra tax allowance as a significant instrument  that reinforces the importance of firm-based training within a lifelong learning strategy.

"~"

Strengths include the low administrative/redtape costs involved
column19: both for government as well as businesses
column20: and the absence of market-related distortions. The 6% tax credit (which is an alternative to the 20% extra tax allowance) is regarded as particularly advantageous for start-ups
column21:
as they often do not have profits.

"~"

No comprehensive evaluation has been conducted of this instrument. Not all firms are aware of these incentives. Deadweight losses are likely
column22: as large firms in particular are likely to carry out training
column23:
even without tax incentives. Disadvantaged groups are not targeted.

"~"

No information available.

businesses interested in doing business in Cyprus

The Cyprus Investment Promotion Agency (CIPA) operates as a full-service centre for companies exploring investment opportunities in Cyprus. It constitutes the central agency of information

Its objectives are as follows:

  • to constitute itself as a central agency for the provision of information and support to interested investors;
  • to develop and implement an investment promotion strategy;
  • to liaise with any governmental
column6: semi-governmental

column9: services
column10: agencies and authorities
column11: with a view to facilitating the process for granting any necessary permits
column12: approvals

column1:
Vaeksthusene~"Regional Business Development Centres"~"Denmark"~"

This is available to new and smaller businesses that have a potential for growth.

"~"

Since 2007
column2: five regionally based business development centres
column3: known as the Vaeksthuse
column4: have been providing assistance to new and smaller businesses with potential for growth. The Vaeksthuse are owned by the 98 Danish municipalities. During a transitory period
column5: they have been financed by an allocation from the state. Since January 2011
column6: the Vaeksthuse have been entirely under the aegis of the municipalities. A Vaeksthus works with enterprises to identify potential areas of growth and refers to private service providers such as banks
column7:
accountants and lawyers and to a large number of public actors who may help the enterprises to realise their potential.

\r\n

The Vaeksthus also acts as project operator of initiatives with regional or EU funding
column8: developing new opportunities and knowledge to the benefit of enterprises. A Vaeksthus is staffed with experienced advisers and coaches
column9: often with an executive background from private companies
column10: but also with representatives from a wide range of stakeholders. The Vaeksthuse collaborate closely with the local public business service; in many cases
column11:
this service refers enterprises to the Vaeksthus for more focused advice.

\r\n

This cooperation is facilitated by a joint CRM-system
column12: Væksthusene on-line (at www.startvaekst.dk). This offers a number of tools for enterprises and service providers. The Danish Authority for Enterprise and Construction holds an annual contract with each Væksthus. This sets out specific quantitative targets in areas such as coaching
column13: cooperation with other relevant players (both public and private)
column14: and effects on employment
column15:
turnover and exports.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Enterprises benefit from a 360 degree mapping of their potential for development
column16: challenges ahead
column17:
and tailor-made support offers for their further development.

"~"

Many enterprises with growth ambitions do not seek advice to realise their potential
column18: particularly not from public service providers. For this reason
column19:
a challenge arises in terms of reaching target group enterprises.

column1:
Vaekstguiden~"Guide to growth"~"Denmark"~"

This is available to all companies.

"~"

The internet portal 'Guide to Growth' offers entrepreneurs the missing link between their needs and the initiatives from all parts of the public sector
column2:
including all regional and EU initiatives. Version 1.0 includes 170 initiatives encompassing counselling and financial facilities. Future versions are expected to include private initiatives as well.

\r\n

The Guide to Growth is an internet portal containing all significant public services. This includes initiatives
column3: funding and programmes designed to support growth
column4: innovation and development among private businesses. The internet portal is built with several gateways to search for relevant initiatives. This includes a guide in which the company enters information about the business (such as its size
column5: date of founding
column6:
current growth activities and support needs) and get precise search results that reflect the needs of the company.

\r\n

A call centre is also provided. This supports users in using the portal. The call centre also gathers knowledge from both the users and the public organisations that administrate the different public services
column7: so that the portal can be developed in a focused and relevant way. Ultimately
column8:
this dialogue between the public administrators and the companies concerned can help develop a common understanding of the balance between services on offer and concrete company needs.

column1:
Innovation voucher programme~"Innovation voucher programme"~"Ireland"~"

This is available to small limited companies. These companies are defined as those with less than 50 employees and an annual turnover and/or an annual balance sheet total not exceeding €10 million. Companies must have a company registration number in order to access this programme; an exception is made  for those in the transportation and agricultural sectors.

"~"

Vouchers of €5
column2: 000 can be exchanged for knowledge transfer projects from the knowledge provider. Knowledge transfer projects are defined as those involving the transfer of knowledge of a scientific
column3: technological or innovative nature that it is new to the small enterprise. The small enterprise may then use the new knowledge for many purposes. For example
column4: they may use it to innovate a product
column5: process or service
column6: to develop a new business model
column7:
or to access tailored training in innovation management.

\r\n

Every year
column8: five invitations for applications are made. In addition
column9: two new application routes have been set up. A 'fast track' application allows the companies to apply for a voucher outside the usual invitations. In order to take this route
column10:
the company must have identified the knowledge provider with whom they will collaborate and the project must be completed within six months. The second new route is that of a 'pooled voucher'. This allows up to 10 companies to pool or combine their individual vouchers on a single project. A list of knowledge providers is provided on the Enterprise Ireland webpage.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The bureaucracy involved is as light as possible. The grant is a welcome boost to struggling small companies that would otherwise find it difficult to access the knowledge providers. Enterprise Ireland has put pressure on the knowledge providers to be proactive in engaging with the companies and to facilitate them where possible.

"~"

This is available to craft enterprises in the sectors of machinery
column2: construction
column3: mechanics
column4: food
column5:
fashion and health.

"~"

In the Innovation Club
column6: craft enterprises meet regularly to exchange experiences about innovation in management
column7: marketing
column8: and technical areas. Participants are invited from different sectors to promote the exchange of best practices between sectors. Every meeting is organised around a specific topic; examples include creativity
column9:
financing and technology transfer. Topics are usually of general relevance to all sectors. The club can also discuss a specific innovation project of one of the members.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Visits or meetings can be organised for members if they find they need additional services
column10: such as support around making national or international contacts. Every session is followed by a drinks reception
column11:
in order to facilitate networking. Subjects that are addressed are of direct concern to all the participants from the different sectors. The number of participants is limited to ensure effective discussions.

Prêt de Reprise~"Transfer loan"~"Luxembourg"~"

This is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

This loan finances assets within the framework of a business transfer. The business being transferred must be an SME
column2: and 15% of own funds are required to finance the transfer. All expenses and costs are eligible. The minimum loan is €5
column3: 000. The loan may not exceed 40% of the eligible amount and may not exceed €250
column4: 000. The normal period for the loan reimbursement is between 10 and 14 years
column5:
depending on which assets are part of the business transfer.

column1:
Forsknings-og utviklingskontrakter (IFU)~"Norwegian Industrial Research and Development Contracts (IRD)"~"Norway"~"

This is mainly available to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

"~"

An industrial research and development contract is a binding agreement between two or more companies to cooperate in the development of a new state-of-the-art product
column2: process or service. The customer must be a market leader
column3:
professionally acknowledged and with a broad market access. The parties themselves define the contents in such a way that they get the maximum benefit from the support scheme.

\r\n

An IRD contract can only be granted to projects of an exceptional level of innovation and value creation
column4: clearly defined market potential and high additionality. It enables SMEs with high growth potential to penetrate international markets with new and innovative solutions. The IRD scheme provides grants to research and development projects where a SME supplier teams up with a demanding
column5:
larger and preferably international customer. The originality of the IRD relies in the fact that it allows SMEs to match technology and market driven innovation processes by supporting technological development with a clear international market potential. A typical IRD projects runs for 1-3 years.

The grant given is equal to those laid down in the EEA framework Pilots can receive 40 to 50 % funding depending on the size of the company while research and development projects can receive from 25 to 45 % funding. No partner can contribute less than 20 %.

Funding can consist as a combination of grants and loans to cover:

 

  • personell costs;
  • expenses to equipment and buildings
column6:
counselling;
  • administration expenses;
  • and more.

    •  

    "~"

    In recent years
column7:
more than 200 projects have annually received an IRD funding. An external evaluation of 10 years of the IRD shows that over 80 % of the projects were technologically successful. It also found that over 44 % of the IRD projects had developed a new product or service that had penetrated the targeted markets. The projects involve an international customer in more than 25 % of the cases.

"~"

column1:
Företagsakuten~"Company helpline"~"Sweden"~"

Coverage extends to the Region Västra Götaland
column2:
Värmland and Jönköping. The helpline is available to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that are facing insolvency and have less than 20 employees.

"~"

The company helpline (företagsakuten) provides an established and well-functioning method for helping enterprises facing insolvency. It offers advice and negotiation assistance to SMEs that are suffering crisis; this is mainly of an economic or legal nature. For example
column3: the expert advice can help SMEs to avoid bankruptcy. The helpline gives five hours of consultation free of charge. In some cases
column4: this is sufficient to get them back on track. If not
column5: companies can request further assistance
column6:
from reconstructuring agencies and auditors that belong to the network of the helpline service. Each case is treated confidentially.

The helpline is led and driven by qualified and competent staff. All cases are treated confidentially and anonymously. Up to five hours of consultation are povided free of charge.

column1:
Passport to Export~"Passport to Export"~"United Kingdom"~"

Passport to Export is available to businesses in England
column2: Scotland
column3: Wales and Northern Ireland whose proactive exports do not exceed 10% of turnover and whose combined proactive and reactive exports do not exceed 25% of its turnover. Coverage extends to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) that are research and development (R&D) intensive
column4:
aged between one and five years that may have been 'born global' and hence do not meet the ‘new to export’ criteria.

"~"

The Passport to Export service from UK Trade & Investment is delivered locally by international trade advisers (ITAs) with private sector experience
column5: based in UK regions. Exporters are assigned local UKTI trade experts to work with. The service lasts twelve months and provides a flexible programme of support including:  a detailed assessment of readiness to export
column6: an action plan for export activity
column7: workshops on stages of exporting
column8: help with market research and visits to target markets
column9: event networking and tradeshow opportunities
column10: advice and guidance from International Trade Advisers (ITAs).  While advice to clients is free
column11: clients may have to contribute to the cost of activities in their activity plan. In addition
column12: free advice is provided from up to three UKTI offices overseas and advice on other UKTI services
column13: as appropriate. A small amount of matched funding is also available for activities agreed in the action plan. This may include non-government services if appropriate. To ensure quality of delivery and that all the aspects of the programme are delivered
column14:
an ‘audit’ is carried out every six months.

"~"

Annual report of the UK Export Finance provided £2.3 million (€2.9 million on 20 August 2014) of support to UK exporters to help businesses achieve sustainable growth in the financial year ending 31 March 2014. Given its aims
column15: the key measures for Passport to Export are whether it boosts exports and export activity amongst SMEs by providing the gateway to overseas sales growth. To this end
column16: Passport to Export has provided services to around 14
column17:
000 companies since 2001.   

"~"
column18: sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"">Passport to Export’s strength
column19: as with the other export support schemes provided by UKTI
column20: lies in helping companies in the early stage of their preparation for development of exporting. Its advisers and teams are regarded as a good source of information and support in this regard. According to data reported by a UK
column21: sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"">Parliamentary select committee
column22: sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"">
column23: sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"">from the quarterly Performance and Impact Monitoring Survey (PIMS)
column24:
73% of SMEs using Passport to Export had improved business performance as a result of that use and a 2012 evaluation gave Passport to Export an 87% quality rating. Witnesses to the select committee also rated ITAs as highly competent and knowledgeable. 

\r\n

 

"~"

Users of the service note that companies have to initiate contact with the scheme and would prefer UKTI to be proactive
column25: instead contacting companies to offer their services. With this lack of proactiveness
column26: many SMEs
column27: it is claimed
column29: by extension
column30: of Passport to Export and the services it offers. Moreover
column31: whilst Passport to Export is acknowledged to be good at supporting companies in the early stages of exporting
column32: follow-through with these companies appears not to exist
column33: which companies involved in the scheme lament. SMEs would like to see continued support beyond that early stage. However there is debate about whether
column34: at a time of government cutbacks
column35:
this shift would divert resources from supporting early stage support.

"~"

column1:
Насърчаване на заетостта на 'зелени работни места'~"Promotion of employment in ‘green workplaces’ "~"Bulgaria"~"

This measure is available to people who are unemployed
column2: registered at the labour office (the registration should be maintained for not less than 6 months). The employers from specific sectors
column3:
as laid out in the list of sectors approved by the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy and the Ministry of Environment and Waters could hire unemployed for environmentally friendly economic activities related to the production of goods and the provision of services in support of environmental protection.

"~"

In 2014
column4: for each unemployed person for the time that he/she was working
column5:
but not more than 6 months (no more than 8 months for employees in positions requiring a tertiary qualification or degree higher education) the 'green jobs' programme covers from the state budget:

  • Remuneration amounting to 340 BGN (€173.83) per month
  • Additional compensation of the minimum amounts set out in the Labour Code and regulations for its implementation
  • Remuneration of paid annual leave under Art. 155 or 319 of the Labour Code
  • Remuneration of Art. 40
column6:
para. 5 Social Security Code (e.g. paying social security for the first three days of temporary disability at the amount of 70% of the average daily gross pay for the month)
  • Contributions payable by the employer in accordance with Art. 30
column7: paragraph 1
column8: items 4 and 5 of the Employment Promotion Law for the funds 'Pensions'
column9: 'Occupational accidents and diseases'
column10: 'Health Insurance Fund'
column11: '<span>Unemployment Fund'
column12:
etc.
\r\n\r\n

This measure sets up subsidised 'green workplaces' for no more than 6 months (or no more than 8 months for persons employed in positions that require a third level of qualification or higher education) in companies providing services and products that protect the environment
column13:
in line with the European Green Agenda and Europe 2020.

\r\n

A total of BGN 3
column17: 876) are allocated to this measure. At the end of 2010
column18: the Minister of Labour and the Minister of Environment and Waters approved the list of economic activities and positions eligible under the measure. In late March 2011
column19:
the local branches of the National Employment Agency started to approve the applications of employers intending to establish green workplaces.

\r\n

The state budget reallocated to the 'green workplaces' programme in 2014 will be 472
column20: 132 BGN (€241
column21: 397) in order to ensure employment of 276 unemployed people
column22: 100 of them newly recruited individuals (i.e. employed under the measure of the Operative Programme
column23:
not having previous relationships with the same employer).

\r\n

column1:
Servicii de preconcediere – Legea nr. 76/2002 privind sistemul asigurărilor pentru şomaj şi stimularea ocupării forţei de muncă~"Pre-redundancy counsellling services - Law no. 76/2002 on unemployment benefit and employment stimulation"~"Romania"~"

This is available to employees who are to be made redundant
column2: and to every person who is at risk of losing their job and requests this service (art. 51
column3: 52 from the Law 76/2002). Although the law does not explicitly stipulate what category of employees are ""at risk of becoming unemployed""
column4:
it is considered in principle that they are employees who received notice or are targeted for future restructuring.

\r\n

These measures are effective prior dismissal. According to existing legislation
column5:
the employer is obliged to inform their local employment service at least 30 days before notifiying workers that they are to be made redundant.

"~"

This pre-redundancy counselling service
column6: which is regulated by law
column7:
involves the following:

  • informing workers of local job vacancies;
  • listening to the opinions of these workers
column8:
and counselling them;\r\n
  • briefing them on how to look for a job;
    • \r\n
  • identifying available vocational readjustment opportunities in the same company
column9:
and/or providing short-term training courses. "~"

According to data from the 'Quarterly statistical bulletin on labour and social protection'
column11: from 1 January to 30 September 2010
column12: a total of 53
column13:
235 people gained employment via the information and counselling services provided by local employment services.

\r\n

In 2013
column14: there were 22
column15: 791 persons affected by redundancies
column16:
of which 8145 persons received pre-redundancy counselling services. The average time an information session was 82.38 minutes.
An important indicator in the pre-redundancy counselling services is the placement on existing vacancies locally and training in ways of searching for a job. Of the total persons assisted in 2013 (8145 persons)
column17:
7430 persons were trained in searching of employment and 725 people were referred to various measures to stimulate employment.
From monitoring indicators of outplacement transmitted by territorial agencies
column18:
it follows that the number of people employed within 30 days after the dismissal was in 2013 of 172 persons and those attending training courses was 256 people.

\r\n

 

"~"

The local agencies for employment are notified 30 days before dismissal takes place; this provides an opportunity to avoid or minimise the effects of the dismissals at local level. The employees have free acces to public employment services before the dismissal takes place.

"~"

The main weakness of this measure is the lack of employment opportunities at local level.

column1:
Bureau de conciliation~"Conciliation office"~"Belgium"~"

Coverage extends to companies that are members of a sectoral joint commitee with its own conciliation office.

"~"

Most sectoral joint commitees have a conciliation office. In cases of conflict
column2: as can arise during restructuring
column3: each party can appeal to this office for conciliation. The office is made up of employers' and workers' representatives. Firstly
column4: the office listens to the applicant party's version of events. After this
column5: it hears the view of the other party. Following this
column6: members of the office may request additional information; at this point
column7: they cannot express an opinion. When the members of the office have listened to both parties
column8: they begin to deliberate. If they reach a unanimous opinion
column9: this is convey by non-binding recommendations. If a unanimous opinion is not reach
column10:
the conflict situation continues; this can involve events such as strike and lock outs.

column1:
Teadmiste ja oskuste arendamise toetus~"Grant for the development of knowledge and skills in companies"~"Estonia"~"

Applicants for this grant may be self-employed persons or companies registered in Estonia. Other eligible applicants include non-profit associations
column2: foundations
column3: association of companies or professional associations
column4: business incubators or country development centres
column5:
in cases where companies are the beneficiaries of the support.

"~"

The aim of this grant is to raise the level of knowledge and skills among employees and managers in companies
column6: thus helping to improve their competitiveness. The grant can be applied to projects lasting a maximum of 12 months that aim to develop skills and knowledge in different fields; this can include management training
column7: professional in-service training
column8: participation in professional conferences outside Estonia
column9: and the use of counselling services. Eligible projects must cost a minimum of €2
column11: and up to 50% of these costs are funded. Since November 2010 a ceiling for the grant has been set at €64
column12:
000 per project.

"~"

According to monitoring data
column13: the grant is popular among enterprises. In 2009
column14: funding provided totalled €2.36 million. In that year
column15:
the total number of projects that received funding exceeded the planned number.

\r\n

In 2012
column16: 9
column17:
638 persons participated in training activities financed under the measure. 

\r\n

 

"~"

The measure is popular among enterprises. Implementation has been faster than expected
column18:
in terms of the total number  of projects that have been funded to date.

"~"

As a result of this measure's popularity
column19: some training projects have not reflected the aims of this source of funding. Consequently
column20:
some projects had little or no impact on knowledge levels and skills among employees in enterprises. Information events have been planned to address this question.

"~"

Not applicable.
