column6: Ukraine
column7: Japan
column8:
USA and China. Part of the work of these foreign divisions is to attract foreign investments into Estonia by organising events to potential investors and providing counselling. Potential investors are also served through a website.

\r\n

Foreign divisions are engaged in developing the reputation of Estonia in these countries. The objective of the reputation-creating events organised by Enterprise Estonia is to achieve a better reputation of the Estonian economic environment in the target countries. Some examples of the reputation-creating activities include advertisements in foreign presses
column9: arranged visits for journalists
column10: trade fairs
column11:
contact days  and presentations at the seminars.

"~"

According to a research study conducted in 2008
column12: the brand used by Enterprise Estonia for marketing purposes is not well known in target countries. It was most well known in Finland; there
column13: 16% of respondents had seen the brand. In 2009
column14: Enterprise Estonia served more than 50 potential investors and included 20 new foreign investments. In 2009
column15: 64 events regarding the reputation of Estonia were organised with the participaiton of Enterprise Estonia. Several documents on Estonia were also published. Over 2009
column16: the webpage had 52
column17: 000 visitors. A total of 95 queries on investments were filed. In 2013
column18:
Enterprise Estonia included 26 new foreign investments.

"~"

Enterprise Estonia is actively working on broadening its network of activities and on increasing its level of active participation in events.

"~"

One identified risk is that the quality of work conducted with clients might deteriorate as the number of queries made by potential investors to the foreign divisions increases. In order to address this
column19:
there are plans to increase the number of staff. 

\r\n

In addition
column20: with increasing wage costs in Estonia
column21:
debate has been raised as to what competitve advantage Estonia has in attracting foreign investments. An activity plan called 'Made in Estonia' has been introduced to address these questions and to target activities that aim to attract foreign investments.

"~"

column1:
KredExi ettevõtluse valdkonna meetmed~"Entrepreneurship related measures by the Credit and Export Guarantee Fund KredEx"~"Estonia"~"

This start-up loan is targeted at small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and self-employed persons that have been active for up to three years. A business loan guarantee is not limited to a particular type of enterprise
column2: although some specific areas of activity are excluded. The subordinated loan is meant for sustainable companies that are growth-oriented
column3: but which banks are not ready to finance due to low rates of self-financing
column4:
operating in a 'risky' sector or insufficient collateral.

"~"

KredEx provides five main entrepreneurship related measures. Start-up loans can finance investments and working capital of starting businesses
column5:
enabling fast growth and development.

\r\n

A start-up loan will help a company that has just started out or has a short credit history and whose collateral assets are either difficult to estimate or are not sufficient for a bank loan. The entrepreneur is responsible for the loan: the joint and several liability corresponds to 30%-40% of the loan amount. In case of guarantee
column6: KredEx will take secondary responsibility. If a business plan fails and the entrepreneurs are not able to manage the loan
column7:
their surety will be used before other steps are taken.

\r\n

The second measure is a business loan guarantee. This enables a guarantee of investment and working capital loans
column8: leasing transactions and bank guarantees. KredEx prefers to guarantee projects that result in a company expanding
column9:
with new jobs being created or a growth in export.

\r\n

The third measures is a subordinated loan. This is meant for sustainable companies that are growth-oriented and which banks are not prepared  to finance due to their low rate of self-financing
column10: operating in a 'risky' sector or having insufficient collateral. KredEx provides capital for the entrepreneur to use. Subordinated loans will conditionally enhance an enterprise’s equity capital before the eyes of the bank which
column11: in turn
column12: enables the enterprise to borrow additional amounts and to develop more quickly. In addition to providing financing that would be otherwise unavailable
column13: the KredEx does not interfere in the management of the enterprise
column14:
unlike the case with risk capital funds.

\r\n

The fourth measure is technology loan is designed for export-oriented enterprises in the areas of processing industry
column15: mining industry
column16: production
column17: transfer and distribution of electrical energy and waste processing and disposal
column18: investing into machines and devices. Technology loan helps if a bank loan or leasing is used for an investment
column19:
but the entrepreneur lacks the required capital for self-financing.

\r\n

The fifth measure is meant for companies wishing to finance large-scale export transactions of goods manufactured in Estonia. The export loan helps if a company wishes to offer a long payment term to a foreign buyer
column20:
pay a credit insurance premium or finance the production of goods to be sold to a foreign buyer.

 

 

 

"~"

According to KredEx
column22: a total of €54.7 million was provided to 111 enterprises. These years also saw a large increase in KredEx loan guarantees
column23: indicating that this has been an important source of access to financing for many companies during the recession. In 2010
column24: the highest share of KredEx loan and guarantees have been used in wood processing (11%)
column25:
construction (10%) and metal industry (9%).

"~"

Opportunities to access KredEx loan guarantees were increased during the recession; this has provided companies with better access to financing.

"~"

The support package introduced in the recession was only temporary. There is a need for an assessment of the impact of these changes. Since no recent assessment has been conducted on the package that was introduced in the recession
column26:
it is difficult to point out any specific strength or weakness.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Bedriftsintern opplæring (BIO)~"In-house training (BIO)"~"Norway"~"

No restrictions apply to accessing this training programme.

"~"

The aim of the BIO scheme is to prevent employees from being excluded from the labour market in connection with restructuring processes. By the BIO scheme employees can rise their competence. The BIO scheme has traditionally been invoked in connection with major restructuring processes
column2: where they are seen to have substantial labour market effects; an example would be a cornerstone company facing major financial challenges. Companies can apply for cofunding for training measures to ease the restructuring process
column3: and contibution to wage expenses. The training may be related to changes in production methods
column4: transition to new products or services
column5:
changes in manufacturing equipment. 

\r\n

The training period for participants should as a rule not exceed 13 weeks and should include theory. 

\r\n

The funding should as a main rule not exceed 25% for large companies and 35% for SMEs when it comes to special training (training targeting the existing position). General training
column6: that is training that is not mainly targeting the existing work place
column7:
could recive up to 50% funding. 

Funding may include:

 

  • expenses to teachers;
  • travelling exenses for teachers and participants;
  • equipment necessary for training purposes;
  • expenses to counselling related to training;
  • wages for participants.

 

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The scheme can be used as an alternativ to temporary and permanent lay offs.

This instrument is available to the following groups: people who are unemployed; workers who were made redundant as a result of restructuring
column2:
during their notice period; people who are looking for a job and are receiving social benefits.

"~"

These programmes are primarily designed to upgrade the skills of people who are threatened by the risk of long-term unemployment due to low qualifications. The programmes aim at supporting the creation of jobs for participants (including training and assistance in active job searches
column3: vocational counselling
column4:
job broking services).

\r\n

The programmes provide funding for: maintening jobs
column5: for example
column6:
by covering the cost of salaries and insurances; employees' travel costs; participants’ accommodation; workplace equipment; participants’ training costs. They also provide loans to employers and other financial support for job creation.

\r\n

The main objectives of the programmes are: to support job creation for the people participating in the programme
column7: enhancing the participants' employability
column8:
professional activation of the participants of the programmes.

According to available information
column9: only a small number of Poviat Employment Agencies run these programmes. In 2011 the special programmes were run in 42 Poviat Employment Agency (12.4% of all agencies)
column10: while in 2012 the programmes were run in almost 50% of the Poviat Employment Agencies. According to the ministerial report
column12: 142 people participated to the programmes in 2011-2012 (6
column13: 681 persons in 2011 and 14
column14:
461 persons in 2012). The main reason for this is a low interest among Poviat Employment Agencies and employers.

"~"

The measure responds to the identified needs of local labour market. The programmes might be combined with other programmes/measures.

"~"

These programmes have led to the development of very few initiatives. Indeed for many public employment scheme (PES) and companies
column15:

column1:
Program wspierania inwestycji o istotnym znaczeniu dla gospodarki polskiej na lata 2011-2020~"Programme for supporting investments of major importance to the Polish economy for years 2011-2020"~"Poland"~"

This instrument is available to companies operating in the following technologically advanced sectors: automotives
column2: electronics
column3: aviation
column4: modern services (IT services
column5: financial services
column6: accounting and other back-office services)
column7:
research and development and biotechnology.

"~"

The scheme provides financial support for foreign investors carrying out new investments in Poland. The main objective of the scheme is to boost innovation and productivity of the Polish economy by increasing the inflow of technologically advanced investments and creating highly productive jobs. Support is provided in the form of a grant on the basis of a bilateral agreement concluded between the Minister of Economy and the investor
column8: pursuant to the Council of Ministers’ resolution on the establishment of a multi-annual programme of support for the completion of the investment. The agreement between the Ministry of Economy and the investor may be concluded for up to five years.  The agreement lays down detailed conditions for the payment of the grant whilst respecting the principle that the grant is paid proportionately to the degree of fulfilling one’s commitments. The state aid awarded under the scheme falls under the category of regional ad hoc aid and therefore it must
column9: as a general rule
column10:
be notified to the European Commission before it is granted. The level and amount of support for new investment having innovative potential ranges from 30% to 70% of the value of eligible expenditure across to maximum permitted levels of aid across individual regions. The maximum permitted level of aid granted for new investment projects in the sector of business services (such as shared service centres or IT centres) may not exceed 30% of expenditure eligible for support.

"~"

The Council of Ministers has funded 59 multi-annual programmes for supporting investments for the period 2004-2009. In 2009
column11: 40 agreements were signed. A total of 30
column12: 500 new workplaces are expected to be created and about PLN 9
column13: 500 million (EUR 2
column14: 257 million). In 2012
column15: 11 bilateral agreements with investors were signed. 3
column16: 378 new workplaces are expected to be created and PLN 56
column17: 760 million (EUR 13
column18:
488 million) were granted for the support in 2012.

\r\n

In 2013
column19: the Ministry of Economy signed 22 agreements with investors. A total of 7
column20: 398 new workplaces are expected to be created. The amount of support was PLN 69
column21: 341 million (EUR 16
column22:
478 million).

"~"

The measure provides support for greenfield and high-tech investments that improve the competitiveness of the country’s economy.

"~"

The measure is only designed for foreign companies.

"~"

column1:
Specjalne strefy ekonomiczne~"Special economic zones (SEZ)"~"Poland"~"

Coverage extends to all companies and individuals
column2:
excluding several types of business activity defined in the Ordinances of the Council of Ministers: Dz.U. 2008 nr 232 poz. 1548; Dz.U. 2010 nr 15 poz. 78.

\r\n

 

"~"

The Special economic zone (Specjalne Strefy ekonomiczne
column3: SSE) is a region in the Republic of Poland where business activities can be conducted on special
column4: preferential conditions
column5: defined both in the Law on Special Economic Zones (Dz.U. z 2007 r. nr 42
column6:
poz. 273) and in the Ordinance of the Council of Ministers on establishing SSE in a specified region.

The aims of the special economic zones are:

  • to accelerate the economic development of regions; manage post-industrial property and infrastructure;
  • to create new jobs; and
  • to attract foreign investors to Poland.

All companies and persons have to meet the defined conditions for obtaining a business permit to operate within SSE. These include: the specified amount of investment; share of own resources of total investment costs; maintenance of the investment in the region from the end of the whole investment; and maintenance of the employment level for a specified period of time.

The basic benefit of investing in a special economic zone is the possibility of obtaining a tax allowance consisting in a corporate income tax exemption. Currently
column7: the corporate income tax rate in Poland is 19%. The maximum income tax exemption is related to the value of state aid available to an individual investor for a particular investment project. This value depends on the investment location
column8: the size of the enterprise and the amount of investment expenditure. For large enterprises
column9: it comprises 30-50% of eligible costs.  For medium-sized enterprises
column10:
it ranges between 40-60% of eligible costs. The value for small enterprises is between 50-70% of eligible costs.

\r\n

This state aid may be granted for setting up a new investment and/or creating new workplaces. The investors can freely choose the aid they want to obtain and benefit from. They receive support until the full amount of the state aid is used
column11:
although this can be  for no longer than the time specified in Ordinance of the Council of Ministers on establishing SSE in specified region.

Currently there are 14 special economic zones in Poland (list)

The companies investing within the SSE can use public help consisting in income tax exemption due to the:

  • costs of the new investment
  • creation of jobs

To be able to use this help a company is required to:

  • be operational for no less than 5 years. In case of SME - for 3 years; 
  • maintain the same structure of the ownership of the company's assets as the one to which investment spendings were related - for 5 years. In case of SME - for 3 years.

 

 

"~"

During both 2006 and 2007
column12: investors poured around PLN 10 billion a year into Poland's special economic zones. In 2007
column13: this resulted in 25% growth in employment
column14: representing 36
column15: 000 new jobs in the zones alone. Unofficial data indicate that in the first half of 2008 companies declared record-breaking investments – around PLN 7 billion (EUR 1.75 billion) in total. Consequently
column16: for many zones this was the best six months of their existence. It is estimated that total investment in all 14 SSEs reached around PLN 50 billion (EUR 12.5 billion) in 2008. At the end of 2007
column17: some 7
column18: 500 hectares of land were being used as SSEs. Following the 2008 amendment to SSE legislation
column19: over 12
column20: 000 hectares still remain available. According to the report
column21: the total capital expenditures made in all the special economic zones in Poland amounted to PLN 6.449 billion (EUR 1.61 billion) in 2011. According to the responses of SSE management boards
column22: capital expenditures should have increased by approximately 13% in 2012
column23: reaching PLN 7.3 billion (EUR 1.82 billion). The number of people employed in special economic zones exceeded 240
column24: 000 in 2011 and rose by 7% compared to 2010. The report shows that in 2011 the number of respondents who rated their SEZ positively dropped by four percentage points (78%). There was also a decrease in the share of companies negatively assessing the operation of their SSE. Only 4% of those surveyed expressed a negative view
column25:
whereas the respective percentage in the previous year's study was 7%.

"~"

SSEs improve the competitiveness of the entire country’s economy and the economy of specific regions
column26: transferring technologies and know-how
column27: as well as developing cooperation in regions covered by the zones. Furthermore
column28:
they lead to the creation of relatively large numbers of new workplaces.

"~"

Workplaces that have been created through SSEs have developed a bad reputation
column29: in terms of social security and the level of wages
column31: strict regulations can cause difficulties. The most important difficulties are as follow: the cost of entering into a SSE; the obligation to maintain the employment level for a specified period of time and to invest strict amount of money
column33: for example economic downturn; the need to move enterprise's headquarter and/or offices to sometimes distant locations. For smaller enterprises
column34: due to a scale of their operations
column35:
presence in SSE may be even more difficult.

\r\n

"~"

Saint-Gobain; Fiat Powertrain Technologies Poland; Dell; and Procter & Gamble; Mondi Packaging Paper Świecie and Sharp; Swedwood Poland; LG Electronics; Shell Polska; and Rockwool Polska.

Ταμείο για Πλεονάζον Προσωπικό~"Redundancy Fund"~"Cyprus"~"

In accordance with the Termination of Employment Law
column2:
employees who have been working for the same employer for more than 104 weeks are entitled to payments from the Redundancy Fund. It should be noted that the Redundancy Fund is not a restructuring-specific instrument; it is available both for collective and individual redundancies.

"~"

Redundant employees get redundancy payments from the Redundancy Fund. The amount paid by the fund depends on the duration of employment and the earnings of the redundant employee. Compensation from the fund serves to sustain the standard of living while searching for another job or as initial funding towards self-employment. The fund is funded by employers' contributions
column3:
at 1.2% of the employee's earnings.

"~"

The effectiveness of this tool is recognised by social partners and public sector executives.

"~"

One of the advantages of the Redundancy Fund is its creation of financial reserves in a period of high economic growth (high income and low payments due to low unemployment rates). The financial reserves of the fund amounted to €286.4 million in 2009
column4:
and €246.8 million in 2008.

"~"

During the recession
column5:
financial reserves are declining.

"~"

Cyprus Airlines.

column1:
Bérgarancia Alap~"Wage Guarantee Fund "~"Hungary"~"

This is available to employees of companies in liquidation. Applied by online.

\r\n

The law does not provide a definition of insolvency
column2:
but it referes to the definition of the Act IL of 1991

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Bankruptcy proceedings are proceedings in the course of which the debtor petitions
column3: for the purpose of reaching a composition agreement
column4:
to have his debts rescheduled or attempts to have a composition agreement concluded.\r\n
  • Liquidation proceedings are proceedings executed for the satisfaction of creditors as prescribed by this Act upon the dissolution of an insolvent debtor without legal successor.
    • \r\n
  • Voluntary dissolution proceedings are proceedings in the course of which solvent economic organisations
column5: having resolved their dissolution without legal successor
column6:
satisfy their creditors.\r\n"~"

Liquidation expenses shall cover wages and other personal costs payable by the debtor
column7:
including:

  • severance pay due upon termination of employment and any other benefits established in the collective agreement or in the contract of employment;
  • wages and other benefits to be paid under a temporary agency agreement
column8:
for which wages and other benefits are part of the agreement between the temporary agency and user undertaking in cases in which the user undertaking is the debtor;

The following accrued payroll (wage costs) of the undertaking under liquidation may be advanced in wage of guarantee proceedings (reimbursed by the wage fund):

  • wage debt of undertaking (as the employer);
  • wage debt of a temporary agency (as the employer) from the fee which is agreed in the contract between the temporary agency and the user undertaking;
  • wage debt of a school cooperative (as the employer) from the fee which is agreed in the contract between the school cooperative and user undertaking.

After the starting date of the liquidation the Hungary-based company can apply the reimbursment of wages straight on the day of normal wage transfer
column9: if the employee(s) work in Hungary
column10: did not conclude the contract with the company within the least half year
column11:
is/are not a relative (according to the civil law). Foreign companies cannot apply for reimbursement.

\r\n

There is a standard form to be filled in and submitted in three official copies. The authority decides within 8 days about the application. Transfers are set from the Fund within 15 days after the authority’s decision. The payment is reimbursable by the company but free of interest. The liquidator transfers the wages to the employees within 3 days after receiving the money from the Fund.

\r\n

The actual unpaid wages have to be applied for by the employer
column12: but it cannot be more than five times the statistical annual gross average wage in the second year before the given year (HUF 1
column15: about € 3
column16:
600).

\r\n

The Fund is finaced by the social contribution funds of employees and emplyers to be paid as a wage supplement
column17: the central budget
column18: additional fund providing emplyment
column19:
EU funds etc.

"~"

According to the Ministry of National Economy there were as HUF 4 billion (€ 13 million) paid from the Fund in the first eight months of 2013 but the budget is HUF 6 billion (€ 18 million).

"~"

relatively fast money transfer for affected employees (within 15 days)

"~"

The Wage Guarantee Fund to pay for the unpaid wages. This includes salary
column20: compensation and severance associated with the period of sick leave. Max paid amount is around a yearly minimum wage (HUF 1.200.000
column21:
EUR 4000). 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Garantinis fondas~"Guarantee Fund "~"Lithuania"~"

According to the Labour Code
column2:
the employer shall be deemed insolvent when bankruptcy procedure is used in respect of him and in other cases provided by law.

\r\n

According to the Enterprise Bankruptcy Law
column3: i<span lang=""EN-GB"">nsolvency of an enterprise means the state of an enterprise when it fails to discharge its obligations (pay debts
column4: carry out works paid for in advance
column5: etc.) and the overdue liabilities of the enterprise (debts
column6: unperformed works
column7:
etc.) are in excess of half of the value of the assets entered in the enterprise’s balance sheet.

"~"

In cases of the employer’s insolvency the claims of the employee relating to employment relationships shall be met by the guarantee institution - the Guarantee Fund.

\r\n

Creditors of an enterprise inter alia are employees of the enterprise - in the event of non-payment of remuneration and compensation for damage arising from employment relations.

\r\n

Upon termination of the employment contract
column8:
the dismissed employee shall be paid severance pay in the amount of his two average monthly salaries.

\r\n

If the enterprise in insolvency lacks the necessary funds
column9:
the administrator shall apply to the Guarantee Fund.

Employee can claim for:

  • wage compensation
column10:
equal up to three average wages in the country; \r\n
  • cash compensation for an unused annual holiday
column11:
equal to the minimum monthly wage; \r\n
  • severance pay
column12:
equal to two minimum monthly wages; \r\n
  • payment for idle time
column13:
equal up to the minimum monthly wage; \r\n
  • pay for the damage caused by occupational accidents or diseases
column14:
as foreseen in the Law on damage compensation in accident at work or occupational disease cases.\r\n\r\n

The Guarantee Fund is financed from employers' contributions (equal to 0.2%) and other sources: Privatisation Fund
column15:
state budget and other resources.

\r\n

The Guarantee Fund is supervised by the Guarantee Fund Council
column16:
consisting of representatives of employees' and employers' organisations and state institutions.

"~"

On average
column17: per year more than 10
column18: 000 employees receive benefits from the Guarantee Fund. However
column19: during the crisis this figure doubled or even tripled (in 2009
column20: the number of beneficiaries was close to 6
column22: whereas in 2010 about 20
column23: 400 and in 2011 about 28
column24: 100; since then this figure is decreasing - in 2012 14
column25: 100 employees received benefits from the Guarantee Fund
column29: LTL 32 million (€9 million) were paid for benefits in Lithuania from the Guarantee Fund.<span style=""color: #1f497d; font-family: "Calibri"
column30:
"sans-serif"; font-size: 11pt;"">

"~"

This is seen as the last resort for the workers of bankrupt enterprises. It provides income support for workers of these companies.

"~"

The benefits paid by the Guarantee Fund are very low.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Garančný fond~"Guarantee Fund "~"Slovakia"~"

All workers with an employment relationship that lasted at least 18 months before the insolvency/the last working day
column2: including fixed-term contracts and part-time workers are eligible
column3: but not employees of the state
column4: public organisations
column5: support organisations
column6:
national funds and municipalities as well as Slovak workers in a family business who have not entered an employment relationship and domestic workers who work for their family relatives without having entered into employment relationship.

\r\n

An employer is considered insolvent if it was filed for insolvency at court.

"~"

The guarantee covers non-paid wages
column7: bonuses
column8: holiday remuneration
column9:
severance payments and travel expenses.

\r\n

There is a maximum benefit covering employee´s claims for three months.

\r\n

To guarantee the claims
column10:
the employee has to apply for it within 60 days after realisation of insolvency or termination of the employment relationship.

\r\n

The Social Insurance Company which administers the Guarantee Fund has to decide/pay within 60 days about the application.

\r\n

The fund is financed by employers’ contributions.

"~"

During the economic crisis
column11: the number of beneficiaries has increased
column12: but all expenditure can be covered. Revenue comes from the insurance paid by employers. While this is not very high
column13: neither are the benefits paid to employees. The increase in claims was not very high
column14:
as companies want to remain active rather than going bankrupt.

"~"

This instrument ensures compensation for employees who have not been paid by their employer
column15:
in cases where a company has become bankrupt.

"~"

Wage compensation is limited to a three month period.

aide à l'investissement pour PME artisanales ou commerciales~"Support of investments for craft and trade SMEs"~"Luxembourg"~"

This is available to craft and trade small and medium enterprises (SMEs)
column2:
and to engineers and architects during the first three years of their business.

"~"

This instrument up to 10% of the eligible costs involved in the following developments:

  • the establishment of a new subsidiary or the modernisation of existing subsidiaries;
  • investments made due to a fundamental change in the product or the production process;
  • investments made due to the reactivation of a subsidiary that was previously closed or would be closed without this investment.

It also support up to 20% of the eligible costs of investments relating to technology transfer. Examples here include the purchase of licences
column3:
patents and other ‘know-how’ related transactions.

column1:
Ostanak u zaposlenosti – sufinanciranje zapošljavanja kod drugog poslodavca~"Employment continuation – subsidising employment with another employer"~"Croatia"~"

This measure is designed for those who have been made redundant and have started to work with another employer. The subsidy is approved for a maximum of 12 months to all employees over the age of 50
column2: the disabled and members of specific groups of society who were made redundant due to business restructuring and now work for another employer
column3: regardless of the size of their new employer's company. However
column4:
the maximum amount of the annual subsidy is limited according to the size of the new employer and the employees' level of formal education.

\r\n

The target groups for this measure are: employees older than 50 who have worked for more than five years with the same employer; disabled employees if they have had a permanent work contract for at least 12 months with the same employer; other specific groups of employees who have had permanent work contracts for at least 12 months
column5: such as recovering addicts
column6: victims of human trafficking
column7: victims of domestic violence
column8: asylum seekers
column9:
and people who were raised in orphanages.

"~"

The subsidy is approved for a period of up to one year for workers who had been made redundant because of their employer facing business difficulties and who now work for a new employer. The amount of public funds available ranges from 50–75% of an employee's gross annual salary. The highest subsidy is given to disabled people and the amount of the subsidy is the same regardless of the size of the employer for whom they now work. For those who have completed primary school
column10: the subsidy is up to HRK 31
column12: 141 as at 20 August 2014) per year. For those with a high school diploma
column13: it is up to HRK 42
column15: 573). For disabled people with a university degree
column16: the subsidy is up to HRK 52
column18:
901) per year.

\r\n

Unlike subsidies approved for disabled people
column19: the subsidies for workers older than 50 and other specific groups of employees such as recovering addicts
column20: victims of human trafficking and others depend on the level of education of the worker in question and the size of the company by which they are employed. Subsidies for employees aged 50 and older and for other special target groups of employees with a primary school diploma and who have had permanent work contracts for at least 12 months and are at risk of redundancy are up to HRK 12
column22: 656) in a large company and HRK 21
column24: 760) in SMEs. For employees aged 50 and over and other special groups of employees other than disabled people with a high school diploma
column25: the subsidy ranges from up to HRK 16
column27: 208) for employment in a large company to up to HRK 28
column29: 680) per year for employment in an SME. The highest subsidy is approved for employees aged 50 and over and other special groups of employees other than disabled people with a university degree – from up to HRK 21
column31: 760) for those employed in a large company to up to HRK 35
column33:
601) for those employed in an SME.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This measure helps older workers
column34:
the disabled and employees from specific vulnerable groups of society. Its goal is to make these employees more attractive to prospective employers.

"~"

The public employment service has an exclusive right to decide on subsidy approval and the amount of the subsidy to be approved in each particular case. The measure is applied regardless of the financial strength of the employer. Employers are not obliged to keep on employees following the one year during which they receive a subsidy for employees' salaries.

"~"

column1:
Neradni petak – potpora za očuvanje radnih mjesta~"Non-working Friday – support for preserving jobs"~"Croatia"~"

Workers for whom the employer
column2: due to business difficulties
column3:
cannot ensure the payment of the salary for a full five-day business week.

"~"

If employers prove to the Croatian public employment service that they cannot ensure the payment of a full business week's wages to their workers due to financial difficulties
column4: the employment service will pay the difference between that amount and what employees would receive for having worked only four days. The maximum difference paid to employees is equal to the minimum net salary (up to HRK 2
column5: 779 or €365 as at 20 August 2014
column6: per month) and employers are still obliged to pay all social security contributions for workers on the basis of a full
column7:
five-day business week's salary. The measure is temporary and can last up to six months. It can be applied for any work time and shift work (not only for not working on Fridays).

"~"

According to the annual reports of the Croatian employment service
column8: subsidies paid to employers for employment preservation amounted to only HRK 20
column10: 677) in 2009 and HRK 26
column12: 515) in 2010. For 2012 and 2013 only data on the number of participants are available. In 2012 there were 170 new participants out of a total of 703 participants in the measure
column13: while in 2013 the total number was 1
column14:
310.

"~"

This measure helps workers keep their jobs for a limited period of time.

"~"

Workers continue to be at risk of redundancy if employers' financial difficulties last for more than six months. The control mechanism is weak and there are no guarantees that employers will not misuse harsh business conditions to continue paying lower salaries after the non-working Friday programme has stopped in order to avoid higher costs. The workers are not informed about the company's chances of survival after the non-working Friday programme stops. The measure is not limited for a certain number of participants per company. Although
column15: in theory
column16: the measure provides employers with a cost saving opportunity
column17: in practice they have not been in favour of using it (as the data for the public expenditure on this measure from 2009 and 2010 suggest)
column18:
partially because of the considerable administrative burden it entails.

"~"

column1:
Mobilni timovi Hrvatskog zavoda za zapošljavanje~"Mobile teams of the Croatian employment service"~"Croatia"~"

For employers who
column2: due to business difficulties
column3:
need to make workers redundant as well as companies putting in place redundancy programmes. 

\r\n

 

"~"

A mobile team is available from each regional office of the Croatian employment service. Mobile teams of the Croatian employment service prepare workers facing redundancy for conditions in the labour market and help them search for a new job while they are still employed. The teams consist of a labour market advisor
column4: a legal advisor and a psychologist
column5:
as well as some other team members if necessary. The services they render include: i

  • nformation on the demand in the labour market; 
  • business advisory services; 
  • visits to potential employers; 
  • group and individual advice on termination periods; 
  • legal advice and so on.

Targeted employees are those in the termination period
column6:
especially those employed by employers experiencing financial difficulties. A mobile team helps prepare the workers to enter the labour market by identifying their strengths and weaknesses and the possible future roles for which they can apply. Other activities include:

  • organising training for efficient job hunting; 
  • helping workers to write their CVs; 
  • helping them prepare for job interviews; 
  • recommending worthwhile training and education to improve workers' professional skills; 
  • organising training for those willing to establish a start-up company; 
  • announcing suitable vacancies on the announcement board in the company; 
  • mediating for jobs in the name of workers to be made redundant and especially with employers who have announced job vacancies. 
Mobile teams also organise public co-financing of gross salaries for employees older than 50 in the case of employment in another company.

"~"

The application of this measure has increased since 2011 when 3
column7: 945 employees were advised by mobile teams and in 2010 when 1
column8: 272 workers participated in advisory training organised by invited mobile teams. In 2011
column9: mobile teams realised individual informing sessions for 3
column10: 945 employees
column11: and group informing sessions for 1
column12: 085 employees. 1
column13: 485 workers facing the threat of redundancy participated in individual information sessions. In 2012
column14: mobile team counsellors conducted individual informing sessions in 134 companies for 5
column15: 672 workers. Group informing services were provided to 1
column16: 986 workers
column17: while 3
column18: 470 workers facing the threat of lay-off participated in individual counselling sessions. In 2013 mobile teams visited 159 companies and provided individual information for 1
column19: 710 employees
column20: while through group information 1
column21:
489 employees were included.

"~"

Advice on job searches
column22: vacancies
column23: training and job possiblities is equally available to all workers of a given employer. Mobile teams help the employees being made redundant to accept their situation
column24: not to give up
column25:
and help them finding a new job in other companies. An important aspect of the mobile teams is that their advice is tailor-made to a specific group of workers or to individual workers. Mobile teams perform their activities through mobile centres established in companies with surplus employees as long as there is a need for team work.

"~"

A mobile team is called in relatively late
column26: when workers have little time to find another job without a period of unemployment. The maximum period that a mobile team can work for in one company is not specified but there is supposed to be a maximum termination period of three months. Although mobile teams are available
column27:
employers are not obliged to call on them at any time.

"~"

Croatian railways in 2001. In 2013 the Mobile team was organised in Brodosplit
column29: and its services were used by 857 workers that were in firing procedures. Mobile teams are currently organised in regional offices Zagreb
column31:
Zadar and Rijeka.

column1:
Porezne povlastice~"Tax incentives for technology investment"~"Croatia"~"

Firms of all sizes that invest in technology modernisation or production process change
column2: business enlargement and internationalisation are eligible for grant application
column3: provided that their investment is higher than €50
column4: 000 for micro enterprises and higher than €150
column5:
000 for other companies and provided that a certain number of job positions are opened within three years from launching the investment.

"~"

This measure was created in order to foster innovation
column6: employment and investments in general
column7: especially in economically weaker parts of the country. The measure is effective only if a micro enterprise opens at least three workplaces related to their investment and if other companies open at least five workplaces related to their investment. The investor needs to ensure at least 25% of justifiable investment costs are covered. The amount of a subsidy can be either related to justifiable investment costs or justifiable cost of employment
column8: whichever amount is higher. For investments of more than €1 million
column9: the income tax rate is up to 50% lower than the statutory tax rate for the next 10 years provided that at least five new jobs related to the investment are created. For investments between €1 million and €3 million
column10: the statutory tax rate is reduced by 75% for the next 10 years provided that at least 10 new jobs are created. For investments above €3 million
column11: no income tax rate is payable for the next 10 years if at least 15 jobs related to the investment are created. The statutory income tax rate is reduced by 50% for the next 5 years for micro enterprises that invest at least €50
column12:
000 under the condition that they create at least three positions and preserve them for at least three years. There are certain rules that need to be fulfilled regarding the investment; the investment project must be pursued exclusively in the business premises of the grant beneficiary and it must be an investment in assets that are subject to depreciation only. The assets must be purchased at market prices from independent enterprises and must be included in the balance sheet of the grant beneficiary and cannot be sold for at least five years.

\r\n

Investments must be higher than €50
column13: 000 for micro enterprises and higher than €150
column14: 000 for all other companies. A maximum grant is calculated as a percentage of justifiable investment costs or justifiable costs for opening new positions in large enterprises. The latter amount is considered on the basis that is increased by 10% in the case of investments by medium-sized companies and by 20% in the case of investments by small companies. This amount must be in line with regional grant allocation rules. In case of very large investments
column15: the maximum tax credit for investments up to €50 million is calculated as 100% of the maximum regional grant. For investments above €50 million and up to €100 million
column16: and for further investments above €100 million
column17: the maximum tax credit is calculated as 50% and 34% of the maximum regional grant
column18:
respectively.

"~"

As this is a rather new measure
column19: no information on effectiveness is available yet. However
column20: legal provisions can help attract investors only to a certain point. As long as Croatia has  lengthy proceedings
column21: as long as it has court proceedings when it is necessary  to protect the interests of investors because there is legal insecurity
column22: as  long as regulations change often
column23: Croatia  will have problems with investments. A favourable economic climate must be built on all levels
column24: i.e. the government
column25: the  state
column26: counties
column27:
cities and municipalities.

"~"

It is a horizontal measure that benefits all enterprises except those that cannot apply for the tax credit due to sectoral specificities and enterprises that have severe businesses problems. If newly created jobs are not preserved for three years in SMEs and five years in large enterprises
column28: the tax credit beneficiary has to return the entire amount of tax credit. Similarly
column29: in the case of job reductions during the period of the tax credit usage
column30:
a beneficiary must return the entire tax credit received together with the corresponding interest accrued whose maximum percentage is capped by a legally binding decree from the Ministry of Finance.

"~"

An applicant can be approved the tax credit without actually creating new jobs if they submit proof that they have invested in modernisation of the technological process and if they keep the same number of workers during the entire period of tax credit usage. Although there is an obligation to preserve created job positions for five years in large firms and for three years in SMEs
column31:
how this is controlled and whether the same workers are employed all the time remains vague.

"~"

column1:
Potpora za opravdane troškove novih radnih mjesta povezanih s investicijskim projektom ~"Subsidy for justifiable costs of creating new jobs related to investments "~"Croatia"~"

Employers creating new jobs based on investment.

"~"

This measure has been created to foster employment related to investments. 100% of the maximum grant is approved provided that the following workers are employed:

  • unemployed who were registered with the Croatian employment service for at least three months before taking a job with the grant beneficiary;
  • first-time workers aged up to 25 years who do not have an exact profession and who were not recorded by the Croatian employment service;
  • first-time workers with at least a high school degree aged up to 29 who were not recorded by the Croatian employment service; 
  • workers aged up to 29 within 90 days of acquiring their qualifications regardless of the level of education
column2:
provided that they have been registered by the Croatian employment service; 
  • workers whose past contracts were terminated due to their previous employer's bankruptcy. 
    • For employment of all other workers
column3:
40% of the maximum grant is approved.

Investments eligible for the grant for creating new jobs must have the following characteristics:

  • The investment project must be pursued exclusively in the business premises of the grant beneficiary and it must be an investment in assets that are subject to depreciation only. 
  • The assets must be purchased at market prices from independent enterprises and they must be included in the balance sheet of the grant beneficiary and cannot be sold for at least five years. 
An employer who creates new jobs with investments in regions where the regional unemployment rate is up to 10% will be approved a grant of a maximum of 10% of justifiable investment costs or up to €3
column4: 000 per created job. If new jobs are created in the counties with an unemployment rate between 10% and 20%
column5: a maximum of 20% of the costs of opening a new job are refunded (up to €6
column6: 000) per created job. If the unemployment rate exceeds 20%
column7: a maximum of 30% of justifiable costs of creating a new job are refunded
column8: which is an equivalent of up to €9
column9: 000 per job created. The basis for grant calculation are justifiable costs related to creating new job positions
column10: which are calculated as an employee's gross salary for a two year period. A maximum grant is calculated as a percentage of justifiable investment costs for creating new positions in large enterprises. The latter amount is considered on the basis that is increased by 10% in the case of investments by medium-sized companies and by 20% in the case of investments by small companies. This amount must be in line with regional grant allocation rules. In the case of very large investments
column11: a maximum grant for investments up to €50 million is calculated as 100% of the maximum regional grant. For part of investments above €50 million and up to €100 million
column12: and for further investments above €100 million
column13: a maximum grant is calculated as 50% and 34% of the maximum regional grant
column14:
respectively. This grant is added to other grants related to investment and the cumulative amount of all grants is limited according to the maximum regional grant allocation rules and special grant rules that apply for very large investment projects.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This measure benefits regions with higher unemployment rates. If a new position is not preserved for at least five years
column15:
the grant beneficiary must return the entire grant received with interest (the rate will be determined by the Ministry of Finance).

"~"

The maximum salary can be determined according to the grant size. There is no guarantee that an employer will deliberately reduce the gross salary of workers after the period of grant rules application. The employer is obliged to keep newly created job positions for five years
column16:
whereas there are no conditions on the extent of workers' salary in the period of grant usage. There is a risk that the rules for awarding grants can be changed during the process of investment as the government is in charge of determining the criteria for the exact amount of grant allocation by a special decree. Having the amount of the grant payable subject to certain employee characteristics can force an employer to temporarily employ less qualified people than desired. It is unclear whether the same individuals need to be employed for the entire period of grant usage.

"~"

SYSTEMCOM Ltd. new products developer of information and communication technology
column17:
offers products and services in building information system and microelectronic design.

column1:
Opravdani troškovi usavršavanja ~"Funding justifiable costs of vocational training"~"Croatia"~"

The grant is approved to companies that finance staff training related to investments in technology modernisation or production process change
column2:
business enlargement and business internationalisation.

"~"

This measure is aimed at covering justifiable costs of new employees' training. The training can be general or specific. The former benefits workers and current and prospective employers
column3:
while the latter benefits workers and their current employers only.

\r\n

A maximum grant for special training cannot exceed 25% of justifiable costs of training for large enterprises
column4: and 35% and 45% of justifiable costs of training for small and medium-sized companies
column5: respectively. General training grants cannot exceed 60% of justifiable tarining costs for large companies
column6:
70% for medium-sized companies and 80% for small companies.

\r\n

In special cases
column7: when it is difficult to differentiate between general and specific training
column8: the maximum grant amount is calculated for special training. In any case
column9: the maximum amount of grant awarded
column10: together with the grants approved for investment
column11:
cannot exceed 50% of justifiable costs of investment. The maximum grant amount for training cannot exceed 50% of the maximum grant for creating new job positions related to investments. The latter rule is prescribed by a special government decree. Justifiable training costs encompass:

  • costs of instructors; 
  • trainees' and trainers' travel-related costs; 
  • depreciation costs of equipment used in the training process. 

Investments eligible for the training grant must fulfil certain characteristics:

  • The investment project must be pursued exclusively in the business premises of the grant beneficiary and it must be an investment in assets that are subject to depreciation only. 
  • The assets must be purchased at market prices from independent enterprises and they must be included in the balance sheet of the grant beneficiary and cannot be sold for at least five years.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This measure fosters investment-related employee training.

"~"

This measure fosters general rather than specific training. It is therefore unclear why the decision on the type of general training is entrusted to employers and not to employees themselves as there is little logic in encouraging the employment of people with no experience or adequate qualifications and subsequently subsidising their general rather than specific education. The latter is also related to employers' temporary preference of employing suboptimal workers only in order to receive the grant. Croatia faces serious challenges in education as regards labour-market relevance and quality of provision across all educational sectors. Work-based learning and career guidance across secondary and tertiary education are lacking while employers' engagement with vocational education and training
column12: and secondary and tertiary education is low. The outdated vocational education and training system is undergoing a reform in the form of piloting new school curricula. The implementation of the Croatian Qualifications Framework and the Strategy on Education
column13: Science and Technology is pending but should improve educational outcomes and align them with labour market needs. Thus
column14: Croatia should implement measures to improve the labour market relevance and quality of education outcomes by modernising the qualification systems
column15: by putting in place quality assurance mechanisms and by improving school-to-work transitions
column16:
notably through strengthening vocational education and work-based learning.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Poslovno savjetovanje za poslodavce~"Business advice for employers"~"Croatia"~"

All employers.

"~"

An industry expert advises employers on the supply in the labour market as well as the ideal profile of their prospective employees. The advice is especially useful for the SME sector because SMEs often do not have staff exclusively dedicated to human resources policy. As representatives of the Croatian employment service visit employers' premises
column2: they have the opportunity to get acquainted with employers' problems regarding business conditions and the qualifications their workers may have or need. An important aspect of this measure is that each employer of particular significance – in terms of the number of people they employ or the importance of their enterprise to the local economy – is assigned an individual advisor who specialises in monitoring the labour market supply in their sector. Although employers have individual advisors
column3:
a territorial coordination of employment service offices is often necessary as employers regularly advertise specific job vacancies in regions other than the one in which the firm is registered.

"~"

\r\n

\r\n

17
column5:
519 employers participated in 2008 in the Programme Business advice for employers.

\r\n

 

"~"

For all needs regarding employment and supply in the labour market
column6:
an employer has a person to contact. It is especially useful for SMEs that often do not have a human resources department. This measure is useful with regard to strenghtening the collaboration between the employment service and employers. Personal contact is developed because the employment service advisor visits the employers at least once every two years. This measure is positive as it enables employment service staff to become specialised for certain industries. The dedicated advisors inform employers about the labour market situation and about the possibility of public co-financing of newly created jobs and the possibility of providing professional selection services for job candidates.

"~"

The measure does not specify if an advisor can be changed if employers are dissatisfied with their services. The initiative to make contact with the employment service is entrusted to employers. The maximum number of firms that one advisor can take care of is not specified. Ideally
column7:
the names and contact details of advisors specialising in certain industries should be publicly available and employers should be able to choose an advisor and change them.

"~"

All employers' and employees' representatives during restructuring.

"~"

The function of the Department of Labour Relations is to safeguard labour peace and ensure the preservation of healthy industrial relations structures. The department initiates social dialogue when necessary and mediates the negotiation of redundancy terms if the involved actors fail to reach an agreement.

Επιχειρησιακό Πρόγραμμα «Ανάπτυξη Ανθρώπινου Δυναμικού» (ΕΠΑΝΑΔ)~"'Human Resource Development' business programme"~"Greece"~"

The beneficiaries of the ΕΠΑΝΑΔ programme include the unemployed
column2: workers or self-employed persons
column3: or persons belonging to vulnerable social groups (people with disabilities
column4: repatriated Greeks
column5: immigrants
column6: refugees
column7: long-term unemployed
column8: asylum seekers
column9: victims of trafficking
column10: victims of domestic violence
column11: groups with cultural and/or religious peculiarities
column12: users and ex users of substances
column13: young offenders
column14: prisoners
column15: persons released from prison
column16: homeless
column17: people in poverty or threatened by poverty
column18:
etc.

 

"~"

The Operational Programme 'Development of Human Resources' (ΕΠΑΝΑΔ) of the Ministry of Employment and Social Protection is one of Greece’s 8 sectoral programmes and one of the country’s 3 programmes that are cofinanced by the European Social Fund. It aims at exploiting all human resources as a driving force for the country’s growth and at strengthening social cohesion. 

The ΕΠΑΝΑΔ finances actions for preventing and tackling unemployment
column19: for social integration and for the reform of the health sector. Specifically
column20:
it focuses on the following general objectives:

  • Improving the adaptability of workers and enterprises;
  • Facilitating access to employment
column21:
in particular that of young people;
  • Promoting social integration;
  • Creating an efficient and financially sustainable health and social solidarity system;
  • Promoting the economic
column22: social and developmental nature of gender equality issues
column23:
through their direct connection to the prevailing national political priorities (growth - employment - social cohesion).

Dozens of actions are funded through ΕΠΑΝΑΔ each year. Some examples are:

  • Supporting the human resources for SMEs in issues of extroversion: The project involves counselling and training actions in issues of extroversion for workers of SMEs from all sectors of the economy. Beneficiaries: 7
column24:
000 - Promoter: Hellenic Management Association (HMA).
  • Employees’ information - support network: Establishment of a consultancy and support services network
column25: aiming to provide valid and timely information and mediation and support to workers
column26:
whether Greeks or economic migrants. Promoter: Institute of Labour of the Greek General Confederation of Labour (INE/GSEE).
  • Support of innovation and cooperation in small businesses: Information and awareness of small business on the concept of innovation and the benefits they can obtain from its practical application in modern business. Promoter: Small Business Institute of the Hellenic Confederation of Professionals
column27:
Craftsmen & Merchants (IME/GSEVEE).
  • Voucher for entering the labour market for unemployed young people up to 29 years of age: Granting of a training voucher for the training of unemployed people up to 80 hours
column29: traineeship/work experience of 5 months
column30:
aid to businesses that will convert the traineeship into an employment contract through the coverage of employer contributions for a year.
  • National network of direct poverty reduction: Provision of integrated services to homeless people and people living in poverty or at risk of poverty by social structures for directly combating poverty
column33: open accommodation centres for the homeless
column34: etc. The programme funds the operation of 275 social structures across Greece for a period of 24 months. 1
column35:
200 new jobs for unemployed people up to 30 years of age will be created in these structures and will be funded throughout the same period. "~"

The Ex ante evaluation of the EΠΑΝΑΔ for the programming period 2007 – 2013 states that through the ΕΠΑΝΑΔ:

  • Positive steps were taken towards the certification of vocational training structures
column36:
systems and programmes. \r\n
  • The institutional framework for the development of job profiles in the context of lifelong learning was created.
    • \r\n
  • As regards the programmes to promote employment and the continuing vocational training programmes
column37: various interventions have taken place
column38:
benefiting a large number of persons.\r\n
  • The development of skills and adaptability of human resources was considerably strengthened through vocational training and counselling actions
column39:
but also through actions to promote the skills and adaptability of human resources. \r\n
  • The issue of gender equality in the labour market was significantly promoted
column40:
through measures such as the creation of childcare facilities and facilities providing care for the elderly and incapacitated persons and the implementation of programmes of integrated interventions and affirmative action in favour of women.
\r\n"~"

The ΕΠΑΝΑΔ comprises systemic interventions for promoting active employment policies through a series of measures to support employment. The promotion of social inclusion and poverty reduction is a further thematic objective of the EΠΑΝΑΔ which is achieved through the implementation of a series of interventions
column41: such as training action for the socio-economic inclusion of vulnerable groups
column42: local actions for the social inclusion of vulnerable groups
column43: operation of social structures for directly combating poverty
column44:
etc.

\r\n

 

\r\n

According to the mid-term evaluation report 2012
column45: the programme has a strong affinity with its objectives and the new needs. It was further established that τhe EΠΑΝΑΔ has strong affinity with the objective of the National Reform Programme and
column47: with the Europe 2020 strategy as regards employment objectives and the reduction of the number of people in or at risk of poverty and social exclusion. In addition
column48: the EΠΑΝΑΔ presents strong affinity with European policies and priorities and also the thematic objectives
column49: as they have been developed in accordance with the Draft Regulation of the European Parliament and of the council on the ESF and repealing Regulation (EC) No. 1081/2006
column50:
which may be the main pillars of the sectoral policy for human resources in the new programming period (2014-2020).

"~"

According to the Ex ante evaluation of the EΠΑΝΑΔ for the programming period 2
column51:
there are estimated risks/difficulties in connection with the implementation of EΠΑΝΑΔ related to:

  • The fragmentation of the resources available to small projects and a large number of final beneficiaries.
  • The care for the faster implementation of the management acts for the administrative maturing of ESF projects.
  • The care for the further strengthening of the management maturity of final beneficiaries of ESF projects in the new programming period.
  • The timely and accurate identification of the criteria on the basis of which the certification/selection of the final beneficiaries will be carried out. At the same time
column52:
the transparency of the certification and selection procedure needs to be ensured. \r\n\r\n

Moreover
column54: it should be underlined that the labour market is a dynamic environment
column55: the components of which are constantly changing. Consequently
column56: there is always the risk of changes in the current socio-economic situation
column57:
to the point that it would redefine the prioritisation of needs and the SWOT analysis.

"~"

column1:
Neugründungs-Förderungsgesetz (NeuFöG)~"Start-up promotion law"~"Austria"~"

Start-ups and business successions or transfers.

"~"

This law exempts those who establish new businesses from certain administrative costs and from incidental wage costs for their employees.

\r\n

Some of these exemptions also apply to business transfers or successions. These exemptions include
column2: for example
column3: stamp duty and fees for national administrative documents and for formal procedures related to a transfer. There are also exemptions for court fees incurred while recording a transfer in the company register as well as for corporate taxes on the acquisition of shareholder rights and taxes related to buying property if the value on the basis of which the tax is calculated does not exceed €75
column4: 000. Additionally
column5: there are exemptions for parts of incidental wage costs for all employees for the first year following a transfer and for up to three employees for the second and third years
column6:
provided that the transfer occurred after 31 December 2011.

\r\n

To benefit from exemptions
column7:
the company's successor or new owner must submit an official form confirming the transfer. This form is provided by the employers' organisation representing the respective industry or the social security body.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The exemption from certain administrative and wage costs supports the establishment of new companies.

"~"

Unemployed
column2:
hired for the first 5 work places by employers who are micro enterprises.

"~"

This measure is aimed at job creation by facilitating the employment of unemployed. When new job positions in a micro enterprise become available
column3: employers receive a subsidy for 12 months if they hire unemployed people referred to them by the National Employment Agency for the first 5 positions. The subsidy covers the amount that employers would have to pay in social security contributions for one year for each of these new employees. In order to avail of this measure
column4:
new employees' contracts must have a minimum duration of 24 months.

\r\n

The National Action Plan for Employment for 2014 envisages employment for 338 persons
column5: of them 100 newly recruited (i.e. employed under the measure of the Operative Programme
column6: not having previous relationships with the same employer)
column7: at the total state budget of 488
column8: 750 BGN (€ 249
column9:
893).

"~"

According to the
column10: d.ZWU&cad=rja"">report of the National Employment Agency for the first half of 2008 1
column11: 935 were employed through this measure (5.9% more than the planned 1
column12: 883). Several years later
column13: the number of the participated persons decreases and according to the National Employment Agency Annual report 2012
column14: 153 persons were included in the programe in 2012 (eligible to participate
column15: applications accepted
column16: but not employed)
column17: 148 persons employed. In comparison
column18: 194 persons included
column19:
141 employed in 2011.

"~"

The measure effectiveness depends on the employer's initiative to participate in the programme
column20:

Zákon č.5/2004 Z. z o službách zamestnanosti § 47 Vzdelávanie a príprava pre trh práce zamestnanca §48 Oprávnené náklady na vzdelávaniea prípravu pre trh práce~"Funding for labour market education and preparation for employees and eligible costs"~"Slovakia"~"

Workers in companies employing more than 20 people and experiencing financial difficulties.

"~"

The aim of this programme
column2: carried out by the national employment agency
column3:
is to motivate employers to organise training for their employees with the ultimate goal of avoiding mass redundancies and increasing competitiveness.

\r\n

This measure is available throughout the country
column4:
but the level of support provided to employers varies regionally and depends on the strength of the local economy. The total funding can amount to between 20% and 80% of eligible costs.

\r\n

The programme is financially backed by the European Social Fund whose conditions are defined in the employment operational programme and by the state budget. Eligible costs include training expenses
column5: salaries including tax and social security
column6:
and transport expenses.

\r\n

Training and education can be specific and tailored for the company's needs or general
column7: such as language classes
column8:
management training and quality control courses.

column1:
Sikoflex~"Sikoflex"~"Germany"~"

Scaffolding trade
column2:
construction sector including both blue-collar and white-collar workers.

"~"

This instrument guarantees employees a 100% payment in lieu of accumulated time credits (in the framework of working time accounts) in the case of their employer's insolvency.

\r\n

Payments are made according to agreed hourly wages at the time of payment
column3:
not of deposit. Individual security tickets guarantee reimbursement of time accounts based on monthly per person or per hour (gross wage) deposits by the employer. The employer pays an additional lump sum of €7.50 plus €1.50 per employee. An external IT service can be used to reduce bureaucracy. Usage is voluntary and it is up to the employer to decide whether or not to implement this scheme.

"~"

As of December 2011
column5: 151 companies
column6: covering 19
column7: 962 employees
column8:
held a Sikoflex account.

"~"

Working time accounts are spreading
column9: resulting in concern about employees' risk of loosing credits and reimbursement in the case of employer insolvency. While the 2009 Act for improving the framework conditions of safeguarding flexible working time arrangements addresses this problem for long-term working time accounts
column10:
Sikoflex addresses short-term accounts of 12 months' duration. It thereby provides working time flexibility and income security. Simple administrative procedures support small businesses' use of working time accounts.

"~"

Employers might be unwilling to act proactively and consider the consequences of insolvency for their employees.

"~"

column1:
Reducerea temporara a activitatii~"Temporary reduction of activity"~"Romania"~"

In cases of temporary business slowdown for economic
column2: technological
column3: structural or other
column4: similar
column5: reasons
column6:
over periods exceeding 30 working days.

"~"

In cases of temporary business slowdown for economic
column7: technological
column8: structural or other
column9: similar
column10: reasons
column11: over periods exceeding 30 working days
column12:
there are three possibilities of internal flexibility available to the employer:

\r\n

1. After consultation with the trade unions or workers' representatives
column13:
the employer may reduce working time from five to four days per week.

\r\n

This may come with a corresponding reduction of salary
column14: after prior consultations with the relevant trade union or with the representatives of the employees
column15: until the situation that caused the reduction of the working time is removed. So workers will be paid less as before
column16:
proportional to the reduction in working time.

\r\n

2. During the periods of reduced activity
column17:
the employer has the possibility to grant paid holidays to compensate for the extra work to be done in the following 12 months.

\r\n

3. During business slowdown and/or temporary interruption of operations
column18: employer may suspend the employment contract of workers. In this case
column19:
the employees involved must receive a compensation paid from the salary fund that should not be less than 75% of their usual salaries.

\r\n

During this period
column20: the employees must remain available for the employer
column21:
should the employer decide at any time to resume activity.

"~"

"~"

These measures allow the employer to overcome periods of reduced activity without recourse to layoffs
exceed.

Employees will temporarily have lower incomes than their usual salaries.

column1:
IMK Konjunkturindikator~"IMK Economic Performance Indicator"~"Germany"~"

Whole economy.

"~"

The economic performance indicator estimates the probability of a recession within the next two to three months. A recession is considered to be a considerable decrease of industrial production
column2: whereby different levels are possible (such as a decrease of production by at least 1% for 5 months or a decrease of 0.5% for 10 months). The probabilities are calculated on the basis of data combinations which in the past resulted in recessions. Data from the financial markets as well as indicators of the real economy
column3: such as interest spreads or order levels
column4:
are used.

"~"

Data is used in a wide range of research projects.

"~"

Data from the IMK Economic Performance Indicator is used in many research projects.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

A list of recent publications using data from the IMK Economic Performance Indicator is published on IMK's website.

column1:
COIN Cooperation Innovation~"COIN Cooperation Innovation"~"Austria"~"

Whole economy
column2:
with specific focus on SMEs.

"~"

The COIN Cooperation Innovation run by the Austrian Research Promotion Agency (FFG) aims to foster innovation
column3: particularly in SMEs
column4: through supporting cooperation between companies and non-university and cooperative research organisations via financial funds (see effectiveness). The programme supports the establishment of tangible and intangible infrastructure related to research and development and innovation
column5: as well as competence development within providers of applied research. Furthermore
column6: application-orientated networking projects between companies (particularly SMEs)
column7: research centres and intermediaries resulting in the development of innovative products
column8:
services or processes are supported. This explicitly includes international networks aiming to generate value-added benefits for Austrian companies.

"~"

In the fourth call for proposals for establishment projects (deadline September 2012)
column9: 56 projects were applied for
column10: of which 19 were supported with €12.4 million (total volume of €17.8 million). Results for the fifth call for proposals are not yet available at the time of writing (June 2014). In the sixth call for proposals for networking projects (deadline April 2013)
column11: 14 projects were supported with €4.5 million (total volume of €7.9 million). For the seventh call for proposals for networking projects (deadline March 2014
column12: outcomes not yet available in June 2014)
column13:
the available budget amounts to €4.5 million.

"~"

Research and innovation activities (with a focus on SMEs) are strengthened
column14:
and more efficient implementation of knowledge is supported.

No information available.

column1:
Innovationsscheck~"Innovation Voucher"~"Austria"~"

SMEs

"~"

There are two different instruments. The first is the €5
column2: 000 innovation voucher for SMEs that want to engage with research and innovation for the first time. With the voucher
column3: they can pay for advice provided by research organisations participating in the programme. Studies to produce innovative ideas
column4: preparatory work for research and development and innovation
column5: the development of prototypes
column6:
analysis of potential technology transfers and a company's innovation potential and concepts for technical innovation management are all supported. 

\r\n

The second instrument is the €10
column7: 000 innovation voucher PLUS for SMEs that want to implement their research and innovation. With the voucher
column8: a company can pay for 80% of research organisations' consulting services
column9: totalling a maximum of €10
column10: 000. In other words
column11: to benefit from the full €10
column12: 000 support
column13: the total project costs need to amout to €12
column14: 500. Research orientated studies
column15: preparatory work for research and development or innovation projects
column16: the development of new methods
column17: the preparation of innovations that are subject to property rights
column18:
the development of prototypes and concepts of technical innovation potential are all supported. 

\r\n

Each company may only receive one of the two vouchers per year.

"~"

Between 2007 and February 2011
column19: a total of 2
column20:
935 innovation vouchers was granted (corresponding to 68%).

"~"

Companies (more than research institutes) benefit from the scheme. The Innovationsscheck is especially valuable for micro enterprises (fewer than ten employees) which are usually neglected by such funding schemes.

"~"

The number of follow-up projects after receipt of the funding is not very high.

"~"

No information available.

Foreign companies interested in establishing a business in Austria.

ABA-Invest in Austria
column2: a state-owned organisation
column3: acts as a contact point for foreign companies interested in setting up an establishment in Austria. Services are provided free of charge and include advice related to all location-specific questions

\r\n

The organisation also assists foreign companies already established in Austria with their growth activities
column5: such as provision of data

and personal advice.

column10: ABA-Invest supported €6.9 billion of foreign investment in Austria
column11: resulting in the creation of more than 47

The organisation has good online presentation and competence in handling enquiries.

column1:
Congé éducation~"Educational leave"~"Belgium"~"

All private sector employees working more than half time.

"~"

The Royal Decree of 23 July 1985 regulates educational leave and the Royal Decree of 20 July 1998 regulates the rules and special implementing provisions for educational leave in SMEs. All employees working at least 51% of the normal amount of full-time working hours as defined in the collective agreement are entitled to educational leave of at least 40 hours per year. They are also entitled to up to 240 hours per year for professional training and up to 160 hours per year for general training
column2: which requires the approval of the employer. Employees continue to be paid their usual wage by the employer who receives a reimbursement from national funds
column3:
which covers half of the payments made (including social security contributions). The employer must delcare that the training will improve the employee's qualifications.
