Regionaal Economisch en Sociaal Overleg Comité (Flanders), Comités Subrégionaux de l’Emploi et de la Formation (Wallonia)~"Subregional structures"~"Belgium"~"

The Flanders and Wallonia regions of Belgium.

"~"

RESOC (Regionaal Economisch en Sociaal Overleg Comité) in Flanders and CSEF (Comités Subrégionaux de l’Emploi et de la Formation) in Wallonia are responsible for developing local employment strategies. RESOC draws up a regional pact every six years
column2: including strategic solutions for  resolving and anticipating socioeconomic problems in the region
column3: which could cause unemployment. This includes the stimulation of innovative initiatives
column4: the development of a consultative framework of regional actors on labour market and economic policy developments
column5: mentoring of company diversity plans
column6:
local social economy projects and the improvement of local employment services.

\r\n

CSEF provides continuous analysis of the levels of employment and training supply and demand at regional and subregional levels and proposes measures for job creation.

column1:
IAB-Betriebspanel~"IAB-Establishment Panel"~"Germany"~"

Whole economy.

"~"

The IAB Establishment Panel is a representative annual survey conducted face to face among about 16
column2:
000 establishments from all sectors and size classes who have at least one employee who is subject to social security contributions.

\r\n

The survey started in 1993 in western Germany and in 1996 in eastern Germany. It uses a random sample based on the company database of the public employment service
column3: covering about two million firms. Standard questions include the following topics: factors determining employment development (production
column4: turnover
column5: working time
column6: investment and so on); demand for staff and employment expectations (vacancies
column7: staff turnover
column8: employment strategies); status quo and development of technology and organisational aspects and their effects on jobs; use of public support; engagement in education and training. Each year
column9:
questions on special issues can be added. National and regional data analysis is possible.

"~"

Data is used in a wide range of research projects.

"~"

Data from the IAB-Establishment Panel is used in many research projects. Questionnaire and annual repetition allow for an in-depth analysis of many labour market related topics. The IAB-Establishment Panel can be combined with personal data from the Federal Employment Agency (BA). Both datasets combined are known as LIAB; making it possible to analyse both sides of the labour market
column10:
i.e. supply and demand.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

A list of recent publications using IAB Establishment Panel data is published on the website of the Institute for Employment Research (IAB).

column1:
Moravsko-slezský pakt zaměstnanosti ~"The Moravian-Silesian Employment Pact (MSEP)"~"Czech Republic"~"

Geographically: Moravia Silesia cohesion region (NUTS 2)

\r\n

MSEP operates in the three basic areas of relevant policies
column2:
i.e. (1) Economic development; (2) Employment; (3) Social inclusion based on employment opportunities.

\r\n

 

"~"

The MSEP has been inspired by several similar approaches employed in several European countries and regions (mostly inspired by Austria
column3: but also by Catalonia
column4: Scotland
column5: and Germany) and was established in compliance with the OECD recommendation ""Vienna Action Statement on Partnerships""
column6:
which was approved in 2007.

The MSEP was set up in February 2011 as a first employment pact in the Czech Republic and was signed by four key partners:

 

  • (1) Moravian-Silesian regional government; 
  • (2) Union for the Development of the Moravian-Silesian Region (association of more than 140 members); 
  • (3) Chamber of Commerce of the Moravian-Silesian Region; 
  • (4) Regional Council of the Moravian-Silesian Cohesion Region. 
  • In September 2012 The Labour Office of the Czech Republic (5) also signed the MSEP. 

 

The overall objective of the Pact is to contribute significantly to change the previous long-term unfavourable situation in the regional labour market. By 2020 employment should grow reaching the national average and the unemployment rates should equally decrease to the national average. The objective is to coordinate activities of the key regional stakeholders focusing on identification
column7:
development and implementation of integrated programmes and projects within five strategic priorities of the Pact:

 

  • (1) More and better jobs; 
  • (2) Technical and crafts excellence;
  • (3) Good services; 
  • (4) Entrepreneurial region; 
  • (5) Employment for all.

 

To fulfil these five strategic priorities an Integrated programme for employment (IPE) has been defined as the major programme document of the MSEP in 2011. This programme is composed of 10 integrated projects:

 

  • (1) Regional Observatory of the Labour Market and Competitiveness; 
  • (2) Regional Network of Career Counselling Centres; 
  • (3) Talent Pool; 
  • (4) Pathway to  technical careers; 
  • (5) Competencies development and job placements for students; 
  • (6) Smiling services; 
  • (7) Pathway to language skills development; 
  • (8) Entrepreneurial region;
  • (9) Ten4Life; 
  • (10) Labour Pools.

 

Until now
column8: 42 subprojects have been prepared within the 10 integrated project mentioned above of which approximately 1/3 have been successfully completed. Importantly
column9: all 10 types of integrated projects
column10: which are addressing the key challenges in the labour market sphere and which represent a core of activities of MSEP
column11:
have been endorsed by regional actors. ""Validation"" of these 10 types of projects has been performed via two main channels.

 

  • Firstly
column12:
a special seminar has been organised to gain insights form various stakeholders about functioning and design of particular projects. \r\n
  • Secondly
column13: as a sort of on-going activity
column14:
the implementation team continuously discusses particular types of projects with relevant stakeholders.

 

Currently
column15:
the IPE has been partly transferred to the Joint Action Plan called ""Pathway to Technical Careers"". This plan will be negotiated on the national and EU levels to be a part of programming documents for the years 2014 to 2020.

"~"

There have been four major results since 2011:

 

  • The Pact has proven to be a very effective platform for structured communication of key regional stakeholders leading to consensual strategic priorities in the area of Employment
column16:
Economic Development and Social Inclusion.
  • The Pact enables to translate the priorities into coherent and integrated development programme and to promote implementation of the programme.
  • The Pact becomes a respected vehicle for communication with the relevant ministries and institutions on the national level.
  • The pilot Pact and its model of cooperation inspires other regions of the country.

    •  

    "~"

    The following strengths have been identified:

    • Strategic approach
column17:
i.e. integration of strategy of MSEP and of its action plans into Integrated Programme for Development of Employment and into much broader Programme for Development of the Moravia Silesia region.
  • Partnership resulting in cooperation and coordination (about 80 experts participating in working groups of the MSEP).
  • Ability to identify smart solutions (based on the fact that the roots of a given problem are often deeper than expected).
    • "~"

    There is one main barrier which relates to building trustful relations with the officials of various bodies of central state administration. Originally
column18: the proponents met with a sort of formal (i.e. declaratory) support
column19: while in reality the initiators had to overcome reserved attitudes of officials
column20:
who were afraid that this initiative would represent additional workload for them or - in an even worse case - that this is yet another lobby group searching for public money.

 

"~"

Plato Ireland ~"Plato Ireland "~"Ireland"~"

SMEs

"~"

Plato Ireland Ltd is a company limited by guarantee
column2: and governed by the Irish Business and Employers Confederation (IBEC) and the Chambers of Commerce of Ireland. It was established in 1995 to provide small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with a unique business support forum for exploring business growth and expansion where business owners and managers can tackle the challenges and issues of today's business world. Plato creates a confidential and safe environment where SMEs can benefit from facilitated group learning
column3: training activities
column4: business linkages and networking events. Plato encourages participants to share experiences and resources
column5: to stimulate new ideas
column6:
and to support each other as they make the strategic decisions that determine how their businesses will grow.

"~"

There are currently about 1
column7: 000 participating SMEs in seven Plato regional networks around Ireland. More than 1
column8:
500 companies have already participated in Plato Ireland programmes.

column1:
Insolvenz-Entgelt-Fonds~"Insolvency Income Fund"~"Austria"~"

Employees
column2: freelancers
column3: home workers
column4:
apprentices and any of their inheritors in case of employer insolvency.

"~"

Employees
column5: freelancers
column6: home workers
column7:
apprentices who have a contract with a company to conduct work in Austria (and their inheritors) are entitled to claims from this employment relationship in the case of the employer's insolvency/bankruptcy if these claims have not yet been satisfied.

Insolvency is understood as

  • opening of a bankruptcy proceeding
column8:
\r\n
  • appointment of an administrator
column9:
\r\n
  • rejection of an application for opening bankruptcy proceedings due to insufficient assets or lack of court jurisdiction
column10:
\r\n
  • deletion from the commercial register due to lack of assets
column11:
• lack of assets in the case of the death of the entrepreneur or court decision that inheritance proceedings are to be devoted to the creditors.

    • Eligible are claims from

    • wages and severance payments;
    • compensation from damages;
    • other claims against the employer (like company pensions
column12:
daily allowances etc.); and
  • costs related to the legal and administrative procedures to realise payment from these claims;

    • if they arose up to six months before filing for insolvency
column13: up to a maximum of twice the maximum amount considered for social security (once the maximum amount as regards severance payments)
column14: that is up to a gross monthly income of €9
column15:
060 in 2014.

\r\n

Employees of the state
column16: federal states (provinces) and municipalities
column17:
as well as those having decisive influence on the organisation are not eligible.

Employees have to apply within six months after the opening of insolvency proceedings. The claims will then be assessed. The assessment will include a consultation with the employer or insolvency administrator.

Payment is effected by the state-owned Insolvenz-Entgelt-Fonds-Service GmbH which was specifically established for this purpose. The fund is financed by employers’ contributions (top up of the employers’ contribution to unemployment insurance by 0.55%) and public funds.

If an employer does not pay
column18:
this does not reduce the benefits of the employees in case of insolvency.

"~"

In 2011
column19: the Insolvenz-Entgelt-Fonds-Service GmbH realised payments of € 103 million to workers. In 2010
column20: this amounted to € 258 million
column21: in 2009 to € 277 million. Since its establishment in 2001
column22: about € 2.5 billion were paid to about 330
column23:
000 workers. No more recent data are available.

\r\n

In practice
column24: employees' outstanding claims are usually (on average) met within three to six months after filing
column25:
that is in practice within six to nine months after the opening of insolvency proceedings.

"~"

Employees are granted an income when the companies they are employed have become insolvent or bankrupt.

"~"

Only claims that date up to six months back are secured.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Insolvency Service~"Insolvency Service"~"United Kingdom"~"

The Insolvency Service administers compulsory company liquidations and personal bankruptcies and deals with misconduct through investigation of companies and enforcement. It is also responsible for making redundancy payments. Workers who have lost their job due to insolvency of the employer and have not received the full wage/salary owed to them. A company is considered insolvent in case of filing for insolvency
column2: being put under administration or a voluntary agreement with creditors that has been accepted by law
column3:
as well as if the entrepreneur has died and the company is administered.

"~"

In the UK
column4: a public agency called the Insolvency Service advises workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the bankruptcy of their firms and have not received the full wage or salary owed to them. The Insolvency Service is part of the UK Department for Business
column5: Innovation and Skills (UK BIS). The Insolvency Service was established the National Insurance Fund that guarantees the workers' claims. It is financed by contributions from employers
column6: employees and the self-employed. Workers eligible for assistance may claim wages
column7: holiday pay
column8: or notice pay that is owed to them by their employer. Workers may claim a maximum of eight weeks unpaid wages capped at the statutory rate of £464 (€579.91 on 19/08/14) as well as bonuses
column9: remuneration for overtime work
column10: sickness
column11: pregnancy
column12: and a maximum of six weeks holiday pay. Workers may also claim up to 12 weeks’ worth of notice pay. Claims must have accumulated up to the date that insolvency is filed for. If after payment of the insolvency income there are still unsatisfied claims from the employees
column13: these are considered by the insolvency administrator in the insolvency procedure. Everybody with an employment contract is eligible
column14: irrespective of the duration of employment. Claims can only be made after redundancy/dismissal. A company is considered insolvent in case of filing for insolvency
column15: being put under administration or a voluntary agreement with creditors that has been accepted by law
column16:
as well as if the entrepreneur has died and the company is administered. Employees have to submit their application with the public employment service where the claims are calculated and the amount directly transferred to the employees.

"~"

The Insolvancy Service publishes annual reports
column17: which include figures of the number of claims.  In 2013-14 the Insolvency Service processed 75
column18:
387 redundancy claims (the total number of cases was 26 per cent lower than 2012-13 because there were no failures of high profile employers during 2013-14).

column1:
Unemployment Insurance Act~"Töötuskindlustuse seadus"~"Estonia"~"

Workers who are entitled to receive benefits
column2: in case of employer insolvency
column3: are: all employees
column4: public servants
column5: natural persons providing services on the basis of a contract
column6: non-working spouses accompanying and officials serving in a foreign mission of the Republic of Estonia who have paid the unemployment insurance premiums pursuant to the procedure provided for in this Act
column7: including part-time and fixed-term workers
column8:
irrespective of the duration of the employment.

\r\n

Exempted are sole proprietors
column9: notaries
column10: bailiffs
column11: sworn translators
column12: other independent persons engaging in a profession in public law
column13: creative persons engaged in a liberal profession
column14: management or controlling bodies of a legal person
column15: some civil servants
column16:
those who have reached pensionable age and persons receiving early retirement pension.

\r\n

Employers are defined as legal persons or structural units thereof if granted the rights of an employer
column17:
or a natural person with active legal capacity.

Insolvency is understood as either the bankruptcy of the employer or the abatement of bankruptcy proceedings (if the assets cannot meet the costs of liquidation).

"~"

The Unemployment Insurance Fund pays employer insolvency benefits in case of company bankruptcies.

Benefits upon insolvency of the employer include:

  • unreceived salary from the period before the declaration of the employer as insolvent;
  • unreceived holiday pay from the period before the declaration of the employer as insolvent;
  • benefits from the period before or after the declaration of the employer as insolvent which were not received at the time of cancellation of the employment contract.

In case of unreceived salary
column18:
the amount paid is up to the employee's gross wages for the last three months of work but not exceeding in total the amount equal to three average gross monthly wages in Estonia during the quarter preceding the declaration of the employer as insolvent (according to the data published by the Statistical Office).

\r\n

In case of unreceived holiday pay
column19:
the maximum paid amount is one gross monthly wage of the employee but not exceeding the amount equal to one average gross monthly wage in Estonia during the quarter preceding the declaration of the employer as insolvent (according to the data published by the Statistical Office).

\r\n

In case of unreceived benefits
column20:
the maximum paid amount is equal to the employee's two gross monthly wages but in total not exceeding the amount equal to one average gross monthly wage in Estonia during the quarter preceding the declaration of the employer as insolvent (according to the data published by the Statistical Office).

\r\n

 

"~"

The number of people entitled to benefit upon insolvency of the employer was 2
column22: but then 6
column23: 709 and 6
column25: respectively. The cause of the increase is the economic downturn. More recently
column26:
in 2013 the number of people has decreased to 956.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Coverage is poor: in 2011 unemployment insurance benefits were paid to a fifth and unemployment allowances were paid to just a third of the newly registered unemployed; half of the unemployed did not receive either.

\r\n

Net replacement rates are low
column27:
which should generate higher incentives to return to work as the prospective salary income would be considerably higher than insurance allowance.

\r\n

However
column28:
the relatively low insurance allowance involve a relatively high risk of poverty among the unemployed in comparison with the rest of the population.

column1:
Palkkaturvalaki (866/1998)~"Pay Security Act (866/1998)"~"Finland"~"

According to this law
column2: employees (part-time as well as fixed-term workers) are entitled to pay security in the event of the employer's insolvency. An employer is considered insolvent
column3: if the proprietor died or terminated the business activity and it can be proven that the amount in question cannot be paid from the assets
column4: or if he/she filed for insolvency
column5:
left the country or is hiding so that it is impossible to find assets that could be used to pay the claims.

"~"

In cases of employer insolvency
column6:
wages and other claims of employees resulting from the employment contract are secured by the national loan guarantee system.

\r\n

The guarantee covers all claims that became due within the three months before applying for the loan guarantee
column7:
irrespective of the duration of the employment or its timing.

\r\n

There is a maximum amount per employee and employment contract with the same employer (about €15
column8:
000).

\r\n

The loan guarantee is administered by the regional Centres for Economic Development
column9:
Transport and the Environment (ELY Centres). It is financed by the employer’s contribution to unemployment insurance.

"~"

Between 2006 and 2009
column10: about 9
column11: 500 applications have been registered
column12: and claims of about 28
column13:
000 workers were satisfied.

\r\n

Between 2007 and 2009
column14: the costs doubled and have annually been approx. € 35 million ever since. Between 2012 and 2013 (November)
column15: the number of decisions had increased from 7
column17:
300. 

\r\n

column1:
Fondo di Garanzia INPS ~"Wage Guarantee Fund in the Event of Employer Insolvency"~"Italy"~"

Employers subject to insolvency or enforcement proceedings.

"~"

'Fondo di Garanzia’
column2: administered by the National Institute of Social Security (Istituto Nazionale della Previdenza Sociale
column3: INPS)
column4: pays remuneration related to the last three month of the employment contract as well as the severance indemnity (the so-called ‘Trattamento di Fine Rapporto’
column5: TFR) to employees
column6: apprentices
column7:
industrial firms’ management and members of cooperatives.
The conditions to apply for ‘Fondo di Garanzia’ are the termination of the employment relationship
column8: the ascertainment of the worker’s credit by a Court
column9: the existence of insolvency or enforcement proceedings against the employer
column10:
and the employer’s state of insolvency.
Payment is made within 60 days. The maximum amount paid is equal to three times the amount of the ‘Cassa Integrazioni Guadagni’ (CIG) treatment. Interest and monetary adjustment are also added to the due sums.
In 2014 the maximum monthly amount for CIG is the following:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • for salary up to

097.51 net of 5.84%).\r\n\r\n

The CIG treatment received during the 12 months preceding the opening of the insolvency proceedings must be deducted from the amount due. To be deducted are also wages paid during the three months preceding the termination of the employment relationship
column21:
as well as the mobility allowances benefitted during the three months following the termination of the employment relationship.
‘Fondo di Garanzia’ intervenes even if the employer has failed to pay social contributions. Workers
column22: in the event of insolvency proceedings
column23: may request unpaid social security contributions to be considered as paid. Moreover
column24:
INPS intervenes also in case the employer fails to pay contributions to a supplementary pension fund.
‘Fondo di Garanzia’ is financed by employers’ contributions. Payments to workers are independent from whether or not employers have paid contributions.

\r\n

column1:
Working time flexibility~"Working time flexibility"~"Malta"~"

Exceptional cases.

"~"

In exceptional cases
column2: the employer
column3: in agreement with the employee or union representatives
column4:
may provide for different conditions of employment as a temporary measure to avoid redundancies and as long as it is approved by the director responsible for employment and industrial relations. The approval needs to be reviewed every four weeks.

\r\n

Furthermore
column5: in <span style=""font-family: inherit;""><span>all sectors
column6: whether they fall under a Wage Council Regulation Order or not
column7: the employer may bank up to 376 hours of the normal annual working hours in each calendar year
column8: per employee. This can be done in order to allow extra hours over and above the normal weekly working hours
column9: to be worked during periods of higher work activity. These extra hours would then be redeemed during periods of lower activity
column10:
by having working hours below the normal weekly working hours.

\r\n

This legislation among others protects employees whose contract of employment is terminated by providing the following measures:

\r\n

1. If the contract is terminated before the banked hours could be redeemed
column11: such outstanding banked hours are to be paid at the applicable overtime rate in force on the date of termination
column12: by the date of the next pay day. In the case of participating part-time employees or full-time employees with reduced hours
column13:
any banked hours shall only be paid at the applicable overtime rate if the total hours worked by such employees when averaged exceed the normal hours of work of a comparable full-time employee.

\r\n

2. If the contract is terminated and the employee worked less hours than the yearly average
column14:
the employer cannot claim a refund in respect of hours not actually worked.

"~"

Flexible employment contracts may relieve employers from some financial pressure during difficult times.

column1:
Wage guarantee fund~"Wage guarantee fund"~"Malta"~"

The fund covers all employees who work in companies that are in a state of insolvency
column2: except private domestic servants
column3: share-fishermen
column4:
and employees who own or co-own the company and had considerable incluence on its activities.

"~"

The Guarantee Fund satisfies employees’ claims for unpaid wages and unpaid contributions to schemes arising out of contracts of service with employers who are insolvent.

There is no minimum duration of the employment relationship.

Insolvency is understood as a request for the commencement of proceedings for bankruptcy and the court has established that the business is definitively closed and that the available assets are insufficient to cover the payment of the claims; or the court has appointed a liquidator.

Any claim by any employee in respect of a maximum of three months of the current wage payable by the employer to the employee
column5: and compensation for leave to which the employee is entitled
column6: together with any compensation due to the employee in consideration of the termination of employment
column7: or any notice thereof
column8: constitutes a privileged claim over the assets of the employer and must be paid in preference to all other claims provided that
column9: in every case
column10:
the maximum amount of the privileged claim shall not exceed the equivalent of the national minimum wage payable at the time of the claim over a period of six months.

\r\n

In instances where
column11: due to the fact that an employer is insolvent
column12: the employees’ claims for unpaid wages arising out of contracts of service cannot be paid
column13: the Guarantee Fund will pay an amount not exceeding 13 weeks’ national minimum wage payable at the time of the dismissal or termination
column14:
for the period starting from the date of termination of the employment and ending on the end of the thirteenth week after such termination.

\r\n

The employee has to register a valid claim for unpaid wages with the Administration Board within one month from the onset of the insolvency of the employer.

"~"

Data for the years 201
column15: 2011 and 2012 shows that the fund was only used in 2011. During 2011
column16: 52 claims were processed and the sum of EUR44
column17: 667.96 were paid out of the fund.  In 2012
column18: the balance of the fund stood at EUR477
column19:
882.80.

"~"

The fund assists workers who end up unemployed due to their company's insovency. It gives these persons and their families some economic protection until they find another job.

column1:
Munkaidőkeret~"Allocated cumulative working time"~"Hungary"~"

All employers and employees.

"~"

\r\n
column2:
sans-serif""; mso-ascii-font-family:Calibri; mso-ascii-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-hansi-font-family:Calibri; mso-hansi-theme-font:minor-latin; mso-fareast-language:EN-US;} -->

\r\n

Companies may face ad hoc tasks or sometimes tasks are not equally distributed in time. In these two cases it is worth allocating cumulative working time. Sections of the Labour Code introduced last July enable companies to apply this flexible method.

\r\n

 

"~"

A maximum of 16 weeks (4 months) cumulative working time can be allocated
column3: however
column4:
with meeting other requirements even 26 weeks (6 months) cumulative working time can be allocated – for the employer or in the case of activities concerning the operation of the company.

\r\n

Differing from the above mentioned instances
column5: with collective  agreement the period of cumulative working time can be a maximum of 52  weeks (12 months) if this is justified by technical or organizational  reasons. The period of cumulative working time shall always be recorded  in writing and the concerned colleagues shall be informed. On the other  hand
column6:
separate agreement does not need to be made about it.

"~"

The system is an important tool in managing the working time as well as the labour costs. The system give flexibility for the employers because they can better shape the employees' working time. Today the pressure is on employers in order to utilize better the resources including human resources and reduce undue personal expenses.

"~"

increasing of administration
column7:
employee dissatisfaction in the beginning of the period

"~"

For example
column8: in a 16-week cumulative working time there are 83  workdays
column9:
and the employee’s daily full worktime is 8 hours meaning that 664 hours can be distributed in the allocated working time.

column1:
loongarantieregeling/Werkloosheidswet – WW~"Pay guarantee regulation/Unemployment Insurance Act"~"Netherlands"~"

If an employee has a financial claim against an employer who is permanently unable to fulfil its payment obligations
column2:
he can benefit from the guarantee in case of:

  • bankruptcy (declared by court);
  • suspension of payments (surceance van betaling);
  • debt sanitation (if private persons after the finalisation of bankruptcy proceedings are still confronted with debts they are unlikely to pay in future
column3:
the debtor has to do everything possible to collect the money needed to pay creditors for three years);
  • permanent cessation of payments.

    •  

    Domestic servants that usually work fewer than three days a week are excluded from the pay guarantee regulation.

    Part-time and fixed-term workers are eligible.

    There is no minimum duration of the employment relationship.

    "~"

    In cases of bankruptcy
column4:
employees’ pay and unpaid premiums constitute debts which are paid directly out of the estate with preference over the claims of other creditors.

\r\n

Benefits awarded may comprise pay (over the last 13 weeks immediately preceding the date of notification of the dismissal and the period of notice for dismissal)
column5:
holiday payments and holiday bonuses as well as sums owed by employers to third parties in connection with the employment relationship (over a maximum of one year immediately preceding the date at which the employment relationship has been ended).

\r\n

The UWV (Institute for Employee Benefits Schemes) operates as the guarantee institution. Benefits are paid out of the general unemployment fund
column6:
funded by premiums paid by employees and employers.

\r\n

There is no direct link between payment of these premiums and the right to receive benefits.

column1:
Fonds pour l’Emploi ~"Employment fund "~"Luxembourg"~"

Claims which arose from employment contracts (provision of services in exchange of remuneration and submission of the employee to the authority of the employer) in the event of bankruptcy of the employer

"~"

The Employment fund (Fonds pour l'Emploi) guarantees the payment of claims which arose from employment contracts (provision of services in exchange of remuneration and submission of the employee to the authority of the employer) in the event of bankruptcy of the employer.

\r\n

It includes apprentices and domestic servants
column2:
as well as part-time and fixed-term contracts.

\r\n

There is no minimum duration of the employment relationship.

\r\n

The Fonds pour l’Emploi is financed by a solidarity tax
column3: which is (for 2013) a 7% surcharge on personal income              (9% when the personal income is over 150.000 euros per year)  and 7% on corporation tax
column4:
a contribution from local authorities and an advance from the government funds.

The Fonds pour l’Emploi must guarantee the remuneration and indemnity of any nature due to employees for the last six months of work before the declaration by the court of the bankruptcy.

It must also guarantee any claims arising from the termination of the employment contract.

The guarantee provided for applies to the last six months of employment of the concerned employees irrespective of the date of opening by the court of collective proceedings and irrespective whether the reference period of six months is situated immediately before the decision of the court or even prior to that decision.

The payments made cannot exceed six times the minimum social salary.

column1:
Compte épargne-temps~"Time-saving accounts"~"Luxembourg"~"

Whole economy

"~"

At the request of employees
column2: time-saving accounts can be introduced through internal regulations or a collective agreement to accumulate rights to paid leave in return for untaken leave or overtime work (compensated at a rate of 1.5 hours of time off for every extra hour worked). Alternatively
column3: employees can gain additional paid leave in return for part of their renumeration (wage supplements for work on Sundays
column4: bank holidays and night work). In this case
column5: the proportion of salary exceeding the minimum wage is converted into time credits at the request of the employee
column6:
provided that this does not exceed 10% of their total annual wages.

\r\n

The collective agreement or time saving account scheme should record the beneficiaries
column7: the rules for supplying
column8: using or settling the account
column9: the rules on transferability from one employer to another
column10: and so on. When such a scheme is introduced without a collective agreement
column11: the monetary exchange value of the acquired rights is registered with an insurance company. It manages the funds received and pays them to the employer in the case of complete or partial settlement of a time-saving account
column12:
or to the employee if the employer goes bankrupt.

\r\n

When the scheme is introduced in the context of collective bargaining
column13:
the parties are free to determine the way to secure employees' rights. Only permanent employees are entitled to avail of a time-saving scheme. The employer is in charge of managing the working time accounts and has to inform employees about applicable regulations and their working time credits. Employees can request a withdrawal from the scheme and this must be granted by the employer unless there are serious reasons for refusal.

\r\n

The bill Nr. 6234 introduced on the 22nd of December 2010 regarding the working time account has been withdrawn on 10.3.2014 (parliamentary document Nr. 6234/3). Indeed the bill was strongly criticized by professional chambers (workers and employers). A new bill will be prepared
column14:
introducing ""framework law"" which will allow more freedom for social partners to implement it.

column1:
Association pour la Gestion du regime de garantie des creances des salaries (AGS)~"Wage guarantee fund"~"France"~"

Wage guarantee is offered in case the employer is insolvent (debt cannot be covered by assets)
column2: reorganises the company
column3:
or is in temporary financial difficulties.

\r\n

All workers are eligible irrespective of the duration of the employment
column4: including freelancers
column5: part-time and fixed-term workers
column6:
workers that temporarily work outside of France and foreign workers working illegally in France.

"~"

It covers everything that is owed to the worker on the day of filing for insolvency
column7: including indemnification in case of termination of the employment contract
column8:
claims from financial employee participation and social plans.

There is a maximum amount per employee.

  • If the contract has been concluded less than 6 months before the opening judgment for insolvency
column9: the maximum is set at € 50
column10:
060 for 2014.
  • If the contract has been concluded between 6 months and 2 years before the opening judgment for insolvency
column11: the maximum is set at €62
column12:
580 for 2014.
  • If the contract has been concluded more than 2 years before the opening judgment for insolvency
column13: the maximum is set at €75
column14:
096 for 2014.

There is no minimum duration of the employment relationship.

The guarantee is administered by the Association pour la Gestion du regime de garantie des creances des salaries (AGS).

The insolvency administrator has to draft an overview of all employees’ claims and submit this to the AGS. The AGS pays the amount to the insolvency administrator who pays it to the employees.

The system is financed by contributions from all employers (0.30% of the payroll).

The national body responsible for collecting social contributions and family allowances (URSSAF) is responsible for collecting these contributions.

"~"

During the period running from 1 April 2013 to 31 March 2014
column15: approximately € 2
column16: 219 million were spent on advance pay (+7.5% annual growth)
column17: for 291
column18:
775 employees concerned (+4.3% annual growth). 

"~"

Strong protection for the workers in case of insolvency of the company. 

\r\n

Amounts owing are paid quite quickly (maximum time limit should be no longer than 3 months after the legal decision of judicial redress).

"~"

Litigations with the Wage Guarantee Fund are quite numerous
column19:
as money is at stake. Either the Fund claims back overpayments or workers fill a complaint to recalculate their rights.  

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Accords de maintien de l'emploi~"Agreement to maintain employment"~"France"~"

Companies which are facing serious cyclical economic difficulties.

"~"
column2: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;""><span style=""color: #000000;""><span style=""font-family: Verdana
column3: sans-serif;"">Articles L5125-1 to L5125-7 of the Labour code introduce a new category of collective agreements: the agreement 'to maintain employment'. In companies which are facing serious cyclical economic difficulties
column4:
these agreements are supposed to help to temporarily adjust the organisation of working time and the remuneration while avoiding dismissals.

\r\n
column5: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">These agreements are concluded between the employer and employee representatives. To be valid
column6:
they have to be signed by one or more trade unions representing at least 50% of the votes cast at the last professional elections. Special provisions apply for companies without unions.

\r\n
column7: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">The agreement 'to maintain employment' aims at adjusting the organisation of working time and the remuneration. In return
column8:
the employer is committed to maintain the employment for the whole duration of the agreement.  This may include for instance a reduction of the remuneration and the working time or an increase in working time without increasing the remuneration. The agreement can be applicable to all employees or just to a portion of the workforce.

\r\n
column9: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">Once the agreement is signed by both parties
column10: the employee still have to give their opinion.  If the employee agrees
column11: the terms and conditions of his contract that are contrary to the agreement are suspended for the duration of the agreement and he cannot be dismissed on economic grounds. If the employee refuses
column12: he will be individually dismissed on economic grounds. As a consequence
column13: the employer does not have to comply with the requirements of a collective dismissal
column14: even if several employees are dismissed (namely
column15:
he will not have to negotiate a redundancy plan).

\r\n
column16: sans-serif;""><span style=""font-size: x-small;"">In any circumstances
column17: an agreement 'to maintain employment' cannot lead to deprive the employees from certain essential  protective provision
column18: called the 'social public order' (statutory working time
column19: minimum wage
column20: paid leave
column21: etc.).  Besides
column22: if the agreement provides for a reduction of the remuneration
column23: this reduction cannot go below 120% of the minimum wage. Therefore
column24:
employees that are earning 120% of the minimum wage or less cannot be subject to a reduction of their remuneration.

\r\n
column25:
sans-serif;"">An agreement 'to maintain employment' is signed for 2 years and is not renewable.

"~"

In May 2013
column26: 11 months after this instrument was implemented
column27:
only 4 companies signed such agreements. 

"~"

Helps avoiding dismissals.

"~"

Cumbersome and constraining scheme. 

 

"~"

No information available.

Observatoire des aides aux entreprises et du développement économique~"Business Support and Economic Development Observatory "~"France"~"

All enterprises.

"~"

Developed by the Institut supérieur des Métiers (Higher Institute of Jobs) since 2002
column2: the Observatory is a central information source about support available for companies
column3: with more than 3
column4:
000 public schemes identified.  

The Observatory has two main objectives: 

  • Orientate SMEs towards support they can benefit from 
  • Inform public actors and support bodies on the evolution of economic development of public policies 

In practice
column5:
via the observatory's website companies have access to a database that identifies support measures available and provides information on how to access these measures and how effective they are. The website also offers feedback from other companies and guidelines as well as updates on current relevant developments.

 

"~"

No information available.

The instrument addresses the problem that there is a lack of a coherent concept of state support instruments and coordination among them. The internet resources that were made available in this instrument at least facilitate access to state support for SME managers and is free.

column1:
Fonds National de Revitalisation des Territoires, FNRT~"National Fund for the Renewal of Disadvantaged Areas "~"France"~"

SMEs with more than ten employees
column2: companies with fewer than 500 employees if they do not belong to a group that employs more than 5
column3: 000 people
column4:
companies with fewer than 500 employees that are in operation for less than three years if it is the result of a takeover of an enterprise that had been bankrupt. Eligible enterprises should be situated in regions that have been suffering from economic restructuring and did not receive appropriate support from other sources previously.

"~"

The scheme provides funding for companies suffering from economic restructuring through the activity of a Local Steering Committee. At the beginning of the funding process
column5: the local prefect asks the National Administration Council to check if the department under their responsibility is eligible to gain the status of a ‘disadvantaged region’. If the status is granted
column6: a Local Steering Committee is set up. It is chaired by the prefect and consists of representatives of the Regional Directorate for Business and the Public Investment Bank. The Steering Committee collects then project proposals from local businesses and receives
column7: eventually
column8: funding for them. Decisions about the funding of proposals are taken by a National Steering Committee (Comité stratégique d’orientation
column9: CSO). The measure is of particular relevance because it is relatively large in scope and involves numerous actors at different levels. Finally
column10:
the bottom-up approach is of interest.

"~"

At the end of 2010
column11: €100.5 million had been allocated to business. At the same time
column12: Oséo had granted 202 loans to revitalise disadvantaged regions. For these reasons
column13:
members of the National Steering Committee gave a positive review.

"~"

The decentralised nature of this system fosters a good use of local structures to evaluate the actual need of the companies.

"~"

SMEs that are not located in a designated area do not benefit from this measure.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Krajowy System Usług~"National SME Services Network (KSU)"~"Poland"~"

SMEs.

"~"

The measure targets potentially all types of restructuring. The network is composed by 200 non-commercial organisations cooperating with each other to provide broad advisory
column2: information
column3:
training and financial services.

"~"

In the years 2004 – 2006
column4: Consultation Centres provided more than 107
column5: 500 information services
column6: free of charge
column7: to almost 77
column8: 000 customers. With time the number of services kept rising and in 2010 only
column9: the Consultation Centres serviced almost 68
column10: 500 clients. The report shows that 103
column11:
014 information services were provided to customers in 2012. A complex evaluation of the system in 2009–2010 showed the high efficiency and substantial impact of the programme on micro enterprises and start-ups. The report shows that more than 90% of customers were satisfied with the services provided by KSU. Other research shows that customers were especially content with the information about and the assistance in establishing new businesses.

"~"

It is an all-Poland programme that has been growing for years and has assisted tens of thousands of entrepreneurs especially micro and small ones
column12:
mainly in the fields of business growth and internal restructuring.

"~"

The survey asked about the greatest weaknesses of KSU and 61% entrepreneurs answered that the information about this system was insufficient. Same percentage of entrepreneurs
column14: declared that they did not use the KSU because they didn’t know about it. In the survey from 2012
column15: 69% of entrepreneurs answered that information about KSU was insufficient and
column16: same as in 2011
column17:
61% of them declared that they didn't know about KSU and that was the main reason they didn't use the services provided by it.

"~"

The list of good practises including enterprises have used services provided by KSU.

Crédit d'impôt recherche~"Research tax credit"~"France"~"

Industrial
column2: commercial
column3: craft and agricultural companies
column4: irrespective of their legal status subject to corporation tax. Companies exempted from corporation tax are not eligible
column5: except for 'young innovative companies'
column6:
companies that were created to take over another company in difficulty and companies located in assisted areas. 

"~"

French companies carrying out innovative projects can benefit from a tax credit equal to 30% of the research and development expenses up to € 100 million. For expenses above € 100 million
column7:
tax credit goes down to 5%.  

"~"

This instrument has been criticised by academics who claimed that funds are mainly devoted to the private sector (i.e companies) and by SMEs that claimed that only large companies benefit from it. 

\r\n

The French court of auditors is also very critical towards this instrument
column8: that is considered as a 'fiscal niche'. A report from the court of auditors shows that between 2008 and 2013
column9: companies' expenses for research and development have not increased
column10:
whereas at the same time the amount of the tax credit has been multiplied by 3 (from € 1.8 billion to € 5.8 billion). 

\r\n

Likewise
column11: the CNRS (national scientific research centre) has put forward that
column12: despite the increase in the amount devoted to the tax credit
column13:
recruitments in research organisations are declining.

column1:
Médiation du Crédit aux Enterprises~"Credit mediation structure"~"France"~"

Whole economy.

"~"

In light of the difficulties faced by SMEs in accessing finance
column2:
a credit mediation system has been promoted by the French government. This is aimed at facilitating access to loans and ease cash flow problems. A credit mediator was nominated by the government to ensure that banks pass on financing to companies facing temporary economic difficulties.

\r\n

In practice
column3: companies can file an application online. 48 hours after the application has been validated
column4: the departmental mediator will get in touch with the company and will define a framework for actions to be taken. Financial institutions are informed about the mediation and have 5 days to reconsider their position. After those 5 days
column5: if the company still experiences difficulties in accessing finance
column6:
the departmental mediator will directly get in touch with financial institutions to identify and solve the obstacles.

"~"

As reported by the Office of the mediator for credit
column7: a total number of 37
column8: 157 requests for assistance (4
column9: 077 in 2012) have been filed since November 2008. The success rate is of 58%
column10: which represents 34
column11:
854 jobs saved. 

"~"

Quick process
column12:
available online and free of charge. 

"~"

No information available.

column5:
and the reindustrialisation and conversion of areas and productive sectors affected by difficulties.
UGV – that collects crisis management experts from the Ministry of Economic Development and the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs – promotes meetings with enterprises experiencing difficulties. It coordinates disputes
column6: deals with social partners and institutions (also at local level)
column7:
and adopts measures to prevent and face business crisis in order to safeguard employment levels.

Meetings often turn out to be a mere formality and do not lead to any result.

column1:
Go:Global Slovenia ~"Go:Global Slovenia "~"Slovenia"~"

High potential start-up companies and entrepreneurs whose business priority is to establish and create exceptional global companies that will offer high quality products

"~"

The programme which was initiated in 2011 is intended to support young and internationally oriented high-technology start-up companies offering high value-added products or services. The companies are evaluated and selected
column2: following their application
column3: based on a.) credibility of entrepreneur and its team
column4: b.) level of innovativeness/technology
column5: c.) global marketing potential of the product being developed
column6: d.) fabricated/finished (minimally acceptable) product
column7: e.) global growth potential
column8: f.) classification in Start:up Slovenia competition. The purpose is to provide selected companies with suitable support in their global growth and market penetration endouvers both by providing the infrastructure
column9: mentoring and networking at international level.  Among support measures provided within the framework of the programme are:  Mentoring: This part of the programme consists of  five weeks business training with a practical orientation. Systematic education meetings paired with practical work under scrutiny of mentors
column10: i.e. experienced business experts are organised. Following those
column11: 1:1 mentoring meetings are organised in order to address specific needs or problems of programme participants and to provide them with tailored consulting support. Mentors are being paid.                                                                      Support for international growth: Go:Global offers participants relevant knowledge and the possibility to exploit opportunities within the IASP (International Association of Science Parks)
column12: intervening and providing support in first steps abroad by finding the contacts
column13: premises for subsidised price and quality local services (e.g. cleaning service
column14: maintenance). The programme is financed by the Ljubljana Technology Park (as project/programme leader)
column15: Tovarna podjemov (Maribor Technology Park) and RC IKT d.o.o. (Research Centre for Information and Communication Technologies)
column16:
although it is envisaged that the programme will be financing itself through participation fees in the mid-run.

"~"

While the first wave of Go:Global consisted of 12 companies
column17:
9 companies finished first module (business programme) by 2012.

column1:
No information available~"Go International Slovenia"~"Slovenia"~"

All enterprises intending to establish export relations for the first time or expand their international coverage. In practice
column2:
the focus of the programme are SMEs.

"~"

The aim of the programme is to provide support related to international activities of eligible enterprises. More than 50 activities within the programme are classified into four measure groups: - Analysis of market opportunities and counselling - Education support - Financial support - Promotion activities. Under the first pillar market research and analysis as well as feasibility studies are provided to eligible companies. Financial support for cofinancing such studies is provided through the Public Agency of the Republic of Slovenia for Entrepreneurship and Foreign Investments (JAPTI). For SMEs
column3: the amount of the support reaches up to 50%  to a maximum amount of €4.000 (as of 2012). For other (larger) companies
column4: the amount of the financial support is determined according to de minimis rule. Advice on internalisation activities and related issues is being provided through the Export Window portal of JAPTI. JAPTI seeks to complement this activity by contractually hiring external consultants in order for them to provide such information to target enterprises for foreign markets that can not be covered by JAPTI employees. Outsourced consultants need to be available for consultations whenever required. Regarding the training support
column5: co-financing of international business education (Internationalisation Academy) and preparation of an export plan are among measures provided. The academy encompasses 25 hours of lectures
column6: presentations of good practice cases and talks by guests from various industries.  Content modules cover: 1. business strategy in global environment
column7: 2. presentation of institutions supporting internationalisation
column8: 3. internationalisation and (international) marketing
column9: 4. legal aspects of internationalisation
column10: 5. culture and negotiations in international trade
column11: and 6. effective presentation of the company to international actors. Financial support is provided in form of insurance and credits and grants to international businesses by SID Bank (SID – Slovenska izvozna in razvojna banka)
column12: whose sole shareholder is the Republic of Slovenia. The primary mission of the SID Bank is to be complementary to the financial market in the area of insurance and financing of non-marketable risks
column13: promoting branches of industry and markets in which Slovenia has competitive advantages as specified in the Development Strategy of Slovenia. On behalf and for the account of state
column14: SID Bank provides services like export credits and investment insurance as well as an interest rate equalisation programme. SID Bank acquires resources mainly through borrowing in foreign financial markets on its own behalf and for its own account
column15: as well as with the guarantee of the Republic of Slovenia. As regards support of promotion activities
column16: organisation of outward economic delegations
column17: international trade fairs and providing support for either individual (co-financing up to 50%) or group appearances (100% financing) are provided. Furthermore
column18: financial support of business clubs and Slovenian Houses hosting Slovenian companies
column19: agencies and organisations in specific/selected foreign markets is provided.  In addition
column20:
organisation of conferences and round tables organised by internationalisation support entities are financially supported within the framework of this programme.

column1:
PACE- Partnership Action for Continuing Employment~"PACE- Partnership Action for Continuing Employment"~"United Kingdom"~"

The Partnership Action for Continuing Employment (PACE) is the Scottish Government's initiative dedicated to helping individuals and employers with advice and support when faced with redundancy. PACE aims to minimise the time people affected by redundancy are out of work through providing skills development and employability support.

"~"

PACE provides tailored support (e.g. training
column2: counselling) to individuals facing redundancies by ensuring that local and national public sector agencies respond to potential and proposed redundancies quickly
column3: effectively and consistently; it originally targeted only large-scale redundancies but was refocused in 2009 to apply to all redundancies situations. This change in the focus was prompted by the global recession. PACE has been in place since 2000
column4: with Skills Development Scotland (SDS) now co-ordinating PACE nationally and locally in Scotland. The PACE initiative is delivered via a partnership which includes the Scottish Government
column5: Skills Development Scotland
column6: Department for Work and Pensions (DWP)
column7: Business Gateway
column8: Jobcentre Plus
column9: local authorities and other agencies and organisations including colleges
column10: universities and the Scottish Citizens' Advice Bureau. Skills Develoment Scotland (SDS) has set up 25 PACE regional partnership areas across Scotland with a dedicated team of PACE advisers.  In terms of support for individuals
column11: PACE advisers can help people impacted by redundancy via:  providing information about the redundancy process
column12: rights and entitlements guidance on options and opportunities  advice on entitlement to benefits
column13: taxation and financial management  job searches and assistance with preparation of CVs and job applications and interview preparation  In terms of support for employers
column14: PACE advisers can:   suggest alternatives to redundancies
column15:
providing options to retrain and retain staff; and/or provide impartial advice on approaches to making redundancies.

"~"

Approximately 3
column16: 410 clients were listed as having received PACE services in the period from April 2012 to January 2014. A PACE Client Experience Survey (2014) was commissioned by the Scottish Government. The survey found that the suite of PACE services were generally well received and that they were being accessed by high proportions of clients. Clients on the whole were positive about the service and found the services relevant to their situation. There was evidence to suggest that earlier intervention and even more active engagement would improve the effectiveness of the service. The majority of clients were sucessful in finding work after having been made redundant with their new roles tending to be at a similar or higher level to the redundant role. However
column17: over half of the clients had to take pay cuts in their new position. The client survey also suggests that there is further scope for improvement in terms of personalising the service and early intervention. An independent evaluation of the effectiveness of PACE service delivery for a specific PACE intervention (Vion Food Group Limited Uk closure of its Hall of Broxburn meat processing plant in 2013) was commissioned by the Scottish Government. While some of the findings from the evaluation may be specific to the Vion case
column18: some of the recommendations are likely transferable as standard PACE services were offered. For this reason
column19: likely provide insight into the effectiveness of the PACE programme. In general
column20:
most service users felt that PACE had helped increase their chances of finding work (p. 5).

"~"

PACE provides a specific
column21: dedicated and publicly funded support service for redundant workers. The PACE partnership model is viewed as one of the key strengths of the initiative. An independent evaluation of the effectiveness of PACE service delivery for a specific PACE intervention (Vion Food Group LImited UK closure of its Hall of Broxburn meat processing plant) found PACE service users considered the best things about the support from PACE to be the range of services on offer
column22: the range of services accessible from a single site
column23: availability of foreign-language staff (in this case
column24: Polish-speaking) and the quality of the information provided (p. 4). As the services offered were largely standard to PACE
column25: these strengths are likely transferrable to the PACE programme in general. PACE staff saw one of the major strengths of PACE as being the strong partnership model
column26: having staff who could speak a foreign language (in this case Polish) and having a wide range of services
column27:
(that is similar strengths to the clients (p.5)). The ability of the PACE partners to be responsive to the needs of the workforce and to customise their approach in line with the needs of the company was seen as critical to success.  

"~"

An independent evaluation of the effectiveness of PACE service delivery for a specific PACE intervention (Vion Food Group Limited UK closure of its Hall of Broxburn meat processing plant) found formal mechanisms for raising awareness may be lacking
column28: with most workers finding out about PACE via 'word of mouth' (p. 4). In addition
column29: service users thought the premises used did not provide enough privacy
column30: not enough staff were always available and more support for individuals while they were still in employment
column31: were identified as areas for improvement. PACE staff thought that gaining access to workers as early as possible
column32: and before they were made redundant
column33: would be beneficial. Key data was not comprehensively collected about how many individuals were assisted and outputs achieved. As the services offered were largely standard to PACE
column34:
these weaknesses are likely transferrable to the PACE programme in general.

"~"

Vion Food Group;

column1:
GrowthAccelerator~"GrowthAccelerator"~"United Kingdom"~"

GrowthAccelerator involves growth experts from the private sector and leaders of high-growth
column2:
small and medium businesses (SMEs) providing advice and support to other SMEs. The criteria for eligibility of SMEs involves: Any independent business based in England and registered in the United Kingdom; Businesses must have fewer than 250 employees; turn over less than £40 million (€50 million on 19 August 2014). Sole traders with more than 10 employees are also eligible. Eligible businesses must also be able to demonstrate the ability to achieve high growth. GrowthAccelerator targets high growth businesses who want to enter the next growth phase.  

"~"

Established in 2012 with funds of £200 million(€251 million on 28 August 2014)
column3: GrowthAccelerator aims to support 26
column4: 000 high growth potential small to medium enterprises (SMEs)
column5: offering bespoke business advice. Following the European Community definition
column6: SMEs are defined as having less than 250 employees. The service provides these SMEs with access to a network of business professionals. These SMEs can also access a leadership and management grant of up to £2
column7: 000 per person (€2
column8: 514 on 28 August 2014)(requiring matching funds from the company) to train the company’s senior management.  SMEs are assigned Growth Managers to develop a growth plan. The programme provides coaching to managers in areas such as strategy
column9: change management
column10: sales
column11: marketing
column12: organisation and systems
column13: along with expertise on innovation and access to finance. The GrowthAccelerator service provides access to a network of over 120 experts with experience of starting
column14: managing and growing successful businesses.  Participating SMEs pay a one-off fee to participate in GrowthAccelerator. The fee depends on the size of the business
column15: as follows:  1 to 4 employees:  £600 (€750 on 19 August 2014) plus £700 (€875 on 19 August 2014) in VAT (based on notional value of service of £3
column17: [€4
column18: 373 on 19 August 2014]) 5 to 49 employees: £1
column19: 500 (€1874 on 19 August 2014) plus £700 in VAT (as above) 50 to 249 employees: £3
column21: 748 on 19 August 2014) plus £700 in VAT (as above)  This fee is for the guidance and support provided by the Growth Manager and Growth Coach
column22:
the masterclasses and workshops and access to match funding offer for leadership and management training.   

"~"

Over 15
column23: 000 companies are now enrolled for the service
column24: with 6
column25: 647 enrolments over the financial year 2012-13 and 8963 over 2013-14. Whilst enrolments are spread reasonably well across the regions
column26: enrolments in the North-east of England are low and high in the South-East. Most are established businesses operating already for five or more years. Significantly
column27:
participating companies grew at a rate of 32% over 2013-14; a rate much higher than the 5% average for SMEs in the same period.

"~"

On average
column28:
participating countries have shown higher growth rates than the average growth rate for SMEs.

"~"

A key weakness is the lack of awareness of the service by SMEs. A survey by the financial service company AXA found that less than 20% had any understanding of available government support schemes generally and 70% of SMEs did not know about GrowthAccelerator. AXA suggests that the government needs to better promote the service.

"~"

Overton UK

Talousapu~"Talousapu financial and debt counselling helpline"~"Finland"~"

Entrepreneurs

"~"

The Talousapu service is a national
column2: free-of-charge and confidential financial and debt counselling helpline that is targeted at entrepreneurs and small companies. The service also includes an online service as part of ‘Yritys-Suomi’ (‘Enterprise Finland’)
column3: the talousapu.fi website
column4:
containing a vast array of advice and instructions related to companies financial planning and business development.

"~"

Due to the outbreak of the financial crisis
column5: the service was launched in October 2009. The service is in high demand
column6: with some 10 to 15% of companies struggling with financial problems
column7: regardless of economic cycles. Every year
column8: the helpline receives around 2
column9:
000 calls. The helpline reports that it can help about two thirds of its callers with their financial problems. For one third the financial situation is already so serious that the company has to discontinue its business. 

"~"

The service is confidential (anonymous
column10: if desired) as entrepreneurs often find it difficult to ask for help. The helpline is also availabe late night (6-9 p.m.) and weekends
column11:
then operated on a voluntary basis by the nonprofit organisation CBMC Christian Businessmen Connection. 

"~"
column12:
sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"" lang=""EN-GB"">The service does not have permanent financing. It is being financed by the Ministry of Employment one year at a time and was under threat of closure in 2013.

column11: 000 as of 2012) will be subject to subsidy (€4
column12: 000 to be paid by the ICEX); in the latter case

column14: 000 to the company. Moreover
column15: ICO (the official credit institute belonging to the Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness) offers loans to those companies that are awarded an ICEX programme or are shortlisted by ICEX to have a good internationalisation potential. Cobertura de riesgo del tipo de interes: convenio de ajuste reciproco de intereses (CARI)~"Coverage of interest rate risk: agreement on reciprocal adjustment of interests "~"Spain"~"

Firms exporting goods or services

"~"

There are basically three types of entities involved in any credit transaction CARI: the Spanish exporter and foreign importer involved in commercial operations
column2: and signing the necessary export trade agreement and the credit agreements; the Spanish private financial institutions (banks
column3: savings banks
column4: credit unions
column5: etc.) granting export credits; and the Spanish public agencies and entities (ICO
column6: Directorate General for Trade and Investment from the Ministry of Industry
column7: Tourism and Trade)
column8: that channel the official support to the export credit granted. The loan availed by the CARI system may finance a maximum of 85% of the amount of exported goods and services (Spanish and foreign) and merchant fees
column9: and up to 100% of local costs
column10: taking into account some limitations. It is a system to support Spanish exports of goods and services by encouraging financial institutions to provide long term export credits (2 or more years) with fixed interest rates. The public authorities cover the risks involved in the financial operations between the financial entities and the exporters. Depending on how financial markets evolve throughout the course of the credit term
column11:
the national government may end up making payments to the financial institutions.

column1:
Exportgarantie~"Export credit guarantee"~"Austria"~"

Exporting companies.

"~"

The OeKB is Austria’s official export credit agency (ECA) on behalf of the Federal Ministry of Finance (BMF). It acts based on the export promotion law (Ausfuhrförderungsgesetz (AusfFG)) and international guidelines of the OECD and EU. It runs a system of export credits for non-marketable risks of foreign trade (more risk intensive markets
column2: risk duration often more than 2 years). Precondition for receiving a credit is a guarantee of the state
column3:
of a credit insurance company of the Austria Economy Service (AWS) or of an international organisation. OeKB checks the applications and then the finance ministry decides on giving a guarantee.

"~"

Large
column4: stand-alone domestic firms (which are not part of a multinational enterprise) with a high R&D intensity and a high risk exposure are most likely to make use of the public export credit guarantee. In 2011
column6: 300 companies were dealt with
column8: 600 credits were supported
column9: and 5
column10:
950 new financing agreements given. No more recent information is available as of June 2014.

"~"

Important policy tool to mitigate the negative trade effects of financial constraints due to market failures such as asymmetric information; the export-promoting effect of guarantees certainly has positive repercussions for output
column11: employment
column12:
and general tax revenues.

column1:
L'indemnisation des travailleurs licenciés en cas de fermeture d'entreprises ~"Wage guarantee in case of employer insolvency"~"Belgium"~"

Collective dismissals (at least 10 in companies with 20-100 employees
column2: 10% in companies with 101-299 employees
column3:
at least 30 in companies with 300 or more employees) caused by bankruptcy or insolvency of the employer

"~"

In case of collective layoffs as a result of bankruptcy or insolvency of a company
column4:
workers receive a closing-down indemnity paid by a closing fund managed by the public employment services.

The employment contract must be terminated 12 months before to 13 months after the closing in order to receive guarantees in case of employer’s insolvency.

There are no exclusions of part-time or fixed-term workers.

The fund will intervene in the payment of wages due and indemnities and benefits that are due. There is a maximum (about €22
column5: 000 yearly or about €1
column6: 900 monthly for outstanding salary
column7: holiday pay
column8:
severance indemnity and the indemnities and benefits that are due to the employee) per employee (with exception of additional payments in case of early retirement) (as of 2013).

There is no minimum duration of the contract of employment to qualify for wage guarantee in case of insolvency.

The fund is financed through social security contributions by the employer levied on the gross salary of employees.

Payment will be realised also if the employer does not contribute.

"~"

Between 2006 and 2009
column9: about 16
column10: 000 applications have been registered
column11: and claims of about 72
column12:
000 workers were satisfied; the Fund states in its 2005 annual report that it pays on average within a period of 12 months after the payment request has been filed.

No information available~"Overtime work"~"Belgium"~"

Extraordinary workload

"~"

The daily eight-hour working time limit can be exceeded in response to an extraordinary workload. Authorisation from the relevant government authority and the agreement of the workers' union representative is required. An employee may work a maximum of 12 hours per day and 50 hours per week. Overtime work entitles the worker to extra compensation of 50% during weekdays and 100% on Sundays and public holidays.

column1:
FOGASA~"Insolvency Guarantee Fund"~"Spain"~"

There is a special insolvency state fund addressed to workers whose employer has been declared insolvent or bankrupt
column2:
or who had to stop paying wages for certain economic reasons.

\r\n

 

\r\n

Anyone providing services for an employer and receiving wage for this
column3: including part-time and fixed-term workers
column4:
irrespective of the duration of employment is eligible.

\r\n

Domestic servants employed by families
column5: artists
column6:
partners of workers' cooperatives are exempted.

\r\n

Insolvency is considered if it is for economic
column7: technical and organisational reasons
column8:
when force majeure terminates employment contracts or when not enough assets are found by a judicial execution proceeding.

\r\n

An employer is declared insolvent by law if there are not sufficient means to satisfy the obligations.

"~"

The insolvency law from 2003 establishes the workers’ privilege as creditors in cases where the company goes bankrupt. In this case the claims of the workers of the company (wages for the 30 days before the opening of the collective proceedings; wages for work after the start of the collective proceedings; economic compensation related to termination of the employment contract etc.) have the priority
column9:
ranking ahead of all other claims.

The guarantee only becomes active if there are not enough assets available.

 

The guarantee covers wages
column10: bonuses and fringe benefits
column11:
financial employee participation that arises up to one year before the insolvency.

\r\n

In terms of wages pending to be paid
column12: the fund pays an amount which is the outcome of multiplying the double of the daily National Minimum Wage by the number of days of wages pending do be paid. There is a maximum of payment of 120 days. However
column13: if the employer was declared insolvent before the 15<sup>th</sup> of July of 2012
column14:
the maximum of payment is 150 days.

\r\n

In terms of severance pay
column15: there is a maximum payment of 12 months per year worked. However
column16: the wage which is taken into consideration in order to calculate the severance pay cannot be higher than the double of the daily minimum wage. However
column17: if the employer was declared insolvent before the 15<sup>th</sup> of July of 2012
column18:
the maximum of severance pay can be equal to three times of the daily minimum wage.

\r\n

The guarantee is administered by the Guarantee Institution FOGASA of the labour ministry and financed by employer contributions.

"~"

In 2007
column20: 032 applications were solved
column21: and claims of 20
column22: 498 companies and 73
column23: 447 workers were satisfied. In 2008
column24: figures remained more or less stable: 49
column25: 792 applications were solved
column26: and claims of 25
column27: 637 companies and 90
column29: two years later those figures dramatically increased. Thus
column37: 036 applications were satisfied
column38: and claims of 85
column40:
931 workers were satisfied.

\r\n

That increase led the government to reduce the level of payment by means of Royal Decree 20/2012.

"~"

column1:
Social Insurance Fund ~"Social Insurance Fund "~"Ireland"~"

All employed in an employment relationship underlying full social security protection
column2: irrespective of the duration of the employment contract. Part-time and fixed-term contracts are covered. For temporary agency workers
column3: the party which pays the wage/salary is considered the employer - if the hirer company pays wage/salary and becomes insolvent/liquidated
column4:
the temp agency worker comes under the criteria for access to the SIF.

\r\n

An employer is considered insolvent if the company went bankrupt
column5: has been put under administration/liquidated
column6:
filed for insolvency (either in Ireland or in another EU Member State) or is legally administered because of the death of the entrepreneur. Examinership and winding up of partnerships are excluded.

"~"

To apply for support
column7:
employees have to fill in some forms and submit them to the insolvency administrator who checks them and confirms them at the guarantee fund.

\r\n

The SIF pays the claims to the insolvency administrator who forwards them to the employees after deducting taxes and similar.

\r\n

The insolvency administrator is also responsible to answer employees’ questions regarding the extent of the claims. For other questions
column8:
employees are referred to the insolvency income department of the ministry.

\r\n

Guaranteed are non-paid wages
column9: holiday remuneration as well as other claims the employee has against the employer
column10: such as severance payments
column11:
maternity payments or similar.

\r\n

Non-paid wages
column12: sickness payments
column13:
holiday remuneration and income for non-worked hours are paid for a maximum of eight weeks.

In most of the cases claims that arose during the 18 months prior to the insolvency/being made redundant are considered.

There is a maximum weekly level that is subject to change (€600 as of 2014).

The Fund is financed by employers and employees contributions as well as through taxes.

The guarantee of the Fund is independent of the employer paying the contributions.

The regulation provides that the Fund should satisfy the employee within 60 days of the request.

The Minister for Enterprise
column14:
Jobs and Innovation can also use the Fund to make payments into the assets of an occupational pension scheme so as to cover contributions that could not be paid by the employer due to insolvency.

\r\n

The weekly cap on payments from the SIF (€600 as of 2014) is the same cap that applies to statutory redundancy payments (which as of 2014 is two weeks' pay per year of service
column15:
plus one week's pay).

"~"

Between 2006 and 2009
column16: about 1
column17: 300 applications were registered
column18: which satisfied claims of around 41
column19:
100 workers.
