column1:
Qualifications and Credit Framework (QCF)~"Qualifications and Credit Framework (QCF)"~"United Kingdom"~"

The Qualifications and Credit Framework (QCF) is a credit transfer system that recognises qualifications and units by awarding credits. The system gives learners the ability to get qualifications at their own pace. The measure covers all private and public organisations in England
column2:
Wales and Northern Ireland that offer inhouse training to their workers. Organisations in Scotland are covered by the similar Scottish Credit and Qualifications Framework (SCQF). 

"~"

The Qualifications and Credit Framework (QCF) was designed to help learners
column3: learning providers and employers understand different qualifications and how they relate to one another. The QCF was formally launched in November 2008. Most of the qualifications offered within the QCF are vocational. The QCF is a comprehensive framework that recognises achievements at any level. The Qualifications and Credit Framework (QCF) includes a credit transfer system in which employers can have their inhouse training programmes nationally accredited and recognised. In the QCF system
column4: learners can gain three types of qualifications: awards
column5: certificates and diplomas. The QCF has an Entry Level plus 8 levels. It is very similar to the SQCF
column6:
with the later having 12 levels. The titles are also slightly different between the QCF and SQCF.  

"~"

No information available.

"~"

The QCF (and SCQF) provides flexible routes to gain qualifications and is accessible to a wide range of learners. Learners can get credit for their work-based skills and learning that can count towards units and qualifications. There is also the provision for assessment and recognition of prior learning (RPL). Credits can be transferred between qualifications and organisations in the QCF. It is also relevant to employers as it helps learners obtain qualifications that meet industry needs.  The QCF is deliberately similar to the Framework for Higher Education Qualifications (FHEQ) and creates the potential for credit transfers from the QFC to FHEQ qualifications. All accredited qualifications and organisations with their qualifications are listed in the Register of Regulated Qualifications. The Register is managed and operated by the Ofqual for the regulators of England (Ofqual)
column7:
Wales (DCELLS) and Northern Ireland (CCEA). 

"~"

The United Kingdom (UK) has two qualification frameworks in place - the QCF (in England
column8: Wales and Northern Ireland) and SCQF (in Scotland). The frameworks are very similar but differ in terms of the number of levels and titles of qualifications. This creates potential confusion for learners who move between England
column9:
Wales or Northern to/from Scotland and for employers recruiting workers with qualifications obtained under the two different systems.

"~"

No information available

column1:
Nachfolgemoderatoren~"Succession facilitators"~"Germany"~"

All companies anticipating business succession.

"~"

The succession facilitator scheme was established in Baden-Wuerttemberg by the chamber of commerce and industry (CCI) Heilbronn-Franken in order to support companies facing a business succession. The objective of the scheme is to establish a dialogue with companies facing succession in the future and advise them personally in the different phases of the succession. This includes for instance the support in the search for potential successors or advise on the transfer of firm-specific know-how to the successors. Advise comes from experienced entrepreneurs or business experts who are themselves part of the CCIs. This fosters trust in the facilitator and the level of confidentiality that is needed in the sensitive processes of a business succession.

\r\n

In Baden-Wuerttemberg
column2: the scheme is administered by five CCIs
column3: with the CCI Heilbronn-Franken being the leading force. Furthermore
column4:
other CCIs in Germany have established their own succession facilitator programme.

"~"

In Baden-Wuerttemberg
column5: there are about 1
column6: 000 business successions facilitated by the scheme each year. In 2012
column8: 357 senior entrepreneurs throughout Germany have approached the CCIs in order to get support for a business succession. At the same time
column10:
522 potential successors were registered. The trend shows that there has been an increasing number of successions and a decreasing number of potential successors over the last years.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

column1:
VækstKaution~"Loan guarantee scheme "~"Denmark"~"

There is a list of criteria a company must fulfil in order to be eligible for loan guarantees: The company must have no more than 250 employees
column2: be independent of larger companies and have an annual turnover of less than DKK 372 million (about EUR 50 million) or balance less than DKK 320 million. The company's three last financial statements must show a positive trend
column3: the management must provide over all relevant competencies and the<span style=""font-size: 10px;""> investment must amount to at least DKK 2 million (about  EUR 268
column4: 033)
column5:
either on its own or in combination with the loan. Companies must have a sound business plan.

"~"

The loan guarantee scheme (VækstKaution) is offered by the Danish Investment Fund (VækstFonden) since the year 2000. This scheme helps SMEs by co-financing their investments.

"~"

Since 2002
column6: the Danish Investment Fund has co-financed investment plans of more than 4
column7: 500 companies with a total of DKK 12 billion (about EUR 1
column8:
6 billion).

column1:
Ochrana zaměstnanců před platební neschopností zaměstnavatele~"Wage guarantee in case of insolvency"~"Czech Republic"~"

All employment relationships based on private law are eligible
column2: including part-time workers
column3: fixed-term workers
column4: domestic servants
column5: but excluding some public officials (e.g. emplyoees of territorial self-governing units or other legal bodies founded by the law
column6:
if the state takes on their debts).

\r\n

Employees who are members of the employer’s statutory body or shareholders with half and higher participation or employees who work for the employer as temporary agency workers are excluded.

\r\n

Managers must not obtain any property from assets of their employer (Bankruptcy Law).

"~"

In cases of an employer becoming insolvent
column7: employees' claims have priority in the liquidation process (judicial liquidation and reorganisation). In court decisions
column8:
wages have the same rank as the claims of the liquidation administrator (‘super priority’) (Bankruptcy Law).

\r\n

All claims (wages
column9: payment for holidays
column10: termination of a job
column11:
payment for time off to visit a doctor etc.) that arose within the last six months before the insolvency are covered.

\r\n

There is a maximum of three months' unpaid wages
column12:
with one and a half times the average wage per month in the Czech Republic. The guarantee is directly effected by the state. The application has to be submitted to the public employment service which approves or rejects it. The guarantee is financed by the state; there are no employers’ contributions.

"~"

column1:
Lønmodtagernes Garantifond ~"Employees' Guarantee Fund "~"Denmark"~"

Support is provided in case of bankruptcy
column2: the employer’s death where the court declares the company insolvent
column3:
the termination of the business while it is proven that the employer is unable to pay the employees’ claims or during the employer’s court-supervised suspension of payments according to the provisions of the bankruptcy law.

\r\n

All employees are eligible
column4: including part-time and fixed-term workers
column5:
except for family members and close associates of the insolvent employer.

\r\n

There is no minimum duration for the employment relationship in order for workers to qualify for the guarantee.

"~"

Employees can apply to the Employees’ Guarantee Fund (Lonmodtagernes Garantifond
column6: LG) for wage and holiday compensation
column7:
indemnification for interruption of the employment relationship and compensation in connection with discharge from employment.

The claims have to arise in the period of four months after bankruptcy or six months after notice of suspension of payments or the death of the employer.

LG is an independent national institution governed by the social partners and regulated by law. All private employers pay a quarterly contribution to the fund.

The maximum compensation from the fund is DKK 160
column10: about 7
column11: 300 applications have been registered
column12: and claims of about 74
column13:
200 workers were satisfied; an employee's claim is usually paid 4 weeks after the fund has received the application.

"~"

column1:
Building Financial Capability in SMEs~"Building Financial Capability in SMEs"~"Ireland"~"

The programme is open to owners and senior managers of micro
column2: small and medium sized companies in all sectors
column3:
including farming.

"~"

Starting in 2014
column4: the Building Financial Capability in SMEs programme is to foster the capabilities of small and medium size business owners to secure finance for their firms. The programme consists of 2-day training courses
column5: in which 15 to 20 business owners participate in workshops
column6: organised by ManagementWorks
column7:
an initiative of Skillsnets Ltd.

\r\n

In these workshops
column8: the main aims are to inform about different sources of finance
column9: to increase capabilities to discuss business plans vis-a-vis financial institutions
column10: to teach about banks' standards to evaluate credit applications
column11: and to inform about options to secure finance with the Credit Review Office. Furthermore
column12:
the programme offers each participant 2 personal information sessions about their own business with an experienced business mentor.

\r\n

Participation costs EUR 250 per person (ex. VAT). ManagementWorks receives funding from the National Training Fund through the Irish Department of Education and Skills.

\r\n

column1:
Fundusz Gwarantowanych Świadczeń Pracowniczych~"Guaranteed Employee Benefits Fund "~"Poland"~"

Insolvency is considered as a situation in which the employer cannot fulfil its obligations. Such a situation needs to be permanent
column2:
hence the employer should start a liquidation process or an extrajudicial agreement after rejection of legal procedures due to lack of assets.

\r\n

Public entities are exempt.

\r\n

All employees that are in an employment relationship with the employer are eligible
column3:
except of those that are close relatives of the entrepreneur and domestic staff.

\r\n

Payments will only be made for the first insolvency of the same employer and the same employees.

\r\n

There is no minimum duration of the employment relationship in order for employees to be eligible.

"~"

In the case of employer insolvency
column4: all claims of workers
column5:
previous workers and their surviving dependants are guaranteed by the Guaranteed Employee Benefits Fund (Fundusz Gwarantowanych Świadczeń Pracowniczych).

\r\n

The fund covers all claims stemming from the employment relationship or its termination that have not been paid to the employee due to the insolvency or economically difficult situation of the employer.

\r\n

These costs include work income
column6: indemnification for non-worked hours that arose without the fault of the employee
column7: sickness and holiday payments
column8: severance payments
column9:
retirement payments that arose up to three months before the start of the insolvency procedure or the end of the employment relationship (as long as this did not happen longer than nine months before the insolvency).

\r\n

The total monthly payment from the fund cannot exceed the employee's average salary from the previous quarter.

\r\n

The fund is mainly financed by employers’ contributions
column10: supplemented by debt collection
column11: recovery of funds from employers and other sources
column12: donations
column13:
voluntary payments of employers or subsidies.

\r\n

Payments to employees are realised independently of the employer paying their contributions.

\r\n

Since 2012 the Fund has no longer the legal personality and it is only a special fund at the disposal of the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy.

"~"

The Fund is operational and its activity is highly appreciated by employers and trade unions. For example
column14: in the Masovian Voivodship in 2013 about 5
column15:
000 persons got payments from the Fund for the amount of PLN 29 million (EUR 7.25 million).

"~"

The special fund supervised by the state always will have sufficient amount of funds for its activities.

"~"

Social partners claim that funds should be allocated for additional purposes
column16: such as maintaining workplaces during temporary difficulties (partial compensation for any work stoppage
column17: monthly subsidies for partial remuneration for reduced working hours
column18:
debt payment relief). The procedures of the instrument are perceived as too complicated and time-consuming. They should be simplified and shortened.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Wydłużony okres rozliczeniowy czasu pracy~"Extension of working time settlement period"~"Poland"~"

If it is justifiable by objective
column2:
technical or organisational reasons.

"~"

In any system of working time arrangement
column3: if it is justifiable by objective
column4: technical or organisational reasons
column5: the reference period
column6: i.e. working time settlement period
column7: can be extended to 12 months. If trade unions exist in a company
column8: such extension has to be laid down in the special agreement concluded with them. In a non-unionised company
column9:
a similar agreement must be concluded with the workers representatives choosen in the way established in the company (they are not identical to representatives from a works council). The Labour Inspectorate must be informed.

"~"

According to the
column11: 901-firm-z-elastycznym-czasem-pracy.html"">information of the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy
column12: 901 enterprises have introduced agreements on the extension of working time by 15 March 2014. Most of them were in large companies employing from 50 to 249 people (335 agreements). Slightly less were in medium-sized companies
column13: employing up to 49 employees (249)
column14: and in the largest companies
column15: with over 250 employees (157). Most of the agreements were established in companies operating in manufacturing (37%)
column16:
wholesale and retail trade and repair (17%) and construction (11%).

"~"

The new working time regulations are seen by employers and the Ministry as the important measure which helps to protect existing jobs and create new workplaces
column17:
especially in companies dependent on seasonal employment.

"~"

The changes in working time could pose a threat to employees' health
column18: safety and work-life balance. They would make it possible for employers to avoid paying overtime. At non-unionised workplaces employee representatives
column19: needed to sign the agreement
column20: could be selected by a minority of workers and employees' real participation is not guaranteed.  The way in which such representation should be established
column21:
was not defined in the Labour Code.

"~"

column1:
Darbinieku aizsardzību darba devēja maksātnespējas gadījumā~"Protection of Employees in Case of Insolvency of the Employer"~"Latvia"~"

All employees are eligible for satisfaction of claims in case of insolvency of the employer. Insolvency of an employer is in effect from the day when a court judgment regarding insolvency of the employer enters into legal effect.

\r\n

There is no minimum duration for the contract of employment for workers to qualify.

"~"

For cases where the company becomes bankrupt
column2: an Employee Claims Guarantee Fund has been established in Latvia
column3:
operated by the Insolvency Administration (state agency). Employees can submit the claim to the Fund after the court's decision on companies insolvency. No claims can be submitted before.

\r\n

From the resources of the Employee Claims Guarantee Fund
column4: the following payments have to be covered: work remuneration
column5: reimbursement for annual paid leave
column6: reimbursement for other types of paid leave
column7: severance pay in connection with the termination of an employment relationship
column8:
reimbursement for injury in connection with an accident at work or an occupational disease.

Employee claims is satisfied to the following amounts:

  • work remuneration for the last three months of employment relationship in the twelve months before the insolvency of the employer came into effect;
  • reimbursement for annual paid leave
column9:
the right to which has been acquired in the twelve months before the insolvency of the employer came into effect;
  • reimbursement for other types of paid leave in last three months of employment relationship in the last twelve months before the insolvency of employer came into effect;
  • severance pay of the minimum amount prescribed by law;
  • reimbursement for damages for the whole unpaid time period;
  • reimbursement for damages for the four subsequent years.

    • Resources of the Employee Claims Guarantee Fund consist of the share of the State entrepreneurial risk fee
column10: employers' contribution for each employee (amount determined by the Cabined of Ministers)
column11: gifts and donations
column12:
and resources recovered by administrators.

"~"

In 2012 2
column13:
158 employees' claims to the Fund were satisfied.

"~"

column1:
Insolvenzgeld~"Insolvency compensation"~"Germany"~"

Outstanding payments resulting from the termination of business activities following the opening/rejection of insolvency proceedings are covered. An employer is also considered insolvent if the company is definitively closed down or if there is a high probability that payment obligations cannot be settled at due date or if the assets are not sufficient to cover debts.

\r\n

All workers employed with private employers are entitled
column2:
including trainees or apprentices and homeworkers.

"~"

In case of outstanding payments resulting from the termination of business activities
column3: workers are entitled to three months of financial compensation prior to the opening of insolvency proceedings or the rejection of insolvency proceedings (if the employment ended before that
column4:
for the three months before the termination of the employment contract).

\r\n

The worker is informed by works council (covered by the Works Constitutioin Act in case of insolvency) and the employer representative
column5:
the insolvency manager.

\r\n

The compensation comprises net wage including holiday remuneration
column6: payment in case of illness
column7: remuneration for overtime
column8: travel costs etc.
column9:
with certain maximum limits; income from a new employment contract or from self-employment during the 'insolvency income period' will be deducted.

The compensation is covered by a central public fund set up for covering potential claims of workers in case of insolvency. The fund rests on monthly contributions by private employers (0.15% of pay roll) paid alongside with social security contributions to the statutory health insurers. Public employers and public agencies/bodies exempt from risk of insolvency do not have to contribute to the fund.

The compensation is paid by the Federal Employment Agency.

Application for insolvency income has to be filed with the public employment service within two months after the agency has attested the termination of business or the insolvency case
column10:
otherwise the employee loses the entitlement.

"~"

The Federal Employment Agency gives statistics on the claimants of 'Insolvenzgeld'. In 2011
column11: the claims of 130
column12: 649 workers were satisfied
column13: some 8
column14: 075 were rejected. The number of claimants decreaed to 114
column15: 608 in 2012 and to 119
column16: 437 in 2013. Some 7
column18:
300 (2013) claims were rejected.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Fondul de garantare pentru plata creanţelor salariale~"Guarantee fund for debt salaries"~"Romania"~"

The Guarantee Fund for debt salaries is designed to ensure payment of wage claims arising from individual employment contracts and collective concluded by employers who were given final judicial decision to open insolvency procedures and to which total or partial removal of the right of management was prepared (employers in the state of insolvency).

"~"

Employers are required to pay a monthly contribution to the Guarantee Fund
column2: in the quota of 0.25%
column3: applied to the fund's total monthly wages. They are also obliged to notify the fiscal administration
column4: every  month until the 25 day
column5: the amount of contribution to the wage guarantee  fund. The fund is administrated by the National Agency for Employment
column6:
through its local agencies.

\r\n

Form this Fund
column7: the employees may claim the outstanding wages for a  period of three calendar months
column8:
in case their employer is in insolvency.

From the guarantee fund resources wages or compensatory payments and indemnities for temporary interruption of activity may be paid. From this fund it is not possible to be paid the social contributions of the companies in insolvency.

The total amount of the claims incurred by the guarantee fund may not exceed the amount of three average gross salaries at national level per employee.

The Law transposes the Council Directive 80/987/EEC of 20 October 1980 on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to the protection of employees in the event of the insolvency of their employer.

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This measure is meant to provide for the protection of employees in the event of the insolvency of their employer
column9:
in particular in order to guarantee payment of their outstanding claims

column1:
Public Guarantee, Alimony and Disability Fund of the Republic of Slovenia ~"No information available"~"Slovenia"~"

The Public Guarantee
column2: Alimony and Disability Fund of the Republic of Slovenia (hereafter
column3: the Guarantee Fund) protects claims of the employees whose employment has been terminated due to the bankruptcy proceedings
column4: a valid decision on compulsory composition
column5: insolvency procedure in one of the other EU Member States or European Economic Area (the job was being carried out or generally being carried out in the Republic of Slovenia)
column6: or the company being deleted from the court register without liquidation under the provisions of the Financial Operations
column7:
Insolvency Proceedings and Compulsory Dissolution Act (ZFPPIPP).

"~"

In case of insolvency
column8: wages and their compensations for the last three months prior to insolvency proceedings
column9:
compensations for work accidents and occupational diseases and unpaid severance pay shall be paid prior to other unsecured claims.

Coverage by the Guarantee Fund includes the right to receive payment (in total amount not exceeding four and a half minimum wages) of the:

  • unpaid wages for the period of the last three months prior to the termination of the employment relationship (maximum of three minimum wages prescribed by the Minimum Wage Act
column10:
lowered by taxes and contributions);
  • unpaid wage compansation for sick leave for the last three months before the termination of the employment relationship (maximum of three minimum wages prescribed by the Minimum Wage Act
column11:
lowered by taxes and contributions);
  • wage compensation for unused annual holidays
column12: to which the employee was entitled in the current year (maximum of one half of minimal wage prescribed by the Minimum Wage Act
column13:
lowered by taxes and contributions);
  • severance payment
column14: as provided by the law on employment relations (maximum of one minimum wage prescribed by the Minimum Wage Act
column15:
lowered by taxes and contributions).\r\n\r\n

The Guarantee Fund is financed (with regard to covering payments to the employees) by the state budget
column16:
by employers and by the Guarantee Fund through means of transfer and enforcement of claims from the insolvent employer.

\r\n

The deadline for filing the request to enforce the above mentioned rights is 90 days after the termination of the employment relationship. The Guarantee Fund has to meet all its obligations within 30 days after the decision and the procedure is final.

"~"

The last published annual report of the Guarantee Fund shows that payments to beneficiaries in 2011 were provided from the budget in the amount of € 18
column18: 436 (91.7 % of the funds paid) and from subrogation funds in the amount of € 1
column21: the average net payment amounted to € 1
column22: 640.75 per beneficiary (in 2010
column23: € 1
column24: 583.31). Most of the funds in 2011 (76.1 %) were paid for unpaid wages and unpaid wage compensation
column25:
14.1 % for unpaid severance payment and 9.8 % for wage compensation for unused annual holidays.

"~"

column1:
Statsgaranti for lønnskrav ved konkurs ~"State guarantee for wages in case of insolvency "~"Norway"~"

Employer bankruptcy
column2: public administration of insolvent estates
column3:
compulsory liquidation and public administration of insurance companies or banks.

"~"

In the case of bankruptcy
column4:
any outstanding pay and pay for the termination period as well as any accrued holiday pay is paid to employees by the state through a guarantee system.

\r\n

Once bankruptcy proceedings have commenced
column5:
claims are covered for one month from the date on which bankruptcy proceedings commenced. This applies even if a longer period of notice applies through agreement or by law. Coverage for holiday pay is only offered for such pay accrued in the same year as the final date for claims and the year before.

The final date of claims is the date on which the bankruptcy proceedings commenced in court.

The guarantee applies to all employees that are in an employment relationship subject to payroll tax. Self-employed and shareholders (who own at least 20%) are not covered.

The following claims can be covered:

  • Pay for a maximum of six months. The pay claim must not have been due for payment more than twelve months before the deadline. This time limit is absolute.
  • Holiday pay accrued in the same year as the final date of claim and the year before.
  • Pension benefits for a maximum of six months.
  • Compensation for lost remuneration for the performance of work for maximum six months.
  • Interest.
  • Reasonable costs linked to filing a petition for bankruptcy.

Maximum coverage is limited to a gross amount equivalent to two times the National Insurance basic amount. Reasonable costs linked to filing a petition for bankruptcy are in addition to this.

"~"

The number of employees making claims under this scheme in 2013 was around 18
column7:
and the scheme paid out in total around € 105 million (NOK 820 million).

column1:
Παροχή λόγω αφερεγγυότητας του εργοδότη~"Wage guarantee in case of insolvency "~"Greece"~"

All employees are protected through an OAED (Organisation for the Employment of the Workforce) account set up to cover cases of employer insolvency.

\r\n

The guarantee covers claims from dependent employment
column2: irrespective of the duration of employment and whether or not the employment is still upright
column3:
even covering illegal employment relationships if they have the structure of a relationship of dependent labour. There is no minimum duration for the employment relationship.

There are four types of insolvency:

  • the company is announced insolvent by court and its business activities stopped;
  • the company is put under administration;
  • an insurance company that loses its authorisation due to violating legal regulations and therefore becomes insolvent;
  • an employer terminates all employment contracts and goes into insolvency in order to pay its debts.

If the company is put into provisional administration (creditor administration and management) or into receivership so that a compromise can be reached with its creditors
column4:
the case is excluded from protection.

"~"

The guarantee covers all claims of the employee for up to three months
column5:
but the claims have to have come into existence within the last six months before filing for insolvency.

There is a maximum of three times the agreed work income. The application has to be registered with OAED (the public employment service) within six months after the insolvency became public.

The fund is partly funded by employers' contributions (0.15%) and partly by the labour ministry.

The employees’ claims are independent from whether or not the employer paid the contributions.

On average
column6:
claims for remuneration are met within 1 month after the application by the employee has been made.

"~"

The wage guarantee in case of insolvency has been provided to many individuals since 2008
column7: given that the number of enterprises which  become insolvent has grown substantially. However
column8:
there are no relevant data published from OAED.

"~"

Given that the rate of enterprises closing down is high
column9: and that the unemployment benefit is low (approx. € 360 per month) and provided for a limited time only (approx. one year)
column10:
the wage guarantee in case of insolvency is an important benefit for the people who lose their jobs. 

"~"

The wage guarantee in case of insolvency is a relief for people entering unemployment
column11: however
column12: it is provided for a limited time and given that social protection in Greece is in general limited
column13:
it cannot guarantee a living standard above the limit of poverty for the people who lose their jobs. 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Διευθέτηση του χρόνου εργασίας~"Organisation of working time"~"Greece"~"

Whole economy.

"~"

Organisation of working time was instituted and readjusted with the 'Memorandum' labour act (Act 3986/2011)
column2: which introduced a series of new regulations with collective bargaining at the core. In brief
column3: the relevant provisions provide that in firms with conventional working hours of up to 40 hours a week it is permitted for a period of time (a period of high employment) for an employee to work 2 hours more than the eight-hour day
column4:
on the condition that the weekly working hours which are in addition to the 40 hours or the minimum hours stated in the contract are subtracted from the weekly hours of another period (period of low employment).

\r\n

 

\r\n

In firms with conventional working hours of up to 40 hours a week
column5: it is permitted
column6: instead of the arrangement in the previous paragraph
column7: to be agreed that up to 256 working hours from the total annual hours of employment in 1 calendar year may be allocated so that there is an increased number of hours during certain periods
column8: which may not exceed 32 weeks annually
column9:
with a correspondingly reduced number of hours for the remaining periods of the calendar year.

 

Employees have the right to refuse the additional work if they are not in a position to perform it and their refusal is in good faith. Salaries for the periods of deviating working hours shall be those of the usual working hours.

 

The organisation of working time is determined by firm-level collective labour agreements or by agreement between the employer and the trade union representing the firm’s members or by agreement between the employer and the works council or by agreement between the employer and an association of persons. The association of persons can be set up by at least 25% of the employees of a firm with more than 20 employees and 15% if the total number of employees is no more than 20.

 

With firm-level and sectoral collective labour agreements a different system for organising working time can be established
column10:
depending on the particularities of the sector of the firm.

"~"

In 2010
column12: 253 alterations to contracts were registered with SEPE (labour inspectorate)
column13: of which 18
column14: 713 were altered from full-time to part-time and 7
column15: 540 from full-time to rotating employment. These figures rose in 2011 to 58
column16: 962 alterations to contracts (an increase of 124.6% over 2010)
column17: of which 32
column18: 420 were altered from full-time to part-time and 26
column19: 542 from full-time to rotating employment. In 2012
column20: alterations to contracts soared to 84
column21: 490 (an increase of 43.3% over 2011)
column22: of which 49
column23: 640 were altered from full-time to part-time and 34
column24:
850 from full-time to rotating employment.

\r\n

In 2012
column25: there was a 18.42% reduction in full-time contracts of employment compared with 2011
column26:
and a 3.61% increase in part-time employment contracts. New hirings on part-time and rotating employment contracts represent 45% of all new contracts.

"~"

Through this measure lay-offs can be hindered and at the same time the employer is saving emploument costs in times of crisis.

"~"

It is not proved that in times of harsh economic climate this measure alone can hinder the business closure.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Закон за гарантираните вземания на работниците и служителите при несъстоятелност на работодателя~"Law for guaranteeing workers' and employees' receivables in the event of employer's insolvency"~"Bulgaria"~"

Insolvency of the employer.

"~"

The purpose of the law is to provide a maximum degree of protection for workers when insolvency proceedings have been opened against their employer. To achieve this
column2: a special fund (fund guaranteeing the claims of workers and employees in the event of insolvency of the employer) was established to secure the payment of parts of the unsettled claims of the workers affected
column3:
including wages and social security contributions and other compensations.

\r\n

The guaranteed receivables
column4: according to the law
column5: are the last six accrued but unpaid monthly wages and cash benefits in the last 12 calendar months preceding the month in which the decision of insolvency is entered pursuant but not more than the maximum amount of guaranteed claims
column6: and if the employee has been in employment with the same employer for at least three months. (Paragraph 22
column8:
Law for guaranteeing workers' and employees' receivables in the event of employer's insolvency )

\r\n

In general
column9: the employers are obliged to pay mandatory monthly contributions to the Fund for guaranteeing workers' and employees' receivables in the event of employer's insolvency for workers on labour contract. According to Art. 14
column10:
para. 1 from the Law for the Budget of the State Social Insurance in 2014 the employers should not pay contributions for the Fund.

\r\n

For 2013
column11: the maximum amount of secured claim was 1
column12: 000 BGN (€511). For 2014
column13: the maximum amount of secured claims is BGN 1
column14: 200 (€613.55). The total budget of the Fund for Guaranteeing receivables in case of insolvency for 2014 is 2
column16: 000 BGN (€1
column19:
according to the Law for Social Security Budget 2014.

"~"

In 2012
column20: 485 employees from 47 companies were beneficiaries of the fund. The average compensation was BGN 1
column21:
702 (€870).

"~"

The adoption and application of this law marks considerable progress in the development of the Bulgarian labour law. It strengthens the protection of the employees and widens the protective function of Bulgarian labour law as a whole.

column1:
Lönegarantilag~"Wage Guarantee Act"~"Sweden"~"

In case of employer insolvency
column2:
all employees who have not been indemnified for claims for the same activities during the last two years are eligible. Workers having been hired with the intervention of the public employment service as well as those who alone or together with close relatives own at least 20% of the company are not eligible.

\r\n

Claims are not only guaranteed in case of employer insolvency (permanent inability of the employer to pay the debts)
column3: but also if the company undergoes restructuring (current or foreseeable inability of the employer to pay the debts at due date
column4:
but there are activities to make the company survive a temporary crisis and avoid insolvency).

"~"

The wage guarantee is independent from the duration of the employment contract. It covers all claims that arose within the last three months before registering for insolvency and one month after the decision of the insolvency court.

\r\n

There is a maximum amount of about SEK 177
column5: 600 for 2014 (about € 19
column6:
700).

\r\n

The guarantee is financed by employers’ contribution and the state; there is no specific fund
column7:
but the financial means are registered as a special element in the national budget.

\r\n

The payments towards the employees is realised by each regional county administrative board
column8:
independent from the employer paying the contributions.

"~"

Between 2007 and 2011
column9: about 13
column10: 300 applications have been registered
column11: and claims of about 107
column12:
500 workers were satisfied (Kronofogden 2012).

"~"

The Wage Guarantee Act gives employees salary 1-6 months after their employer goes bankrupt which gives the employee time to look for other jobs. 

"~"

There have been some cheating cases related to the Wage Guarantee Act. In 2010 the Swedish Tax Authority and The County Administrative Board of Stockholm discovered that several people repeatedly got payments from the wage guarantee act. Further evidence that some people have been cheating was provided in a report published in 2011 (svt.se). The report concludes that it is hard to map the extent of the cheating since the is no coordination between the 21 County Administrative Boards in Sweden that handles the payments. 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Национален гаранционен фонд~"National Guarantee Fund (NGF)"~"Bulgaria"~"

Small and medium enterprises.

"~"

The National Guarantee Fund (NGF) aims to provide guarantees for SMEs. The application of the guarantee scheme will facilitate financing for SMEs by compensating the lack of history or sufficient guarantees when applying for a loan
column2: and will reduce the risk assumed by commercial banks in the country providing finance for SMEs. NGF supports the National Economic Policy
column3:
approved by the Council of Ministers.

\r\n

The guarantees issued by the fund cover 50% of the respective loan. With a change of the Loan for the Bulgarian Development Bank (December 2012)
column4: according to the schemes under the Programme for development of rural areas 2007-2013
column5: and the Operational Programme for development of the fishery sector 2007-2013
column6:
the guarantees might cover up to 80% of the loan.

\r\n

In addition
column7: NGF administers  micro credits within the Project 'Micro-credit Guarantee Fund'
column8:
transfered from Ministry of Labour and Social Policy to the Bulgarian Development Bank in 2009.

\r\n

The support provided by the NGF is in line with the following programes: Measure 121 'Modernisation of agro-farms' (2013-2015) under the Operational Programme 'Development of rural areas 2007 – 2013'; National Guarantee Fund programme 2014-2015; Executive Agency for Fishery and Aquacultures (2009-2015)
column9:
under the Operational Programme 'Fishery'.

"~"

Up to May 2014
column10: the total sum of credits
column11: guaranteed by NGF 2009-2013 is  390 million BGN (€199
column14: and 2
column15: 325 SMEs have been supported. Within the National  Fishery programme 2009-2015
column16: 19.4 million BGN (€9
column18: 092) were guaranteed
column19: and 20  SMEs were supported. Under the programme with the Ministry of Agriculture  and food
column20: 132.9 million BGN (€67
column22: 691) were guaranteed
column23:
and 262 SMEs were supported.

\r\n

According to the Executive manager of the Fund
column24: for the 5 years of its existence
column25: the Fund issued bank guarantees amounting to 254 million BGN (€129
column27: 137). With the support of the Fund
column29: 500 companies have received credits for half a billion BGN (€255
column30:
645) under different guarantee schemes.

column1:
Фонд 'Условия на труд'~"Working Conditions Fund"~"Bulgaria"~"

The eligible applicants are the folowing:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Individual and legal entities
column2: branch
column3: regional and district councils for working conditions - with projects and programmes for improving working conditions with industry relevance and applicability of the results as well as for development and publishing of educational and informational materials and and conducting courses in the area of health and safety issues; individual and legal entities who meet the requirements set out in
column4: d.bGE"">Regulation
column5:
d.bGE"">№1 of 23 March 2006 on the terms and conditions for financing of projects and programs from the ""Working Conditions"" Fund could apply for funding up to 30% of projects about improving working conditions in companies with specific practical feasibility; \r\n
  • Medical institutions that meet the requirements stipulated in
column6: d.bGE"">Regulation № 8 of 26 November 2007 about
column7:
d.bGE"">the terms and conditions for financing the diagnosis of occupational diseases from the ""Working Conditions"" Fund are able to apply for financing activities for diagnostic of occupational diseases;  \r\n
  • Ministries and state institutions are eligible to apply with projects for development of regulations
column8: rules
column9:
standards and requirements. "~"

The Working Condition Fund (WCF) provides financial support for projects and programmes addresing the following:

  • Improvement of working conditions in projects with industry relevance and practical applicability of the results;
  • Projects improving working conditions in individual companies with specific feasibility (financing up to 30% of the project cost) related to reconstruction and modernisation of existing facilities; 
  • Introduction of new and modernisation of existing technologies and/or facilities; 
  • Construction or improvement of the system for the prevention of workplace hazards; construction or improvement of the system in order to ensure the quality of work;
  • Improving the sanitary conditions; safety of machines and equipment; other projects related to the improvement of working conditions; 
  • Diagnosis of occupational diseases;
  • Development and publishing of educational and informational materials; organising and conducting courses in the area of health and safety at work;
  • Development of regulations
column10: rules
column11:
standards and requirements.\r\n\r\n

The funding comes from an annual subsidy from the state budget
column12: the Social Security Fund
column13: voluntary contributions
column14: donations and bequests from Bulgarian and foreign citizens and legal entities
column15: interest on account of the fund
column16:
as well as income from charitable activities.

\r\n

For 2013
column17:
the overall WCF budget was more than BGN 4 million (2045167 EUR).

"~"

According to the Ministry of Labour and Social Policy (MLSP)
column18: WCF signed contcats with 13 companies and funded modernisation of the work places for BGN 0.5 million (23 July 2014). Executing these projects will assure better work places for 1
column19: 871 workers. According to the Annual Report of MLSP for 2013
column20:
WCF signed 46 contracts.

column1:
Mobilité volontaire sécurisée ~"Secured voluntary mobility "~"France"~"

Workers can benefit from this measure if they fulfil two conditions: 

  • they are working in a company or a group employing at least 300 people 
  • they have 24 months seniority
column2: consecutive or not
column3:
within the company \r\n"~"

Articles L.1222-12 to L.1222-16 of the Labour Code
column4: introduced by Law n°2013-504
column5: allow workers to benefit
column6: with the agreement of their employer
column7: from a period of 'secured voluntary mobility' during which the performance of the employment contract is suspended. This measure is supposed to help workers to enrich their career path by getting experience from another company
column8: without having to terminate their employment contract. During this period
column9: as the employment contract is suspended in the company of origin
column10:
workers are paid by the receiving company. 

\r\n

This period of mobility must be established in an amendment to the employment contract
column11:
which will provide for:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • the objective
column12: the duration
column13:
the starting and the ending day of this period (there is no minimum or maximum limit stated in the law) \r\n
  • the arrangements in case of an early return to the company of origin
column14:
which is always possible\r\n\r\n

At the end of this period
column15:
there are two possibilities: 

  • the worker comes back to his company of origin and gets his job - or a similar one - back 
  • the worker decides to stay in the company where he performed his period of mobility
column16:
and then he has to resign from his prior job \r\n\r\n

The employer can refuse to grant such a period of mobility and does not have to justify it. If he refuses twice
column17:
the worker has direct access to individual training leave. The employer has to communicate every six months to the employees' representatives the list of requests and the answers given to those requests. 

\r\n

 

"~"

No information available. 

"~"

It helps securing the workers' career path when they decide to change employment in order to develop their skills. 

"~"

column1:
Accords de mobilité interne ~"Internal mobility agreements"~"France"~"

Any company can enter into negotiations regarding the workers' internal mobility. If the negotiations lead to an agreement
column2:
this agreement will establish whether the mobility concerns the whole staff or just a part of it. 

"~"

Articles L.2242-21 to L.2242-23 of the Labour code allow the employer to start negotiations on internal occupational and/or geographic mobility in the framework of usual collective organisational measures that do not imply redundancies. 

\r\n

If negotiations lead to an agreement on internal mobility
column3: this agreement must provide certain guarantees for the workers
column4:
namely: 

  • geographical limitations 
  • measures aiming at reconciling professional and family life 
  • measures for supporting the mobility (such as training actions or employers' participation to cover extra costs)

Internal mobility can never lead to a decrease in the level of remuneration and must guarantee the maintainance or the improvement of the worker's professional qualification. 

If the worker refuses internal mobility
column5:
he might be made redundant on economic grounds. 

"~"

No information available.

"~"

Internal mobility agreements were introduced with the purpose of anticipating collective dismissals. They are supposed to help restructing without resorting to dismissals. 

"~"

Some stakeholders claim that
column6: although it is supposed to foster employment security
column7: internal mobility can be detrimental to workers as they can in some ways be forced to agree to change jobs because if they refuse
column8:
they are dismissed. 

"~"

Bigard

column1:
Crédit d'impôt pour la compétitivité et l'emploi - CICE~"Tax credit for competitiveness and employment"~"France"~"

There is no real eligibility criteria: any company that employs workers can benefit from this tax credit. Independent workers are excluded
column2:
as they are not employing staff. 

"~"

The tax credit for competitiveness and employment is a fiscal advantage for companies employing workers and amounts to a reduction in the companies' social contributions. The only condition for benefiting from this tax credit is to have workers. The tax credit is calculated according to amount of remuneration paid to the workers. 

\r\n

Its rate is of 4% for the remunerations paid in 2013 and 6% for the remunerations paid in the subsequent years
column3:
as from 2014. Only the wages that are not above 2.5 times the minimum wage are taken into account. 

\r\n

The CICE aims at funding the efforts of the companies in the field of investment
column4: research
column5: innovation
column6: training
column7: recruitment
column8: prospecting new markets
column9:
ecological or energy transition.

"~"

In 2013
column10:
about €800 million were prefinanced through the CICE. 

"~"

No information available.

"~"

This tax credit has been criticised by some stakeholders who consider it as an unjustified gift for the companies. 

\r\n

In August 2014
column11: the French minister for economic affairs deplored that companies have not played by the rules. The money made available to companies through this tax credit was supposed to be devoted to investments and creating employment. However
column12: companies do not seem to have used the money in this way
column13:
as investment was down during the second quarter of 2014. 

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Удължаване на работното време~"Extension of working time"~"Bulgaria"~"

For economic reasons.

"~"

According to the Labour code
column2: Art. 136
column3: the working week is five days
column4: and the normal working day duration per week is up to 40 hours. For economic reasons
column5: companies can extend working time by a written order and in this case are obliged to consult with representatives of trade unions and representatives of employees under Art. 7
column6: para. 2. of the Labour Code
column7:
and to inform the Labour Inspectorate in advance.

\r\n

The extension of working time could not be more than 10 hours per day
column8: and for employees with reduced working time up to 1 hour more per day. In such cases
column9: the working week duration cannot be more than 48 hours
column10: and for employees with reduced working time 40 hours (Art. 136a
column11:
Labour Code).

\r\n

The employer is obliged to record extended
column12: reduced and compensated working time in a special record book. The extension of the working time is allowed for 60 working days in one calendar year
column13:
but no more than 20 working days in a row.

\r\n

In cases of working time extension
column14: the employer is obliged to compensate the employee with the respective reduction of the working time within 4 months for each extended working hour. In case the employer does not compensate the extension within the listed period
column15: the employee has the right to define the time that will compensate the extension of working hours by notifying the employer in writing at least two weeks in advance. In case of termination of employment contract prior to compensation
column16:
the difference to the normal working day shall be paid as overtime.

column1:
Stimularea ocupării forței de muncă~"Stimulation of employment"~"Romania"~"

Persons who have acquired skills in other ways than the formal

"~"

Ministry of Labour has issued a new draft law on procedures to stimulate employment. The law will complete the Government Decision no 377/2002. The project aims to include a separate chapter on ""Evaluation of professional competences acquired in other ways than formal"".

Skills acquired in other ways than formal will be certificated by special assessment centres and used in employment accordingly.

 

"~""~"

Job loss due to corporate restructuring makes the most vulnerable people to be those who have not acquired formal competences. The project aims equivalence of these competences
column2:
in order that the level of employability of this group of people not to decrease.

The initiators of the law anticipate that its implementation will cause significant positive effects on employability through simplification and flexibility of the measures designed to boost employment. People looking for a job became more confident in their skills and more attractive to employers.

column5: "sans-serif"; color: black;"" lang=""DE"">The SIREVE is part of the the Revitalization Programme (Programa Revitalizar)
column6: "sans-serif"; color: black;"" lang=""DE"">. It aims at improving   the extrajudicial recovery of companies in economic dificulties
column7: through the   streamline the negotiation process
column8: by extrajudicial way
column9: with the companies‘   creditors
column10:
in order to improve the operating conditions and the continuity of its activities.

\r\n
column11: "sans-serif"; color: black;"" lang=""DE"">This   procedure is based on the conclusion of an agreement between the company and   some or all of its creditors
column12: which should represent at least 50% of the   total debts of the company

and that makes possible the recovery of its financial situation.

column1:
Assicurazione sociale per l'impiego, ASPI~"Aspi benefit"~"Italy"~"

Article 2 of Law No. 92/12 defines the ASPI benefit.
Since January 2013
column2: the application of the ASPI benefit is extended to all the private sector workers (both blue-collars and white-collars)
column3: including apprentices
column4:
members of cooperatives and fixed-term workers in the public sector.
To access the ASPI benefit
column5:
law establishes the following requirements:

  • involuntary unemployment;
  • two years of insurance seniority and at least one year of contributions during the two years preceding the beginning of the period of unemployment. 

The ASPI benefit is also provided in case of consensual termination of the employment relationship occurred under the conciliation procedure
column6: introduced by Article 1
column7:
paragraph 40 of Law No. 92/12.
In order to receive the ASPI benefit
column8: unemployed workers have to declare themselves immediately available to new work proposals
column9: and have to actively seek for a new job
column10: following the procedures defined by competent authorities
column11:
according to Article 2 of Legislative Decree No. 181/01.

\r\n

 

"~"

In 2014
column12: the maximum monthly amount for the ASPI benefit cannot exceed <span><span style=""font-size: 7.5pt; line-height: 115%; font-family: Verdana
column13: sans-serif; background-image: initial; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"" lang=""EN-GB"">€ 1.165
column14:
58.

"~"

The ASPI benefit was established by Law No. 92/12 with effect from 1 January 2013
column15: and is subjected to a transitional regime during 2013
column16:
2014 and 2015. It will definitively come into force on 1 January 2016.

"~"

Involvement of unions and employer organisations; State control on access requirements; good attempt to mix up ASPI with active labour market policies.

column1:
Incentivi all'occupazione dei lavoratori disoccupati di lungo termine~"Tax Allowances Aimed at Job Promotion for Long-Term Unemployed"~"Italy"~"

The following tax allowances/relief schemes aimed at promoting jobs for long-term unemployed have recently been introduced into the Italian labour system:

  1. ‘Contratto di ricollocazione’ – Affirmative action for job-seekers enjoying unemployment benefits (Law No. 147/13);
  2. Over-50 Job-Seekers – Tax allowance/relief for employers hiring long-term unemployed aged over 50 years (Law No. 92/12);
  3. Job-Seekers Falling Under the ASPI Regime – Tax allowance/relief for employers hiring unemployed benefitting from the ASPI regime (Law No. 76/13);
  4. Job-Seekers in Mobility Allowance (Indennità di Mobilità) – Tax allowance/relief for employers hiring unemployed benefitting from Mobility Allowance (Law No. 223/91);
  5. Job-Seekers in CIGS – Tax allowance/relief for employers hiring unemployed benefitting from the CIGS regime (Law No. 236/93).

"~"


Employers may benefit from tax relief/allowances in case of hiring of long-term unemployed. Tax allowances/relief may consist of tax reduction (in a certain percentage variable for each case) and/or tax deductions. These can be added to social security contribution deductions. The State authority is in charge of checking the requirements and taking care of the legal proceedings aimed at accessing the above-mentioned allowances/relief.

"~"

A significant use of such tools is related to SMEs and firms facing with the crisis.

"~"

Geographical mobility of workers; intersectoral mobility of workers; fare competition; skills interchange.

column1:
Növekedési hitelprogram~"Funding for Growth Scheme"~"Hungary"~"

In April 2013
column2: the National Bank of Hungary (MNB) unveiled a package of measures under the Funding for Growth Scheme (FGS)
column3: intending to stimulate the growth of the economy by lending to micro businesses and SMEs.  Those enterprises are entitled to receive the credit who have no public debts
column4: yearly net revenue is EUR 50 m at most
column5:
have financial guarantees and the enterprise’s credit rating was approved.

"~"

The Hungarian central bank aims at putting HUF 2.750 billion (EUR 9 billion)at the service of the country's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in a bid to boost economic growth through active monetary policy in 2 pillars. The credit can be used for the following purposes: new investments
column6:
new working capital.

"~"

SMEs needed access to credit and capital to survive and
column7: as a response
column8: FGS provides preferential loans exclusively for investment
column9: working capital financing
column10: pre-financing EU funds as well as for the redemptions of existing HUF loans. The FGS has significantly reduced the interest burden on enterprises in terms of both new loans and loan redemptions
column11: which helped to improve their profitability. In addition
column12: the FGS has eliminated the exchange rate exposure of enterprises
column13: which creates a predictable operating environment for them. The FGS has penetrated all sectors
column14: but agriculture
column15:
the manufacturing industry and trade account for a dominant share. The FGS has also reduced the regional concentration of SME loans.

"~"

SMEs could receive loan at an interest rate of a maximum 2.5 per cent.

"~"

No information is available.

"~"

For the assessment of the FGS see: http://english.mnb.hu/Root/Dokumentumtar/ENMNB/Monetaris_politika/fgs/FGS_analysis.pdf

http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-05-29/hungary-central-bank-expands-funding-plan-to-boost-growth.html

column1:
Prêt temporaire de main-d'oeuvre~"Temporary sublease of employees"~"Luxembourg"~"

As defined in article L. 132-1 of the Labour code
column2:
prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre is limited to companies that are not temporary work agencies.

"~"

As defined in article L. 132-1 of the Labour code
column3: prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre is allowed to companies with prior authorisation from the Ministry of Labour
column4:
Economy and Social Solidarity Economy on advice of the public employment agency (ADEM) for a limited period of time and in the following four limited circumstances:

  • threat of layoffs or under-employment;
  • performance of casual work (provided that the receiving company is not capable of performing it itself and that the receiving company belongs to the same branch of activities than the sending company)
column5:
\r\n
  • company restructuring
column6:
\r\n
  • implementation of another legal measure
column7:
the Employment Retention Plan.

This last condition was introduced by the law of 22nd December 2006 promoting retention of employment. This is the only small reform the prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre mechanism has ever been subjected to.

The use of temporary sublease of employees means that
column8: in practice
column9: workers are sent by their initial and legal employer - the sending company -  to work for a third party - the receiving company. This third party can be a company
column10:
but it may also include public authorities such as public agencies or local authorities in limited and strict circumstances.

\r\n

 

"~"

This scheme helps to prevent companies from dismissing some of their employees
column11: when they know that they are experiencing a cyclical crisis on the short-term and not a structural one
column12:
and that they might therefore have to re-hire employees at the end of it.

\r\n

\r\n

The main effect for workers who are subleased and are going to work for another company is that they experience a change in their working conditions. The receiving company does not necessarily have the same mode of functioning than the sending company
column13: and workers will have to adapt to these changes
column14: whether there are positive or negative. For instance
column15:
workers might experience a change in their work schedules or in the internal rules applicable within the company.

\r\n

This can be considered as a positive aspect
column16: in that it increases the workers' employability and stimulates them. It is indeed seen as a way of gaining new experiences and skills
column17:
as workers often have to adapt to other technologies and work processes different from the ones they were using in their company of origin.

 

"~"

From the companies' point of view
column18: prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre has considerable benefits. It prevents them from frequently going through dismissals and recruitment processes and hence saves costs. Likewise
column19: companies manage to keep their qualified and trained workforce
column20: even if they have to temporarily send them to another company. For receiving companies
column21: the period during which the temporary sublease takes place can also be used as some sort of trial period
column22:
during which they can test what the employee is worth and decide to employ him directly after this period or not.

\r\n

The greatest advantage is constituted by the fact that the sublease provides them job security. At the end of the provisional period
column23: they either re-join their company of origin as if they would always have worked for this one
column24: or they will be integrated to the permanent staff of the host company. The prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre seems to be very effective on this aspect
column25: as there is no report that after the sublease period
column26:
employees might end up being dismissed. 

 

 

"~"

As mentioned earlier
column27: there is no intermediary body which would coordinate this atypical relationship. It is up to the sending companies experiencing downturns to find a receiving company that would welcome some employees for a certain period of time. Companies also have to present jointly the request for implementing prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre to the Ministry of Labour. Even if there is some support to encourage exchange between companies on this matter (see above - Economic committee and monthly meetings held by the FEDIL)
column28:
it remains tricky to convince companies in the same field of activity that they can use workforce hired by their competitors.

\r\n

Despite being rather effective
column29: prêt temporaire de main d'oeuvre remains very little known. While conducting this analysis
column30:
information were quite difficult to gather and the interviewed stakeholders did not have many things to say about this mechanism. 

\r\n

 

"~"

The prêt de main d'oeuvre was implemented by Textilcord and ArcelorMitall (see Eurofound (2014)
column32:
case studies)

column1:
programme Fit4Job ~"programme Fit4Job "~"Luxembourg"~""~"

The Fit4Job programme is an initiative of the ministry of Work and Employment (Ministère du Travail et de l'Emploi - MTE) which aims to stimulate the job market. It involves bringing together professionals from a particular business sector and job seekers. Together with the professionals from the sector
column2:
it aims to quickly increase job seekers' employability.

\r\n

 

"~""~""~""~"

As part of a sector-specific approach
column3: the programme was launched with ""Fit for financial market""
column4:
dedicated specifically to the financial sector in collaboration with the Association of Banks and Bankers in Luxembourg (Association des Banques et Banquiers Luxembourg - ABBL) and the Institute of Banking Training in Luxembourg (Institut de Formation Bancaire Luxembourg - IFBL).

\r\n

With the supervision of the Agency for the Development of Employment (Agence pour le développement de l'emploi - ADEM)
column5: and the Institute of Banking Training in Luxembourg (Institut de Formation Bancaire Luxembourg - IFBL)
column6: the approach involves an assessment of technical skills
column7: on the basis of which people can be redirected to the financial sector or any other sector of the economy
column8:
with or without qualifying training.

\r\n

A first assesment launchd in 2010 highlights that 26 jobseekers have successfully been re-employed (sse press release of ABBL)

\r\n

column1:
Διαθεσιμότητα μισθωτών~"Temporary lay offs of salaried employees"~"Greece"~"

Whole economy.

"~"

The conditions and procedure for temporarily laying off salaried employees have been put on a new basis with the 2010 labour act (Act 3846/2010). The relevant provisions provide that firms and undertakings with restricted economic activity may
column2: instead of terminating an employment agreement
column3: serve written notice temporarily laying off salaried employees for no longer than 3 months annually
column4: provided they have first consulted with the employees’ legal representatives. Employees’ representatives are defined
column5: in the following order of priority
column6:
as:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Representatives of the firm or undertaking’s most representative trade union
column7: covering
column8: according to its statutes
column9: employees irrespective of category
column10:
position or skill;
  • Representatives of the firm or undertaking’s existing trade unions;
  • The works council;
  • In the absence of trade unions or a works council
column11:
the entire workforce is notified and consulted with. \r\n\r\n

Notification may be via a single notice posted in a conspicuous and accessible place at the firm. Consultation takes place at a place and time set by the employer. At the end of the three-month period
column12:
the same employee cannot be temporarily laid off for at least another 3 months.

\r\n

The relevant departments of the Labour Inspectorate (SEPE)
column13: the Social Insurance Foundation (IKA) and the Labour Force Employment Organisation (OAED) must be notified by the employer in any manner of the declaration of temporary layoffs of all or part of the workforce. For salaried employees in public utility firms or undertakings employing more than 5
column14: 000 salaried employees
column15: approval is required from the Ministry of Labour and Social Security
column16:
which is granted by application of the employer with the approval of the Plenary Supreme Labour Council.

\r\n

During the period of temporary layoff
column17: salaried employees receive half the average of their full employment earnings for the previous 2 months. When the employer temporarily lays off salaried employees
column18:
OAED pays those who remain unemployed while laid off 10% of the average of their regular full employment earnings for the previous 2months. These allowances are paid for a maximum of three months every year.

"~"

In 2010
column20: 253 alterations to contracts were registered with SEPE
column21: of which 18
column22: 713 were altered from full-time to part-time and 7
column23: 540 from full-time to rotating employment. These figures rose in 2011 to  58
column24: 962 alterations to contracts (an increase of 124.6% over 2010)
column25: of  which 32
column26: 420 were altered from full-time to part-time and 26
column27: 542 from  full-time to rotating employment. In 2012
column29: 490 (an increase of 43.3% over 2011)
column31: 640 were  altered from full-time to part-time and 34
column32:
850 from full-time to rotating employment.

\r\n

In 2012
column33: there was a 18.42% reduction in full-time contracts of employment compared with 2011
column34:
and a 3.61% increase in part-time employment contracts. New hirings on part-time and rotating employment contracts represent 45% of all new contracts.

"~"

Through this measure lay offs can be hindered and at the same time the employer is saving emploument costs in times of crisis.

"~"

It is not proved that in times of harsh economic climate this measure alone can hinder the business closure.

"~"

No information available.

column1:
Εκ περιτροπής εργασία~"Rotating employment"~"Greece"~"

Whole economy

"~"

\r\n

\r\n

When drawing up a labour agreement or while it is in force
column2: an employer and a salaried employee may
column3: through an individual written contract agree any form of rotating employment. Rotating employment is considered to be employment for fewer days a week or fewer weeks a month or fewer months a year or a combination thereof compared to full-time work. The protection provided by this article also covers those employed on the basis of the agreements described in the previous section. Employers whose economic activity is limited may
column4: instead of terminating the contract of employment
column5: impose a system of rotating employment in their firms
column6: the duration of which may not exceed 9 months in the same calendar year
column7: only providing they have previously informed and consulted the employees’ lawful representatives. Employees’ representatives are defined
column8: in the following order of priority
column9:
as:

\r\n
    \r\n
  • Representatives of the firm or undertaking’s most representative trade union
column10: covering
column11: according to its statutes
column12: employees irrespective of category
column13:
position or skill;
  • Representatives of the firm or undertaking’s existing trade unions;
  • The works council;
  • In the absence of trade unions or a works council
column14:
the entire workforce is notified and consulted with. \r\n\r\n

 

"~"

In 2010
column16: 253 alterations to contracts were registered with SEPE (labour inspectorate)
column17: of which 18
column18: 713 were altered from full-time to part-time and 7
column19: 540 from full-time to rotating employment. These figures rose in 2011 to  58
column20: 962 alterations to contracts (an increase of 124.6% over 2010)
column21: of  which 32
column22: 420 were altered from full-time to part-time and 26
column23: 542 from  full-time to rotating employment. In 2012
column24: alterations to contracts  soared to 84
column25: 490 (an increase of 43.3% over 2011)
column26: of which 49
column27: 640 were  altered from full-time to part-time and 34
column28:
850 from full-time to rotating employment.

\r\n

In 2012
column29: there was a 18.42% reduction in full-time contracts of employment compared with 2011
column30:
and a 3.61% increase in part-time employment contracts. New hirings on part-time and rotating employment contracts represent 45% of all new contracts.

"~"

Through this measure lay offs can be hindered and at the same time the employer is saving emploument costs in times of crisis.

"~"

It is not proved that in times of harsh economic climate this measure alone can hinder the business closure.

"~"

No information available.
